HEADLINE: Furor in Seoul Over North's Atom Plant

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 15

 BODY:
South Korea's Defense Minister said last week that his country might be forced to mount a commando raid against a nuclear installation near Pyongyang that experts believe could produce crude atomic weapons within five years. In response, North Korea accused the South today of issuing "virtually a declaration of war."
The South Korean Defense Minister, Lee Jong Koo, made his comments about the installation on Friday at a meeting with Korean editors, but retracted them that evening after they were reported by the South Korean press. It was the first time that any South Korean official had publicly suggested that a pre-emptive strike might be the best way to prevent North Korea from making nuclear weapons. 
 North Korea's leader, Kim Il Sung, has repeatedly denied that the nuclear installation is designed to produce weapons. But he has said he will not let inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency visit the plant until the United States removes all nuclear weapons from the South. The United States maintains more than 40,000 troops in South Korea, and they are believed to be equipped with nuclear weapons.
 
Concern in Asia
 The nuclear plant at Yongbyon, 60 miles from the North Korean capital and about 100 miles from the demilitarized zone, has become the focus of increasing concern throughout Asia.Japan has said that it will not provide badly needed economic aid to the North until it accedes to international inspection of its nuclear sites.
Japanese and American experts say the plutonium output of the plant should be big enough by the mid-1990's to to produce a half-dozen simple nuclear devices a year. North Korea already has advanced Scud missiles, and officials in Seoul fear they could be fitted with nuclear warheads.
Roh Tae Woo, South Korea's President, is expected to raise the issue of the North's weapons potential on Friday, when he meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the first visit of a Soviet leader to South Korea. He is scheduled to stop on Cheju, a resort island off the southern tip of South Korea.
In Tokyo today, Vladlen A. Martynov, a senior official of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, told reporters that the "Soviet Union has warned North Korea that if it does not let in the international inspectors, the Soviet Union will stop all kinds of supplies regarding this facility." It is unclear how much that would hurt the North Koreans, since they already have the basic technology for the plant, and the North mines its own natural uranium.
In the meeting with the Korea Newspaper Editors Association, Mr. Lee said that by the end of 1995 the North would be making nuclear weapons. Some participants said that he then discussed the idea of an "Entebbe-style" raid, a reference to the 1976 Israeli raid in Uganda to free passengers on a hijacked airliner.
Immediately after Mr. Lee made the comments, the Government ordered Yonhap, the news agency that it partially controls, to withdraw its dispatch on the comments.

HEADLINE: In New York, the Trip Is Not Quite as Bumpy

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Despite declining ridership, swelling budget deficits and a potential decline in Federal and state financing, New Yorkers have no reason to fear drastic cuts or elimination of service like those being considered in Philadelphia, New York transit officials said.
But the officials said that the effects of the region's weak economy, including a recent drop in tax revenue, and proposals to decrease government subsidies would lead to fare increases and reductions in service on bus and subway lines where ridership is relatively light. 
 They said the cuts could be taken before the end of the year.
"We are facing some very tough problems, but shutting down the subways and buses is just not an option for us here in New York," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the agencies that operate the city's subways, buses and railroads. "Mass transit is critical to the New York region, and without it we could not function."
 
3.5 Million People a Day
 New York City depends more than any other city on mass transit. One of every three people who take mass transit in the United States does so in New York City. Every day, its subways carry 3.5 million people over 700 miles of track in 6,232 cars and its buses carry 1.5 million passengers.
Mr. Stangl said the New York City Transit Authority would have a deficit of about $215 million in its operating budget for 1991. He said the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad would have deficits of $22 million and $17 million, respectively.
Half of the agency's $2.9 billion-a-year operating budget comes from fare revenue; the other half comes from government subsidies, including 6 percent from the Federal Government, 13.9 percent from the state, 13.9 percent from the city, 55.6 percent from taxes on real estate, telephone service and corporate profits and 10.5 percent from surpluses in the operating budgets of certain toll bridges and tunnels.
In the past, Mr. Stangl said, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature supported the authority, allocating billions of dollars for operating expenses and major improvements . But Mr. Stangl and other transit officials said the region stood to lose millions of dollars in government financing for its mass transit system in the 1992 fiscal year.
The Bush Administration has proposed eliminating Federal subsidies for cities with more than one million residents, and Governor Cuomo has proposed to reduce the state's assistance.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
For Beene, Finis Means Let Us Begin

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
With a distinguished collection of innovative clothes, Geoffrey Beene brought six weeks of fall fashion shows to a brilliant conclusion on Friday. The showings, which had begun in March in a lugubrious mood in Milan, Italy, as economic clouds darkened all over the world, had a happy ending.
The gloom that persisted through the London openings lifted finally in Paris with clothes that were upbeat and imaginative by Karl Lagerfeld, for himself and for Chanel, and by Claude Montana, Christian Lacroix, Emanuel Ungaro and Yves Saint Laurent. 
 The surprise of the Paris openings was the acceptance of Oscar de la Renta, the first American to show a collection on the same scale as the French. Mr. de la Renta acquired some European retail accounts and considerable exposure in the world press.
But perhaps his most important achievement was the recognition that American designers are no longer provincial or limited to sportswear. His emphasis on plaids was ranked with the ethnic themes ricocheting through the designs of the world's most prestigious designers. It is widely called the Highland fling.
In New York, Christian Francis Roth's painstaking reproductions of Amish quilt patterns and Isaac Mizrahi's evocation of American Indian culture with his beaded leathers and fringe were among the most provocative of the cross-cultural fashion moves.
But it was not necessary to be ethnically oriented to create a stir. Calvin Klein did so quietly with simple clothes like jacket dresses and tunics that focused, like most designers' work, on legs. Not bare legs; they were almost always covered with thick tights or clinging stretch pants. Donna Karan was somewhat more blatant with her snugly wrapped skirts and stretch dresses. And Ralph Lauren's clothes were serene and sophisticated.
Those three, who are associated with sportswear, the all-American field of design, have moved beyond casual clothes. While the elements of sportswear are still part of their work, they have gone far afield with clothes suitable for work, party-going and travel. In the top echelons of fashion, sportswear has pretty much ceased to exist.
The issue of longer skirts, which loomed large in March, had pretty much dissipated by the end of the showings. Again, it was the Americans who put the question to rest. If an American designer had found an impressive new way to make longer skirts palatable, or if enough people had pursued the issue, the results might have been different. But a vast majority of skirts cleared the knees, some considerably.
Long styles occasionally made an appearance. While some were attractive, notably Mr. Mizrahi's full skirts and Mr. Roth's Amish-inspired styles, they weren't enough to tilt the balance. Short remains the norm, although some designers, like Mr. Klein, said they had lengthened their hems -- a whole inch.
The one area where long clothes have made an impact is in coats. Whether they are big wrappy styles like Mr. Klein's or supple narrow columns like Mr. Beene's, the long coats make sense for cold weather over midthigh-length skirts and dresses.
In the end, it was Mr. Beene's rhapsodic approach to dressmaking that left the most lasting impression. With hardly a straight seam, the clothes curved around the body, sometimes opening unpredictably to show an arc of skin. Though they were mostly narrow, there was no sense of stress as the models passed swiftly across the stage, no inhibition of movement.
Each style was an exploration of the possibilities of fabric and cut, and a result was a collection that owed no homage to any other designer. Mr. Beene believes his voyage of discovery has just begun.
Such innovation is rare indeed. It may ultimately have as great an impact on fashion as Madeleine Vionnet's discovery of the bias cut in the 1930's or Gabrielle Chanel's investigation of the possibilities of black jersey as a fashion fabric in the 1920's.
It can only increase New York's prestige as a fashion center to have a designer in such control of his craft at work in the city. That his audience was aware of his accomplishment was evident by the ovation Mr. Beene received after the last model appeared in a long, gently draped black column with her head swathed in filmy lace. While there had been plenty of applause and some "bravos" at earlier showings, this was the only standing ovation. It was an appropriate ending to the season's shows.

HEADLINE: Anchorage Prices $84.4 Million Issue

 BODY:
An $84.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Anchorage was initially priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The maximum yield offered was 7.20 percent for an issue due 2005.
The offering of hospital refunding revenue bonds for a Sisters of Providence hospital project, includes shorter maturities that are priced to yield from 5.20 percent in 1991 to 7 percent in 2001.
Underwriters said proceeds from the sale would be used to refinance other bonds that were issued when interest rates were higher. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Debate Flares Over IUD Challenge

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
A NEW challenge to the validity of research that led to the removal of the Dalkon Shield and other intrauterine devices from the United States market has raised serious questions about the factors that influence the birth-control choices made available to Americans.
An unfortunate result of the Dalkon Shield story has been a narrowed choice of contraception for American women and a decline in the research to develop new devices and alternative methods of family planning. 
 A report last year from the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine in Washington stressed the need for new contraceptive methods because those on the market are not well suited to the religious, social, economic or health circumstances of many Americans.
Further, because women remain fertile for 35 years and men longer, contraceptive methods appropriate at one stage of life may not be at another. Nursing mothers, teen-agers and older women may have differing contraception needs and many women cannot use some contraceptive methods like the birth control pill because they have high blood pressure or diabetes, or they smoke. New contraceptives for men are also a goal.
But the United States legal system has slowed the development and marketing of new contraceptives, the report said. Loss of consumer acceptance of IUD's has led many manufacturers to abandon research in contraceptives.
"Without changes in the product liability rules and procedures, it appears likely that even fewer firms will allocate even fewer resources to contraceptive research and development," the report said.
Perhaps the biggest price of the IUD litigation is the number of unintended pregnancies, which also carry risks of illness and death. By one estimate, the lack of IUD's will lead 160,000 American women to have unintended pregnancies each year. More than half will elect to have an abortion. The remainder may give birth to unwanted children.
The report urged that liability for contraceptive products be preserved. But it urged Congress to pass legislation that recognized the importance of the careful review the Food and Drug Administration performs before it licenses a drug or device. In effect, the National Research Council said, the F.D.A.'s review process was a quality control mechanism that should protect the manufacturer.
Nevertheless, experts have faulted as inadequate the F.D.A.'s surveillance system, which is aimed at detecting problems after a contraceptive product is marketed. The system needs to be improved to provide systematic and timely feedback about the benefits and hazards of contraceptive products.
The F.D.A.'s authority over the marketing of devices has changed from 1971, when the Dalkon Shield was introduced, based on research data that were so skimpy and flawed that it is highly unlikely that it would lead to approval today.
Although many experts believe the Dalkon Shield was faulty in its design, they say the defect in one device does not necessarily apply to other IUD's.
Shortly after the Dalkon Shield was introduced, doctors began reporting life-threatening infections among users. Experts did not know whether the device caused the infections or whether the women had independently developed sexually transmitted infections.
Beginning in 1976, Federal health officials sponsored the Women's Health Study to evaluate the risks of pelvic infection developing among women who used IUD's.
Lawyers for women who contended they had been harmed by the Dalkon Shield said data from the studies played a central role in the litigation against the device's manufacturer, A.H. Robins of Richmond.
Douglas E. Bragg, a lawyer in Denver who has represented more than a dozen plaintiffs, said the studies were among the most important evidence in the litigation because they were Government sponsored, involved several medical centers and were considered carefully designed.
Although the studies "certainly were a strong piece of evidence in support of our cases," Mr. Bragg said, he won two cases before they were completed.
Now a team headed by Dr. Richard A. Kronmal, a biostatistician at the University of Washington in Seattle, has raised serious questions about the methodology used in the Women's Health Study, which found a 60 percent increased risk of pelvic infection among IUD users. Two of the three authors of the study, Dr. Kronmal and Dr. Stephen Mumford, were consultants to A.H. Robins.
The Dalkon Shield problem led to the removal of other IUD's from the market, even though the F.D.A. did not raise questions about their safety and very few successful lawsuits had been brought against manufacturers other than A.H. Robins.
"It was never a medical decision to withdraw the devices," said Dr. Sheldon Segal of the Population Council in New York City, a leading expert in contraception. "It was a corporate decision based on a view of expense."
At a recent meeting in Finland, Dr. Segal said he was struck by seeing displays of more than a dozen different types of IUD's that were marketed outside the United States. But only two IUD's are now approved for use in the United States.
Many American doctors are surprised at the extent of use of IUD's in other countries. Dr. Harold Kaminetzky, an official of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in Washington, attributed that in part to the provincialism of American medicine. Most American doctors do not read foreign journals and therefore pay little attention to trends and practices that are reported elsewhere.
Dr. Kronmal's analysis was unusual because, unlike many other critiques, he went back to the raw data from the Women's Health Study to do the analysis, which appears in the current issue of The Journal of Clinical Epidemiology.
"Writing critiques is not something that makes you very popular because people tend to think of you as a gadfly," Dr. Kronmal said. Also, he said, "it is hard to get published."
But he said it was crucial that any studies that could have such dire consequences as those involving IUD's be based on sound methods and subject to repeated scrutiny.
 Although Federal health officials have check lists for approving claims of benefit for new drugs and devices, they have no similar formal evaluation of putative hazards, said Dr. Alvan R. Feinstein of Yale Medical School, who is the editor of The Journal of Clinical Epidemiology.
He criticized what he called "hit and run epidemiology." "Epidemiologists attack a product as a menace, it is removed from the market, or some other action is taken, and that is the end of it," Dr. Feinstein said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 468 words

HEADLINE: A Multiracial Council District Best Reflects Lower East Side

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lower East Siders for a Multiracial District, of which we are coordinators, believes ours is the only proposal for a New York City Council district for the Lower East Side that adheres to the City Charter mandate to "keep intact neighborhoods and communities with established ties to common interest and association, whether historical, racial, economic, ethnic, religious or other."
We support mapping to maximize minority representation and do not regard this as gerrymandering in reverse. On the Lower East Side, no single minority has the population needed to create a Latino, Asian or African-American council district. But by combining their numbers, we achieve lines within which lives an 83 percent minority population. From that district a minority candidate has the best opportunity to be elected. (Most people working on districting around the city believe a minimum of 75 percent minority population is necessary to assure the election of a minority candidate.) 
 Furthermore, such a united district on the Lower East Side keeps together people with shared economic and other interests, including better schools with responsive bilingual education, quality health care and affordable housing for low and middle-income families.
Our united district stretches from the Brooklyn Bridge north to 14th Street and includes the most eastern census tracts of the area, as well as Chinatown. Thus we include the neighborhoods in which people of many ethnic and economic groups have lived and worked together, and to which immigrants from all parts of the world continue to come to find refuge and opportunity. This resembles one of the proposals presented by the Redistricting Commission (news article, April 11).
While creating an Asian district is an admirable goal, an analysis of the 1990 census data shows this is not possible. The district that will best serve the political interests of the Asian community brings it together with others having similar concerns. Combining parts of Chinatown with areas to its west, as several Redistricting Commission proposals would do, creates a district with a majority of higher-income nonminority voters, whose numbers will increase over the next 10 years as such housing as Battery Park City is occupied.
In addition, such a district would dilute the impact of the Latino vote by splitting it with a district boundary cutting east-west through the heart of the Lower East Side.
While pride in culture and race are important, winning the bread-and-butter issues depends on electing a candidate who can be held accountable to the majority. In 1991, that majority on the Lower East Side consists of low- and middle-income people: Latinos, Asians and African-Americans.
 
CARLOS CHINO GARCIA
ELAINE CHAN
New York, April 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Caller Beware if Bell Companies Are Let Loose;
Anticompetitive Bill

 BODY:
 To the Editor:
"A Justified Ban on 'Baby Bells' " (editorial, March 30) is on target in saying that Senator Ernest Hollings's proposal to lift the manufacturing ban on regional Bell companies "offers few potential benefits, and substantial potential abuse."
The American telecommunications industry is strong and growing. It is delivering consumer choice, innovation and dramatically lower prices. 
 The Bell companies argue that the restrictions that prevent them from manufacturing damage United States competitiveness. Sam Ginn ("Lift the Ban on 'Baby Bells,' " Op-Ed, March 28) cites the manufacturing restriction as the reason for anemic investment in research and development and a balance-of-trade problem. The facts suggest otherwise.
We face a chronic deficit in consumer telecommunications products (telephone sets, answering machines, for example), which the Hollings bill does not remedy. Yet the total telecommunications trade deficit has fallen 70 percent in two years. Exports increased at an average annual rate of 29 percent in 1989 and 1990, while imports leveled off. We have a trade surplus in network equipment. A.T.&T. alone exported more than $1 billion of equipment from its United States facilities in 1990.
Our excellent trade results show United States products to be fully competitive against foreign products, and United States investment in telecommunications research and development more than adequate.
The lower level of research and development investment of the Bell companies is consistent with their business. They are service companies, not manufacturers. If they become manufacturers while retaining their monopolies, the Bell company marketplace could become closed to fair competition. A.T.&T. and other United States companies would thus lose any business incentive to continue making heavy research and development commitments. The result would be less, not more, American investment. The Hollings bill should be defeated.
 
RANDALL L. TOBIAS
Vice Chairman, A.T.&T.
Basking Ridge, N.J., April 1, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Transit System Nearly Out of Money

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 15

 BODY:
Intensifying their pleas for help, officials here say the nation's fourth largest mass transit system is about to run out of money.
The Federal and state governments are planning substantial reductions in aid to mass transit, and if both go through with the cuts, the transit system here will have no way to pay its daily expenses. Officials say the system will also fall hopelessly behind in repairing hundreds of failing bridges, miles of rusting elevated steel structures and corroding concrete tunnels. 
 "We're not crying wolf -- a total shutdown is a real possibility," said Louis J. Gambaccini, chief operations officer and general manager of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, or Septa, as the system of street cars, buses and trains is known.
Federal and state officials are still negotiating their budgets for the next fiscal year, and Mr. Gambaccini said he was hoping that the warning would be extreme enough to avoid cuts in financing and avert a shutdown.
 
Highest Fare in Nation
 Septa officials believe they cannot turn elsewhere for the needed money. The system, which carries 600,000 people a day, has reduced service, closed 30 of its 250 miles of rail lines and, just last year, raised its base fare to $1.50, the highest in the nation. And it has promised riders that it will not raise the fare again until service is improved.
Just as Philadelphia, with its financial crisis still-unresolved, led most of the nation's cities into an era of deepening financial difficulties, Septa is providing a bleak glimpse of what the future might hold for some of their mass transit systems.
"Philadelphia's transit system is the leading locomotive, heading down the tracks into mass transit bankruptcy, and right behind it are just about every other mass transit system in the country," said George Sternlieb, an urban specialist who is professor emeritus of public policy at Rutgers University. Transit operators around the nation offer less dire forecasts, but nearly all of them see flashing yellow lights ahead.
Most transit systems face declining public subsidies, hastened by the recession, as well as increasing costs for repairing or replacing everything from bridges to buses to, in Septa's case, 1920's-era crank telephones and wooden drainpipes. In recent years, the nation's transit operators have been investing only $3.6 billion annually, on average, for major improvements, or about one-half to one-quarter of the investment needed to keep their systems in good condition.
"We're talking about a chronic problem that is just getting worse and worse each year," said Jack R. Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association, a trade group in Washington. "The point at which the chronic problem becomes acute, you have a Philadelphia."
Federal support for mass transit has declined by half in the last decade, as first the Reagan Administration and then the Bush Administration shifted more responsibility to the states and local governments.
The Administration now wants to eliminate the operating subsidies for large transit systems, which carry nearly all of the nation's riders. It is proposing to spend $16.6 billion for mass transit over the next five years. When compared with current spending, and adjusted for inflation, that works out to a 2 percent decrease in the 1992 fiscal year and a projected 20 percent decrease by the 1996 fiscal year.
The Federal subsidy currently averages about 5 percent of a system's operating budget. Some systems, including Houston, spend all or nearly all of their Federal subsidies on new equipment and major repairs.
As part of its proposal, the Administration wants to reduce Federal participation in major improvements by requiring local governments to increase their share of a project's cost, to 40 percent from 20 percent. But transit officials say they will have a hard time finding the extra money.
Transportation specialists expect Congress to restore some money to mass transit, but not enough to reverse the trend of declining Federal aid.
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, a former chairman of Chicago's Regional Transit Authority, said recently that the Administration's plan would be viewed as a setback. But he said transit systems would just have to run more efficiently with more local support. "Transit systems probably should cut back service," he said. "Most places run service where it's a luxury rather than a necessity."
 
Dependence on Tax Revenue
 Transit officials disagree and say their budgets have already been squeezed by declining state and local support. In addition, most transit systems depend on tax revenue dedicated to mass transit, and the recession has deeply cut into those funds. And raising fares means losing riders.
"We're looking at serious problems," said William A. Utter, a spokesman for Chicago's transit agency. "We'd need a fare increase of up to 20 percent and we'd be shutting down service late at night and closing certain rapid train stations and bus routes."
Miami's Metro-Dade Transit Agency has already raised fares twice in the last nine months and cut 500,000 miles from the routes its buses and trains travel. Proposed county and Federal reductions next year would require cutting almost 3 million more miles of transit routes, or about 10 percent of service. "We're talking about cutting routes that have good ridership," said Chester E. Colby, the agency's director.
But cutting service is not always politically possible, and that reality can send a transit system into a death spiral, Mr. Colby said. "If we can't cut service and have to defer maintenance, we could end up like Septa, and we wouldn't be alone."
Transportation policy analysts in Washington also criticized the Bush Administration's approach to mass transit, but for different reasons.
 
Arguing for Rider Support
 For instance, William G. Laffer 3d, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, said the people who benefit from roads and subways should pay their full cost, not the Federal Government. Although that would not mean more money for mass transit, said Mr. Laffer, it would indirectly help mass transit because the higher cost of driving would encourage people to use buses and trains.
Clifford Winston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, is less sure about eliminating Federal aid, but he maintains that mass transit will survive only if it can compete with other forms of transportation. "We can't make a determination whether the Federal Government should be subsidizing one form of transportation or another until we know how efficiently each system operates," Mr. Winston said. "The Administration proposal lacks any vision or coherence."
In Philadelphia, Septa officials say the uncertain timing of the budget bills in Washington and in Harrisburg means they cannot say when they would make a decision on closing the system. But for legal and political reasons, they say, they would probably close the whole system, rather than shutting down some routes and keeping others open.
The timing, moreover, could not be worse for Septa because the State Legislature, which has ignored its pleas in the past, is already struggling to close a budget gap of almost $3 billion for this fiscal year and the next.
Septa could lose $37 million in state aid for its operating expenses and major improvement projects in the next fiscal year, starting July 1. It could also lose at least $28 million more in Federal aid. In addition, Philadelphia, which subsidizes the system, is already $10 million behind in its payments.
"If the state and Federal proposals go forward, we will almost certainly have to close down," said Mr. Gambaccini, who was assistant executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey before coming here in 1988.
Septa officials say that unless they are assured of receiving $450 million a year for new equipment and major improvements -- about $300 million a year more than it receives now -- a significant portion of the rail system will deteriorate beyond repair within five years. Septa is one of a handful of major systems that do not have a tax whose revenues are dedicated to its needs.
 
'A Catastrophic Future'
 "Without the dedicated tax for capital improvements, there is no future for Septa," said J. Clayton Undercofler, chairman of Septa's board. "It is a catastrophic future, but I don't know when the catastrophe begins."
Septa has always been synonymous with problems. The Legislature created Septa in 1964 as a regional transit system to coordinate and operate a handful of systems, including bus, trolley, trackless trolley, subway, elevated and high-speed commuter train routes, in Philadelphia and the surrounding counties of Bucks, Chester, Delaware and Montgomery. The systems were once privately owned and were badly maintained. In 1983 Septa took over battered and largely obsolete commuter lines from the quasi-public Conrail. It now operates 2,500 vehicles over 3,500 miles of roads, tracks and trolley lines. The pace of deterioration has always exceeded Septa's limited budget for repairs.
Some say Septa is operating a safety hazard, not a transit system. "Their own engineers have serious concerns about the safety of the system," said Harry Lombardo, president of the Transport Workers Union, the largest transit union here, with 5,600 members. Mr. Lombardo, who advocates closing the system to force a political solution, cited internal Septa memorandums describing safety concerns.
Mr. Lombardo provided several memorandums, including one written in January by a senior engineer. It stated that transit workers were not able to "maintain Septa's structural systems in a reliable state" and that a major failure could possibly result in the collapse of station platforms and elevated tracks on the Market-Frankford Elevated Subway line, the system's busiest route in the city.
Mr. Gambaccini is no apologist for the system. "We're walking a tightrope," he said. "We feel the system is safe, but it is rapidly worsening."

HEADLINE: Caller Beware if Bell Companies Are Let Loose;
Unfair Restrictions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Justified Ban on 'Baby Bells' " (editorial, March 30), protesting Senator Ernest Hollings's bill to remove manufacturing restrictions on the seven regional Bell operating companies, does not fully address the impact of this legislation on small and medium-sized manufacturers.
The restrictions are not limited to manufacturing by regional Bells; they also preclude vital investments in land ventures with small and medium-sized American manufacturing companies. But the restrictions leave the regional Bells free to pursue both activities with overseas companies. 
 The rapidly growing telecommunications business is very cash-intensive, and critical research and development investments must be made constantly. Although you suggest there are "hundreds of U.S. equipment manufacturers in a vibrant industry," the opportunities for knowledgeable telecommunications investment have shriveled.
United States venture capital investment is in decline. Only one large telecommunications company in this country, Motorola, has demonstrated an appetite for investment, and the other, American Telephone & Telegraph, is focusing on downsizing and entering the computer business.
The practical alternative for growth financing for many American manufacturers today is foreign investment. At Centigram Communications Corporation, our experience with investors from Canada and Singapore has been excellent. However, additional investment by our major customers (the regional Bells) could increase opportunities for companies like ours to grow.
As president and chief executive officer of a small United States manufacturing company, I believe American telecommunications policy is at a critical juncture. These restrictions unfairly limit American companies.
It is time to repeal the manufacturing prohibition on the regional Bells by supporting the Hollings bill. Otherwise, economic reality will cause United States telecommunications policy to be set outside the United States.
 
GEORGE SOLLMAN
President & Chief Executive Officer
Centigram Communications Corp.
San Jose, Calif., April 4, 1991

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A sentence in an April 16 letter on regional Bell telephone companies from George Sollman appeared incorrectly as follows: "The restrictions are not limited to manufacturing by regional Bells; they also preclude vital investments in land ventures with small and medium-sized American manufacturing companies." The sentence should have read: "The restrictions are not limited to manufacturing by regional Bells; they also preclude vital investments in and joint ventures with small and medium-sized American manufacturing companies."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Executive at Citicorp To Help Lead Quotron

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Thomas J. Cirillo has been named president and chief operating officer of Quotron, a provider of stock and foreign-exchange trading information owned by Citicorp. Mr. Cirillo, who joined Citicorp in 1979, was most recently division executive in charge of much of Citicorp's leasing activities in the United States.
The 42-year-old Mr. Cirillo will succeed Paul F. Glaser, who is retiring on May 1 at age 65. He will report to the subsidiary's chairman and chief executive, Leland H. Amaya. 
 Quotron has not made a profit since it was acquired by Citicorp five years ago, and in 1990, it had a loss exceeding $200 million. In February, according to the American Banker, a trade newspaper, Quotron signed a contract renewal with its largest customer, Paine Webber, but at a substantial price concession that could cause Quotron to lose money on the deal. Executives at Citicorp declined to comment on Quotron's financial problems.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Cirillo said Quotron planned to develop a new data center, data network and support system that would "improve customer delivery and our service to the customer." He added, "When it is completed several years from now, the new infrastructure will give our customers better tools to work with."
He said Quotron's ability to serve its customers "is constrained by our technology, adding, "that's why we are undertaking this new project."
The project, still in the planning stages, will be carried on in New York, Los Angeles and other cities, he said.
Asked if Quotron was suffering in part because of the Wall Street consolidations, Mr. Cirillo replied: "The overall economic effect has hurt, and we would like a better Wall Street climate. But, while we have to await the new infrastructure, we will continue to make improvements by broadening our product and improving our service."
Mr. Cirillo is a native New Yorker. He attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology but did not complete his undergraduate studies. After leaving M.I.T., he spent 10 years in the systems industry as a consultant on software before joining Citicorp.
Currently, Quotron has about 85,000 terminals operating at financial companies, down from about 100,000 in 1989. As the financial community continues to consolidate, Quotron expects the number of terminals to drop to about 80,000 by year-end.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Consumer Trends Bothering P.&G.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
WHEN the Procter & Gamble Company bought Max Factor and other cosmetics lines from Revlon Inc. for $1.14 billion last week, it won general praise on Wall Street. Now comes the hard part.
Later this month, Procter & Gamble will report how severely the recession has punished the 97 percent of its business that is not cosmetics. 
 In recent months, securities analysts have been steadily whittling their forecasts for P.&G.'s third-quarter earnings, from about $1.29 a share to about $1.20 or less. That compares with $1.14 a share in the 1990 quarter. Modest or flat unit sales growth in the United States, where P.&G. does more than 60 percent of its business, is to blame for the weak expectations, analysts say.
Despite the soft short-term outlook, many analysts think Procter & Gamble has strong growth possibilities, especially in its stock price. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, P.&G. gained $1.875 a share to close at $89.375, almost 18 times estimated 1991 earnings. Jay H. Freedman, a consumer-products analyst at Kidder, Peabody, thinks that the share price could reach $110 in the next year and a half.
Getting there may be a bumpy road, however. Although many consumer-products companies are perceived by investors as safe harbors in a recession, they are nonetheless harmed when increasing numbers of consumers lose their jobs, or even when those still employed begin to cut back spending. Analysts say that an internal P.&G. survey found that 18 out of 24 markets that the company serves -- including detergents and toothpaste -- are showing soft or declining unit sales.
Added to that is the fact that population growth in the United States has been only 1 percent or so a year. So, the supply of consumers with money in their pockets is growing slowly even without a recession. In addition, supermarkets and mass merchandisers have built too many stores, adding to the pressure to stock less.
Procter & Gamble is especially vulnerable when people curtail spending because the typical American home offers a cavalcade of the Cincinnati giant's products. Wake up in the morning and you can wash with Ivory soap, shampoo with Pert Plus and brush your teeth with Crest. Don't forget the Secret deodorant. Still groggy? Have some Folgers coffee. Before you leave the house, be sure to load the dishwasher with Cascade detergent and the washing machine with Tide laundry detergent.
But even such a roster of strong brands cannot entirely offset some apparent trends in the marketplace. Analysts say that retailers, despite already lean inventories, are continuing to cut back, a development affecting many packaged-goods companies. Bonita Austin, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder, said the Colgate-Palmolive Company reported that some of its supermarket accounts were maintaining inventories of 1.5 weeks on some products, compared with 3 weeks, only a few months ago. "Even three weeks isn't a whole lot," Ms. Austin said.
Inventories may be thinning because money-conscious consumers are stocking up less, buying one bottle of shampoo instead of two, for instance.
Moreover, there is scattered evidence that consumers, either newly jobless or simply cautious, are increasingly "trading down" to cheaper generic or store brands for detergents, toilet paper, toothpaste and other consumer goods. The strength of the trend isn't clear yet, however. Ms. Austin notes that Helene Curtis Industries is reporting booming sales of its budget Suave shampoo, but is also seeing strong sales of its higher-priced Salon Selective.
The hazards of recession have focused Procter & Gamble's attention on acquiring health and beauty lines. In recent years, it bought such brand products as Nyquil cold remedy, Oil of Olay moisturizing cream and Cover Girl cosmetics, and last week, it made the Max Factor deal.
Health and beauty products have above-average growth possibilities in unit sales, perhaps 3 percent to 5 percent annually, because the population is aging and older consumers are more likely to buy products like P.&G.'s Pepto-Bismol. A growth rate of 2 percent or so is expected for P.&G.'s more basic products, like laundry detergent.
Profits, too, can be above average in health and beauty products, another attraction for P.&G. Alice Beebe Longley, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said a successful fragrance could have a profit margin as high as 40 percent, compared with 10 percent or 11 percent for detergents.
Not all analysts, of course, are excited about Procter & Gamble's Max Factor deal, which at least doubled, to about $1.6 billion, the company's revenues from cosmetics and fragrance lines. Mary Ann Winter, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, noted that those revenues would still be only a small part of Procter & Gamble's total, which was $24 billion in the 1990 fiscal year.
Ms. Winter, who has been neutral on P.&G. since the start of the recession and the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis, said: "I'm not excited about the deal. I'm not against the deal. I'd like to see how the company as a whole performs in the next few months."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Parental Leave: Symbols Matter

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT'S no mystery why the Democratic leadership is pushing hard for passage of the Family and Medical Leave Act. The bill, which would require employers to give workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newborns or seriously ill family members, is strongly supported by the Democrats' allies in organized labor and women's groups. And it apparently ranks up there in popularity with three-day weekends and hot fudge sundaes: A Louis Harris poll last June found that 74 percent of Americans favored the measure.
The real surprise is that President Bush, the pragmatist's pragmatist, vetoed similar legislation in 1990 and shows no signs of relenting this time around. While any Government-mandated benefit treads on ground sacred to free-marketeers, this one would barely leave a footprint: Two federally commissioned studies suggest employers' costs would run to pennies a week per worker. 
 The President's stand is all the more remarkable in light of whom it is likely to offend. Middle-class working women, the group with the most to gain from the right to unpaid leave, may represent the swing vote in the suburbs.
One plausible explanation for White House intransigence is the fear of a far more expensive mandated benefit, medical insurance. But some analysts take Mr. Bush's veto message at face value: The President, they believe, really does mean to stand on principle -- albeit one that has mostly been honored in the breach.
The bill being shepherded through Congress by Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado and Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut would mandate leaves up to three months. Businesses with fewer than 50 on the payroll would be exempt. Leave time would be unpaid; accumulating benefits -- for example, pensions tied to years of service -- would be put on hold. The only direct cost to employers would be any health insurance that went with the job.
Most other industrial economies demand far more generous leave benefits, including some minimum weekly cash payment. And a dozen American states already mandate leave under some circumstances. Typically, the state laws demand only that which is freely given: A 1988 survey by the Small Business Administration shows that large corporations usually accommodate employees with babies or sick family members.
The General Accounting Office says this legislation "would not cause major disruptions." Employers bother to replace temporarily absent workers only one-third of the time. And when they do, the substitutes rarely cost as much as the wages saved. The G.A.O. reckons that the net cost of the mandated benefit would thus amount to the cost of continuing health coverage -- $330 million if 5 percent of eligible workers took leaves each year.
Eileen Trzcinski and William Alpert, economists at Cornell and the University of Connecticut, respectively, offer a more cautious assessment. Their analysis for the Small Business Administration estimates that leaves would cost large employers about $90 a week in net producitivity loss, plus $35 in insurance coverage. Thus if an extra two million workers took six extra weeks of leave, the bill would total $1.5 billion.
That sum may be nothing to sneeze at. But according to labor economists, roughly half of the cost of this fringe benefit would come out of wages. And employers' share would be further pared by the reduction in labor turnover costs: Some workers who are not granted leaves would simply quit. In any case, $1.5 billion represents just one-twentieth of 1 percent of labor compensation.
Why, then, is Mr. Bush apparently willing to be tarred as the President who kept working moms from their tots' sickbeds? There is the camel's nose theory: Mr. Bush's advisers may fear that unpaid leave in large businesses could lead to, say, paid leave for all job holders. Or it could help the prospects of a Massachusetts-style program mandating health insurance for all employees -- anathema to Administration economists. In the view of some analysts close to the White House, however, it is just reflexive opposition to government interference in labor markets.
The Feds already bar child labor, set minimum wages and maximum working hours, regulate pension plans, collect payroll taxes for unemployment compensation and Social Security, and keep watch on shop-floor health and safety. But the President's fight last year to stop an increase in a minimum wage that had been badly eroded by inflation suggests that he is not inclined to look the other way on mandated benefits. And sometimes the lure of a good fight over a simply stated principle is too much even for a pragmatist to resist.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Meets Kaifu and Both Urge Flexibility

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 16

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, opening the first high-level attempt at warmer ties between the Soviet Union and Japan, appealed to each other today to show greater flexibility on a territorial dispute long dividing the two countries.
In a friendly atmosphere on a sunny spring day, the two leaders sparred politely during the first of several negotiating sessions intended to reduce tensions and redefine their relationship. 
 The visit by Mr. Gorbachev, the first by a Soviet leader, was a day of solemn anthems and cannon fire, visits to the Imperial Palace and speeding past gleaming skyscrapers and blossoming cherry trees in Zil limousines brought in from Moscow. Later Mr. Gorbachev will get a chance to travel to Kyoto as Japanese do, by bullet train from Tokyo Station.
The main issue for both sides was whether ties could improve to the extent that Japan would be willing to help Moscow with aid and investment. But on the first day of talks, spokesmen for both leaders indicated that each side continued to hold the other responsible for keeping relations tense.
 
Ties 'Absolutely Not Adequate'
 Mr. Gorbachev was quoted as telling Mr. Kaifu that Moscow had managed to improve ties with the United States, Europe, India, China, Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand -- but not with Japan.
Soviet-Japanese relations are "absolutely not adequate," a spokesman quoted him as saying, adding that the level of contacts does not "correspond to the actual weight and prestige" of the two countries.
But a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman said Mr. Kaifu responded by asserting that it was up to the Soviet leader to change the atmosphere by offering concessions on the territorial matter, a dispute over some islands at the end of the Kurile chain.
Despite the fact that they are neighbors, Japanese-Soviet trade was less than $6 billion, a relatively paltry sum.
 
Territorial Concessions
 Although rumors have swirled in recent weeks suggesting that Japan might offer billions of dollars in aid to the Russians in exchange for territorial concessions, Japanese Government officials have dismissed them.
But Soviet officials are in town this week to talk up as many joint economic cooperation projects as possible. A senior aide to Mr. Gorbachev, Arkady I. Volsky, told reporters today that Japanese money and experience would be particularly valuable in helping the Soviet Union to convert military enterprises to commercial ventures. He said a plant that made navigation systems might be converted to make video recorders, or a plant that used to make tanks could now make tractors.
Mr. Volsky said that Japan had the know-how because industrial giants like Mitsubishi changed from war production after 1945.
"I'll let you in on a big secret," he said. "Mitsubishi used to make tanks."
But instead of improving trade and investment ties, the countries have focused their energies on the Kurile Islands dispute.
The key question hovering over the talks was whether Mr. Gorbachev was prepared to make enough of a concession on the islands -- ceding sovereignty of most if not all of them -- in order to warrant large amounts of Japanese aid, investment and technical assistance.
For most of the last 100 years, the disputed islands have been in Japanese hands, but they were seized by the Soviet Union in the closing days of World War II.
Japan regards that seizure as an illegal betrayal that must be redressed before there can even be a peace treaty officially ending war with Moscow. A Japanese official said that in the initial three hours of meeting at the ornate State Guest House, Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Kaifu spent half their time on that subject.
The spokesman for Mr. Kaifu said that a news blackout had been imposed on all discussions of the territorial issue, including how much money Japan might offer the Soviet Union if it is resolved favorably to Tokyo.
Moscow and Tokyo plan to announce agreement on 15 topics when the meetings wind up on Thursday, before Mr. Gorbachev's departure on Friday, but few of them amount to a significant financial breakthrough. One economic accord involves Japan sending 300 specialists to help the Russians bring about a restructuring of their economy.
There was tight security throughout the capital, although the police watched quietly as a thousand right-wing marchers took over a street in the Ginza in the afternoon to demand return of all the islands demanded by Japan.
Nations throughout the region, and perhaps throughout the world, were watching the Gorbachev-Kaifu summit meeting for a glimmering of how the so-called new world order might change life in East Asia, where cold-war and East-West tensions still exist.

HEADLINE: Weicker to Close 19 More Parks in Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 16

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that 19 more state parks would close on Friday, the day before the opening of the fishing season, because the state cannot reach a resolution with state employee unions over wage and benefit givebacks.
The move seemed certain to increase public pressure on the unions, especially when tied to the second half of the today's announcement -- that all the parks would immediately reopen if the labor talks were properly resolved. 
 Five other parks will close on Wednesday, as was previously announced, as a result of budget cuts, and another eight parks are scheduled to close on May 1. When the final closings take effect, more than a third of Connecticut's 92 state parks and forests will be closed as a result of the budget problems in Hartford, caused mainly by the recession and the resulting shortfall in tax revenues.
Of the 19 additional parks, many are small but several draw more than 50,000 visitors a season, including Harkness Memorial Park in Waterford, which drew 187,000 people in 1989 and Gay City State Park in Hebron, with 98,000 visitors, according to the most recent figures,
 
More Layoffs Possible
 Mr. Weicker said that the lack of a union agreement, and the possibility that more state employees could be laid off beyond the 2,600 announced two weeks ago, made it inappropriate to hire the usual number of seasonal workers. The Governor authorized only 82 positions to be filled, instead of the 298 summer workers sought by the Environmental Protection Department -- mostly students hired to clean up and maintain the picnic grounds and beaches.
By redeploying current full-time employees, all 14 state campgrounds will open this weekend as scheduled, said the Environmental Protection Commissioner, Timothy R. E. Keeney, in a statement. The most heavily used state parks, most on Long Island Sound, will also open, Mr. Keeney said, though with less parking than usual.
Mr. Keeney said that 60 public parks and forests and the state campgrounds will remain fully open, and that even the closed parks will be open if people want to park their cars outside the grounds and walk in for day hiking, or picnicking. All access roads will be closed to vehicles, and there will be no electricity or running water or lifeguards. Mr. Keeney said that "minimum law enforcement" would continue in the closed areas, mainly through periodic police patrols.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Pacific Telesis Advances Slightly

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Pacific Telesis yesterday reported a slight earnings gain, while two sister Baby Bells, Ameritech and Southwestern Bell, posted modest declines. Analysts said the figures showed that all the telephone companies were feeling the impact of slower growth during the recession, especially among business customers.
United Telecommunications Inc., the owner of U S Sprint, reported that earnings dropped sharply from a year ago but were up from the previous quarter. Analysts who follow the long-distance companies use comparisons with the previous quarter to determine who is gaining market share, but it will be unclear how favorable yesterday's figures were for Sprint until the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the market leader, and MCI Communications Corporation, No. 2 in long distance, report their earnings. 
 Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Pacific Telesis
 The Pacific Telesis Group said that earnings crept forward 1.5 percent in the first three months of 1991, to $266 million, from $262 million a year ago. Because the San Francisco-based company bought back nearly 10 million of its own shares during the year, the income gain lifted earnings per share by 4.6 percent, to 68 cents, from 65 cents in 1990's first quarter.
Revenues climbed by just 1.7 percent, to $2.41 billion for the quarter from $2.37 billion in the 1990 period.
The company's performance closely tracked that of its main operating unit, Pacific Bell, which provides service in California. Pacific Bell's net income rose 1.2 percent, to $245 million from $242 million, as revenues rose 1.9 percent, to $2.16 billion.
The brightest spot continued to be Telesis's cellular phone companies, where net income rose 21 percent, to $20.5 million, from $16.9 million a year ago, despite a 12.5 percent decline in revenue per customer. Telesis attributed the decline, to $91 a customer from $104, to both the weak economy and the effect of bargain calling plans. The negative impact was overcome by the addition of 34,000 new subscribers, a 31.5 percent increase, to 543,000.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Pacific Telesis's shares added 37.5 cents, to $41.875.
 
Southwestern Bell
 Southwestern Bell, which is based in St. Louis, said it earned $223.9 million, or 75 cents a share, in the quarter, down 9.6 percent, from $247.8 million, or 82 cents a share in the first quarter of 1990. Revenues were $2.14 billion, compared with $2.13 billion a year ago.
Edward E. Whitacre Jr., chairman and chief executive, attributed the decline to a $37 million decline in income at the company's main subsidiary, the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company. The decline was $13 million when extraordinary gains last year were eliminated from the comparison. The main operating problem was changes in Texas regulations that led to price cuts to customers in that state.
"Although we felt the impact of rate reductions in the first quarter, we're encouraged by continuing growth in operations," Mr. Whitacre said. The company added 90,000 new access lines, bring its total to 12.2 million. The company's cellular phone subsidiary added 64,000 new subscribers in the quarter, bringing the total to 731,000 in 28 cities.
Southwestern's shares were unchanged yesterday at $53.375.
 
Ameritech
 Ameritech said that net income fell 6.8 percent, to $283 million, or $1.07 a share in the first quarter, from $303.5 million, or $1.13 a share a year ago. Revenues for the Chicago-based company were essentially stagnant, rising just $9.4 million, to $2.63 billion.
Rate reductions, slower growth in the addition of new lines, and reduced calling volumes all hurt results, said William L. Weiss, Ameritech's chairman and chief executive. The company's local phone operations serve Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin.
Mr. Weiss said that new lines were added at a rate one-third below the first quarter of 1990. The total of 16.4 million is up just 2.1 percent from a year ago. But the cellular business grew at a 42.5 percent rate, to 366,500 subscribers.
Return on equity dropped to 14.4 percent, from 15.8 percent a year ago. Ameritech's shares slipped 62.5 cents yesterday, to $65, in Big Board trading.
 
United Telecom
 United Telecom's net income fell 22.3 percent, to $83.6 million, or 38 cents a share, from $107.6 million, or 51 cents a share in the first quarter of 1990. But net income rose 18 percent, compared with the $71 million reported in the last quarter of 1990.
"Despite recessionary trends and continued intense competition, our Sprint long-distance division experienced strong traffic volume growth of 4.7 percent," said William T. Esrey, United Telecom's chairman and chief executive, comparing the recent quarter with the last three months of 1990.
The Kansas City, Mo., company said that revenues were $2.16 billion for the quarter, up almost 7 percent, from $2.02 billion a year ago. Sprint's revenues accounted for $1.34 billion of that total, up 9.8 percent from the $1.22 billion of the corresponding quarter in 1990 but basically unchanged from the previous three months. The long- distance company's operating profit was $52 million, down 39 percent from $85 million a year ago but up slightly from $51 million in the last quarter of 1990.
United Telecom's shares rose $2, to $25 yesterday, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Technologies' Net Off 70.1%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 16

 BODY:
The United Technologies Corporation today reported a 70.1 percent slump in its first-quarter net income, saying the recession had hurt three of its key businesses: aircraft components, building supplies and automobile parts.
The company said earnings of $40.2 million, or 25 cents a share, in the quarter were down from $134.5 million, or $1.05 a share, in the 1990 period. Sales were virtually unchanged at $4.8 billion. 
 Robert Daniell, the company's chairman, said cost-cutting measures would continue "on the assumption that the recession is nearing an end."
The Pratt & Whitney subsidiary, which builds commercial aircraft engines, suffered a slump of more than 25 percent in spare parts revenues as carriers struggled with empty seats and cut spending.
The company's shares fell $1.125, to $46.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed On Uncertainty Over Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar, stymied by uncertainty over United States interest rates, turned in a mixed performance against other major currencies yesterday.
Gold prices were narrowly lower in New York, with the April contract falling 20 cents, to $361.40 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $359.85 an ounce, down 45 cents. 
 Analysts said the foreign exchange markets were awaiting more clues about the United States economy and where interest rates were headed.
On Monday, the Federal Reserve took steps that the markets interpreted as indicating the central bank would not allow interest rates to fall to stimulate the economy.
 
Signs of Weakness
 But yesterday the Commerce Department said housing starts fell 9.3 percent in March, while the Fed said industrial production fell three-tenths of a percent in last month. Both reports provided more evidence that the economy remained weak. But after Monday's Fed action, the markets were unsure what the central bank would do.
The dollar, which traded in a narrow range for much of the day, gained ground against the British pound. In New York, sterling fell to $1.7905, from late Monday's $1.7910. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.7900, from $1.7920 late on Monday.
The dollar also picked up some ground against the Japanese yen. The dollar rose to 134.60 yen in New York, from 134.25, after falling overnight in Tokyo to 135.15 yen, from 135.22. It was quoted at 134.80 yen in London.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday prices, included: 1.6648 German marks, down from 1.6710; 1.4170 Swiss francs, down from 1.4185; 5.6265 French francs, down from 5.6385; 1,234.00 Italian lire, down from 1,237.25, and 1.14905 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14815.
Gold was unchanged in London at $360.50 an ounce, the same as late on Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $360.75 an ounce, down from $361.20 late on Monday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 32 cents an ounce to close at $361.12.
Silver rose 3 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.011 an ounce. In earlier London trading, silver rose to a late bid of $4.04 an ounce, up from $3.98 late on Monday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Trump Report On Finances

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, April 16

 BODY:
A report prepared by the New Jersey Gaming Enforcement Division says the Trump Organization will topple unless it completes agreements with creditors owed nearly $2 billion on assets owned by Donald J. Trump.
The New Jersey agency prepared the report as part of the relicensing hearings for the Trump Taj Mahal Casino. The state Casino Control Commission must determine if the casino and the New York-based Trump Organization can prove financial stability. 
 "There does appear to be a sufficient level of financial stability for the remainder of the current license term, which expires on April 26, 1991, and for the one-year term that follows," said the division, part of the Attorney General's office.
The casino's stability depends upon completion of a restructuring plan that has holders of $675 million in Taj casino bonds accepting lower interest rates in exchange for 50 percent of the property.
"More worrisome is the fiscal health of D.J.T.," the report said, using Mr. Trump's initials. He will go broke by July if his lenders do not negotiate new debt arrangements, the report said.
Mr. Trump will have personal income this year of $1.7 million from rental income, trust distributions, interest income and other sources, the report said. As income-generating assets are sold, the figure will fall to $700,000 in 1992 and $300,000 in 1993, the report said.

HEADLINE: Yields Decline for 7th Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the seventh consecutive week in the period ended yesterday, with most declines on the moderate side.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., note that yield spreads among money market funds, funds that invest in United States Treasury securities and bank money market accounts have narrowed considerably since the beginning of the year. Money market and Treasury funds had yielded as much as 175 basis points more than the average bank money market account, but as recently as last week the spread had narrowed to as little as 50 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates slipped for the third consecutive week. The results of these bill auctions often indicate what banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The three-month bill fell 3 basis points, to 5.57 percent, while the six-month bill slipped a basis point, to 5.67 percent, the lowest since July 1987.
In its weekly survey of New York area banks, The Bank Rate Monitor noted that the declines at commercial banks were larger than those at savings institutions for the second consecutive week.
This week, the largest yield declines in the New York area were recorded at First Fidelity of New Jersey, which cut its money market account by 115 basis points, to 4 percent; Midlantic Banks of New Jersey, which cut its three-month certificate by 25 basis points, to 5.75 percent, and the Republic National Bank, which cut its six-month certificate by 32 basis points, to 5.97 percent.
Commercial banks lowered the average money market account by 11 basis points, to 5.39 percent, and lowered three-month certificates by 9 basis points, to 5.84 percent. The longer six-month ceritificate was cut 6 basis points, to 6.01 percent.
At savings institutions, the average money market account was lowered 2 basis points, to 5.76 percent, while a three-month certificate was cut by 8 basis points, to 6.25 percent, and a six-month certificate by 6 basis points, to 6.49 percent.
Yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area and around the country show the average money market account yield down 2 basis points, to 5.41 percent, with the average yield for a six-month certificate down 6 basis points, to 6.03 percent.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fell 9% in March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
In reports suggesting that the recession could linger beyond midyear, the Government said today that the pace at which builders broke ground for new homes fell 9 percent in March while production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell three-tenths of a percent.
Private analysts generally took a dim view of the reports, despite a 2.4 percent increase in housing permits, the second straight monthly rise. 
 Housing starts are widely watched because they send large ripples through the economy, leading inevitably to sales of new carpeting, appliances and other goods.
 
Housing May Have Bottomed
 Permits for future home construction, reported today with housing starts, are a forward-looking indicator. For March, the indicator seemed to be moving in line with other data indicating that the housing market, at least, may have begun to rise from a bottom reached during the winter.
The decline in industrial production, although a bit less than expected, was broadly based, analysts noted, and was accompanied by a decline of four-tenths of a point in the operating rate of factories, mines and utilities. At 78.7 percent, the overall operating rate is at its lowest point since September 1986, when it measured 78.6 percent. The rate for factories alone, 77.4, is the lowest since August 1983, when it was 76.0.
"The numbers are very dismal," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group. "Without question, they show the recession is continuing and the recovery is nowhere in sight." Even housing, he added, has shown only "minimal" revival from the severely depressed pace of 847,000 starts in January.
The March pace of 901,000 housing starts followed a surge in February to 993,000, producing an average of 947,000 starts for the latest two months.
 
Home Builders Optimistic
 Another downbeat assessment came from the United States Chamber of Commerce, which cited a sixth straight month of falling industrial output and complained that the Federal Reserve has been too slow to cut interest rates to encourage a recovery.
"Today's figures suggest that the recession will not be shorter and shallower than the average of postwar recessions," said Richard W. Rahn, the chamber's vice president and chief economist. "Therefore, it is peculiar, at the very least, that policy makers seem hell-bent on maintaining the status quo in hopes that a recovery will magically appear."
Yet the National Association of Home Builders, the industry's principal trade association, took some comfort in the housing figures and declared that January "was clearly the low point" for the battered industry.
Mark Ellis Tipton, the group's president, said that housing starts had been expected to fall in March, since the February total had been inflated by exceptionally mild weather in much of the country, particularly the Midwest.
Mr. Tipton added, "Although the March numbers are weaker than expected, we believe the housing economy is starting to build some momentum" with the aid of the lowest mortgage rates in almost a decade.
The Fed continued to refrain from starting another round of interest rate cuts to pull the economy out of recession, perhaps in the belief that the economy, though weak in most sectors, is stabilizing.
 
Housing Starts
 The March decline in housing starts embraced all kinds of structures and two of the four regions of the country.
Starts of single-family housing fell 5.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 732,000, while starts for multiple-unit dwellings fell 21.4 percent, to a record low pace of 169,000. Single-family starts ran at a 778,000 rate in February, while multifamily starts ran at a rate of 215,000, the Commerce Department reported.
By region, starts rose by 7,000 in the Northeast, to 97,000, and by 5,000 in the South, to 393,000. But starts fell 80,000 in the Midwest, to 223,000, and dropped 24,000 in the West, to 188,000.
Without seasonal adjustment or annualization, 74,100 houses were actually started last month, 61,200 of them single-family units. This compared with 45,700 single-family starts in February and 39,200 in January.
For permits, the March pace was 884,000, 2.4 percent above the revised February pace of 863,000 but still 28 percent below the figure a year earlier. All of the March gain, which was concentrated in the West, was accounted for by multifamily dwellings.
The report also showed that shipments of mobile homes, which are published with a one-month lag, fell to 157,000 in February, 7 percent below the January level of 168,000.
 
Industrial Production
 The three-tenths of a percent fall in industrial production last month followed a decline of nine-tenths of a percent in February and was the smallest of the string of declines that began in October.
Nonetheless, the Fed's report noted, for the first quarter as a whole output fell at an annual rate of about 9.25 percent, compared with 7 percent in the final three months of 1990.
The March decline put the production index at 105.3. That is 3.3 percent below the March 1990 index, and the lowest level since a 105.0 reading in June 1988.
The drop in March was attributed mainly to further weakness in business equipment, construction supplies and durable materials. Output of motor vehicles rose about 2.5 percent, as a sharp increase in truck production more than offset another decline in automobiles.
 
Food Production Up
 By market groups, production of consumer goods apart from motor vehicles rose a modest four-tenths of a percent last month after falling for four straight months, the Fed reported. Food and energy bought by consumers, particularly residential electricity, advanced last month, but clothing and household goods like appliances, carpeting and furniture remained depressed.
Business equipment fell another five-tenths of a percent and construction supplies fell 1.6 percent, the report showed.
Manufacturing output fell five-tenths of a percent, with operating rates falling that amount for both primary and advanced processing industries.
 
Mining Output Down
 Mining output also fell, by eight-tenths of a percent, but utility output climbed 1.4 percent to regain nearly half of the ground lost in February, reflecting unseasonably warm weather during that month.
The biggest declines in the operating, or capacity utilization, rate among primary processing industries last month were in stone, clay and glass products and in fabricated metals, the former 10 points below its March 1990 level. Lumber, another construction-related industry, is now operating at 72.4 percent, 13 points below its pace a year earlier.
The February decline in overall production was revised to nine-tenths of 1 percent from the eight-tenths of 1 percent initially reported.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New York Takes Over Big Insurer

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
New York State insurance regulators yesterday seized control of the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, the New York unit of the First Executive Corporation.
Salvatore R. Curiale, New York's superintendent of insurance, said the move had been taken after worried policyholders rushed to cash in their policies, threatening the company's financial health. At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Curiale said he was indefinitely suspending all policy surrenders, the procedure for policyholders to withdraw their funds quickly. 
 Death benefits, annuity payments, pensions and other regular payments will be honored without interruption, Mr. Curiale said.
It is the largest seizure of an insurance company in state history and the first time the state has come to the rescue of a troubled insurer since 1974.
"The whole purpose of this is to stabilize the situation and assure people that we are in control," Mr. Curiale said.
 
No Risk for Now
 No state funds are at risk in the seizure, and no policyholders are at risk at this point, officials said.
Last week, in the largest failure of an American insurer, California regulators took control of the Executive Life Insurance Company of California, the largest insurance unit of First Executive. The state placed Executive Life into a court-supervised conservatorship.
First Executive, headed by Fred Carr, grew into one of the nation's largest insurers by investing heavily in high-yield "junk bonds." First Executive's finances deteriorated along with the junk bond market.
Executive Life Insurance Company of New York is considered to be in better financial shape than the California unit. In 1987, the State of New York restricted junk bond investments by insurance companies.
Earlier this month, New York officials ordered Executive Life of New York to stop issuing new polices and to bolster its reserve by $125 million.
As of Dec. 31, the company had assets of $3.2 billion and liabilities of $3 billion. The company has 103,000 policyholders in 23 states, but the majority live in New York.
 
Policies Are Surrendered
 Mr. Curiale said that in recent days there was a sharp rise in the number of policyholders trying to cash in their policies. He said the number had risen to nearly 500 a day, from 25 a day several weeks ago.
"The growing rush to withdraw capital assets from the company threatens its solvency and undermines the ability of the company to meet its obligations," he said.
While officials say policyholders are not at risk, Mr. Curiale acknowledged that the company had financial difficulties and that about 60 percent of the company's investment portfolio is invested in high-risk "junk bonds." The value of the portfolio has eroded during the recession.
Regulators received a temporary restraining order Monday night, allowing them to take control of the company, which is based in Jericho, L.I. The department will seek a permanent court order next Tuesday.
Insurance department officials said the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York had sought to take a lead role in providing management help to reorganize the insurer.
Metropolitan Life officials said they supported the actions of the insurance superintendent, but declined to discuss their plans. Insurance officials said other large insurers had also expressed interest in helping resolve First Executive's problems.
The New York insurance industry has a financial interest in a quick resolution to First Executive's problems. If First Executive is unable to pay its obligations, the New York Life Insurance Guaranty Corporation, a group made up of insurance companies, will be financially responsible. "They have a financial interest in seeing that this thing plays out successfully," said Kevin Foley, deputy superintendent of insurance.
 
Plan by Europeans
 A European consortium, which includes Altus Finance, a unit of Credit Lyonnais, has presented a plan to buy the California unit of First Executive and is now interested in the New York company as well.
A spoksman for Altus said the group hoped to have discussions with the insurance department about an acquisition within the next few days. "The consortium is prepared to commit a sizable sum," said the spokesman, who insisted on anonymity.
Once the state stabilizes First Executive and analyzes its financial health, it has several options, Mr. Foley said. Mr. Foley said a takeover of the company was one option, as was selling it in pieces. "We would like to keep the company together," he said.
Mr. Curiale said that the state was likely to be in control of the insurer for a few months, possibly more.
