HEADLINE: Settlement Defeat Speeds Film Exodus From New York

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The exodus of feature films from New York City resumed with surprising speed yesterday, a day after a film-crafts union defeated a tentative settlement in a 19-week dispute that had put a number of productions on hold.
The departures, by producers who had been planning to shoot movies about New York in New York, are creating potential windfalls for cities like Chicago, Pittsburgh and Toronto -- places with urban streetscapes that could fool the camera and perhaps some moviegoers. 
 Jaynne C. Keyes, director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, said that "Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune" -- about a quintessential New York love story -- and "The Babe Ruth Story" -- about one of the most famous Yankees of all time -- were among at least seven films that would be shot elsewhere.
 The prospect of no lights, cameras or action appeared to increase the pressure on the unions that negotiated the tentative settlement with Hollywood producers last month. The president of the unions' umbrella group, Alfred W. DiTolla, said 10 East Coast locals had drawn up a petition complaining that the local that voted against the settlement "has placed them in imminent danger."
The producers contended that the local that rejected the contract proposal, Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators, had reneged on a promise to recommend the deal to the local's rank and file.
 The producers, through the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers in Sherman Oaks, Calif., said that they had made concessions in the negotiations based on assurances that Local 52 would recommend ratification.
Yesterday the alliance issued a statement denouncing Local 52's failure to urge ratification as "outrageous and unprecedented."
"Local 52's leadership has no interest in reaching an agreement with the producers," the statement from the alliance said.
Ray Fortune, the business manager of Local 52, denied the allegation. "Wally and I did not have the power to make any kinds of deals," he said, referring to the president of Local 52, Walter Stocklin.
"We took it back to the rest of the negotiating committee," an 18-person panel that did not go to California for the bargaining, Mr. Fortune said. That group and Local 52's executive board voted not to recommend the settlement to the members, he said. Mr. DiTolla said the issue would be discussed at a union meeting next week.
The producers indicated that they would continue to steer big-budget productions away from New York, as they have done since last fall, and city officials expressed new concerns about the economic consequences. Movie making is estimated to generate from $500 million to $2.5 billion a year in fees to the city and in jobs for everyone from actors and camera operators to caterers.
But it is hard to quantify the total cost of the filmmaking boycott in dollars. By another measure, last year was the busiest for feature-filmmaking that New York has ever had. Ms. Keyes said that 139 full-length films were shot in the city in 1990, up from 110 in 1989.
The business manager of one of the other unions that negotiated with the producers, Louis D'Agostino of Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries, said he was concerned that the vote by Local 52 would hurt the industry. Local 644's members are still voting on the proposed contract by mail. Ratification is expected.
Ms. Keyes named at least seven films that she said were heading for other locations. The Martin Scorsese production of "Mad Dog and Glory" -- set in the Bronx -- is being moved to Chicago. "With this dispute going on, they felt it was perhaps too dangerous" to film in New York, a spokesman, Marion Billings, said of the production team. She did not elaborate.
The other four films, Ms. Keyes said, were "Mambo Kings," which has been shifted to Los Angeles; "The Analyst," starring Richard Gere, which had been moved to San Francisco; and two films that would be shot in Chicago, "Prelude to a Kiss" and "The Gladiator."
The film version of "Frankie and Johnny" will go before the cameras on schedule next month with Al Pacino and Michelle Pfeiffer in the leading roles, but not in New York. The producers have not decided where to set up shop, but are said to be considering Pittsburgh, Toronto and Chicago.

HEADLINE: CUOMO SEEKS SHIFT IN CITY FISCAL RULE

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16

 BODY:
Adding to the growing edginess over New York City's finances, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo suggested today that the city be allowed to run up a larger deficit before a state panel steps in to take control of its budget.
The Governor's comments come amid anxiety here that the city, with its finances deteriorating almost daily, will not be able to avoid a takeover this summer by the state panel, known as the Financial Control Board. 
 Today, the city offered its first official estimate of its worsening budget situation. The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, estimated that the gap for this fiscal year was now $465 million, although he said he had a plan for closing roughly half of it through reserve funds and spending cuts.
 
Trigger for Takeover
 Under state law, the Financial Control Board would take over the city's finances if the city ended its fiscal year with a deficit of more than $100 million. The Governor suggested today that that figure be adjusted upward for inflation since the law setting it was passed in 1975.
Mr. Cuomo's comments baffled many financial experts, who said the changes the Governor was suggesting probably were not legal because the $100 million takeover trigger appears to be included in bond covenants -- the guarantees the city gives to investors when it sells bonds.
Today's remarks by the Governor were the latest in a series of veiled statements he has made on Mayor David N. Dinkins's budget problems, and they seemed to have a dual message -- half fiscal, half political.
In part, they seemed aimed at countering charges by some city officials that Mr. Cuomo has not been aggressive enough in staving off a possible takeover by the Financial Control Board, of which he is the chairman. And they seemed intended to bolster the Governor's case, if there is ever a takeover, that he sought to avert it.
"I want the world to know that I am very, very much opposed to control," the Governor said in an interview after a news conference today. "I may not be able to stop it, but control is not desirable."
 
A Pointed Declaration
 Yet at the same time that he was suggesting technical ways to avert a control board takeover, Mr. Cuomo pointedly declared today that the state had no means of providing the city with cash to balance its budget during its current fiscal year, which ends on June 30.
Earlier Mr. Cuomo had suggested that the state might be able to provide some assistance to the city through complicated deals involving the sale of bonds by the Battery Park City Authority, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey or the Municipal Assistance Corporation. But as a condition for this aid, he said the city would have to extract concessions from its workers.
This evening, as the city moved closer to the end of its fiscal year with a budget gap now pegged at about $465 million and as the state entered the third week of its fiscal year with budget talks still mired in confusion, New York seemed to be staggering toward a crisis born of sheer inaction.
While the various factions involved in the budget negotiations -- the Mayor, the State Legislature and the municipal labor unions, to name a few -- continued to wrangle over who was responsible for the disarray, talks remained deadlocked.
"We are now apparently in a situation that appears to be stalemated," Norman Steisel, the city's First Deputy Mayor, said. "We need to move on several fronts simultaneously."
But even the new urgency provided by news that the city's budget gap was getting worse has not made any of the participants in the discussions budge enough to make compromise possible. While Mr. Cuomo, for example, has linked additional aid to the city to concessions from the unions, union leaders have tied concessions to a detailed plan from the Governor about how the state intends to help.
 
Particularly Crucial
 The current round of budget talks is particularly crucial to the city because if it ends its fiscal year with a deficit of more than $100 million, its finances would be subject to a takeover by the Financial Control Board. The board was established during the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, and it ran the city's finances for several years.
Under the recommendation made today, which he first mentioned in a Newsday interview on Monday, the $100 million control board trigger would be raised to something closer to $300 million.
"If there is some legal way," Mr. Cuomo said, "to deal with technical problems that arise out of $100 million holes, when that's a 1975 requirement, and that can somehow legally be stretched so that you're talking about the same value, $100 million given inflation, well, that could be an interesting approach."
"I'm not at all sure that's possible," he added.
 
'Nothing Magic'
 Several fiscal analysts concurred in this doubt.
"There are contracts out there that are predicated on the statutes as they exist," said Maury Cooper, senior vice president at Standard & Poor's, the bond rating agency. "There's nothing magic about $100 million. But what's disturbing are the circumstances that make it necessary to consider this change."
Mayor Dinkins, too, said he doubted the change would be legal. And in what appeared to be a cautious and rather cryptic rebuke of the Governor, Mr. Dinkins said today: "If there is the capacity to do something as chairman of the control board, I am hopeful there is capacity to do that as Governor, and the Governor will do those things."
 
Trial Balloons
 The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, was critical of both the Governor and the Mayor, saying they were spending more time posturing and floating trial balloons than addressing the substantive fiscal issues.
"I think it is diversionary," he said of the Governor's latest recommendation. "The issue is: Will the state pass a budget and will the city give us good tough management and solid figures?"
In Albany today, the prospects for the state's passing any budget soon appeared dim. Aides to the Governor and the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, reported that the two had had a heated argument over the telephone and that the day's desultory talks had produced no signs of progress.
In his frustration, Mr. Cuomo went so far today as to suggest that rank-and-file legislators get involved in budget talks, which are usually conducted in private by the Governor, the Assembly Speaker and the State Senate majority leader.
"I think you have to try something radically different," Mr. Cuomo said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
4 Big Banks Post Drops In Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Four of the nation's 10 largest banking companies announced substantially lower quarterly profits yesterday, with Citicorp's falling the most.
Citicorp said its profits fell nearly 70 percent in the first quarter as the weak economy and rising unemployment caused a buildup in delinquent and defaulted loans among consumers. It also cited its already high level of troubled loans for commercial real estate projects. 
 Citicorp was joined by Security Pacific, Chemical Banking and Manufacturers Hanover in announcing declines in profits from the quarter a year earlier. Although none of the large banks reported big losses or reduced dividends, as they did on occasion in 1990, their profits were below the levels that analysts say are needed for long-term health. All four reported fewer loans on their books in the first quarter than in the last quarter of 1990.
Despite the declines, many bank stocks posted strong gains yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 53.71 points, to a 1991 high of 2,986.88. [Page D8.]
 
Lackluster Recovery
 John S. Reed, Citicorp chairman, said he expected the economy to improve before the end of the year. "But there is little evidence of this now," he said. "Nor is there reason to expect a robust recovery."
While waiting for the economy to improve, banks have reaped only limited benefits from the Federal Reserve's moves to push interest rates lower. Falling interest rates have helped many banks by allowing them to reduce interest rates paid on deposits and borrowed funds faster than they cut rates charged on loans. But the drops have not prevented losses on defaulted or delinquent loans.
"The improvement in their interest margin is being eroded by the costs of poor-quality loans," said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Outside New York, in regions where the economy was not so depressed and loan problems were less severe, profits improved or were stable at several large banks.
PNC Financial and Mellon Bank, both in Pittsburgh, said profits had improved 18.7 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively. Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, said profits had increased 18.6 percent. Wells Fargo of San Franciso said profits fell about 5 percent.
Because of the dismal earnings posted last year, recent reports by banks have tended to be better than many analysts had forecast, often resulting in rising stock prices. At Wells Fargo, for example, the absence of a sharp rise in bad real estate loans caused its stock to rise $7.50, to $80. Other companies with good-sized gains included Security Pacific, up $1.875, to $26.25, and PNC, up $1.875, to $32.625.
Citicorp rose 37.5 cents, to $16.375; Chemical 75 cents, to $20.375, and Manufactuers Hanover 87.5 cents, to $27.875. Mellon gained $1.375, to $31.875, and Banc One climbed $1, to $38.75.
Following are details of the banking companies' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp, the nation's largest issuer of credit cards and home mortgages, said the increase in bad and delinquent loans for individual customers was an important reason for its profit decline of 69.7 percent, to $70 million, or 10 cents a share, from $231 million, or 60 cents a share, in 1990's first quarter. The 1990 figure does not include a gain of $140 million from an accounting adjustment.
Worldwide consumer banking earned only $174 million in the first quarter, down from $270 million a year earlier.
 
Delinquencies Continue
 Although Citicorp has not yet published delinquency rates in credit cards and mortgage loans for the first quarter, Thomas Jones, its chief financial officer, noted that last year's trend toward higher delinquincies had continued. Following its standard practice of writing off after 180 days of delinquency all credit card loans and all mortgage loans in excess of the home value, Citicorp charged as a loss $430 million of consumer loans in the first quarter, up from $369 million in the fourth quarter of 1990. Reflecting the negative trend in delinquencies, Citicorp added $531 million to its reserve for consumer loan losses, or $100 million more than it wrote off as a loss.
The economic downturn also hurt Citicorp's consumer business by reducing the use of credit cards and the growth in its customer base. Revenues from consumer banking grew at a 9 percent annual rate in the first quarter, the first time in several years growth had fallen to less than 10 percent.
Commercial real etate loans continue to be the weakest segment of Citicorp's corporate banking group in North America, Europe and Japan, accounting for $402 million of the $752 million increase in nonperforming loans. Nonperforming loans in the group totaled $5.5 billion.
 
Adding Capital
 Mr. Reed said Citicorp planned to add $750 million of capital in the future with profits from the sale of assets or some other arrangement, like taking a partner in part of its business. He said that idea of selling part of the credit card business -- a move that would also have the benefit of reducing the company's reliance on that single line of business "won't happen by July," but "may happen this year."
After raising more than $1.2 billion of capital through the private sale of preferred stock to a Saudi Arabian prince and other investors, Mr. Reed said Citicorp still intended to strengthen its captial, but was not inclined to make a public offering until later in the year "if it's a favorable market."
 
Chemical Banking
 The weakness in the New York area economy was also apparent at the Chemical Banking Corporation, which reported first-quarter profits of $87 million, or 74 cents a share, down 14.4 percent from $101.7 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier. The 1990 figure excludes a gain of $54 million resulting from the profits from the sale of an investment in a Florida banking company and a special charge for the cost of reducing its payroll.
Chemical's earnings were hurt by the addition of $135 million to its reserve for loan losses, up from $70 million a year ago. Nonperforming loans and holdings of real estate acquired from bad loans rose $191 million from the fourth quarter to $3.48 billion.
Texas Commerce Bancshares, a Chemical subsidiary, earned a profit of $27.9 million, up from $18.3 million a year earlier, excluding tax benefits. While Chemical was accumulating bad loans in its New York and New Jersey operations, problem loans at the Texas bank were declining.
 
Manufacturers Hanover
 The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said first-quarter profits fell 18.8 percent, to $78 million, or 87 cents a share, from $96 million, or $1.21 a share. Increases in net interest income, foreign exchange trading, and a $39 million profit on investment securities were offset by the need to set aside $144 million in the reserve for bad loans, up from $73 million a year ago. The addition of the reserve was, however, much less than the $353 million set aside in the fourth quarter.
John F. McGillicuddy, Manufacturers Hanover's chairman, noted that the bank, like many others, had benefited from an ability to charge higher prices to borrowers as some lenders have pulled out of the market. The difference between interst rates Manufacturers Hanover paid and the rates it collected increased to 2.73 percent, from 2.54 percent in the fourth quarter.
 
Security Pacific
 The Security Pacific Corporation, based in Los Angeles, has been hurt by its real estate lending outside California. It earned $96.5 million, or 71 cents a share, in the first quarter, down 48.8 percent from $188.4 million, or $1.54 a share, in the 1990 period. The bank, which is in the midst of a cost-cutting drive and recently laid off several top bankers in its New York office, is trying to concentrate on the California market.
In the first quarter, Security Pacific set aside $271.1 million in its reserve for bad loans, up from $131.4 million a year earlier, but far below the $624.6 million set aside in the fourth quarter of 1990.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo & Company said its drop in profits to $152 million, or $2.86 a share, from $160 million, or $3.04 a share, in 1990's first quarter was related to the cost of combining recently acquired branches of a savings institution with its network.
Although Wells Fargo has heavy concentrations of risky loans for commercial real estate projects and highly indebted companies, it continues to do a better job of avoiding losses than other banks. In the first quarter, it set aside $85 million in its reserve for bad loans, the same as the last quarter of 1990 and up only $10 million from the first quarter of last year. Nonperforming loans rose to $1.1 billion, up only $95 million from the end of the year.
 
PNC Financial
 The PNC Financial Corporation, the holding comapny for the Pittsburgh National Bank, said its increase in first-quarter profits to $88.4 million, or 92 cents a share, from $74.5 million, or 78 cents a share, was accompanied by a decline in troubled loans and a reduction in the amount of reserves set aside to cover loan losses.
Thomas H. O'Brien, PNC's chairman, said "aggressive actions we took last year" were more responsible for the gain than was the improvement in the regions where the company operates. PNC, which owns banks in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana, and New Jersey, lost $168.4 million in the fourth quarter, when it set aside $430 million in a reserve to cover bad loans. In the first quarter, the company set aside only $103.1 million in its reserve, down from $108.9 million a year earlier. Non-performing assets fell $10.7 million from the end of the year, to $1.29 billion.
 
Mellon Bank
 The Mellon Bank Corporation, whose first-quarter profit of $68 million, or $1.25 a share, was up from $65 million, or $1.25 a share, in the 1990 period, also benefited from stable loan quality. The company, whose profits are now back to the high levels that preceeded its problems in the late 1980's, set aside only $45 million for loan losses, down from $175 million in the fourth quarter. A year earlier, it set aside only $35 million.
 
Banc One
 The Banc One Corporation, earned a record $120.7 million, or 75 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $101.8 million, or 70 cents a share, for the comparable period last year. Although nonperforming assets rose by 7.6 percent from the end of the year, to $476 million, the company benefited from strong growth in low-cost consumer deposits and good demand for the consumer and small-business loans that are its specialty. The difference between the interest it paid on deposits and the interest received from loans and investments increased to 6.31 percent in the first quarter, from 5.47 percent in the fourth quarter of 1991.

HEADLINE: Poverty Blamed for Blacks' High Cancer Rate

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Poverty, not race, is largely to blame for the higher rate of cancer among blacks than whites, according to a study by scientists at the National Cancer Institute.
The study, which is being published Wednesday in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, says programs to fight cancer should thus be aimed at poor urban areas rather than at black communities. 
 "Poor Americans constitute a high-risk group for developing and dying of cancer," Dr. Harold Freeman of Harlem Hospital Center in New York wrote in an accompanying editorial. "Accordingly, substantial resources should be directed toward prevention, detection, diagnosis and treatment of cancer in the economically disadvantaged."
In explaining the link between the incidence of cancer and socioeconomic status, he cited poverty's association with low educational levels, substandard living conditions, bad nutrition and poor access to health care.
 
Cancer Rates Compared
 Scientists have long been aware that blacks are significantly more likely than whites to get cancer, and to die sooner once cancer is diagnosed. Depending on the type of cancer and the part of the country, the cancer rate for blacks is 6 to 10 percent higher than that for whites.
In the new study, Dr. Claudia R. Baquet and others at the cancer institute compared black and white cancer rates in Atlanta, Detroit and San Francisco-Oakland from 1978 to 1982.
Then, using data from the 1980 census, they adjusted the data for socioeconomic factors, including population density, education and income levels. The adjustments were used to estimate the cancer rates that would be observed for blacks if they had the same socioeconomic characteristics as whites. The researchers looked at overall cancer risk as well as the risk at some common sites.
While the raw data showed that blacks had a higher risk of cancer over all, the adjusted data showed whites had a higher overall risk. And while the unadjusted data showed whites running a greater risk of breast and rectal cancer only, after adjustment it showed whites running a greater risk of lung cancer, too. After adjustment, blacks still ran a greater risk than whites of stomach, cervical and prostate cancers.
The researchers acknowledged that unidentified racial factors linked to culture or genetics appeared to affect the incidence rates of some cancers.

HEADLINE: Chamorro Pleads With Congress for Increases in Aid

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Speaking in the House chamber where the debate over the war in Nicaragua resonated for years, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pleaded today with Congress for increases in economic aid to fortify her country's new democracy.
As she entered the House of Representatives to address a rare joint meeting of Congress, a number of legislators embraced her and kissed her on the cheek, and her half-hour speech was interrupted seven times by enthusiastic applause. The event seemed to symbolize the end of an era in relations between Washington and Managua that was punctuated by the contra war and the Iran-contra scandal. 
 Wearing a red dress and speaking through an interpreter, she recounted her political career, which has spanned Nicaragua's last 14 years of war and revolution. She talked of her assassinated husband, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the nine months she worked on a junta dominated by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, and her electoral victory over President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in February 1990.
"In Nicaragua an authentic revolution is beginning," she said. "It is a revolution for democracy and liberty."
 
'Steadfast' Aid Needed
 Mrs. Chamorro emphasized the economic needs of her war-ravaged country, saying, "We need steadfast financial assistance from the United States throughout this entire decade to reconstruct our economy."
The United States has pledged $541 million for Nicaragua since her election, but only about $207 million has been disbursed. The Administration has conditioned its aid on a reform of the banking system and privatization of the statist economy developed over a decade of Sandinista rule.
While her relations with the Bush Administration have been publicly warm, there have been a series of private disputes beginning with her early retention of Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the former President's brother, as commander of the army. Most recently, her aides have complained that the Administration has leaked allegations to the press that there is strong circumstantial evidence linking Sandinista army officials to the assassination in February of Enrique Bermudez, a former contra leader.
In a vague reference to the case, she said: "Justice is one element that cannot be missing from this system. Crimes cannot remain unresolved, as we have witnessed in the past."
Mrs. Chamorro mentioned the word Sandinista only once, and she spoke in generalities. But she sought to distance herself from what she called "the delirium of a totalitarian ideology" and to address concerns expressed by officials in the Administration and Congress that Sandinista units continue to ship arms to guerrillas in El Salvador and Honduras and abuse the human rights of peasants in the countryside.
"It is important to reiterate that Nicaragua does not now tolerate, and will not tolerate the sending of arms by civilians or military men to neighboring countries," she said.
Members of Congress said that Mrs. Chamorro had said all the right things to allay fears that the Sandinistas maintained a large share of power in Nicaragua, but they also said they could not satisfy all her economic needs.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the House subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, said: "Her speech could have been written by the State Department. It's a recognition that she understands the reality that she has political problems with this Administration."
Mr. Torricelli said her speech "helps her and it helps those of us who want to help her rebuild the country."
Mrs. Chamorro ends her three-day state visit on Wednesday with a meeting with President Bush and the Cabinet and a formal White House dinner.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in the House Chamber yesterday. At rear were Vice President Dan Quayle and the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley. Mrs. Charmorro's state visit ends today. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Talk About Culture Shock: Ant People in Sky-High Huts

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Davi Kopenawa Yanomami had left his communal hut and traveled from his village deep in the Amazon rain forest to tell of the horrors that white men were visiting upon his people. Then he saw Times Square.
"Man has become crazy," Davi said, as he shuffled down Seventh Avenue in crinkly white running shoes, looking for what had been described to him as the heart of New York. For protection, he wore a necklace of macaw feathers and hollowed seeds beneath his blue work shirt. But his eyes still darted nervously to the blur of passing automobiles. 
 New Yorkers scurried by on the sidewalk, drafting his small, stocky frame to one side, then the other. "They are like the ant," he announced. "They start one way and turn around and go the other way. They look all the time at the ground and never see the sky. Why do they do that?"
In New York's annals of awe-struck visitors and cultural confrontations, Davi (who doesn't really have a last name, but borrows that of his tribe) begins a new chapter. Among the Yanomami of Brazil, part of the hemisphere's largest tribe of unacculturated Indians, he is the first to visit the United States.
 
Reluctant Traveler
 As a shaman-in-training, a village notable and the primary hunter-gatherer of his young family, Davi was not really eager to leave his home near the Demini River. He had been trying to find money for an emergency health project, planning the first Yanomami school and hoping to find time for some spiritual journeys. Also, he was worried about visiting a country so recently at war. Among the Yanomami, war is a messy business of axes and clubs and long, bamboo-tipped arrows; years ago, an American anthropologist labeled them "the fierce people," for their tendency to kill each other.
But Davi (pronounced dah-VEE) is one of few Yanomami who speak Portuguese, or any other foreign language, and there is much for them to tell. More than three years ago, gold prospectors began swarming into the forests that his people have occupied for millenia, polluting their rivers with mercury, scaring off their monkeys and tapir, and carrying in deadly diseases like malaria, tuberculosis and the common cold.
Davi is planning to explain all of this to the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States, to high officials of the World Bank and to anyone else who will listen. He was brought to the United States for two weeks by Indian-rights groups eager to dramatize the plight of the Yanomami.
Unlike most of his contemporaries, Davi, who has been saying for several years that he is about 35 years old, saw his first white man while still a boy. He has since visited Sao Paulo, and even London and Oslo, where he has made speeches, received awards and heard a lot about New York.
An American friend hoped to soften the shock of Manhattan by lending his Upper West Side apartment -- and stocking the refrigerator with bananas and Chiquita Caribbean Splash fruit juice. The friend would have rigged up a hammock, too, had the beams of his pre-war building held the screws.
Anyway, Davi arrived angry. In Rio de Janeiro, Pan American airline stewards insisted that he check the bow and arrows he had carried along as a gift. At Kennedy Airport, people wearing the same uniforms gave him back only a form, to report lost luggage.
As might have happened with any first-generation son of the earth, a note of condescension crept into Davi's voice as he rode down Broadway on the 104 bus.
"Everything in the world here, everything in these countries is mixed up," he said in his rough Portuguese, glancing out at 72d Street. "Nothing is separated. All the races are mixed. They don't have blood of their own."
Even dogs.
"Another race of dogs in New York," Davi said, admiring a Pekinese whose hair, he figured, would substitute wonderfully for the feathers used to decorate the headdresses that the Yanomami call cocar. A poodle minced by, tied to a man by a long rope. "They have other hair, the dogs; other customs."
The customs of the people seemed no less strange.
"That man is coming from the laundromat," Davi's traveling companion, Claudia Andujar, explained, referring to a man with plastic bags of clothing slung over his shoulder. The party was walking back along 106th Street after a look at the Hudson. "People here don't wash their clothes," she said.
"But the river is right there!" Davi protested.
He was kidding.
 
Spiritual Questions
 At the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, though, Davi was vexed by the marble sarcophagus holding the remains of a bishop. When the Yanomami die, their bodies are cremated and their ashes consumed in a grog of plantain mush. The names of the dead are never spoken again, making it hard to determine just how many have been killed by the miners and their diseases.
"If his body is in there," Davi asked, "where does his soul go?"
It is not that the Yanomami have no explanation for the ways of white men. A Yanomami myth holds that whites came into the world long ago, when a fight among men interrupted the ritual seclusion of an Indian girl during her first menses. The forest was plunged into darkness and a flood swept many Yanomami away. Remori, a supernatural being, skimmed up some of the foam and mumbled into his cupped hands. The bits of foam then became white people, who, to the Yanomami way of thinking, still use the same burbling noises to communicate.
 
Where King Kong Clung
 In the souvenir shop of the Empire State Building, Davi wondered about the monkey depicted on all of the coffee cups and key rings.
A friend explained that the items referred to an old movie about a giant ape that terrorized New York. The friend pointed to posters of King Kong hugging the skyscraper's top.
"Does the monkey still exist?" Davi wanted to know.
It is not the Yanomami way to be impressed by new things, and on leaving the building Davi seemed nonchalant.
"I have been higher than that before," he confided in a taxi cab that squirted down Fifth Avenue. "The homes of the shabori," he said, using the Yanomami word for shaman, "are much higher."
In the Surucucus range of northern Brazil, where many Yanomami live (the roughly 20,000 members of the tribe are divided about equally by the Brazilian-Venezuelan border), the hills rise to more than 3,000 feet. But Davi was really talking about something else, said Ms. Andujar, who is trying to have the Brazilian Government declare Yanomami lands a national park.
"Nothing ever surprises him because he has already experienced everything in his spiritual trips," she said, meaning the journeys that Yanomami make with the help of yakoana, a hallucinogenic that is blown into the nostrils through long tubes.
By the next afternoon, at the Museum of the American Indian, Davi had become positively didactic. At one display case, he pointed to the small likeness of a shaggy quadruped.
"That," he said, "is the buffalo."
His companions stared in disbelief. Where could he have seen a buffalo?
"In Sao Paulo," he explained. "I saw that movie, 'The Dance of the Wolf.' "
In coming to the United States, the hope of raising money for sick Yanomami was foremost in Davi's mind. The Brazilian Government that took office last year promised to evict the estimated 45,000 prospectors on Yanomami lands and even dynamited their airstrips. But some of the miners have already returned, and their diseases continue to kill Indians who have no immunity, even to common colds.
 
In the South Bronx
 As he was driven through poorer parts of New York on Saturday afternoon, Davi began to question the salubriousness of things here.
"When I see white men like that," he said of a ragged-looking man walking along Southern Boulevard in the South Bronx, "I feel very sad. He has no food. He has no place of his own."
Davi felt better when he looked down from his airplane at the green surroundings of Washington, Ms. Andujar said. Then the people in Pan American uniforms at National Airport told him that they had lost his luggage again.

HEADLINE: Darman Forecasts Dire Health Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, delivered a dire warning today about increases in the cost of health care, telling Congress that annual Government spending on Medicare and Medicaid would exceed Social Security outlays by the turn of the century.
The Government expects to spend $156 billion on the two health programs in this fiscal year, as against $269 billion for Social Security. Public and private health spending in the United States now exceeds $600 billion a year, or about $1.7 billion a day. 
 "Total health spending has grown from less than 6 percent of the gross national product three decades ago to about 12 percent today," Mr. Darman said at a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee. "It is currently projected to reach 17 percent by the year 2000 and 37 percent of G.N.P. by 2030."
Mr. Darman did not say how he had computed those estimates. He did say that the country would probably not let current trends continue to the point that health care accounted for more than one-third of the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services.
 
Spending More Than Profits
 Mr. Darman said business spending on health insurance premiums and health care for employees and former employees had increased so much that, in 1989, it was "in excess of 100 percent of after-tax profits" of all American companies, taken together.
Health care is usually treated as a cost of doing business. Under current law, employers who pay health insurance premiums for employees may deduct the payments as a business expense on their tax returns.
The hearing did not focus on any specific legislative proposal, but, as with similar hearings being held this month by the House Ways and Means Committee, it reflected Congress's seemingly insatiable appetite for information about health care.
Business executives told the Finance Committee today that urgent action was needed to help control health care costs. Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive officer of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, said his company's medical expenses rose to $115 million last year from $60 million in 1985.
 
Big Problems for Big Steel
 Walter F. Williams, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said health costs for the steel industry had more than doubled in the last decade and now accounted for more than 15 percent of total employment costs. Health care costs seriously threaten the competitiveness of this country's steel industry because they are two to three times as high as for steel industries in other countries, he said.
As if to underline the problem, Federal researchers reported today that health spending accounted for a far bigger share of the gross national product in the United States than in other countries.
George J. Schieber, research director of the Health Care Financing Administration, the Federal agency that runs the Government health insurance plans for the elderly and for the poor, said he had found that no other Western industrialized country spent more than 9 percent of its gross national product on health care. Moreover, he said, the proportion of G.N.P. spent on health has actually declined in some countries commonly thought to have more comprehensive national health care programs.
Mr. Schieber's findings were reported in Health Affairs, a quarterly journal published by Project Hope, a private health foundation.
He said that spending on health care averaged $2,354 for each person in the United States in 1989. That was 40 percent higher than the comparable figure in Canada and twice the average for the 24 industrial countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
In his projections of health spending, Mr. Darman assumed that Medicaid outlays would grow 12.7 percent a year, as they did from 1985 to 1990. That assumption seems implausible but not impossible, health economists say.
Mr. Darman objected to suggestions that the United States put some type of overall limit on national health spending. Such a limit would lead inevitably to the rationing of health care, he said.
But Senator Thomas A. Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, said health care was already being rationed, on the basis of people's ability to pay.
The political difficulty of restraining health care costs was dramatized today as House Democrats denounced President Bush for proposing cutbacks in Medicare. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said the proposals "would place the quality of medical care for senior citizens at risk."

HEADLINE: Ruling Removes Last Hurdle For 6 Real-Estate Projects

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
The last legal obstacle to the construction of six major real-estate projects, including several apartment and office buildings on the West Side, was removed yesterday when a state appeals court restored two New York City zoning law amendments.
The amendments, which had been struck down by a lower court, cleared the way for Manhattan West, a complex of 1,000 apartments on West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets; a 51-story office building at Ninth Avenue and 31st Street; a hotel near the Convention Center; a major expansion of the United Parcel Service distribution center in Tribeca, and a small part of Metrotech, a development in downtown Brooklyn. 
 "I'm gratified by the ruling," said Victor A. Kovner, the City Corporation Counsel. "It will now permit some much needed development without sacrificing any enviromental interests."
Richard L. Schaffer, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said: "This is an important victory for effective planning. It will enable the commission to focus on real enviromental concerns rather than speculative ones."
 
'Environmental Consequences'
 The ruling was said to have little impact on Donald J. Trump's proposed development project, Riverside South, between West End Avenue and the Hudson River largely because it has not yet begun the formal city-review procedure.
The ruling overturned a decision by Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court, who ruled in November that the Board of Estimate "failed to take the requisite hard look" when it approved two zoning changes that would allow the projects to be built.
Justice Gammerman, in siding with a coalition of environmentalists and West Side opponents of the projects, said that in approving the zoning changes the city failed to accurately assess the future "enviromental consequences" that large-scale building would have on West Side residents.
The city "chose not to see what was there to be seen," the judge said.
But in a unanimous decision yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court overruled Justice Gammerman. In an opinion written by Justice Theodore R. Kupferman, the court concluded that the board, which has since been abolished under the new City Charter, had studied the enviromental impact of the zoning changes and had given them "the requisite hard look throughout the review process."
"It cannot be said that the Board of Estimate's determination was affected by an error of law or was arbitrary and capricious or an abuse of its discretion," the court said."
"What the court ruling means," said Leonard J. Koerner, an Assistant Corporation Counsel, "is that all these projects can now go ahead, there are no more legal impediments."
At issue were two changes in the zoning law that the board approved on Feb 22, 1990. The first incorporated a series of enviromental safeguards concerning large-scale commercial, manufacturing and mixed-used development in congested areas of the city.
The second dealt with development within or over railroad or subway lines.
Opponents of the changes, like People for Westpride and several other enviromental groups including the Natural Resources Defense Council, said they relaxed environmental standards and allowed larger construction than was appropriate.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
Four of the nation's 10 largest banking companies announced substantially lower quarterly profits, with Citicorp's falling the most. It was joined by Security Pacific, Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover. [Page D1.]
MGM-Pathe's main lender agreed to $145 million in new loans, but only after Giancarlo Parretti said he would step down. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Dow Soars 53.71 to Reach Its High for Year

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Strong buying that intensified in the afternoon lifted all sectors of the stock market in heavy trading yesterday. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was at a high for 1991 and less than 13 points away from its record, while most other popular share indexes were at highs.
The 30-share Dow average closed up 53.71, at 2,986.88, passing its 1991 high of 2,973.27, set March 6. The Dow's peak of 2,999.75 was reached last July 16 and 17. 
 "The strength of the Dow tells us that investors are once again interested in the basic industrial issues, such as the metals, papers, chemicals and other sectors that were thought of as vulnerable during a recession," said Michael Metz, chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company.
What kept many investors away from the basic industrials and blue chips until now, Mr. Metz said, was a hesitation to act until first-quarter corporate earnings and other potentially negative news were out. Prices backed and filled early in the session yesterday, but "after a nervous start, the market apparently decided the bad news was out and that it was time to look ahead," he said.
Many institutional investors did not need much persuasion once the rally began after midday, when the Dow average stood at about 2,930. For months, portfolio managers for pension and mutual funds, insurance companies, bank trusts and other institutions have watched the yields on Treasury bonds and other fixed-income securities shrivel.
As the buying turned into a near frenzy in the last hour of trading, some of the last of the institutional fence-sitters joined the rally. At the final bell, the New York Stock Exchange composite index had set a record for the second day, closing up 3.12, at 211.71, and Big Board volume had soared to 214.5 million shares, from 161.8 million the day before.
Among the Big Board issues that benefited from the new-found support were those that had been placed under a cloud because of poor earnings or poor prospects. I.B.M., for example, was up 2 3/8, to 109 1/4. Citicorp, which reported a plunge in earnings yesterday, nevertheless, saw its stock rise 3/8, to 16 3/8.
RJR Nabisco led the list, gaining 1/8, to 12 1/4, on a volume of eight million shares, after a positive response to a note offering, and American Telephone was the second-most-active issue, rising 1 3/8, to 37 1/4, on a turnover of 3.4 million shares. There were hints that A.T.& T. might raise its bid for NCR.
Bank shares, which had been out of favor for a long time, were in demand, because their latest earnings reports were not so depressed as expected. For example, Wells Fargo jumped 7 1/2, to 80, because its earnings declined only 5 percent and it had no new significant loan problems. BankAmerica rose 1 5/8, to 39, in sympathy. Security Pacific said it did not expect to cut its dividend more than the 40 percent reduction announced last month and its shares climbed 1 7/8, to 26 1/4. Corestates Financial reported lower earnings that were still well above expectations and its stock rose 2 5/8, to 39 1/8.
In all, 1,126 Big Board issues advanced and 514 declined. Analysts said many a computer had signaled "buy" when the Dow passed 2,950.
But far more buy orders were set off when the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which most professional portfolio managers follow, finally settled over 380 in the last hour after meandering in a relatively narrow range for most of the session. The S.& P. 500 ended up 6.43, at 387.62, eclipsing the previous record set the day before.

 TOKYO, Wednesday, April 17 (Reuters) -- Tokyo stocks closed higher in trading today. The Nikkei average gained 167.07 points, or 0.62 percent, to 26,980.37.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
"DINERS zero in on names." So said a restaurateur in Seattle, in response to the second annual poll on wine-drinking habits in restaurants compiled by Wine and Spirits magazine. The restaurateur, Lotta Hashizume, could have added: "and white wine." She did note that at her place, Chez Shea, the producer most often mentioned was Sonoma-Cutrer, a Windsor, Calif., winery that makes only chardonnay.
Consciously or not, Ms. Hashizume put her finger on something fundamental: consumers go for good-quality wines that are well-marketed and, most important, available. In other words, popular brand names. 
 Many consumers have never read a tasting note, no matter how precious or baroque. Many have never read a wine column, newsletter or magazine. They recognize a name from previous restaurant forays, probably recommended by a sommelier or captain, and they feel comfortable ordering it.
The five names mentioned most by guests in the 122 restaurants responding to the poll were, in order: Robert Mondavi Winery, in Napa Valley; Sonoma-Cutrer Vineyards , in northern Sonoma; Jordan Winery , in Alexander Valley; Kendall-Jackson Vineyards in Lake County, and Clos du Bois Winery , in Healdsburg. Each of them makes fine wine, each markets aggressively and each one's wines are widely distributed. And, it goes without saying, they are all in California. The best any foreign wine company could do was Louis Jadot, in Burgundy, France, in eighth place.
This year, Wine and Spirits sent questionnaires to 750 restaurants, including the 40 most popular restaurants in each of the 16 markets where the Zagat restaurant guides are compiled and the most popular hotel restaurants in the Zagat hotel surveys. One hundred twenty-two restaurants responded.
Respondents were asked for a list of the 10 top-selling wines in the last quarter of 1990, as well as their top-selling after-dinner drinks, and for some answers to questions about how customers order and what they see in the future. In last year's poll, in which 100 restaurants responded, Sonoma-Cutrer was first, Mondavi second and Jordan third. Grgich Hills Cellar and Trefethen Vineyards , both in Napa Valley, were fourth and fifth.
Of the restaurants responding, 39 said they were American, 38 French, 21 Italian, and 5 Spanish. The 19 others included Chinese and seafood.
Chardonnay continued to outsell all other wines, the poll found. The top five chardonnays were Sonoma-Cutrer, Kendall-Jackson, Robert Mondavi, Trefethen and Edna Valley Vineyards in San Luis Obispo County. Grgich Hills, ranked third last year, dropped into sixth place.
When it comes to French wine in restaurants, the favorite wine is Pouilly-Fuisse, followed at a considerable distance by Meursault and Chassagne-Montrachet, both quite expensive wines these days. The Macon whites, which represent good value in restaurants and retail shops these days, could do no better than fourth.
Again, name brands predominated; in this case, Jadot, Louis Latour and Joseph Drouhin, all exporters of considerable standing in this country and with good distribution. What is not clear about the French wines is whether patrons asked for the type of wine -- Beaujolais, for example -- and took whatever brand was offered, or whether they specified the brand name.
 Counting both red and white wines, the top French label was Jadot, with Louis Latour, Joseph Drouhin, Georges DuBoeuf and Guigal following in that order. Not one of them, incidentally, is from Bordeaux. Last year, the top five were Jadot, Drouhin, Latour, DuBoeuf and Chateau de Meursault .
Jordan was the most popular cabernet sauvignon by a wide margin. Wine and Spirits asked each restaurant to rank their top-selling wines from 1 to 10, with the best seller getting 10 points. Thus Jordan amassed 139 points to second-placed Silver Oaks Cellars ' 59 points. Mondavi was third, Beaulieu Vineyard was fourth and Chateau Montelena was fifth. Every one of these wineries except Jordan is in Napa Valley.
For some reason, Wine and Spiritscalled pinot noir "perhaps the most dynamic varietal" in the poll. In fact, the ratings were very low, indicating that the wine may be the darling of the wine buffs, but that it still has a long way to go to make its mark among the restaurant crowd. The top pinot noir, and one of only a handful of American wines from some place other than California, was from Knudsen-Erath , in the Willamette Valley of Oregon.
Calera , which is an exception to the stipulation that these wines be widely distributed, was No. 2. But it qualifies on both other counts: its single vineyard pinot noirs are widely viewed as among the very best made anywhere, and are certainly among the best promoted. Louis Jadot, in Burgundy, was third; La Crema , in Sonoma County was fourth and Rex Hill Vineyards , in Newberg, Ore., was fifth.
The number of restaurants listing French wines among the best sellers was fewer than one might think. The relative weakness of the dollar against the French franc had much to do with it, the poll takers concluded, as well as the fact that French restaurants are much less likely than others, particularly American, to offer wine by the glass.
Mr. DuBoeuf, who is billed as the King of Beaujolais, got far more points for his Pouilly-Fuisse than for his Beaujolais-Villages. For some reason, Americans love to snap the wine list shut with authority and announce, "We'll take the Pouilly-Fuisse."
The best-selling Italian label was Santa Margherita, apparently because its best-known wine is pinot grigio, an inoffensive and popular white wine. To dedicated Italian wine drinkers, this must come as a shock. To them, Italy is a land of superb red wines and an ocean of mostly forgettable whites. That is not the way the Saturday night restaurant crowd sees it. Of the 12 producers who made the list, 7 were there exclusively for white wines, and even famous old houses like Ruffino, Antinori and Frescobaldi scored a substantial number of points for their white wines.
The same is true for Spain: prominent producers of fine red wines, including Torres, Cune and the Marques de Riscal, scored more points for their whites.
Fewer sparkling wines made the list, reflecting the economic downturn. Moet & Chandon, from France, led, followed by its Napa Valley subsidiary, Domaine Chandon. Schramsberg, also in Napa Valley, was third. Charles Heidseick and Veuve Clicquot tied for fourth, Perrier-Jouet was fifth and expensive Krug was sixth. Last year the top three were Moet, Clicquot and Perrier-Jouet.
High prices in Champagne and the continuing weakness of the dollar certainly helped Domaine Chandon become one of the top five sparkling wines and helped Schramsberg move up.
Are there lessons in all this? Several. First, that restaurants continue to be showcases for good wine. Second, that the public rewards consistency in quality and availability. Third: where fine wine is concerned, brand recognition is here to stay.
 
TASTINGS
Guenoc Winery, 1985 Cabernet Sauvignon, Lake County, Calif.; about $9.
 Lake County is north of Napa and east of Mendocino and Sonoma. The Guenoc Winery is at the southern end of the county; so much so that some of its vineyards extend down into northern Napa, around the base of Mount St. Helena. The area differs from the northern part of the county in soil and temperature to the extent that it has its own appellation from the Federal Government: Guenoc Valley. Lillie Langtry, the British actress and demimondaine lived here for a time in the 1880's; her picture is on Guenoc labels. Lake County reds tend to be lush and rounded rather than tannic and structured. This 1985 could hardly be called lean and tight, but it has plenty of backbone to go with the fruit. Cassis is a preponderant flavor. A wine to
enjoy now at a most reasonable price. Guenoc also makes a delicious zinfandel.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Fumbling New York's Fiscal Crisis

 BODY:
New York City is in a state of emergency, suffering from an economy in free fall. Sales and income tax revenues are below even pessimistic projections, the budget gap keeps growing and no relief is in sight. Yet there is scant evidence that City Hall is prepared to make the difficult decisions to lead the city out of danger.
Mayor David Dinkins has yet to provide clear, consistent leadership that could anticipate and limit damage. Instead the Mayor has reversed himself time and again, and now, faced with a newly discovered budget gap, City Hall is doing a very good impression of panicking. 
 Forced to close a new hole of more than $250 million in less than three months, the Mayor and his advisers are scurrying for solutions. They almost sound surprised, as if the economy hadn't been wreaking havoc for months.
Few anticipated the severity of the decline in tax revenues, but budget experts warned of the recession's destructive path months ago. Gov. Mario Cuomo has long sounded the alarm and called on the Mayor to go further. Had Mr. Dinkins taken more decisive steps early, the city might have weathered this latest onslaught without a crisis. But every time the Mayor showed signs of truly confronting the city's problems, he pulled back. He was trying, no doubt, to limit the pain. But that is only making things worse now.
After realizing that the city couldn't afford its imprudent settlement with the teachers' union, the Dinkins administration approved a similar contract with other unions, then agreed to a wage deferral that will ultimately cost the city dearly. The Mayor called for further concessions from labor but so far has gotten none. He pledged to consolidate agencies, but they are unchanged. He proposed sizable layoffs but averted all but about 1,000 of them through a wage deferral. Right now, the city work force is larger -- by about 1,600 people -- than it was on the day Mr. Dinkins took office.
This crisis is likely to get much worse. In the fiscal year beginning July 1, the deficit in a $29 billion budget could exceed $3 billion. Debt service is enormous, the needs of the poor are growing and the state cannot do much because of its own crisis.
If New York City is to get through the recession, it needs radical changes. The municipal work force, which accounts for half the budget, will have to shrink. If huge corporations have responded to the slide by consolidating, reducing salaries and dropping jobs, is that impossible for the city?
There are sound reasons, for example, to try to expand sanitation routes, merge some firehouses and take a more critical look at vacations, other fringe benefits, the Police Department and even the Mayor's police plan.
Standard assumptions won't get the city through this crisis, and more mayoral wavering will only make it worse. If Mr. Dinkins hopes to minimize future damage to the city, he has little choice but to redesign the government.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
The Party of April 15?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
With millions of Americans having just trooped glumly to the post office to send in their annual tribute to the Government, why are Democrats hesitating to back Senator Daniel P. Moynihan's proposal to cut taxes for lower- and middle-income people while raising them on the affluent?
What step could Democrats take that would be more likely to counter charges that they are the party of "tax and tax and spend and spend," or Ronald Reagan's quip that Republicans are the party of July Fourth while Democrats are the party of April 15? 
 Senator Moynihan, the New York Democrat, has proposed again, as he did last year, that the Social Security payroll tax, the most onerous of Federal levies, be lowered from 6.2 to 5.2 percent by 1996, but that the maximum wages subject to the tax be increased in the same period from $53,400 to $82,000.
Sum up the political advantages for the Democrats:
* A tax cut for those of lower income, and in a highly regressive tax at that, since those earning hundreds of thousands a year now pay no more in Social Security taxes than someone earning only $53,400.
* A significant and partly compensating shift of the payroll tax's heavy burden to those better able to pay, by taxing up to $82,000 of their earnings.
* A clear Democratic initiative -- if the party signs on -- that would benefit those claimed as its constituency.
* An issue that probably would evoke the opposition of the Bush Administration and loyalist Republicans, thus blunting their tax-and-spend charges against Democrats.
Unfortunately for these prospects, Lloyd Bentsen and Dan Rostenkowski, the chairmen of the Senate and House committees that write tax legislation, and other conservative Democrats argue that the Moynihan proposal would endanger Social Security benefits.
It wouldn't, now or later. Apart from the compensating increase in wages subject to the payroll tax, the Social Security trust fund is amply sufficient to cover its obligations, and would remain so after the proposed changes. The Social Security Actuary Office reports, for example, that assets "from 55 percent to 110 percent of annual expenditures" would carry the fund safely through a 5-to-10-year period of economic downturn.
At the beginning of this year, assets were 83 percent of annual expenditures. Even after a 1 percent cut in the payroll tax, of course, and even during a lengthy recession, the trust fund would continue to receive enormous annual revenues.
It's also argued that the Moynihan plan would increase the Federal deficit. Baloney. The Social Security trust fund only masks the size of the actual deficit, since the Government borrows from it to pay general obligations -- something the trust fund was never intended for, and which represents a greater lack of fiscal responsibility than cutting an unfair tax.
The Congressional Budget Office huffs and puffs, too, that lowering the payroll tax would reduce gross national product perhaps 1 percent annually. An increase in the deficit, according to this reasoning, would cause savings to fall, interest rates to rise and investment to decline.
This tortured scenario seems hardly to take into account the stimulative effect of the increased buying power that the payroll tax cuts would give to millions of Americans. Nor does it reflect a concern for the widespread and plausible belief of so many low-to-middle-income taxpayers that they are heavily and unfairly taxed while the wealthy get off lightly.
Even if the C.B.O. were right -- economic forecasting, after all, is as fallible as any other kind -- it does not exactly predict doom; and the political considerations involved are at least as weighty as the economic. Two Republican Administrations, while compiling unmatched records for borrowing and spending over the last decade, have made a major and damaging issue of the Democrats' alleged taxing and spending proclivities. This not only tends to conceal the Republicans' own considerable fiscal irresponsibility; it has been a strong factor in the Democrats' long exclusion from national office.
Now Senator Moynihan offers his party a chance to refute the tax charge, expose Republican pretensions and give hard-pressed Americans a break. Why not grab it?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: A Few of the Reasons for Wanting to Flee New York City;
Most Want to Stay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You sound the right alarm in your April 1 article on fears expressed by several economists about middle-class flight from New York City. 
 Municipal government must deliver services more cost-effectively. Otherwise, the very New Yorkers our city can least afford to lose will continue to leave town.
Rising taxes and declining quality of life are not inevitable, however.
Fiscal discipline and productivity in local government, an effective national urban coalition to obtain the rightful share of cities to Federal assistance and an economic upturn would shore up New York's appeal as a place to live and work.
Most New Yorkers want to stay; City Hall can help by holding the line on taxes and providing maximum service for every tax dollar. These policies would go a long way toward increasing confidence in New York's future.
 
STEVEN SPINOLA
President
Real Estate Board of New York
New York, April 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Homer Bigart, Acclaimed Reporter, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
Homer Bigart, one of the most accomplished reporters in American journalism, died yesterday at the Edgewood Center in Portsmouth, N.H., where he had been hospitalized for two months. Mr. Bigart, who wrote for both The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times, was 83 years old and lived in West Nottingham, N.H.
He died of cancer, his wife, Else, said. 
 In a calling whose end product tends to be ephemeral and forgettable, in which writers nervously jest that they are only as good as their last story, Mr. Bigart stood as an enduring role model.
During a prize-collecting career of nearly four decades, he always seemed to be at the top of his game, much to the dismay of his competitors.
His articles remained taut, witty and astringently understated, even when created under deadline pressure and the appalling working conditions imposed by war and famine; even when they concerned mundane events that lesser reporters regarded as routine. Mr. Bigart knew that what counted was not the place but the poetry and that a reporter could create memorable prose from even the most unremarkable happening.
Such pieces became models of grace by which young reporters measured their own talent, and they were the reality from which a legend was born. In journalism schools and in the drafty city rooms of a town that always prided itself on being the ultimate stop for the nation's most gifted newspaper reporters, Mr. Bigart was regarded with awe.
He won most of the major national and local prizes in journalism. There was a Pulitzer Prize, and there was an uncommon second Pulitzer. There were an Overseas Press Club award and the George Polk Memorial Award and the Meyer Berger Award and a Page One Award, and many others.
All were given for the resourcefulness and courage that Mr. Bigart repeatedly showed in World War II, the Greek civil war, the Korean War and the turbulent years that followed, when he wrote about the civil-rights struggle and hunger and the extraordinary changes that were taking place in urban and rural America.
All of his articles were written either for The Herald Tribune, where he worked from 1929 to 1955, or The Times, where he worked from 1955 until his retirement in 1972.
If his reporter friends told him that the encomiums in his stocking approached an indecent level, they were proud that he had won such praise, because they felt he was the best of them. Wherever he went and whatever he did, his copy rose above the moment; no awards judge could resist Mr. Bigart at his best.
 
Describing History In the Making
 For example, there was the opening of the article he wrote from the battleship Missouri on Sept. 2, 1945, telling readers of The Herald Tribune that one of the greatest military struggles in world history was finally over:
"Japan, paying for her desperate throw of the dice at Pearl Harbor, passed from the ranks of the major powers at 9:05 A.M. today when Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu signed the document of unconditional surrender.
"If the memories of the bestialities of the Japanese prison camps were not so fresh in mind, one might have felt sorry for Shigemitsu as he hobbled on his wooden leg toward the green baize covered table where the papers lay waiting.
"He leaned heavily on his cane and had difficulty seating himself. The cane, which he rested against the table, dropped to the deck of this battleship as he signed."
And there was the time in 1943 that he took a troopship to London and was surprised that it had not been torpedoed, reports of scores of U-boats to the contrary. Three paragraphs from the end of his dispatch he wrote:
"Then you woke up one morning and the ship was very steady, and you knew she had entered the harbor. You had arrived. You had crossed the submarine-infested Atlantic without sighting even a porpoise. A hell of a thing to have to confess to your grandchildren."
War is damaging to the sense of humor of those who are caught up in it, but Mr. Bigart, describing the American Army's pursuit of the Germans in Sicily and noting that civilian conduct had been "exemplary," wrote this on July 25, 1943, as a last paragraph:
"In fact, the Sicilians are too friendly. Their attitude strengthens the impression that this island is a forgotten portion of Southern California, instead of a segment of enemy Italy."<nm But there were times when he had to describe death, as he did on Dec. 18, 1943, from San Pietro, Italy:
"Generally, there is no mistaking the dead -- their strange contorted posture leaves no room for doubt. But this soldier, his steel helmet tilted over his face, seemed merely resting in the field. We did not know until we came within a few steps and saw a gray hand hanging limply from a sleeve."
After he joined The Times, Mr. Bigart covered such important assignments as the trial of Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war criminal, in Israel in 1961. The following year Mr. Bigart surveyed the war in Vietnam. He was already in his middle 50's, but he had lost none of his ability to understand a situation and report it quickly.
 
Shy, Private Man, Insouciant Wit
 David Halberstam, who succeeded Mr. Bigart for The Times, recalled that Mr. Bigart was one of the first reporters to conclude that contrary to the Pentagon's representations, America was not about to win an easy war, and that the war was in fact a tragedy and a mistake. He advised younger reporters to write that the American effort "just doesn't work."
Mr. Halberstam said Mr. Bigart's irreverence, his "unerring instincts," his willingness to challenge "the official version" and his leadership were the sustenance that younger reporters needed to chronicle an unprecedented American military tragedy.
In 1963, when The Times asked him to cover the grim winter confronting unemployed coal miners in Kentucky, it was clear that Mr. Bigart had lost none of his reportorial eye:
"Creeks are littered with garbage, choked with boulders and silt dislodged by strip-mine operations. Hillsides that should be a solid blaze of autumn color are slashed with ugly terraces, where bulldozers and steam shovels have stripped away the forest to get at the coal beneath."
The legend was not built simply on his articles. It rested as much on the man himself.
Mr. Bigart, a shy and private man with a pronounced stammer, was at once retiring and combative, devoted equally, it seemed, to minding his own business and to hoisting a few with friends. It was on these occasions that he told the stories the journalists of his era loved to tell and hear. And he did it as well in bars as in print. His insouciant one-liners about people, places and things were not soon forgotten by colleagues.
At The Herald Tribune, for example, one colleague (and rival) was Marguerite Higgins, a determined World War II and Korean War correspondent who won much fame because of the aggressive way she pursued reporting. Miss Higgins was a pioneer working in what men liked to think of as their province, and she often outmaneuvered most male rivals, who, in those prefeminist days, would have preferred her to be shy and confined to the society page, or, as they might have put it, barefoot and pregnant.
On one occasion, she did become pregnant. When Mr. Bigart learned of it, he snapped: "Oh, g-good. And wh-wh- who is the mother?" Later, when the baby was born, Mr. Bigart cheerily inquired if the mother had devoured it.
Another competitor in the old days was Clifton Daniel, a correspondent for The Times in Jerusalem in the late 1940's when Mr. Bigart covered Israel for The Herald Tribune. Years later Mr. Daniel, who eventually became managing editor of The Times, recalled how hard he had to work to avoid being scooped by Mr. Bigart.
"I worked out a system for keeping an eye on him," Mr. Daniel said. "I persuaded him to move into the Eden Hotel, where I lived after the King David was bombed by the Zionist underground. Moreover I had a car, and Homer didn't; I offered to give him a lift whenever there was a big story to be covered out of town, so I always knew where he was."
But the ploy didn't work. Britain then ran Palestine under a United Nations mandate, and Mr. Daniel said that Mr. Bigart "sneaked out of the press room of the British Office of Information and held a clandestine interview one night with one of the biggest underground leaders."
"I didn't know anything about it until the next day," Mr. Daniel said.
Later, after Mr. Bigart returned to New York, he would occasionally drink martinis at a grungy newspaper bar in the Times Square area where the customers could always see what they were breathing. Taking stock of the environment one night, Mr. Bigart politely inquired of the bartender what day of the week they changed the air.
One evening, late in life, he decided to tell Murray Illson, a reporter friend at The Times, that he was marrying again. "I showed her mine, and she showed me hers," Mr. Bigart said. Before Mr. Illson could say anything, Mr. Bigart added, "Our bankbooks."
Like other great reporters of his generation, Mr. Bigart never hesitated to show disdain for his editors and independence from them. One evening late in his career, he was assigned to write about a riot, drawing on information from reporters on the street.
As one reporter, John Kifner, called in from a phone booth, rioters began shaking it and Mr. Kifner conveyed his fright to Mr. Bigart. But Mr. Bigart, busy fending off editors he regarded as hysterical, comforted Mr. Kifner by noting, "At least you're dealing with sane people."
 
From Architecture To Journalism
 Homer William Bigart was born Oct. 25, 1907, in Hawley, Pa., in the Pocono region, the son of Homer S. Bigart, a woolens manufacturer, and Anna Schardt Bigart. He attended public schools there, then ventured to Pittsburgh to enroll in the Carnegie Institute of Technology. He thought he wanted to be an architect. The institute felt otherwise.
"They found I couldn't draw," Mr. Bigart later recalled, "and invited me to find another school."
In 1929, Mr. Bigart complied. He enrolled in the New York University School of Journalism and got a job as a night copy boy on The Herald Tribune. N.Y.U. liked him well enough, but Mr. Bigart remained unconvinced that his journalism professors knew much about journalism. He dropped out, and in 1929, as the Great Depression was starting, joined The Trib full time.
Since he was neither a college graduate nor adept at office politics, he remained a copy boy for four years. But then The Trib decided to give him a chance and made him a general-assignment reporter at $25 a week.
At first, it seemed he would not make it. He was a painfully slow writer. Editors were amazed at his bizarre typing style, in which he double-spaced between words. He made the errors that young reporters are prone to make. Once, assigned to cover the start of coach railroad service between New York and Florida, he went to the wrong track and wrote about the wrong railroad.
It was in this period that Mr. Bigart found he could use his halting speech to become a more effective reporter. The stammer made it easier for him to pose as a bumbler who was not very smart. He would often say to those he interviewed something like, "G-g-gee, I d-d-didn't really understand that. C-c-could you repeat it?"
Most of those he interviewed went to extra lengths to make sure he got the story straight, and the result was that Mr. Bigart's articles seemed to be clearer than anyone else's; the quotations were invariably rich.
During the 1930's the paper found ample reason to have more and more confidence in Mr. Bigart's skills, and in 1942 he was asked if he would become a war correspondent. He agreed and went on to cover the London blitz, the bombing of Nazi Germany, the battles of North Africa, Italy and southern France.
When the war was over in Europe, he moved to the Pacific and covered the final months of the war against Japan. He always seemed determined to cover war at the cannon's mouth and was one of the first reporters to enter Hiroshima after the Americans dropped the atomic bomb.
Newsweek called him "the hardest kind of worker and the fairest kind of competitor." Philip Potter of The Baltimore Sun said Mr. Bigart "worked over his copy more than any of the rest of us correspondents, who were anxious after a hard day in the field to get our copy written and filed so we could get a drink."
"Homer would still be at his portable, crossing off one word because he had thought of a better one," Mr. Potter said. "He observed things that we had missed."
The plaudits kept coming when he covered the war in Korea. In that war, Newsweek called him "the best war correspondent of an embattled generation."
The people who ran some of the countries Mr. Bigart visited as a reporter did not entirely agree with that appraisal. Because of the independence of his reporting, he was ordered out of Hungary, Egypt, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Oman and Vietnam.
The Vietnamese order was rescinded; the censor admitted he had made a translation error that led him to believe that Mr. Bigart had written something obscene.
When Mr. Bigart left The Trib to join The Times, there was no particular joy in it for him. The Trib was a decade away from its demise, and its economic problems were not lost on Mr. Bigart. But it was a paper with a proud tradition of giving writers their head, and Mr. Bigart loved it.
"It seemed to me that he always looked down on The Times, even when he worked there," Mr. Daniel said. "Its main fault, in his eyes, was that it wasn't The Trib. It was too proud and stiff-necked for his taste. But he knew that if he couldn't work for The Trib, the next best thing was The Times. He was not disloyal to it; he just wasn't in love with it."
Mr. Bigart's first two wives were Alice Veit, who died in 1959 after they were divorced, and Alice Weel, who died in 1969. The next year he married Else Holmelund Minarik, the author of children's books, who survives him. He is also survived by a sister, Margaret Crowe of Lancaster, Pa., and a stepdaughter, Brooke Minarik of Dover, N.H.
No funeral is planned, the family said.
