HEADLINE: Caps Suggested for U.S. Health Spending

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGON, April 17

 BODY:
The Comptroller General of the United States, Charles A. Bowsher, said today that the nation should seriously consider setting limits on total public and private spending for major categories of health care, like doctors' services, hospital care and new technology.
In so doing, Mr. Bowsher said, the United States might follow the example of other industrial countries that seem to have had more success in limiting the growth of health spending. The United States spends more than $600 billion a year on health care. 
 Mr. Bowsher is head of the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress that has, in recent years, moved beyond the auditing of Government accounts to the analysis of diverse Federal programs. His testimony today was significant because the accounting office is normally cautious in its recommendations, making proposals only after extensive research.
Mr. Bowsher did not say exactly how the Government could limit private spending on health care by employers and individuals. Nor did he say how such limits could be reconciled with the principles of a free-market economy.
 
'Must Move to Reforms'
 But Mr. Bowsher told the House Ways and Means Committee: "We must move from incremental cost-cutting initiatives to reforms that encompass the entire U.S. health care system. Further piecemeal reforms, whether undertaken by business or government, are unlikely to reduce the growth of national health spending substantially."
Instead, Mr. Bowsher said, "reform must be comprehensive." Specifically, he said, health insurance should be available to everyone, and "we should cap total expenditures for major categories of providers and services, including physicians, hospitals and new technology."
Mr. Bowsher said that the limits for health spending could be adjusted each year, so that if a particular category exceeded its goal in one year, it would receive less in a subsequent year.
 
He Recommends Many Payers
 He emphasized that he was not recommending a national health insurance scheme with the Federal Government as the only payer. He said health care should be financed by many payers, including private insurers, the Federal Government and the states. But, he said, they should all "play by essentially the same rules," offering similar packages of health care benefits and paying similar amounts to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers for the same services.
The Comptroller General also said he was not suggesting that the United States copy the health care system of any specific foreign country. But he said the United States could learn from other countries, saying:
"For example in Canada, the provincial governments negotiate a fixed budget for each hospital. The hospital has to determine how best to provide care while living within this budget.
"As another example, Germany has controlled expenditures on physicians by establishing a schedule of fees for each type of physician service, and by setting a target for overall spending on physician care. If physicians increase the number of services they provide, and expenditures threaten to exceed the target, the fees are reduced so that actual spending stays within the target."
Republican members of the committee, including Representatives Bill Archer of Texas and Don Sundquist of Tennessee, voiced skepticism. Mr. Archer said it would do no good to limit spending on doctors and hospitals if their costs, for medical malpractice insurance, for instance, rose relentlessly.
"We should not be lulled into simplistic alternatives for cost containment such as price controls," Mr. Archer said. "We know from experience that such approaches are inherently flawed and always make conditions worse."
Mr. Bowsher's proposals appear to be inconsistent with the main themes of the health policies advocated by Presidents Bush and Ronald Reagan. For the last decade, the Department of Health and Human Services has called for more competition in prices and services among hospitals, doctors and health insurers.
Far from seeking uniform benefits or payment rates, the Bush and Reagan Administrations have tried to increase the number and diversity of options avilable to consumers.
Some Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee, including Representative Marty Russo of Illinois, enthusiastically endorsed Mr. Bowsher's conclusions. Mr. Russo noted that more than 30 million Americans still lacked health insurance.
Mr. Bowsher, like many of the Democrats, said that a more comprehensive health care system, with uniform procedures for filing and paying claims, could dramatically cut administrative costs.
"With multiple payers basically offering the same services, you can cut down a lot of the administrative costs," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
At Last, Dow Closes Above 3,000

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,000 for the first time yesterday, marking another milestone in a bull market that has seen stocks around the world rise sharply since last fall, when concerns peaked over the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and higher oil prices.
Propelled by lower interest rates and by expectations that the recession will end soon, the Dow gained 17.58 points, on strong volume of 246.9 million shares, and closed at 3,004.46. It has risen 27 percent since Oct. 11. 
 With the notable exception of Germany, central banks in most major countries have been lowering interest rates. In Britain and the United States, they have sought to end recessions; in other countries, they are trying to avoid downturns.
"Lower interest rates boost stock prices." said Edward Kerschner, the chief investment strategist at Paine Webber Inc. He called that strategy "the big ease," and added, "It is fundamentally bullish." Mr. Kerschner said he thought the Dow would rise to at least 3,150 by the end of this year.
A sharp rise in stock prices usually provides an indication that economic growth will increase, and the Dow's rise since October has been viewed by many as an indication that the recession will end soon -- even though the evidence that economic activity has bottomed is fragmentary, at best.
Whatever its status as a leading economic indicator, the Dow this year has been something of a lagging stock market indicator. The broader stock market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, has been reaching highs since February, and the Nasdaq composite average of thousands of over-the-counter stocks has gained 57 percent since the October low. Both hit new highs again yesterday.
"It's a little belated," said Robert Farrell, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The Dow is finally catching up."
At the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the closing bell at 4 P.M. was greeted with cheering and some throwing of paper, but the reaction was much more restrained than at some previous celebrations of new highs, exchange officials said.
Even without the Dow topping 3,000, individual investors have been flocking back into the market through direct purchases of stocks and investments in stock mutual funds. "We're looking at double to triple the level of new sales we saw last fall," said Michael Hines, a vice president of Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund group.
Institutional investors have also been eager buyers, investing cash they had held back from the market in late 1990, amid worries over war and recession. Most money managers are judged on how well they do compared with the stock market, and those who were not fully invested have scrambled to catch up.
The Dow's assault on 3,000 succeeded on its third try. The first came in July, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, when the average twice closed daily sessions at 2,999.75, the highest level possible without topping the barrier. Then, last month, the Dow briefly topped 3,000 during trading, but again fell back.
The difficulty the Dow experienced in exceeding 3,000 inevitably brought back memories of the average's long and difficult effort to climb over 1,000. It took nearly 17 years, from early 1966 when the Dow first touched 1,000 to late 1982 when it finally crossed that barrier for what now appears to be the final time. On the other hand, in 1987 the Dow moved through 2,000 with barely a moment's notice, and within eight months it had topped 2,700, only to crash to below 2,000 in October.
Although the Dow ended yesterday less than 5 points above where it was on July 16, some components of the average have shown vastly different patterns, reflecting the tumultous events in the world since then. Over that period, Iraq invaded Kuwait and was defeated by an international force. An American recession began, but hopes for a quick recovery have grown since the end of the war.
Still, several large companies heavily dependent on the economy are trading 20 percent or more below their level on July 16, including General Motors, Goodyear and Westinghouse. Less economically sensitive stocks, among them Coca-Cola, Merck and Philip Morris, have posted large gains.
A big stimulus to higher prices, and to investor confidence, has been the Federal Reserve's aggressive easing of credit to spur economic growth. On July 16, when the Dow first closed at 2,999.75, the rate on three-month Treasury bills was 7.62 percent. The rate now is 5.56 percent.
Those lower rates have helped reassure investors that the recession will end and have made investments in bonds less attractive, leading investors to turn to stocks.
But long-term interest rates have not declined as much and have risen recently amid speculation that the Fed might not continue to ease. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, at 8.45 percent in July, is now 8.10 percent.
Investors have nervously watched interest rates. "What would make us nervous is a significant rise in interest rates," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "We do not think that is going to happen."
At current profit levels, there is little doubt that stock prices are unreasonably high. The expectation of improvement has sustained the market, but there may be limits as to how far that can go.
"Right now, the market does not care about earnings," said Byron R. Wien, the chief United States strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company. "It just cares that the recovery is out there. But at a point later this year, if the earnings are not there, the market will be disappointed."
"At numbers much higher than 3,000, the market begins to discount a strong recovery in the second half, and I don't think we will have one," Mr. Wien added. He said he thought the Dow would fall below 3,000 later this year.
For Wall Street, this year's bull market has come as a great relief. While 1990 was the worst year for brokerage industry profits in decades, the first quarter of this year saw generally good earnings, reflecting both rising prices and the commissions that come from rising trading volume.
"This comes after three very difficult years on the equity side," said Richard Grasso, the president of the New York Stock Exchange. "It is greatly welcomed, and hopefully it is a sign of things to come."

HEADLINE: Panel Says Dialysis Cutbacks May Be Increasing Death Toll

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Spending cuts in the Federal Government's life-saving kidney dialysis program may be resulting in unnecessary sickness and death, a panel of experts said today.
But Dr. Gail Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs the dialysis program, disputed the suggestion. 
 The kidney program is the only one in which the Government tries to provide treatment for everyone who has a disease, regardless of income. It was begun with 10,000 eligible patients in 1973, when dialysis treatments were so costly that only the rich could afford them and hospitals were forced to limit access to scarce dialysis machines.
Today the Government pays for treatments for 150,000 people at an annual cost of nearly $4 billion. The treatment filters the blood of the toxic waste products that are normally eliminated by the kidneys and excreted in the urine. But it has been a huge financial burden to the Government because it has cost more than 10 times what was expected.
 
Program in Trouble
 The panel of the Institute of Medicine, which is affiliated with the National Academy of Sciences, said that while the program had succeeded in saving hundreds of thousands of lives, it was now in trouble.
The number of people eligible for the program is expected to rise to 240,000 by the end of the decade. At the same time, because of cuts and because there have been no increases for inflation, the rate of money paid out for claims has dropped by 60 percent.
Because of the drops in financing, services and staff have been cut back, and patients who used to be given 12 to 18 hours of treatment a week now get 9 to 15 hours. The committee said that it was uncertain, but there was indirect evidence that this drop in hours of treatment resulting from financial cutbacks might have "caused an increase in morbidity and mortality" among those treated, said the chairman of the institute's panel, Dr. Norman G. Levinsky, chairman of the department of medicine at Boston University.
 
Need for More Study
 Dr. Wilensky said that one study made that suggestion, but that her agency was carrying out a more complete study to better evaluate the link between reduced financing, less time on the dialysis machine and greater sickness.
She said that "it is certainly a legitimate question" but that to suggest that more people are getting sick now because of reduced financing of the centers "would be an incorrect conclusion." Doctors make the decision about how long a patient should stay on the machine, and "we would like to believe that physicians prescribe the amount of time needed according to good medical practice, not to profit."
Staffs at the dialysis centers have also decreased sharply, but Dr. Wilensky said she believed the treatment was appropriate. "As best we can tell, these facilities continue to make a profit," she said. "We could justify a continued reduction in rates."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices on Corporate Bonds Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of investment-grade corporate and high-yield "junk bonds" rose sharply yesterday, as investors seeking higher yields than those offered on ultra-safe Treasury securities were active buyers.
The activity in those markets stood in contrast to price movements in the secondary Treasury securities market, where prices were little changed in fairly slow trading. 
 In addition to their attractive yields, analysts and traders said the fact that the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record high of 3,004.46 yesterday also helped to push up corporate bond prices.
Moreover, the decline in interest rates and the rise in stock prices over the past few months has increased the possibility that many highly leveraged companies can either refinance or turn high-cost debt into equity. Those conditions, in turn, have lessened investor fears about the quality of the securities they are buying.
"We think that investment-grade corporates represent better value at this stage" than Treasury securities, said William Melton, a vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis.
Prices of most high-yield junk bonds, which posted record increases during the first quarter, rose about 3/4 of a point yesterday, traders said, although some issues were up even more sharply.
"One of last year's concerns, that companies were dependent almost exclusively on cash flow, has changed," said Kingman Penniman, a senior vice president Duff & Phelps/MCM. "Now companies have time to come up with alternative strategies to retire high-cost debt. That has prompted a whole change in attitude among investors."
"I am stupefied by what is going on," said Mariel Clemenson, director of high-yield research at Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.
 
High-Yield Securities Prices
 Ms. Clemenson added that the sharp increase in prices of high-yield securities might be overdone.
"I think the market is highly speculative and way too frothy," she said, "because the fundamental outlook for many companies could not be weaker." At current levels "prices do not reflect fundamentals."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the fading prospects of a near-term cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board led traders to sell short-term instruments and buy bonds. But the movement in prices was very slight.
"There are buyers of the long end and sellers of the short end," one government securities trader said. "That's the way it's been since the inflation numbers came out late last week and the Fed told us on Monday that they aren't about to ease."
On Monday, the Fed pointedly drained reserves from the banking system, a move that credit market analysts and traders took as a clear sign that it had no current intention of lowering short-term interest rates.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 14/32, up 3/32, to yield 8.10 percent, down from 8.11 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 98 23/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.93 percent.
Late yesterday the Treasury announced it will sell $12 billion worth of new two-year notes and $9 billion worth of new five-year notes at auctions on April 24 and April 25, respectively.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.91 percent. The five-year securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.65 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.56 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.61 percent.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues rose by anywhere from 1/2 of a point to 3/4 of a point. Outstanding bonds issued by commercial banks like Security Pacific and First Interstate did even better, market participants said.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Orange County, Fla., offered $100 million worth of sanitation bonds in a negotiated sale through Merrill Lynch & Co. The securities are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company.
The issue consists of serial bonds and term bonds maturing in 2013 and 2016.
The 6 3/4 percent term bonds maturing in 2013 were priced to yield 6.85 percent. The 6 percent term bonds that mature in 2016 were priced to yield 6.75 percent.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 of a point.

HEADLINE: Governors Seek $10 Billion in Increased Taxes

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Governors in a majority of the 50 states have imposed $10.3 billion in new taxes during the current fiscal year to cope with the worst financial conditions many have seen since the 1983 recession, according to a report made public today.
The cash shortage has also forced governors and legislatures in 29 states to slash spending by laying off or furloughing workers, putting a freeze on hiring and capping travel expenses, the National Governors' Association said in its annual survey of state budget conditions for the fiscal year ending June 30. 
 State budget officers said their problems have been fueled by the soaring cost of health care and exacerbated by the recession.
 
Big Rise in Medicaid Spending
 Raymond Sheppach, executive director of the association, said state spending for Medicaid, which is administered jointly with the Federal Government, is expected to rise by 116 percent from 1990 to 1995.
Medicaid requirements imposed by the Federal Government, Mr. Sheppach said, are "devouring virtually every new dollar of revenue and leaving little money for new programs" at the state level. The survey said Medicaid costs have increased 25 percent this year after an 18 percent increase last year, and Mr. Sheppach said 37 states spent more on Medicaid this year than they had initially budgeted.
The cash shortage, which has been widening in state capitals for more than a year, has forced many governors to make unpalatable choices, including higher taxes, to achieve the balanced budgets required by most state constitutions.
The $10 billion in new taxes marks the biggest such increase that state budget officers have recorded since 1978. And although state spending continues to grow, it is increasing far more slowly than in the 1980's, when many states racked up budget surpluses.
Spending reductions totaling $8 billion this year will shave about 3 percent of planned spending from state budgets, the governors' report said. "Economic growth will be slower because of slower labor force participation growth, stiff international competition and a continuing national deficit," said Mr. Sheppach.
 
Concerns About the Future
 Even if the recession ends by late summer as some economists have predicted, Mr. Sheppach said, state government finances may not bounce back quickly.
"When the recession ends," he said, "the states continue to face hard times, because economic growth is declining while human needs continue to increase."
A number of states have raised taxes on gasoline or cigarettes or have increased user fees as a way of balancing their budgets, the report said.
In general, it said, the Plains and Rocky Mountain states have fared best in the current recession and West Coast states excluding California have emerged stronger than average. States in the Northeast were found to be continuing to face the most severe problems.

HEADLINE: Net Falls 48% At Polaroid

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation reported a 48 percent drop in first-quarter earnings today, saying the weak economy hurt consumer spending on the company's instant film.
For the three-month period that ended March 31, Polaroid reported net income of $16.4 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $31.8 million, or 43 cents a share, during the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales totaled $441.2 million, just a 1 percent rise from $436.2 million in the first quarter of 1990. 
 The company said worldwide shipments of instant film in the quarter were down 7.3 percent, to $203.9 million.
The company said profits were also squeezed by increases in marketing costs that were needed to help build future business.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Confusion Is Found to Delay Aid for Kurds Fleeing to Iran

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, April 17

 BODY:
Western officials in Iran said today that efforts to help Kurds fleeing here from Iraq have been seriously hurt by international confusion and by some Iranian delays, endangering the lives of scores of thousands of refugees now in Iran or awaiting entry to the country.
The officials put most of the blame on the United Nations, which they said had grossly underestimated the size and speed of the exodus from Iraq and then lagged in organizing the international response to the crisis. 
 By contrast, one official said, the Iranian Government has drawn "immense admiration" for shouldering the majority of the relief effort alone despite the country's own shortages of food, medicine and money.
Kurds who have fled to regions close to the Turkish border are likely to benefit from the American aid plan announced by President Bush in Washington on Tuesday, under which the American military plans to set up secure camps for the refugees in northern Iraq. But that effort will not reach Kurds inside Iran.
 
Praise for Iranians
 Figures prepared by international relief agencies and provided by Western officials show that as of Sunday, Iran had committed $57 million to the relief effort, far more than any Western or Asian nation and a considerable sum for a government that is itself in economic straits.
"Even the most cynical of the diplomatic observers believe they have been remarkably charitable," a Western official monitoring the relief effort said in an interview today. Like others, he spoke on condition of anonymity.
But he and others said they are increasingly worried that an estimated 500,000 Kurds still trying to flee Iraq will be decimated by disease and exposure if Iran does not speed their entry into the country. The fleeing Kurds, in lines stretching as far as 50 miles into Iraq, are being required by Iran's military to undergo searches and sometimes to get entry cards for themselves and their vehicles before being allowed to cross the border.
The officials said that foreign governments have recently asked Iran to ease restrictions at the Iran-Iraq border crossings, but that Iran has yet to provide a definite answer.
 
'One-Sided' Relief Effort
 "Their general principle was that they don't want to take in more refugees than they can handle at one time," a Western official said. "We've pressed them on it. At the same time I've felt uncomfortable doing so when the relief effort has been so one-sided to date."
Western officials said they were impressed in visits to the area with Iran's willingness to feed and house the refugees even at the expense of its own population. For example, one official said, leaders in the far northwest province of West Azerbaijan have committed the region's next three months' supply of baby formula to the more than 250,000 refugees staying there.
Elsewhere, both Iran and foreign relief agencies are buying up the stocks of local produce markets, creating local food shortages where none existed before, the officials said.
The International Committee of the Red Cross was reported to have committed about $140 million for refugees in both Iran and Turkey and agencies of the United Nations planned to spend slightly more than $420 million.
Some officials sharply criticized the United Nations, which they said had failed to orchestrate any visible response to the Kurdish refugee crisis until last weekend, when planeloads of supplies began to arrive in two provincial capitals that are refugee centers.
One official said today that United Nations refugee experts predicted that no more than 100,000 refugees would flee Iraq's civil war, and then concentrated their efforts on refugees in Turkey when the exodus began.
 
Supplies Still Scarce
 United Nations officials have said critical goods are still in short supply. Figures circulated by the United Nations here show that the Iranian effort needs 774,000 tents and has acquired only 30,000, and that it needs 1.6 million blankets but has only 440,000.
A Red Cross official said tonight on Iranian television that the agency's resources could handle the needs of only 200,000 of the 1.5 million Kurds who are either in or seeking to enter Iran.
"We need more help," she said.
Most deaths are believed to be occurring among refugees still waiting to enter Iran, officials said. They said Iranian officials have estimated that at least 1,000 refugees are dying daily of malnutrition, exposure and disease. Because no one has been inside Iraq to survey the suffering there, no figures are completely reliable.
Iranian officials also have told Western governments that 350 to 400 deaths among refugees have occurred within Iran. That figure appears low, but independent verification is impossible.
Doctors at refugee camps have told reporters that they are losing as many as a dozen babies daily to infant diarrhea and other diseases, and there are dozens such camps scattered across northwestern Iran.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A woman carrying her child after bathing him yesterday outside their new tent at refugee camp in Silopi, Turkey. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: A RISKY UNDERTAKING;
Kurd Relief Plan Takes Bush to the Edge Of the Tangle He Has Tried Hard to Avoid

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
President Bush presented his plan to aid the Kurdish refugees as a straightforward and limited humanitarian operation, but it has raised the possibility of snaring Mr. Bush in just the kind of political and military tangle that he has been trying to avoid.
 Less than a day after the President said he would set up refugee camps in northern Iraq, the United Nations was questioning the legal basis for the effort, which seemed to be predicated on little more than the rights of a conqueror. 
 The White House found itself sidestepping questions about the political future of Iraqi Kurdistan to avoid conflicts with its allies in Turkey, which contains the largest population of Kurds and which has long feared and opposed steps that could encourage any Kurdish separatism.
But, signaling its own awareness that the refugee problem could become political and military dynamite if not properly handled, the White House warned Kurdish opposition groups not to use the proposed refugee camps as a staging area and safe haven for guerrilla bands.
The Bush Administration took pains to reassure the American people that the refugee project was a short-term commitment and that the United States would not be drawn ever deeper into Iraq's tortuous politics.
 
An Unresolved Question
 "We hope and intend to turn them over to the U.N. to administer as soon as possible," Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said of the camps. "This effort in no way is expected to delay the withdrawal of U.S. forces from the region."
But Administration officials acknowledged that they would have difficulty getting the United Nations Security Council to approve an allied plan for coaxing the refugees to return home and that they had not resolved the far more difficult question of how to protect them from reprisals by President Saddam Hussein if they do go back.
Indeed, there was confusion today about the procedural aspects of Mr. Bush's relief plan. The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, asserted that Iraq must agree to the plan before it could proceed and that it would require a new Security Council vote as well. The White House disputed both points and suggested that it would press Mr. Perez de Cuellar to change his position.
In addition to feeding and clothing Kurdish refugees, the United States and its partners in the operation are likely to find themselves caring for their sick and perhaps even arbitrating their political disputes.
Prominent foreign policy analysts suggested that the President could be moving toward an indefinite commitment to protect the Kurds and direct involvement in determining the shape of Iraq's future political structure.
"We should not delude ourselves that this is something we can do for a month and then walk away," said Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State.
 
The Role of Hussein
 In outlining its plans for the refugees, the White House has stressed the humanitarian aspects of providing food and clothing and Mr. Bush said he was reasonably confident that Iraq would not attack the planned refugee camps.
But Mr. Bush and his aides acknowledge that the United States, Britain, France and Turkey will have to protect the Kurds from Mr. Hussein's harsh repression as well, and that poses the most risks and long-term problems.
"We can protect these people for a while," said Mr. Kissinger, "but the basic problem will be either to get a government into Baghdad that one can trust enough to treat these Kurds differently than they've been treated for decades or get some kind of international regimen that limits the capacity of the Iraqi Government for repression in the Kurdish area. Either would be a major intervention in what has heretofore been considered the domestic affairs of another country."
Mr. Kissinger said the trouble with trying to provide an international security apparatus for the Kurds in northern Iraq was that such an effort would presume some sort of autonomy for the region. That could put Washington in conflict not only with Turkey, whose Kurdish citizens are already agitating for autonomy, but also with Syria and Iran, which also have Kurdish populations.
Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, said he did not think Mr. Bush had any alternative to aiding the refugees.
But he said: "It looks like you're going to end up with a lot of big camps, such as we've seen on the West Bank. Where are you going to have these people go so they don't sit in camps indefinitely? They should go back to their hometowns and cities. But unless you have some kind of assurance that they are going to be protected, it's going to be hard to ask them to go back. And that gets us involved in politics."
An Administration official said Mr. Bush hoped to safeguard the Kurds from Mr. Hussein's forces by continuing his efforts to dismantle Iraq's poison gases and biological weapons and by keeping economic sanctions in place as long as Mr. Hussein is in power.
But there are already signs that the pressure to do more will continue to mount on Mr. Bush, who has already been criticized for urging the Iraqis to overthrow Mr. Hussein and then remaining on the sidelines of the ensuing civil war.
"Once you commit yourself to protecting those people, you are committed until you are sure they are 100 percent safe, and they won't be as long as Saddam Hussein and his regime are in power," said Najmaldin O. Karim, a spokesman for the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, one of the two largest Iraqi Kurdish groups.
He added, "We hope that this commitment to protect these people is serious and is open-ended."
 
A Plea by Bush
 For the Administration, the simplest solution continues to be the removal of Mr. Hussein. But American officials are no closer now to finding a way to achieve that objective than they were when Mr. Bush halted the fighting on Feb. 27.
Mr. Bush seemed acutely aware of this problem on Tuesday, when he said at a news conference that he might be open to Mr. Hussein taking refuge in another country with guarantees that he never return to Iraq.
"That was a plea: 'Take this problem away,' " one official said.
For weeks, the President has been proclaiming that the successful end to the war to drive Iraq from Kuwait signaled an end to the "Vietnam syndrome."
But it is clear now that he has been defining that generational problem in relatively narrow terms of America's ability to express its national will and is suddenly confronting the broader aspects of the Vietnam legacy: the risks of being drawn into a political quagmire.
"When I first became Secretary of State, I asked the policy planning staff to give me a memorandum on how a great power avoids becoming a satellite of a small country that is completely dependent on you," said Dean Rusk, who was Secretary under John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. "They didn't come up with a very good answer for a problem that we had in our time and which I'm afraid Bush has now."

HEADLINE: A Meeting Place for Africans and U.S. Blacks

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 17

 BODY:
Many black Americans, says the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, have long been ashamed of Africa and their African heritage, an attitude he is determined to confront at a conference of black Americans and Africans he has invited here for four days this week.
"Psychologically, we've been brainwashed to believe that Africa was the dark continent, a place of crocodiles, trees and Tarzan," said the 68-year-old civil rights leader, a retired Baptist minister from Philadelphia, as he sat in his suite at the Hotel Ivoire Inter-Continental here today and described how he came to organize the "first African, African-American summit." 
 By all accounts the conference, which includes religious and civil rights advocates, academics, entertainers, members of Congress and businessmen, as well as government leaders and prominent figures from a number of African countries. is the largest of its kind ever held.
Mr. Sullivan, who is also a director of the General Motors Corporation, said he hopes the conference will both encourage black Americans to discover their rich African heritage and stimulate support for African economic development at a time when interest in the continent appears to be waning.
"Africa is the forgotten continent," Mr. Sullivan said. "You have the focus being on Eastern Europe, and more recently the Persian Gulf," and because of this, he said, the continent is increasingly seen as a "place not that important to the economic future of the world."
 
Building Connections to Africa
 One means of addressing this problem, Mr. Sullivan said, is to strengthen the involvement of black Americans in the affairs of Africa. He hopes to build the kind of of attachments "that the Irish have with Ireland, the Jew with Israel and the Poles with Poland" -- ties that have often translated into economic and political muscle.
Mr. Sullivan is perhaps best known for devising a code of conduct for American corporations doing business in South Africa in 1977. More recently, he has been at the forefront of those who have encouraged corporations and other businesses to divest themselves of South African financial links.
Asked about the decision this week by the European Community to lift most trade sanctions against the Pretoria Government, Mr. Sullivan said this would be one of the major topics of discussion here in conference sessions involving African heads of government.
"I still hold my 1987 position," Mr. Sullivan said. "I said then until Mandela's free, until statutory apartheid is ended as a system, and until there is a clear commitment of equal voting rights, sanctions should stay on."
Another issue on the agenda, he said, is debt relief. He cited a recent American decision to cancel as much as 70 percent of Poland's debt as something that African governments should also be pushing for.
"Africa is paralyzed with the burden of massive debt, over $100 billion," he said, "and there's no way that these countries can reach their potential as long as they're facing that."
Mr. Sullivan sees the conference as something of a launching pad to stimulate greater exchanges between American blacks and Africans. "The summit is only the setting of the stage for the future," he said. For example, he hopes to create hundreds of African Support Committees, which will will help generate ideas and create something akin to the Peace Corps.
"I envision the best and the brightest professionals," he said, "giving a year, like the old Mormons, to work with Africa."
Among those expected to attend the conference are Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference; the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and a delegation of black members of Congress led by Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania and House majority whip, who will give the keynonte address.
African leaders attending include President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, President Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria, President Abdou Diouf of Senegal and President Yoweri K. Museveni of Uganda.

HEADLINE: Dinkins and Fiscal Pain;
Distaste for Confrontation Has Cost Mayor Room to Maneuver in City's Budget Crisis

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
By adopting an approach to New York City's fiscal problems that strived to inflict the least pain possible, Mayor David N. Dinkins has lost room to maneuver, his own aides concede, and all but assured great pain in the face of the crisis he now confronts.
 Since the current city budget was adopted in July, the Dinkins administration has lifted a freeze on hiring city workers, then reimposed it. It has won special taxes to hire thousands of police officers whose hiring some city officials now wish they could delay. It has granted raises, then threatened layoffs and then avoided most of the layoffs through wage deferrals that will ultimately cost more. 
 Each of those decisions met the problems of the moment, and Mr. Dinkins had understandable political and practical reasons for making them as he struggled to balance the concerns of his contending constituencies and make his mark on a government he had just inherited.
"I'm sure that there are things that we might have done differently," Mr. Dinkins said this week. "I'm not prepared to enumerate. I don't mean that I know and don't want to tell you. But I mean I'm a bit busy trying to handle things day to day."
But in hindsight the policy twists and turns loom large, and they raise questions of whether Mr. Dinkins should have done more sooner, or at least done all he has said he would do when he said he would do it. Just a month ago, he vowed unequivocally that the city would seek major money-saving concessions from its union work force. But in a pattern that has persisted, his oratory has produced no discernible progress and both sides remain mired in defining the problem.
In an effort to break the stalemate in the city's budget crisis -- a $465 million gap in the city's current budget, half of which the city does not know how it will fill -- Mr. Dinkins has scheduled a meeting with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today in which he plans to ask for immediate help in getting several hundred million dollars of one-time revenues through state authorities and corporations.
No one in or out of government fully predicted the steep unexpected declines in tax revenues that have left the city staring at a current budget gap that it has just weeks to close to avoid the grip of the State Financial Control Board.
The board could reimpose binding powers on city spending if the city ended the fiscal year on June 30 with a deficit of $100 million or more.
Indeed, the control board said early last month that there was little doubt the city could balance its budget for the current year and that a bigger problem was how to close a $3 billion gap for the next fiscal year and assure balanced budgets for years to come.
But fiscal monitors and even some mayoral aides say the city has lagged perpetually behind the bad news at least in part because the Mayor has chosen to address it one step at a time, never anticipating that the worst could come to pass nor consistently following through on his own proposed solutions.
 
'Lots of Talk'
 "There's lots of talk, but where's the action?" said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, which was set up to monitor the city's finances in the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. "There's a lot of talk, but everything seems to kind of disappear. Now they have a two-week window at the maximum."
Or as one senior mayoral aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, put it: "Is this a crisis or not? If it's a crisis, then act like it's a crisis."
Mr. Dinkins now seems to have worn down the good will of allies and critics alike at the very moment he needs them most.
Labor negotiations are stalled, the Mayor's own commissioners have resisted his budget-cutting requests and the Governor and the Legislature -- not bound by the strict laws and scrutiny that apply to the city -- are already two weeks late in closing a $6 billion deficit in the state budget.
Not all the problems are of Mr. Dinkins's making. Union leaders' resistance to concessions owes as much to Mr. Cuomo's insistence that they make givebacks before he will even consider helping the city with one-time financing maneuvers, and the economy is no one's to control. The state's own problems have forced Mr. Cuomo to propose cutting $600 million in aid to the city.
But a complex combination of factors has nonetheless produced a yearlong deadlock at City Hall. They range from Mr. Dinkins's innate distrust of the city's budget office (a legacy of his days as Manhattan borough president, when he thought it was hiding money) to his struggle to balance the needs of his constituencies (especially the municipal unions that played a major role in his election) to tension and turmoil among his own top staff members.
"You have a philosophy and a set of policy options that are contradictory," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and an architect of the plan that bailed the city out of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. "The heart is always trying to minimize the pain and avoid layoffs, and the head is always trying to maintain the credit rating and fiscal stability and the city's tax base.
"And because both of these strains run very deep in City Hall, they result in paralysis. They keep canceling each other out."
One of the Mayor's senior business advisers, speaking on the condition of anonymity, put the problem another way: "There is a very basic type of management. People agree to do something. Then they get back together and say, 'Where do we stand?' That's follow-up. You have to have both a will to follow up and a procedure, and I think both are lacking here in terms of the Mayor's distaste for confrontation."
 
A Freeze That Melted
 Internal debates within the administration have gone on since before the current budget was adopted last July. At that time, the new administration lifted a partial hiring freeze imposed months earlier, though some mayoral aides objected.
That decision meant the city work force increased by about 1,000 workers a month, or 4,000 workers, until the freeze was reimposed in October. By last month, the work force had only shrunk back to where it was when the freeze was lifted, or about 243,000.
Pressured by complaints about his handling of a spate of sensational crimes, Mr. Dinkins proposed in October, again against some top aides' advice, to hire thousands of new police officers by using special new taxes designated for that purpose, thus reducing the potential tax pool for the city's general needs. After bruising fights with the City Council and the Legislature, the taxes were passed, but with the provision that the city would lose the right to the money to the degree that it did not meet hiring goals.
Some of the Mayor's advisers are urging that the city reconsider whether it can still afford to hire the officers on time. The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said no such proposal had been made to the Mayor, though it has been debated within the budget office.
"With dedicated funds, you eventually get to the point where you can define yourself out of solutions," he said.
Though what will happen next remains unclear, the ticking time clock means something must.
"You have to get ahead of the game, and that means very often you have to take action before you're satisfied that you have all the facts that you want," Mr. Rohatyn said. "The choice is not really between doing right and doing wrong. The choice is between doing something and doing nothing, and doing nothing never gets you anyplace."

HEADLINE: Chamorro Wins Bush Promise on Debt

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
In an endorsement of Nicaragua's new austerity policies, President Bush pledged today to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro that he would lead an international effort to help the country clear $360 million in overdue payments on its crushing debt.
Administration officials said that while Mr. Bush did not offer her any new aid, he did promise that the United States might augment its previous pledge of $50 million in debt relief if Managua needed it later this year. Mrs. Chamorro and her aides expressed great satisfaction with the White House meeting, saying Mr. Bush's efforts would soon open the way for the first payments on Nicaragua's $9.5 billion debt since 1984. 
 In the first state visit to the White House by a Nicaraguan President since 1939, Mrs. Chamorro was received with full military honors and warm embraces on the South Lawn by several of the Administration's most senior officials, including Vice President Dan Quayle; the national security adviser. Brent Scowcroft, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Mr. Bush heaped praise on her in a speech that referred to Nicaragua's most cherished poets and adoration of the Virgin Mary, as well as the recent civil war fought between the United States-financed contras and the Sandinistas who proceeded her in power.
 
'Exhilarating Victory'
 Referring to her inauguration almost exactly a year ago, Mr. Bush said, "In you we saw the exhilarating victory of democracy, of that glorious new breeze that in one amazing year swept out oppression and dictatorship from Prague to Managua."
Mrs. Chamorro replied that she hoped this day would represent a turning point in a relationship that went from subservience during four decades of the Somoza family dictatorship to 11 years of confrontation ending with her February 1990 electoral defeat of the Sandinista President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra. "It is our responsibility," she said, "to begin fertilizing the seed of a new friendship, a friendship based on our shared belief in democracy and mutual respect."
After the ceremony, Mr. Bush and Mrs. Chamorro met privately in the Oval Office for 15 minutes followed by an expanded meeting including Cabinet members for 45 minutes more. The leaders brushed aside a number of issues that have caused difficulties between the two Governments, including the continued control of the army and security forces by the Sandinistas, and concentrated on economic issues.
 
'Together We Will Do It'
 Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said Mr. Bush promised Mrs. Chamorro that along with the World Bank, the United States "will lead an international effort" to help Nicaragua "clear its arrears and normalize its relations with the international financial institutions." He quoted Mr. Bush as saying, "One way or another together we will do it."
The United States has pledged $541 million for Nicaragua since Mrs. Chamorro's election, but only about $207 million has been disbursed. It has conditioned its aid on banking reform and privatization of the economy.
Mrs. Chamorro announced an austerity program on March 3 that drastically devalued the currency, cut back bank lending, and decreased real wages among state workers.

HEADLINE: Price of Aid for Egypt Is a Dose of Economic Pain

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 17

 BODY:
As the echoes of the Persian Gulf war fade, Egypt's huge economic problems are returning to top the list of this country's principal concerns. The situation is likely to be tougher than many Egyptians expected because there are indications that the rich Arab countries of the gulf -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other emirates -- will not be as generous as their promises indicated.
The Arab countries have already written off some $7 billion in debt owed them by Egypt, and the United States has written off a similar amount of military debts, but the interest burden on the remaining debt is sapping Egypt's already fragile economy. 
 Last week Egypt signed a preliminary accord with the International Monetary Fund after three years of wrenching negotiations to ease its $40 billion foreign debt. The United States played a key role behind the scenes in winning that help for Egypt, in part to reward the country for its role in the gulf war. But the price for that help is that Egypt put economic reforms in place. The changes can only add to the cost of living, which is already rising at an unofficial rate that tops 25 percent a year.
The I.M.F. accord, assuming it wins board approval in May, could lead to rescheduling of Egypt's remaining debts and canceling of about 30 percent of them. But the country's leadership is cautioning the population that the required economic changes will further test the patience of consumers. They will see steep rises in the prices of electricity, gasoline, refined oil products and essential food like bread and meat, which will be eased out of the long list of subsidized goods.
 
Signaled Bad News
 President Hosni Mubarak began to signal the bad news at the end of March, when he told major newspapers in a string of interviews that billions of dollars in interest-free financial aid from the Arabs might not be forthcoming as a reward for Egypt's participation in the alliance that freed Kuwait of Iraqi occupation.
"The gulf crisis does not mean cash will start flowing to us from every direction, and there will be prosperity," the Egyptian leader said. "There is no prosperity in the whole world. If we want to live an honorable life, we must not rely on the outside to provide our food."
The situation will be particularly difficult because of the relentless population increase here. Egypt's has 55 million people now and is growing at the rate of a million every nine months.
President Mubarak's interviews dashed expectations that the oil-rich Arab countries were considering a plan to purchase Egypt's debt from creditors and ease the repayment terms.
These developments are of great importance beyond Egypt. Many political analysts say that the country cannot play a leading role in stabilizing the Middle East, while servicing its debt and struggling to develop new jobs and a bigger economy.
President Mubarak said Egypt had already benefited from the United States' decision to wipe out some $7 billion of its military debts and from a similar decision by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar to forgive $6 billion in debts. But Mr. Mubarak said the forgiven debt did not balance the $20 billion Egypt lost as a result of the gulf war.
He said that 700,000 Egyptians who worked in Iraq and Kuwait had returned jobless and without their savings, and Egypt's Petroleum Minister, Abdelhadi Kandil, said that Egypt's revenues from oil exports had dropped to $1.5 billion from $3 billion in 1982 because of increased consumption by Egypt's growing population. In addition, Egypt has lost billions of dollars from the drop in tourism and Suez Canal revenues during the gulf crisis.
 
Idle Labor Force
 On top of this, various other senior officials are making clear that Arab gulf countries will not open their doors to Eqypt's big idled labor force. Egypt has increasingly depended on the export of laborers to neighboring countries.
Nearly two million Egyptian expatriates were in Iraq and Kuwait, sending at least $3 billion home to their families in Egypt every year. This badly needed infusion of hard currency appears now to be gone, and Kuwait has a long way to go before it begins to recontruct its economy.
Two weeks ago, the acting Kuwaiti Planning Minister, Suleiman al-Mutawa, was quoted by Egyptian newspapers as saying that Kuwait is intent on lowering the number of expatriates in the country so that Kuwaitis will not again be a minority in their own country. Furthermore, he said, many of the old jobs may no longer exist.
 
Outnumbered the Kuwaitis
 Before the Iraqi invasion, there were 700,000 Kuwaitis living in Kuwait and about 1.2 million foreigners, including 450,000 Palestinians and at least 300,000 Egyptians.
Although Government-owned newspapers have avoided linking I.M.F.-induced economic strictures to higher prices, most Egyptians have learned to watch the dropping value of the Egyptian pound against the dollar. They take it as a sign that prices of all imports, including essential ingredients like wheat, will go up.
Last week, most Egyptians who have seen the value of the dollar leap from nearly two pounds to more than three pounds over the last few years, were speculating that by the end of the year the American dollar would hit a peak of four pounds to the dollar.

HEADLINE: Mexico Proclaims an End To Sanctuary for Polluters

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL MONTE, Calif., April 17

 BODY:
Amid growing concern that a proposed North American free-trade agreement might undermine United States pollution controls, top environmental officials from Mexico assured California officials today that American companies would find no sanctuary south of the border.
"That was something conceivable four or five years ago when we did not have the contacts and information we have now," said the spokesman for the Mexican delegation, Fernando Menendez Garza, the air pollution coordinator for Mayor Manuel Camacho of Mexico City. 
 Mr. Menendez said that enforcement had increased at least five-fold in the last two years and that any company seeking to relocate to Mexico would be told that it would have to comply with emission standards at least as strict as where it came from.
In the past, environmentalists have been skeptical of such promises from the Mexicans, citing lack of monitoring and shortage of enforcement personnel, as well as official corruption. Numermous companies operating in several countries make products in Mexico with ingredients and packaging materials that could not be made in the United States.
A representative of the Environmental Protection Agency, William L. Jones, told the gathering in this Los Angeles suburb that the agency and its Mexican counterpart, the Ministry of Urban Development and Environment, were developing an "integrated border environment plan." He said the plan would be aimed at assessing the environmental risks posed by the 1,886 plants along the border at which products are assembled and shipped back to the United Sttes.
Mr. Menendez was part of a 12-man Mexican delegation that came for a three-day workshop here to obtain advice from American officials and work on harmonizing pollution standards. They met with leaders of the South Coast Air Quality Management District, the California Air Resources Board and the Environmental Protection Agency, as well as the World Bank. The air quality district is the powerful state agency that two years ago imposed a stringent smog-control plan on a 6,000 square-mile area that includes Los Angeles, Ventura and Orange Counties and parts of San Bernardino and Riverside Counties.
 
Reports of Company Relocations
 There have been news reports that a number of companies, mainly furniture manufacturers, have relocated in Mexico from the Los Angeles area to escape new emission controls on solvents.
"If they have gotten away, they are only postponing the day of reckoning for a year or two," Mr. Menendez said in an interview.
The smog authorities in California said they believed the Mexicans were serious now. "These guys are tough," said Henry W. Wedaa, an Orange County Supervisor who is vice chairman of the board of the air quality district. "Anybody who moves to Mexico is in for a rude response.
Edward Camarena, deputy executive officer of the district, said: "They don't want American companies dumping pollution on their citizens. They made that very clear."
The session came amid intensifying debate over the proposed free-trade agreement, which would drastically limit tariffs between the two countries.
Among many objections raised to the accord, environmentalists and their allies in Congress fear that Mexico's environmental standards could be an attraction to American companies seeking to reduce their costs. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico traveled through the United States last week trying to address such concerns.
The Mexican delegation included representatives of the government of Mexico City, the Federal enclave of 15 million population that has about the worst air pollution in the world; the Ministry of Urban Development and Environment; Pemex, the state-owned oil monopoly; the Mexican Petroleum Institute; the state of Mexico, and the Ministry of Health.
As evidence of the Mexican Government's new commitment to environmental protection, Mr. Menendez named several recent actions: the shutting of Mexico City's giant Azcapotzalco refinery; the passage of a new Constitutional Law for the Ecological Equilibrium and Protection of the Environment; a 650 percent growth in enforcement efforts in the last two years; a plan to replace all buses, taxis and public-service vans with vehicles that meet strict California emission standards; the introduction of unleaded gasoline nationwide, and the planting of 1.8 million trees in Mexico City.
"We are here because we want to do things," he told the session. "Our president is committed to a cleaner environment in the rest of the country as well as Mexico City."
As for the free-trade pact, Mr. Menendez said the country's goal was not to attract polluting industries but to use the free-trade agreement to substitute clean industries for dirty ones.
While there have been no reliable comprehensive data, according to news reports in Southern California about 40 furniture makers have relocated pat or all of the operations to Mexico since 1988 to avoid the air-quality district's rule that requires the use of low-emission paints, varnishes and solvents.
District officials said that they did not think many companies were moving for such reasons. Mr. Jones of the E.P.A. agreed with Mexican officials that there was less of an economic reason for such a move, apart from cheaper labor.

HEADLINE: NCNB and First Interstate Report Lower Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest banking company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits fell 8.4 percent because of problems with bad loans.
NCNB's loan problems were partly offset by the benefits of lower interest rates, which enabled the company to earn large profits on its bond investments and reduce the rates it paid to depositors. 
 The First Interstate Bancorp, the nation's 11th-largest banking company, which reported a 38.6 percent decline in profits from a year earlier, also felt the effects of bad loans. The decline excludes the effect of an accounting change in 1990.
In contrast, the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, a Northeastern banking company, reported a turnaround in the quarter, posting a profit. It had a loss a year earlier.
Following are details of the banking companies' results:
 
NCNB
NCNB reported first-quarter earnings of $128.4 million, or $1.20 a share, down from $140.1 million, or $1.33 a share a year earlier.
The Charlotte, N.C., company's holdings of nonperforming loans, those that are badly delinquent or not expected to be repaid in full, plus real estate acquired from bad loans, rose $84.8 million in the first quarter, to $1.033 billion. About $83.4 million of loans were written off as a loss. At the same time, $70.7 million was set aside in the reserve for future loan losses.
NCNB, whose $17.6 billion bond portfolio is second only to J. P. Morgan & Company's, earned a profit of $66.6 million after taxes by selling some securities at a profit and reinvesting the proceeds in new securities with shorter maturities.
The bond portfolio was bought primarily with deposits that NCNB has collected in Texas since its 1988 acquisition of First Republicbank of Dallas.
Russell J. Page, a spokesman for NCNB, said the market value of the bond portfolio was about $150 million greater than the amount shown on the company's books, even after the gains taken in the first quarter. During the first quarter of this year, short-term interest rates continued to decline, raising the price of NCNB's holdings enough that the company earned a profit by selling some securities.
Falling interest rates also helped the company by enabling it to reduce the rates it paid on deposits. Deposit rates fell more quickly than the rates it charged on loans and investments.
NCNB's shares gained $1.75 after the earnings announcement yesterday, to close at $39 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
First Interstate
First Interstate said its 38.6 percent decline in profits excluded the effect of an accounting change that increased last year's profits. The Los Angeles-based company had warned analysts that growing problems with bad loans would keep 1991 earnings below 1990 levels.
The company's first-quarter profits of $59.6 million, or 81 cents a share, were down from $127.2 million, or $2.23 a share, a year earlier. The profit for the quarter last year included $30.1 million, or 57 cents a share, for an accounting change.
Edward M. Carson, First Interstate's chairman, noted that the drop in profits reflected decreased loan demand and weakness in real estate markets in California and elsewhere. Nonperforming loans and real estate owned as a result of foreclosure rose $40 million from year-end, to $1.789 billion. Of the total, about 75 percent are real estate related.
The company charged off as a loss $126.9 million in the first quarer, down from $198.1 million a year earlier. It added $135.2 million to its reserve for future loan losses, compared with $91.8 million a year earlier.
First Interstate said efforts to reduce costs were hurt by a $34.3 million increase in expenses associated with operating real estate acquired though foreclosure and a $7.2 million increase in Federal deposit insurance premiums. Over all, its non-interest expenses rose $44.6 million, or 7.2 percent.
The company's shares gained $1.50 yesterday, closing at $36.
 
Fleet/Norstar
Fleet/Norstar, based in Providence, R.I., reported earnings of $25.5 million, or 21 cents a share, in contrast to a loss a year earlier of $98.1 million.
While Fleet continues to suffer from the ill effects of the downturn in the Northeastern regional economy, there are signs that the problems are becoming less severe. The company noted that the pace of deterioration in the region was slowing as nonperforming assets increased $63 million, to $1.44 billion, the smallest increase since the third quarter of 1989.
In the first quarter, Fleet benefited from the diversity of its business. The financial services group, which operates nationally in mortgage lending, consumer finance and some lending, earned $37 million, up more than 50 percent from a year earlier, while its four New York banks earned $20 million, up from $5 million a year earlier. The company's five banks in New England lost $111 million, down from a $115 million loss a year earlier.
Fleet/Norstar's stock picked up 75 cents yesterday, closing at $18.125.

HEADLINE: American Air's Parent Posts $195.6 Million Loss

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 17

 BODY:
The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said it lost $195.6 million in the first quarter, with the weak economy and war-related travel worries cutting passenger loads. Squabbles with its pilots' union, route changes and higher prices for aviation fuel also contributed to the deficit.
Industry analysts said American's huge loss reflected continuing turmoil in the airline industry, which lost $2 billion from operations in the last quarter of 1990. The industry's first-quarter losses will probably exceed $1.5 billion, analysts said, although prospects appear to be improving. 
 Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, in New York, said American's deficit was smaller than expected. He said declining costs and rising passenger loads should enable American to earn a profit in the current quarter.
 
'It's Going to Get Better'
 American and a few other carriers, including Delta Air Lines and United Airlines, should recover significantly by the end of the year to earn a small profit for 1991 perhaps, if current trends hold, said Daniel M. Kasper, an industry adviser at Harbridge House, consultants in Boston.
"It's going to get better as the year goes along," he said.
But financially weak carriers like Trans World Airlines and others in bankruptcy, including Continental and Pan American World Airways, will continue to struggle. Airline travel was down 11.2 percent for domestic-based carriers in March from last year, according to the Air Transport Association, a trade group in Washington.
American said its revenues rose by 3 percent in the quarter, to $2.77 billion, from $2.69 billion in the first quarter last year. The airline lost $19.3 million in the corresponding quarter last year. Operating expenses rose by 11 percent, to $3.01 billion from $2.70 billion, because of the airline's growth and higher fuel costs. American added 18 aircraft in the quarter, raising its fleet to 570 planes.
American's loss was the second worst in its history, after the $215.1 million deficit in the fourth quarter. Robert L. Crandall, AMR's chairman and chief executive, said the performance was terrible, but added that declines in costs for jet fuel and improving passenger sales in March were signs of a turnaround.
Jet fuel costs slipped to an average of 82 cents a gallon in the first quarter from $1.13 a gallon in the fourth quarter. The airline's average jet-fuel cost for April was 55.5 cents a gallon through today.
If the fuel-cost average holds near 60 cents through June, as American anticipates, the airline's fuel expense for the current quarter would drop by about $150 million from the first-quarter figure. American has more than 2,000 daily flights and uses 220 million gallons of jet fuel each month.
The airline faced other unusual costs in the quarter. It scaled back its flight schedule by 4 percent in January as the threat of a pilots' strike mounted, then moved to restore the flights after the pilots agreed to new contract terms in February.
 
Absence of Pilots
 The schedule was further complicated by the absence of as many as 450 pilots on military duty during the war in the Persian Gulf. About 50 have been released from active duty, but the airline is unsure when the others will return, said Andrea Rader, a spokeswoman.
The airline said it sold an average of 57 percent of available seats on all flights during the quarter, but that it needed a level of 63 percent to earn a profit because of higher costs. The break-even point in the corresponding quarter last year was 60 percent.

HEADLINE: Rich's Plans To Close Its Main Store

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Rich's Inc., a landmark in downtown Atlanta for more than a century, announced yesterday that it would close the huge store on July 13 after five years of continuing losses.
The announcement at 5 P.M. surprised the store staff, competitors and the public. Many had assumed that Rich's would stay put in its flagship location because of its participation in local affairs and continue its brisk competition with Macy's, its rival downtown. 
 Rich's is one of nine store divisions of Federated Stores Inc., which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in January 1990. The company also owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in New York, Jordan Marsh in Boston and Miami, Burdines in Florida, Lazarus in Ohio and the Bon Marche in Seattle. The divisions have also been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
 
A Trend in Retailing
 The 13 Rich's suburban stores will stay open after the downtown flagship is closed, a Rich's statement said, and the 242 full-time and part-time employees in the main store will be offered jobs in the branches. Rich's owns both the store property and the land on which it is situated, according to Federated in Cincinnati.
The closing of the Rich's main store continues a trend in big cities.
"The continuing decline in sales in our downtown store, in stark contrast to our success in other locations, has forced us to make this difficult but basic business decision," said Roger Farah, Rich's chairman and chief executive.
He said Rich's had postponed the decision for several years to "lend support to fledgling downtown development initiatives and the city's effort to stabilize the downtown business district."
Company officials also said Rich's had hoped that business would return with the opening of Underground Atlanta, a retail and entertainment complex, but the success of the civic project failed to help the retailer.
 
Pink Pigs and Easy Returns
 For decades, the store lighted a Christmas tree on Thanksgiving night and gave children rides through the store on a miniature train with cars shaped like pink pigs. It offered customers an extremely liberal policy on returns, and its closing will be felt far beyond the loss of sales.
Judith Webb, a native of Atlanta and an employee of the Chamber of Commerce, said: "I got my wedding dress at Rich's; I got my first prom dress at Rich's. I have amazing memories of coming downtown as a little child, riding the pink pig and getting all my school clothes. It's a sad thing."
Rich's spent $9 million in 1985 to renovate the downtown store but customer traffic and sales continued to decline, Mr. Farah said. Profits in the location averaged $5 million to $6 million below the level needed to keep the store open. But sales at the downtown store represent only 3.7 percent of Rich's total 1990 sales of $824 million.
In 1988, Federated merged its Goldsmith stores into Rich's and a headquarters staff was maintained for the combined group in the downtown Atlanta store. That staff of 900, which includes buying, merchandising, marketing, finance and accounting executives and associates, will remain in the building for the time being.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Panel Recommends Sanctions Against Japan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
A long-smoldering trade dispute with Japan has heated up, with the Bush Administration's interagency Trade Policy Group recommending retaliation for Tokyo's failure to open more public works construction to American companies, like a new airport for Osaka, Administration officials said today.
But Japanese officials said Tokyo had decided to send a negotiating team to Washington within a week to try to resolve the conflict before a May 1 deadline for introducing the sanctions. 
 "We have indicated that we will be responding positively" to some of the United States concerns, said Hiroshi Hirabayashi, the economics minister at the Japanese Embassy here.
 
Warning Made
 At the same time, he warned that if the United States resorted to sanctions, Japan would suspend concessions already made that have led to $310 million worth of Japanese contracts to American construction companies since mid-1988.
"We will be offering the maximum we can without prejudicing our basic position," Mr. Hirabayashi said in an interview.
The Trade Policy Group, representing sub-Cabinet officials from agencies and departments with trade responsibility, unanimously recommended sanctions at a meeting on Friday. The sanctions would involve steps to keep Japanese construction companies from wining American public works contracts.
But Administration officials stressed that the Cabinet and the President still had to approve any action, which would be the first ordered by the White House against Japan since 1987 and signal a significant change in the Washington's policy toward Tokyo.
 
Fewer Disputes Than in Past
 Although trade disputes still overshadow the relationship, there now are somewhat fewer than in past years, and the trade deficit with Japan has been declining -- factors that have led the Administration to maintain that the overall trade relationship with Japan is improving.
That was the tenor of a meeting earlier this month in California between President Bush and Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu. The only mention of construction came in a statement by President Bush at the end of the meeting, in which he cited some of the more acute bilateral problems.
Chiefly because of the May 1 deadline mandated by trade legislation, the Japanese practice of excluding foreigners from work on billions of dollars worth of construction on bridges, airports, highways, telecommunications and other projects has again come under attack.
The construction issue has come to a head as the United States is also pressing Japan to improve market access in computer chips, auto parts and telecommuncations and to end a ban on imports of rice.
On construction, Washington wants to expand the scope of coverage of a 1988 Major Projects Agreement between the countries that identified 14, later expanded to 17, projects valued at $23 billion for special foreign bidding.
American officials say they want a commitment by the Japanese to open their entire construction market as a matter of principle. They also want the Japanese to acknowledge that American companies have an interest in certain categories of projects, like airports.
American officials say the retaliation will not take place if the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, can certify by the end of April that the Japanese have taken steps to open their markets.
