HEADLINE: Weicker and Labor Unions Reach an Accord

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 17

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he and state labor unions had agreed on $327.7 million in labor concessions to help ease Connecticut's budget crisis, averting 2,600 layoffs that began to take effect this week.
It was clear from the opening moments of the news conference announcing the agreement that Mr. Weicker had gained a loud and enthusiastic voice on behalf of the sweeping budget overhaul and income-tax plan that is before the General Assembly. 
 The chief negotiator for the unions, Robert J. Krzys, linked the agreement to union support for a "fair budget and tax reform," and urged state workers to support Mr. Weicker's budget at a rally next week at the Capitol.
Mr. Weicker, in turn, praised the unions as being "the first ones to respond to Connecticut's economic winter." He said that the spending cuts agreed to by the unions are real and painful and "will come out of their pockets as employees and taxpayers."
Mr. Weicker said the first wave of employees who lost their jobs, on Tuesday, would be recalled. But he would not disclose any details of the labor agreement, which was reached this morning. In interviews with labor leaders, lawmakers and administration officials, however, the pact emerged as containing mostly short- or medium-term savings that the state will have to make up in future years.
One of the demands earlier identified by Mr. Weicker as a pivotal benefit reduction, for example -- that Connecticut's 52,000 employees be required to pay a greater proportion of their health care benefits -- was apparently dropped entirely. The state also pledged in writing to avoid any layoffs in the year that begins July 1 other than 938 positions already identified in Mr. Weicker's initial budget plan.
Even if Connecticut's budget and economy continues to deteriorate, the document says, further spending cuts "will not result in loss of employment." Instead, Mr. Weicker promised to transfer, reassign or retrain workers if their jobs have to be eliminated, the officials said. Most of the provisions require approval by union rank and file members, and by the General Assembly, and some lawmakers said today they were already troubled.
The single largest element of the package, which involves stretching out the state's payment schedule to the employee pension plan, is clearly of the category to be borne by taxpayers, whether they work for the state or not. The pension change accounts for $190 million of the projected $327.7 million in savings in the next year, and payments would also be reduced in the next two years after that. But those reduced payments would have to be made up over the 32-year life of the pension plan.
The unions also agreed to a pay raise deferral, under which raises promised for July 1 would be delayed for 11 months, until June 26, 1992. The next raise after that for most employees would come 11 months after that, on May 14, 1993. The compromise gives union members an annual pay increase that will still take effect in the next fiscal year. But by delaying the raises and thus paying the higher wages for a shorter period of time, the state will save about $84 million.
Approximately $48 million is expected to be saved by changing the way the state runs its health-benefits program. But the projected savings, from increases in competitive bidding, and direct state management of the payment system, will not come from state employee's hides. Benefits were pledged to remain intact, labor leaders and administration officials said.
The Governor also said he needed $400 million from the unions as their contribution to resolving Connecticut's huge projected tax-revenue shortfall. He declined to say today exactly where else he might go in the budget to obtain the nearly $73 million not conceded by the unions, although he said that a nonunion pay freeze and furlough program for state managers would contribute.

HEADLINE: Congress Votes to Halt Rail Strike Hours After Thousands Walk Off Job

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, April 18

 BODY:
Congress approved a joint resolution late Wednesday to halt the national railroad strike less than 24 hours after it began. President Bush signed the legislation early this morning.
After day and night negotiations involving lawmakers and Administration officials, the House of Representatives moved with unusual speed to draft and then pass the measure a 400-to-5 vote. Minutes later, shortly after 11 P.M., the Senate approved the resolution without a roll call vote. 
 Mr. Bush signed the bill at 1:39 A.M. after being awakened in the residential quarters of the White House, a spokesman said. The President was expected to issue a statement later today.
Samuel K. Skinner, the Transportation Secretary, said Mr. Bush had asked that he be awakened to sign the measure, which would immediately send the strikers back to work. Mr. Skinner called the measure "a resolution everyone can live with."
The unions have said they would abide by the legislation.
The walkout early Wednesday against freight railroads throughout the United States stopped movement of much of the nation's coal, grain, automobile parts and many other goods.
Except for a few small regional railroads, all freight traffic stopped moving soon after 7 A.M. as a result of the first nationwide rail strike since a four-day walkout in 1982.
The nation's railroads carry 37 percent of all freight. Trucks carry 25 percent.
 
Quick Action Shows Importance
 Mr. Skinner added that the swift action by Congress was "an indication of just how important this issue is, how important it is to the economy."
The legislation creates a board that will have 65 days to resolve issues remaining in the dispute. If the strike is not settled in that time, the recommendations of a Presidential emergency board that issued a report in January will take effect.
There was relatively little partisan rancor in the closed negotiations, participants said, out of concern that the strike be resolved quickly. Several lawmakers noted Wednesday that each hour the strike continued would be devastating not only to the rail industry but also to the American economy.
"This means the strike is over," proclaimed Representative Al Swift, a Washington Democrat who leads a transportation subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee that drafted the legislation. He added that he had "never seen an issue resolved with so little partisan politics."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat and chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, said, "This accord is good for labor, good for business, good for the economy and good for the nation, and I look forward to its implementation."
By appointing a new board, lawmakers insisted that they were not rejecting the findings of the Presidential emergency board. They said they were particularly concerned that the new panel clarify unresolved issues, like disputes over work rules.
While the Railway Labor Act of 1926 does not expressly create a role for Congress in rail disputes, Congress since 1963 has intervened in at least 11 strikes that threatened grave disruptions to the economy. Lawmakers have several choices when it comes to rail disputes, from not acting at all to requiring binding arbitration.
Several lawmakers said they were reluctant to impose a settlement. "I do not favor direct imposition," said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, but he noted that "a rail strike that took any period of time to resolve would create devastating consequences."
Representative Dennis E. Eckart of Ohio, a senior Democrat on the committee, warned industry officials at the subcommittee's hearing Wednesday that "efforts to slam dunk or force feed" the Presidential board's recommendations "down anyone's throat ain't going nowhere."
Union leaders told the panel earlier today that they would go along with the limited negotiating period, but officials representing freight carriers said they would have preferred that Congress force the unions to accept the recommendations of the Presidential board.
 
Railroads Back First Board
 Michael H. Walsh, chairman of Union Pacific Railroad Company, urged the subcommittee to go along with the Presidential board's recommendations. "Should you, the Congress, attempt to augment or alter the report?" he asked. "My answer is no. The board's recommendations represent a balance, a compromise between the claims of the parties."
But Fred Hardin, president of the United Transportation Union, which represents about 100,000 train crew members, complained to the panel that the Presidential board's report had sought too many concessions from workers.
"We'll make agreements," Mr. Hardin said, "but we don't want Congress to cram it down our throats just because a few railroad presidents want to make some more money."
Mr. Swift said it was not fair to call his committee's agreement a forced settlement. "I would not call it binding arbitration," he said. "What I'm saying is at some point it's got to end. And Congress is not going to set up a merry-go-round where it comes back here again."
Officials involved in the negotiations said agreement on the legislation was delayed for several hours because of a dispute over who would appoint the three members of the new mediation board. The negotiators finally agreed that one member would be drawn from the Presidential emergency board and the other two would be appointed by Mr. Bush from a list supplied by the National Mediation Board.
 
Some Pessimism
 There was not widespread optimism that the new cooling-off period would ultimately solve the dispute. Mr. Hardin, for one, said he feared that once the cooling-off period ended, "we would just be faced with the same crisis."
Despite the history of Congressional involvement in railroad strikes, several members said Wednesday that they felt uncomfortable with that role. At the hearing, they repeatedly asked Joshua Javits, chairman of the National Mediation Board, for advice on how to handle the strike.
Representative Don Ritter of Pennsylvania, who is the ranking Republican on the transportation subcommittee, told Mr. Javits: "Most of us members of Congress feel somwhat uncomfortable in a position of settling a labor- management dispute via legislation. The National Mediation Board wasn't successful in mediating the dispute -- now we have a strike on our hands."
But Mr. Javits replied that it was not his place to advise the lawmakers, saying it would lead to accusations that he was "gratuitously taking sides, which would undermine my position as a mediator."
Union leaders were angry that the Government appeared unwilling to let the strike run a week or so, a period that they hoped would force more concessions on wages and working conditions than the railroads have been willing to grant over the three years since the negotiations began.
Before Congress's action, Tom DuBose, assistant president of the United Transportation Union, one of those involved in the strike, said: "We don't want Congress to intervene in collective bargaining. That's not their role. We think we can best settle our own problems."
He said fears of a devastating effect on the economy were exaggerated.
Many businesses, including utilities that burn coal to produce electricity, builders that use train-carried lumber and newspapers that rely on trains to bring in their newsprint, had stockpiled as much as a month's worth of supplies.
But other businesses, notably the automobile industry, did not.
Coal represents 38 percent of all rail freight tonnage, and a strike of even a few days could have forced layoffs of possibly thousands of miners. Many coal companies have such large stockpiles at the mine sites that they have no more room to store it above ground, industry officials said.
General Motors, a heavy user of railshipped parts and materials, said its plants kept operating Wednesday. "But we do estimate that 75 percent to 80 percent of our production will be affected within the next 24 hours," which could bring widespread layoffs, said Carol Longridge, a spokeswoman.
 
Few Commuters Affected
 Far fewer people who commute to work on trains were affected than expected in the hours before the strike. The hardest hit were 22,000 who commute between the Silicon Valley and San Francisco. CalTrain, a state-run train service between San Jose and San Francisco, was shut down by Southern Pacific Transportation Company, which owns the CalTrain tracks, shortly after 5 A.M., even though the CalTrain workers' unions had agreed not to extend their strike from freight lines to commuter service.
But tonight, CalTrain and Southern Pacific were trying to devise a plan to restore most commuter service by this morning.
Chicago commuters were expected to be severely affected, but the city's Union Station was awash with trench coats and brief cases Wednesday morning as passengers rode the trains and arrived downtown as usual.
Late Tuesday afternoon, Cook County Circuit Court Judge Sophia Hall issued a temporary restraining order, requiring the Chicago & North Western Transportation Company to keep open its three commuter lines for 10 days. Management of six other lines have voluntarily continued service.
 
Amtrak Continues to Run
 In addition to its Boston-to-Washington corridor, Amtrak was able to continue service along the second biggest corridor, from Los Angeles to San Diego, and along the third busiest, from Albany to New York, with the consent of the freight lines that own the tracks on those routes.
Unions representing 235,000 workers went out on strike against the 10 biggest freight companies and against 88 of the 500 other smaller lines. Three unions have settled the negotiations begun three years ago, when the last contract ended and wages were frozen at levels where they remain today. Their wages, averaging around $36,000 a year, nevertheless put them close to the top of the nation's blue-collar work force.
Eight or nine unions went out on strike, depending on how they are counted. Clerks who belong to the Transportation Communications Workers union, along with two other unions, reached tentative agreements with the railroads. But the carmen in the T.C.U. did not.
 
The Issues
 One issue involves the number of people a railroad needs to run a train -- the unions say four or five in the cases of some trains, and management says just two. Another involves how far a worker must travel to be credited for having worked a full day. Currently the distance is 108 miles, although over an eight-hour period, trains often travel twice that distance. The unions want to reduce the distance to the traditional level of 100 miles; management wants about twice the distance.
With the failure of collective bargaining and Federal mediation, President Bush intervened in the negotiations last May in appointing a Presidential Emergency Board to propose compromises. The board completed its report in January.
The railroads considered most of the recommendations acceptable, but the unions did not. The unions were required to spend 30 days cooling off, but with the war over Kuwait under way in February, they stretched it to 90 days, which ended at midnight Tuesday.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "There is a sense of urgency," Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said about the need to intervene in the rail strike. (Associated Press); A strike by rail unions disrupted movement of freight across the country. Striking workers set up a picket line yesterday in Cicero, Ill. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Chart: "The Rail Dispute: A Primer"
 The nation's freight railroads and unions that represent most of their workers are at loggerheads over two issues, wages and work rules, and close to agreement on one, health benefits.
 
UNIONS' POSITION
 
Wages:
Demand annual wage increase of 5 percent until 1995 and retroactive to 1988, when wages were frozen and the current negotiations began. Also want cost of living increases.
 
Work rules:
A worker is currently paid for a full day's work after traveling 108 miles; unions want to return to the traditional 100-mile day. Also seek to maintain current staffing levels aboard frieght trains at four or five, contending that they are necessary for safe operation.
 
Health Benefits:
 Have agreed to use health maintenance organizations and to have workers pay 15 percent of health care costs. Minor differences remain over increases in deductibles.

RAILROADS' POSTION
 
Wages:
 Claim insufficient funds to keep improving their equipment. Want to maintain the freeze until 1995, when the next talks would begin.
 
Work Rules:
 Seek more than double the 108 miles, since today's faster trains can cover the distance in a couple of hours. Also want to reduce the numbers of workers in many cases to two, maintaining that modern trains do not need large crews.
 Alternatively, management proposes retaining current staffing levels but reducing wages enough so that the wages of the workers aboard a train would not exceed the total earned by two workers.
 
Health Benefits:
Now pay health care costs except for a $100 deductible. With health care costs growing 10 percent to 20 percent a year, want workers to use H.M.O.'s where they are available and, where not, to pay 20 percent of the cost.

HEADLINE: Head of Ex-Im Bank Denies White House Pushed on Iraq

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
John D. Macomber, the president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, told skeptical members of Congress today that the Reagan and Bush Administrations had exerted "absolutely no pressure" on the agency's decision to guarantee $267 million in American exports to Iraq between 1987 and 1990.
Mr. Macomber acknowledged, in an interview after the session, that officials of the Departments of State and Commerce had sought to persuade his agency to lift the ban on such aid. But he said their communications were in the form of suggestions, not commands. 
 "We hear from other agencies," Mr. Macomber said. "Everybody makes his case. But there was absolutely no pressure."
In 1987, the agency reversed its ban on such guarantees solely because Iraq had repaid its debts, Mr. Macomber told the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs.
"The test is creditworthiness," Mr. Macomber told the committee. "As far as we were concerned, they had brought themselves up to date."
Mr. Macomber said the bank provided only short-term guarantees of up to one year and set a limit of $200 million. "We limited ourselves to short-term credit which, in the world of international banking, does not amount to very much." A total of $267 million was guaranteed, in 182 different transactions.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the banking committee, told the hearing that his staff's interviews with State and Commerce Department officials had disclosed communications with Export-Import Bank officials that he said had been intended to persuade the agency to reverse its policy against guarantees to Iraq.
April Glaspie, who was Ambassador to Iraq at the time, was among those who lobbied the export agency on behalf of American businesses and Iraq, Mr. Gonzalez said. The General Motors Corporation and the Bechtel Group Inc. were among the American corporations that sought long-term guarantees for Iraq, he said.
"Because of its tough stance against loaning billions to Iraq, the Export-Import Bank was repeatedly chastised by the staff of the State and Commerce Departments." Mr. Gonzalez said. "During 1989, criticism from State and Commerce Department staff was severe enough to cause the Export-Import Bank board of directors to reconsider its negative conclusion regarding Iraq's creditworthiness."
Asked after the hearing if these charges were true, Mr. Macomber said, "Absolutely not." The bank was not chastised, he said, nor did the criticism cause the bank to reconsider its ban on long-term guarantees to Iraq.
 
Iraq Still Owes $50.8 Million
 Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota, said after the hearing: "It seems to me that here's a case where creditworthiness went out the window, and the Administration's public policy prevailed. On the face of it, this is not what the Export-Import Bank should have been doing."
Mr. Macomber acknowledged in his tesitmony that Iraq still owed the bank $50.8 million.
The banking committee made public a report to the export agency, written in July 1988 by Thomas A. Forbord, vice president for country risk analysis, which Mr. Gonzalez said raised questions about Iraq's creditworthiness. The report concluded: "With oil revenues unpredictable and insufficient to cover Iraq's financing needs, Baghdad wants to secure strategic financiall partners who place their military, political and economic interests in Iraq above their requirements for repayment. Within this context, Iraq repays in full only those who provide credits in excess of payments falling due."
The Export-Import Bank was founded 56 years ago to stimulate trade by providing financing to overseas buyers of American goods at below-market rates. Since 1974, the agency has had a policy of financing only nonmilitary exports, which the Bush Administration is now seeking to revise.

HEADLINE: A Budget Worth Noticing, Barely

 BODY:
The House approved a budget resolution yesterday that sets better domestic spending priorities than those proposed in the President's budget. But both budgets barely nibble at the edges of the huge Federal spending programs.
That's because the budget law passed last fall guts Congress's right to make important decisions for the next two years. The total that can be spent on domestic discretionary programs is capped; the amounts raised by taxes and spent on the Pentagon and entitlements are virtually locked in place. That leaves Congress and the White House room only to play at the margins. 
 The House budget, compared with President Bush's, would pour an extra $13 billion into programs -- education, nutrition and medical -- targeted on low-income families. Much of the money would come from a $1 billion cut in the space program proposed by the President, and a 1 percent across-the-board cut in administrative and other non-priority expenses. A similar bill is working its way through the Senate.
These are the right priorities: a program to build a gargantuan space station can be slowed, a program to feed hungry children cannot. Yet even within the new budget law, the House could have done more. It could have removed the crippling, and unconscionable, welfare load from beleaguered cities by raising the Federal share of expenditures, along with new taxes to pay for it.
At the very least, the House could have backed the bold White House plan to strip some Medicare and agriculture entitlements from the very rich. Over time, targeting entitlements would free up billions for education, training and infrastructure -- the foundations of a healthy economy.
Yes, the House budget is better than the President's. But shuffling $13 billion in a trillion-dollar budget isn't much of a change. So yesterday's vote won't stir passions, and small wonder.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK;
High Noon on High Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT B. SEMPLE JR.

 BODY:
The fierce battle between students and alumni over the admission of women to Yale's most secretive and ritualistic senior society, Skull and Bones, ranks right up there -- or down there -- with the other stories that have diverted readers from the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, including the latest Kennedy family imbroglio in Palm Beach and Kitty Kelley's book about Nancy Reagan.
Still, to someone who attended Yale in the 50's and whose wife says he was an "Old Blue" before he left New Haven, the story has resonance. It offers useful commentary on generational change, on present student priorities and on a durable truth about universities: Both students and alumni think they run them. 
 The battle is simply described. The current delegation of 15 Bonesmen broke radically with 159 years of tradition by "tapping," or choosing, seven women for next year's delegation. A stunned alumni board of directors responded by locking the ancient tomb on High Street, and declaring the election null and void.
Some compromise may be in the cards, but so far the air is heavy with insult. The students are threatening a lawsuit. The graduates have countered with an atavistic "separate but equal" plan under which males and females would eat together but then break up into separate groups for the sharing of "emotional and life histories" -- the intense autobiographical sessions practiced by nearly all of Yale's seven secret societies.
The alumni are fighting a losing battle. Women have been attending Yale for more than 20 years, and the existence of an all-male institution in this determinedly coeducational society is plainly an uncomfortable anachronism, if not an affront. That's precisely what a former Yale president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, told the alumni of his own society, Scroll and Key, which he loved but which he vowed never to visit again unless women were admitted. They finally were, in 1989.
Furthermore, despite the alumni's strong convictions and economic clout, the societies exist mainly to serve the undergraduates. The students run them and perpetuate them, and if the present Bones group chooses not to elect a delegation other than the one it has already picked, then Bones could be out of business: a pyrrhic victory, to say the least, for the old guard.
The attendant publicity may have strengthened the notion that these clandestine institutions are hugely important. They can in fact be wonderful places. Most members enjoy them; durable and comforting friendships are formed.
Acceptance was also once thought to be a referendum on one's undergraduate career, an idea reinforced by a brutal description of Tap Day in the novel "Stover at Yale," where senior members raced into the courtyard and "tapped" their lucky successors, leaving 900 other juniors standing around feeling like failures.
But admission nowadays is neither a certification of undergraduate triumph nor, as was once supposed, a guarantee of future success -- Bonesmen George Herbert Walker Bush and William F. Buckley to the contrary. The Bones stockbroker who (perhaps apocryphally) left his club pin on the window ledge just before he jumped after the crash of 1929 may have cherished Bones, but he did not die a happy or wealthy man.
This is the final decade of the 20th century. Seize it, ye men of Bones.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Tall In the Straddle

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When the President's press secretary opined that his boss did not have to have an arms treaty all set to sign in order to meet at the summit with Mr. Gorbachev, two groups were horrified:
The sniveling, save-Gorby-from-the-baddies arms-control establishment (you know who you are) want a summit linked to a Start treaty because that will pressure the White House to accede to Soviet demands. 
 The ultra-suspicious, press-'em- till-they-cave, unreconstructed cold warriors (we know who we are) want to dangle the prospect of a summit, which Mr. Gorbachev needs, to induce him to keep treaty promises made in days of wine and glasnost.
This crossfire caused Marlin Fitzwater, behind the curve on this arcane negotiating stuff, to flip-flop the same day, calling for a summit conditioned on a treaty. Asked about the disarray, President Bush said, "I'm backing both of Marlin's positions."
Let's hope this confuses the Soviets. The bushed Bushies are finding it hard to walk a straight line on Kurdish relief and chew disarmament gum at the same time.
Here's what the President should do on troop withdrawals and arms reductions:
1. Stick to your guns on putting the withdrawal of conventional forces from Europe (C.F.E., which we want most) ahead of a treaty on strategic missiles (Start, which Gorby needs to lock in his nuclear advantage).
Moscow has pulled a fast one on us by breaking its word on troop withdrawals. After the deal was struck, the Soviets renamed three divisions of army troops "naval adjuncts" -- pure bad-faith dealing. Mr. Gorbachev now grandly offers to settle for half his subterfuge; if Mr. Bush buys that, he sets himself up as a patsy right down the line.
We should insist on an end to "data denial" -- the Soviets' pretense that they have in place only half the tanks and artillery we can count. When we gave them the list of their own forces to be reduced, the Soviet negotiators froze.
2. After credibility is re-established on previously agreed troop pullbacks and tank destruction, remove the non-starters stopping Start.
This means dismissing "down-loading," the unverifiable Soviet promise to load only two warheads on submarine ballistic missiles already proven capable of holding seven.
Do not let them sell new wine in old bottles. Ronald Reagan won a real reduction by half the huge SS-18's targeted on the U.S. But the Soviets tricked us by vastly improving the accuracy of the remaining half: pre-agreement, two Soviet warheads were needed to take out one of our hard targets, but now it's down to one.
Thus, the "reduction" in missile numbers does not reduce their threat to destroy our ability to retaliate. (Go explain that to Marlin.)
3. Stop treating those substantial disagreements caused by the Soviets' duplicity, as well as their resistance to on-site inspection of mobile missiles, as mere "technical differences."
The more Mr. Bush minimizes the made-in-Moscow difficulties, the more Mr. Gorbachev will say "then let's split the difference." (The moment James Baker hears the word "split" he says, "Where do I sign?") It's no negotiating victory to come out half-tricked; let's not permit the Soviets to disavow hard-won agreements.
Now to the original question: Should a summit be linked to a treaty-signing?
Yes, we should let Mr. Gorbachev strut the summit stage if he delivers on his agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe without renaming the Red Army the Coast Guard.
No, we should not tie the summit to a Start treaty because that would help him pressure us. If he wants to sell a lowball warhead count on his subs and modernize his SS-18's, we can apply intolerable economic pressure to stop such trickery by speeding the development of our nuclear shield.
The hard-line plan: First get a C.F.E. treaty. Then agree to hold a summit for its signing. There, while boosting each other's ratings, squeeze him on Baltic independence. Regale his Gromov-Pugo handlers with what Tibet's courageous Dalai Lama says about human rights, and on Kurdistan, hold an enclave conclave. Assure Gorby of trade only after a command economy stops bankrupting his confederation.
Then, in that wide-ranging context, reassert the need for a verifiable, Senate-confirmable deal to really reduce his strategic missile threat.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Looking Again at Iraq Without War Hysteria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A comment on John Chancellor's excellent and timely "War Stories," (Op-Ed, April 1), reminding us that truth is a casualty of war and cautioning against uncritical acceptance of accounts of Iraqi atrocities:
His reference to the "psychology of the war" merits emphasis. Our claim to humanity, in the face of estimates of 100,000 to 200,000 Iraqi deaths, probably the highest rate of killing in the history of organized warfare, is linked to the belief that Saddam Hussein is evil incarnate. 
 There is a further danger from simple juxtapositions of evil and virtue. President Bush cannot exonerate himself from the responsibility to examine if all the carnage was necessary. Blaming the Iraqi Government in the bunker bombing, for instance, seems uncomfortably close to the Irish Republican Army's blaming the British Government for the railway station it targeted recently.
President Bush has decided that he cannot be a party to the breakup of the Iraqi state or engineer the overthrow of Saddam Hussein. This is a more prudent course of action than one that would result from the assumption that Saddam Hussein is unallayed evil and that there are no rivals to his record of human rights violations, including our own allies.
Finally, the typical third-world state, whatever its antiquity as a civilization, is a recent and tenuous political entity, housing ancient divisions and identities. Few countries, whether autocratic or democratic, would survive unscathed the onslaught and breakup of order Iraq has experienced.
 
SUBBIAH KANNAPPAN
East Lansing, Mich., April 4, 1991
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Michigan State University.

HEADLINE: Higher New Jersey Auto Registration Offsets Insurance Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your April 1 report on cuts in New Jersey auto insurance, you fail to observe that the administration of Gov. Jim Florio is playing the old shell game with the state's drivers -- giving with one hand while taking back with the other. Some of us are getting taken more than others.
My wife and I both work, and each of us requires an automobile to get to our places of employment. My wife drives a 1986 Mazda; I drive a 1986 General Motors small pickup truck. 
 I recently received my registration renewal form for the pickup. The fee last year was $56. This year it is $106.40. A notice with the renewal form points out that 40 cents of this increase, which will be in effect for the next six years, will be used for development (not manufacture?) of reflectorized license plates, an outstanding example of setting priorities in tight economic times.
The balance of the increase, or $50, is to "help fund the New Jersey insurance reform program," according to a message sent with the renewal. The increase raises my cost of registration for the pickup almost 89 percent But wait. The increase for my wife's car, the same age as mine, is only $15. There is no explanation why a standard half-ton pickup, essentially the same size, weight and dimensions as many sedans on the road, is surcharged $35 more a year than those sedans. Even a new car is only charged $40 more a year for the first two years, but vans and trucks, no matter their age, pay $50 a year.
The so-called reduction that the state has promised in insurance premiums is offset by higher registration fees for the next six years. The state is pocketing money what previously went to the insurance companies, which have expressed their intention to file for rate increases.
I wonder when we'll see those reflectorized plates?
 
HARRY LEVY
Middletown, N.J., April 2, 1991

HEADLINE: Price Fixing Always Victimizes the Consumer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the course of "Price Fixing Isn't Always Gouging" (editorial, April 1), your apologia for vertical price fixing, you assert that illegal conspiracies to boost the retail price of a product between manufacturers and their retailers "aren't common." This is particularly ill timed.
Just a week earlier, all 50 state attorneys general ended one of the largest vertical price-fixing cases in the history of antitrust enforcement with an $8 million settlement against the Japanese electronics giant Mitsubishi for an illegal scheme that cheated more than 260,000 United States purchasers of televisions. 
 A week after your editorial, 40 states, led by New York, joined the Federal Trade Commission in a case in which Nintendo, a company with $4 billion in United States sales last year, illegally conspired to boost the price of its video game consoles to nine million consumers.
These cases are but the latest in a line that includes a 49-state settlement with Panasonic in 1989 and a 37-state settlement with Minolta in 1986. These cases involved millions of dollars in overcharging by vertical conspiracies. Of local interest to New Yorkers were cases we brought in 1981 in which 47 milk distributors pleaded guilty to criminal charges in a vertical price fixing scheme that inflated consumer prices.
The real issue is not whether or not illegal vertical price fixing exists: it's endemic. The real issue is whether or not antitrust enforcers have the tools to find and prosecute these conspiracies. The two recent Supreme Court decisions you praise put extraordinary roadblocks in our way. These decisions did not, as you state, redefine if or when vertical price fixing is illegal. Rather, the Court adopted absurdly restrictive burden of proof requirements that make it easy for companies to disguise their behavior so that illegal conspiracies cannot be brought to court, by government enforcers or by the discount stores that are victimized by these practices.
Indeed, Terry Calvani, former Federal Trade Commissioner, said the Supreme Court's rulings left such big loopholes that a corporate officer would have to have "an I.Q. two points lower than a carrot" to get caught. Antitrust enforcers can recount scores of tales of retailers calling our offices too scared to give their names, telling of coercion and intimidation by manufacturers' representatives and rival dealers because their prices were too low. Under the Supreme Court's rules we would have little chance of making a case.
The effect of the bill sponsored by Senator Howard Metzenbaum, which you now oppose after years of consistent support for tough antitrust enforcement, would simply be to overturn these burden of proof requirements, so that vertical price fixing cases could go before juries. It would put teeth back into a statute that has been rendered virtually unenforceable, and 45 state attorneys general support it for that reason.
As to the economic effect of vertical price fixing, you pass it off as a generally benign process designed to "encourage better service to consumers." The reality is quite different. If manufacturers want better service, there are dozens of legal ways to require it directly, short of fixing and raising retail prices. The true effect of vertical price fixing is exactly what one would expect: if you increase prices to consumers, you increase profits for the retailers and for the manufacturers.
The Federal Trade Commission found vertical price fixing inflates prices to consumers 10 percent to 23 percent.
 
ROBERT ABRAMS
New York State Attorney General
New York, April 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Retirement Plan For Teachers

 BODY:
The New York City Board of Education approved yesterday a plan to encourage older teachers to retire this year, thereby helping thousands of younger teachers to keep their jobs in the face of the city's fiscal troubles.
James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, said he expected the plan to bring retirements this June to 2,500 -- 1,500 more than usual. That would reduce the number of teachers threatened with layoffs by a far higher figure since senior teachers earn twice as much as novices. It would also allow the system to retain more of its black and Hispanic teachers, with many of them hired in recent years.
The plan requires approval by the Legislature. It would give teachers retiring before July 1 credit for three extra years of service in calculating pensions. Retiring teachers generally receive 40 to 60 percent of their final year's salary, depending on how many years they have worked. Only employees 55 or older with at least 30 years of service are eligible to retire.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 19, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A brief article yesterday about the New York City Board of Education's plan to encourage early retirement of teachers misstated the eligibility requirements. Teachers may retire early if they are 55 or older, or if they have at least 30 years' service; they need not meet both conditions.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Schwarzkopf Plans Return To U.S. and Fall Retirement

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAFR AL BATEN, Saudi Arabia, April 17

 BODY:
Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, plans to return to the United States on Saturday, the American military authorities said today.
General Schwarzkopf, 56 years old, plans to retire from the Army by the fall, and there have been reports that he has received a number of lucrative offers for his memoirs and has been approached to take high-ranking civilian posts. 
 Lieut. Gen. William Pagonis, the top military official in charge of logistics, will oversee the withdrawal of American troops in the Persian Gulf once General Schwarzkopf departs.
General Schwarzkopf's departure will cap an extraordinary eight-month tour in Saudi Arabia, in which the commander marshaled a force of more than 540,000 troops to decisively defeat the Iraqi military.
 
To Return to Tampa, Fla.
 Before Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait, General Schwarzkopf and his command were little known to the American public. The focus was on NATO and the political changes sweeping eastern Europe.
But since the gulf crisis, the burly four-star general has become a folk hero to much of the public, even as debate continues over the Bush Administration's refusal to aid Iraqi insurgents seeking to topple President Saddam Hussein.
Capt. Ronald E. Wildermuth, the general's chief spokesman, said that the commander decided to return to his command headquarters in Tampa, Fla., because American forces were well on their way to leaving southern Iraq, except for a buffer zone along the Iraq-Kuwait border which American troops will occupy until United Nations observers take their place. More than 50 percent of the American forces deployed in the Persian Gulf have left, Captain Wildermuth noted.
 
Speculation on Position
 In addition, Captain Wildermuth said that the General believed that Iraqi refugees "are in good hands," since United Nations observers will be taking up positions in the buffer area, which is to be demilitarized. Many refugees and some American soldiers, however, are fearful that the United Nations observers will not be able to adequately protect the refugees against retaliation by agents of the Hussein Government.
There was some speculation in past months that General Schwarzkopf might succeed Gen. Carl E. Vuono as Chief of Staff of the Army. But General Schwarzkopf appeared to have had little interest in that position, whose principal focus is now to be the unglamorous task of overseeing the shrinkage of the Army from 18 active divisions to 12 active divisions.
Lieut. Gen. Gordon Sullivan, who currently serves as the Army's Vice Chief of Staff, will be General Vuono's successor, the Army announced today.
General Sullivan has risen quickly in the Army's high command. In 1988 he took command of the First Infantry Division at Fort Riley, Kan. Before serving as Vice Chief of the Army he was a deputy chief of staff in charge of planning and operations.
 
Counseled Patience
 As commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, General Schwarzkopf counseled patience at first, rejecting early calls to take military action instead of waiting to see if economic sanctions would work. But at the same time, General Schwarzkopf oversaw plans to envelop and crush Iraq's Republican Guard.
Though General Schwarzkopf presided over one of the most one-sided victories in modern warfare, the United States' handling of the gulf war has been challenged in recent weeks.
President Bush's decision to end the ground war at 100 hours allowed more Iraqi tanks and armored personnel carriers to escape than the American military authorities in Saudi Arabia believed at first, according to American intelligence estimates.
General Schwarzkopf irked the White House and the Pentagon when he said in a television interview that he had recommended that the United States continue the attack to complete the destruction of Iraq's Republican Guard forces, which were later used to put down rebellions in Iraq.
 
A Forward Headquarters
 The White House and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that General Schwarzkopf had not made such recommendations before President Bush ordered the suspension of military action. Since the controversy, the General and the White House have sought to downplay the dispute and project an image of unity.
United States Central Command, which is led by General Schwarzkopf, is headquartered in Tampa, Fla. It is responsible for American military operations in the Persian Gulf. The United States established a temporary forward headquarters in Riyadh and is discussing the establishment of a forward headquarters in Bahrain. If a forward headquarters is established in Bahrain the main headquarters will continue to be in Florida.
Plans have also been made by the American military to stockpile armored equipment in Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: NFL DRAFT;
Tagliabue Looks at Dollars, Deals and N.F.L. Draft

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE

 BODY:
With the National Football League draft opening on Sunday, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said yesterday that he was not concerned that the draft's top prize -- Raghib Ismail of Notre Dame -- might shun the league and play in Canada instead. But he said he was concerned about the draft's future as it pertains to the league's economics, suggesting that a salary cap and a rookie wage scale may be unavoidable.
Tagliabue made his comments in a meeting yesterday with the football writers and editors of The New York Times. In addition to the draft, Tagliabue discussed a wide range of issues, including pay-per-view television, maintaining solvent franchises and league expansion and realignment. For every issue, Tagliabue has a position. Whether he can continue to gain three-quarters support from his head-strong group of 28 owners will decide how successfully he meets the challenges. 
 On the possibility that Ismail, the draft's favored No. 1 pick, might sign with the Canadian Football League, Tagliabue said: "Frankly, I haven't thought about it. He may be unique, but there haven't been too many people that size who have been an impact player."
How about the Jets and the Giants battling in the same division in a natural homegrown rivalry? Tampa Bay and Miami? Dallas and Houston? Chicago and Indianapolis? Tagliabue said his realignment and expansion committees are seriously exploring these and other options.
Economically, to help insure the N.F.L.'s continued health and growth, the commissioner said a rookie wage scale, a salary cap for each team and more creative ways of revenue sharing among the teams make sense to him. Implementing these ideas, he said, are among the most complicated issues he faces.
In short, in everything Tagliabue tackles as commissioner, he appears to stay true to the legacy that George Halas and Rozelle and others formed decades ago: that no matter how bad your club is, there is always hope, because the N.F.L. seeks to excel with many being equal.
"The N.B.A. survived for several years with only seven strong teams, but we can't," Tagliabue said. "We'll always try to have a league competitive across the board. A league of 28 teams and no weak sisters."
Following are the highlights of Tagliabue's comments on the issues facing the league.
 
The Draft
 Q. Would losing Rocket Ismail to the Canadian Football League concern you?
A. Well, I think he's a great player obviously, an exciting player. But, frankly, I haven't spent a lot of time thinking about the consequences of the Rocket going to the Canadian Football League. We would like to have him, but if they have a package they can offer him, we obviously don't have a choice. Part of the question is a larger question the club people have raised: Is he really indeed the type of impact player who over the course of the season is going to affect any particular team in the league? There are different points of view on that. Everyone thinks he's a great athlete. The question is, is he in the game for 5 plays or 15 plays? In the Canadian League I think he'd be a great player for 25 or 30 plays. This is one of the points they have been trying to sell him.

 Q. What about the contract for the draft, which expires after 1992. What do you do then?

 A. We're not wedded to this particular form of the draft and we can work out something as good or better in terms of avoiding holdouts, which I think a lot of people realize are a problem. We can certainly look at that. As you know, if we can get a collective bargaining agreement I'd be as happy as anybody. We'll be working on that between now and next year, and hopefully we will get that and it will include some kind of a new draft. The draft has changed a lot. Since 1977, we've expanded with underclassmen and in 1987 the rounds were cut from 18 to 12. It's clearly changed more in the last 15 years than the last 40 years. I suspect it will change some more.

 Q. The N.C.A.A., particularly its director, Dick Schultz, wants players to be able to enter the draft, find out their market value, and then be able to return to school. If the N.C.A.A. allows this, what will you do?

 A. I've already told them what our reaction is and I think a lot of their coaches have told them what their reaction is, that this would be counterproductive from their standpoint. They are increasingly concerned about the college football player or the college basketball player dropping his studies and dropping out of school. I think this type of system would tremendously intensify the pressures for athletes to drop out.

 Q. Couldn't that eventually become your problem from a public relations standpoint?

 A. I think it could be. We would probably have to create developmental squads or feeder leagues or something to continue to work with the players to develop their skills and also continue to do what we're doing more intensively now, work with them to get their degrees.
 
League Economics

 Q: What are some of your concerns with regard to the economic health of the N.F.L. in the face of the escalating salaries in major league baseball?

 A: I think baseball has some serious problems. Fay Vincent said the Red Sox payroll would exceed the revenue of the Mariners. I don't think you can run a healthy league very long if you have that type of disparity.

 Q: How do you propose solving the problem for the N.F.L.?

 A: Some system that would guarantee the players a percentage of the revenue, whatever the revenue is, with a built-in cap so that your salaries and player cost would stay in some rough relationship to your revenue. I think that would be healthier for everybody.
We had looked at some numbers last year before the most recent escalation of baseball salaries and we were paying about 58 to 59 percent of our revenue to players. The N.B.A. was paying about 48 percent and baseball was paying somewhere around 40 percent, excluding the 10 percent for the support of the minor leagues. We're playing 60 players per team and the N.B.A. is only playing 12 or 13, so their salaries are going to escalate. The average salary per club for the N.B.A. this year is $12 million. Ours is about double that to about $24 million per club.

 Q: What are the other problems?

 A: One of them is the relationship of the big-market teams to the small- market teams. We have a problem, even though we share all our TV revenue equally. We still have some fairly unhealthy differences between our high-revenue teams and low-revenue teams. This year every team will be getting $28 million from the network telelvision contract. We have some teams that will be getting another $25 to $28 million on top of that. Those are the high-revenue teams. We have another group of teams that will have $13 to $15 million. Those are the low-revenue teams. We have a group of teams that have what I call supplemental income. That's a big problem, if you're trying design a system which guarantees players a percentage of revenue at a certain level.

 Q: How do you propose remedying that?

 A: There's going to have to be more cost sharing or more revenue sharing. The N.B.A. is doing it. They have a subsidy assistance program where the low-revenue teams can get a subsidy for some of those reasons.

 Q: Are N.F.L. teams going to go for this?

 A: If you have a cap I don't see it as a real concern. I think some people tend to think of our future system in terms of the current system. The one thing we've found in the last year is that these issues are extremely complicated because of the different revenues of the teams. Some clubs have been spending 70 percent of their revenue on players over the last decades. Other clubs have spent 35 to 40 percent. To take that range and force it to the midpoint is what a guaranteed cap system does.

 Q: If you were to put that before the owners tomorrow would it pass?

 A: I think it would be very close to a three-quarters vote in favor of the concept, but a lot of real and taxing questions on how do we get there and how do we make the transition. The details are critical.

 
 
Labor

 Q: Where does the N.F.L. stand at this point with regard to negotiating a collective bargaining agreement with the players?

 A: We've been able to keep open the lines of communication with the players and their representatives. It began as soon as I was elected. We had some conversations with Gene Upshaw back in November and those lines of communication continue to be open with our new labor relations representative, Harold Henderson. We are finally putting in place all the pieces that I think are needed to make some progress in that area.

 Q: What are the primary issues?

 A: The issues cover the whole gamut of what has to be put in place. What kind of salary system we have for entering players? What kind of salary system we have for the veteran players? And what type of a benefits package do you have? That whole question of how much money is negotiated individually by the players and how much is guaranteed as a collective benefits package is a major issue that has yet to be seriously discussed. We're spending more money than any sport on players as a percentage of our revenue. No one has sat down to conceptualize what's the most ideal way to spend it from the teams' standpoint and the players' standpoint.

 
 
The 1991 Season

 
Q. Will there be any changes in the media-access policy to avoid the Patriots and Bengals incidents of last year?

 A. The basic policy will be the same. Equal access to all accredited media will be guaranteed. We're working on some improvements to implement the policy. I think we'll eliminate some of the problems. We're talking about, while keeping the locker room open, we'll require the clubs to have better interview rooms. We're also focusing on just the physical environment of the locker room. The Saints have put in individualized curtains so that they'll have cubicles. It cost about $5,000. There are a number of things the clubs can do on their own.

Q. Did you get much public response?

 A. I don't know. I don't pay particular attention to what people think on the "Donahue" show.

Q. How are you considering improving the schedule?

 A. We've done some things for the first time I think will help. We're working with a computer consultant, and it has enabled us to deal with some of the problems we had last year: on spacing of games, and better spread of the games within divisions. Last year we had the Giants and Redskins play twice within a couple of weeks. We've been able to come up with a spread in the schedule that's better. There are literally tens of thousands of permutations it can make in a matter of seconds. It doesn't make the schedule, but it helps us. I've seen this year's computer printout, and there isn't one home-and-home series that's over within less than half a season. We had a lot of those last year. This year, every home-and-home series in every division is spread between the first half and second half. The closest anyone comes is the second week and the ninth week.

 
 
The 1990's

 
 Q. Is the league still considering experimenting with pay-per-view on a limited basis in 1992?

 A. At this point I'd have to say it's unlikely. Our major emphasis will be in making our current television contracts work. Our focus will be on improving scheduling and attracting advertisers.

 Q. Has the threat of Congressional investigation into your starting pay-per-view played a role in the decision to delay it?

 A. I don't think so. Once we explained to them that we were still going to have regular free television, and this would be in selected markets, they understood it.

 Q. What about pay-per-view in 1993?

 A. If we can do it without upsetting CBS and NBC.

 Q. Will the Super Bowl be on pay TV?

 A. As I said to Congress, not in this decade.

 Q. What are the possibilities of realignment among the present teams?

 A. I think there are three examples that come up. One is Tampa Bay-Miami. Another is Houston-Dallas. Another is Chicago-Indianapolis. You have tremendous geographical rivalries in college such as Michigan-Michigan State, and Florida-Florida State. If you start with that concept, a Tampa Bay-Miami rivalry would be a very attractive rivalry. Or a Colts-Bears rivalry. You could switch two teams. Take Tampa Bay out of the N.F.C. Central and put it in the A.F.C. East and move the Colts to the N.F.C. Central, and you've solved those two rivalries in a very simple way.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Tagliabue answering questions yesterday. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lawsuit Gain Aids Manville

 BODY:
The Manville Corporation reported yesterday that it netted $35 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter, up 41 percent from $24.9 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. But a one-time, $40 million gain from settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit accounted for all of its profits.
Operating income fell nearly 37 percent, to $41.6 million from $65.5 million a year ago. Revenues fell 4.3 percent, to $495.7 million for the quarter, compared with nearly $518 million a year ago. 
 Analysts said the Denver-based company had performed impressively given the impact of the recession on its key businesses and of Brazil's anti-inflation program on Manville's large forest products operations in that country. Manville makes building products, paperboard packaging and fiber glass for industrial applications and also has substantial mining operations.
"They almost broke even at a time when you would have expected them to get thrashed," said Chriss W. Street , an analyst with the Reorganized Securities Group in Los Angeles who has followed the company since its emergence from bankruptcy in 1988.
In February, Manville received $15 million in damages and $25 million in interest to settle a judgment against the Guardian Industries Corporation of Northville, Mich.
As part of its reorganization, Manville is to start paying a dividend next year equivalent to 20 percent of its profits to the trust fund set up to handle claims against the company by asbestos victims. The recent quarter was the first in which the company began accruing profits for such payments and, in accord with the definitions of income in the agreement, $8.1 million was set aside, according to yesterday's report.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Strong Gains On Positive Economic Signs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged on world currency markets yesterday amid a backdrop of positive news that hinted the United States economy might be ready to rebound from recession.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery declined $3.90 an ounce to settle at $357.90. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $357.50 an ounce, off $3.35 from Wednesday. 
 The dollar advanced in Europe and continued to climb in domestic markets.
Traders were initially encouraged that Germany's Bundesbank did not raise interest rates, as many traders had anticipated. A tightening of German credit would have enhanced the value of mark-denominated securities at the expense of United States fixed-income investments and thus the dollar.
Further, traders were encouraged by a United States Government report showing that initial jobless claims for the week ended April 6 fell 22,000, contrary to market expectations that they would rise.
Traders were also encouraged by a narrowing of the United States merchandise trade deficit, which shrunk to $5.33 billion in February, the smallest gap in more than seven years.
"This means the U.S. economy is moving more into balance," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA. "This combination of factors encouraged the market to test the upside of the dollar's trading range."
The dollar jumped against the German currency in New York trading to 1.7052 marks, from 1.6684 the day before.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar settled at 137.80 yen in New York, up from 136.19 yen on Wednesday. In earlier Tokyo trading, the dollar rose 1.30 yen to a closing 136.27 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 136.75 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7715, from $1.7835 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.7520 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7865.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4570 Swiss francs, up from 1.4225; 5.7615 French francs, up from 5.6430; 1,262.00 Italian lire, up from 1,237.00, and 1.1523 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1503.
Silver prices also lost ground. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.939 an ounce, down from $4.087 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why the Markets Are So Optimistic

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHAT'S going on? It's hard to remember a time of so much confusion on the state of the economy and the financial markets. These questions are being asked:
Q. The Dow has hit 3,000. But what is the basis for this optimism?
A. The expectation that the economy will soon turn up, but so gradually that inflation will come down, so the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates to support the recovery and keep the White House off its back.
Q. But isn't the Fed torn by internal dissension over whether to lower interest rates?
A. There are such conflicts, although some insiders insist they are exaggerated. David D. Hale, chief economist and chief Fed watcher of Kemper Financial Services, said: "Despite all the recent publicity about divisions within the Federal Open Market Committee about the role of the chairman in deciding when to lower interest rates, there is a general recognition that the economy is still weak, and policy remains asymmetrically biased toward ease."
Q. Does the Treasury see it that way? Wouldn't the Treasury like to see the Fed ease interest rates further and faster?
A. Yes it would. The Treasury has made no secret of its leaning on the Fed for greater ease, to help break the credit crunch.
Q. Is there a credit crunch?
A. Some economists insist that loans are off because of weak demand. But Deputy Secretary of the Treasury John Robson is certain there is a crunch. "I've gone around the country talking to many kinds of businessmen, and not just in the Northeast, and they tell me there's not enough credit available," he said in an interview yesterday. "They tell me there's a lack of willingness on the part of the banks to step in and lend or even renew credits already extended -- they're cutting people off in the middle of the movie."
Q. What is the cause of the crunch?
A. Mr. Robson said it has four causes: "The economic downturn and the deteriorated collateral of many borrowers; the weakened condition of the banks, now trying to strengthen their capital positions by stopping loans; the regulators, who are being too tough on the banks, and the Fed, still holding interest rates too high." He added: "Inflation is not the threat today. Growth is the issue."
Q. Do the regulators admit they are being too tough?
A. No. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of Thrift Supervision jointly issued a statement declaring: "We do not want the availability of credit to sound borrowers to be adversely affected by supervisory misunderstandings about them."
Q. With recovery ahead, can we breathe easily about the condition of the banks? Or could there be a replay of the savings and loan debacle?
A. Bank failures have been rising among smaller institutions, but the Administration and the General Accounting Office both support the "too big to fail" doctrine. The Administration says there is no comparability between the commercial banks and the savings and loans; it maintains that the banks are far better capitalized and are not riddled with fraud, as were many savings institutions.
The Administration believes that, with less regulation and new powers to expand across state lines and enter the insurance and securities businesses, the banks can safely expand. Its critics, led by the G.A.O., insist that the banks must first put their houses and balance sheets in order before they can be trusted to expand into new lines. But the Treasury's Mr. Robson blasts the regulators for "regulating with a chain saw."
Q. Has the stock market concluded that in any contest between the Administration and the regulators the Administration has the big guns and will win?"
A. So it seems. The Administration has made liquidating the recession its prime objective. Worsening labor market conditions in March and early April, declines in hours worked, continued weakness in retail spending, slipping housing starts, trims in business inventories, sluggish business plans to invest in new plant and equipment -- all these imply that the economy is still in recession.
The White House wants monetary policy to reinforce fiscal policy to lift the economy out of the slump. The budget deficit is projected to reach nearly $300 billion in the fiscal year 1991 and $290 billion in fiscal year 1992. Even for a non-Keynesian Administration, that ain't hay in the stimulus department.
But a two-year deficit of nearly $600 billion has the traditionalists on the Federal Open Market Committee worrying about inflation. Mr. Greenspan, the peace keeper, is trying to keep the Administration content, without facing an open revolt within the Fed. and without regenerating inflation. This week the stock market was betting it his way.

HEADLINE: New Jobless-Benefit Claims Drop for 2d Straight Week

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
New claims for unemployment benefits fell for the second consecutive week, the Labor Department said today.
Some economists said the report suggested the end of the recession was in sight. But others said it was too soon to tell, adding that next week's jobless claims would be a critical number to watch. 
 The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing for inital unemployment benefits dropped 22,000, to a seasonally adjusted 451,000, in the first week of April.
The previous week, claims dropped by 70,000, to 473,000, after soaring to the highest level in more than eight years, the department said.
"I'm inclined to interpret the number as one of the first palpable signs of the recovery," said Fred Sturm, senior economist at Fuji Securities Inc. "The weekly jobless claims could fall below 400,000 in short order."
Evelina Tainer, an economist at First National Bank of Chicago, said the nation's two previous recessions followed a similar pattern in which jobless claims peaked about six to eight weeks before the economy began to turn around.
"If you apply similar behavior to this cycle, it suggests we'll get a recovery in late May or early June," she said.
Despite the decline in initial weekly claims, the number actually receiving benefits under regular state unemployment programs jumped 183,000, to 3.5 million, for the week ended March 30, the latest period for which that figure was available.
Economists said they expected that rise because continued claims typically lagged behind the initial unemployment claim number.
But some economists said that the weekly jobless claims were a volatile number and that this week's fall could have been helped by the Easter holiday week.

HEADLINE: Cholera Kills 1,100 in Peru and Marches On, Reaching the Brazilian Border

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18

 BODY:
A fast-moving cholera epidemic that has killed 1,100 Peruvians and sickened 150,000 since January has spread to Ecuador and Colombia. Isolated cases have been reported in Chile and the United States, but perhaps the greatest concern is for Brazil, Latin America's most populous nation.
"It's gigantic," said Myron M. Levine, an American epidemiologist who has studied cholera epidemics in Asia and Africa over the last 20 years. "It's really a big epidemic." 
 In the first major outbreak in the Americas in this century, cholera has found in South America a population that has little natural resistance and is highly vulnerable because of a widespread lack of clean drinking water and proper sewage disposal.
The results can be seen in the crowded cholera wards of the state-run Dos de Mayo Hospital in Lima, the Peruvian capital. Earlier this month, cholera admissions hit 162 a day, going off the upper edge of a blackboard chart maintained by the hospital director.
 
A Fateful Cup of Tea
 "I bought a cup of herbal tea from a street vendor, and an hour later I was throwing up," said Oscar Clemente Paredes Rosales, interviewed in his hospital bed as an overhead serum bottle dripped dextrose solution into his right arm. Mr. Paredes, a 33-year-old truck driver, lay in a former women's ward recently relabeled "Cholera II" by a hurried staff member.
His wife, Maria Elena, said, "Two people on our block died of cholera." Residents of their shantytown neighborhood draw water from a communal well.
Disease control experts are largely at a loss to explain why cholera has returned to South America in the first epidemic since 1895. In the 1970's, the disease spread from West Africa down to Angola, a former Portuguese colony. Epidemiologists expected it to jump across the South Atlantic to Portuguese-speaking Brazil, but the South American epidemic never happened.
Spread largely by contact with human feces, the cholera bacillus can kill a person in 10 hours. Through vomiting and diarrhea, infected people can lose 10 percent of their weight in one night. The disease is easily treated with rehydration salts and intravenous solutions, but in remote areas many Peruvians are 10 hours from an adequately supplied health clinic.
The speed and destructiveness of the disease in Peru is a reflection of the explosion of the urban poor there. From a city of one million people in the 1950's, Lima has grown to seven million people, about one third of Peru's population.
With terrorism, hyperinflation and foreign debt obligations causing the economy to shrink in recent years, the city government can barely maintain existing water and sewer systems, much less expand the network of pipes to half of the city that now does without.
Cholera bacteria spread in February to neighboring Ecuador. With the disease now present in half of Ecuador's 21 provinces, health officials there say that 3,500 people have fallen ill with cholera and 18 have died. The Ecuadorean Medical Federation, a private group, says the real toll is 5,000 ill and over 100 dead.
In March, the epidemic moved up the Pacific coast to Colombia, reaching two ports, then jumped 450 miles inland to the Amazon territory of Guaviare. So far, 113 Colombians have fallen ill, and 2 have died.
This week, one confirmed case was reported in Santiago, Chile. In the United States, one confirmed case of cholera and two suspected cases have been linked the Peru outbreak.
Epidemiologists interviewed here said they saw no reason why the disease should not continue to spread, hitting Brazil and Central America.
 
Disease's Route Is 'Guesswork'
 "There is no mechanism to avoid that it goes to other countries," said Carlos M. Cuneo, an Argentine sanitation expert who represents the Pan American Health Organization here.
Dr. Levine, who works for the University of Maryland School of Medicine, cautioned, "It's pure guesswork as to where it is going."
Today, Brazilians' fears materialized after Brazil's Health Ministry reported one confirmed case and three suspected cases in Tabatinga and Benjamin Constant, Amazon border towns that trade heavily with Colombia and Peru.
The nightmare for Brazilian doctors, who have flocked to Lima recently on study missions, is that the epidemic will spread through the Amazon to the slums of Brazil's overcrowded coastal cities. Many health authorities fear that in the warm, unsanitary slums of Brazil and Peru, cholera could become endemic, recurring year after year as it does in India and Bangladesh.
About 20 percent of cholera victims need hospitalization. With the Health Ministry in Lima reporting 147,980 cases, 600,000 additional Peruvians are, or have been, "healthy carriers" -- people who are infected but show no symptoms. With many hospital workers on strike in April, cases are believed to be underreported by as much as 10 percent.
In general, experts praise Peru's doctors for keeping the death rate at under 1 percent, well below the 8 percent average for cholera epidemics in Bangladesh. On the other hand, the experts have criticized Peru's political leadership for seeking to minimize the epidemic to reduce its impact on Peru's food and tourism industries.
"The public information campaign was a disaster," said Uriel Garcia Caceres, a medical doctor who served as Peru's Health Minister in the early 1980's.
Evidently under pressure from Peru's powerful fishing industry, President Alberto K. Fujimori, his wife, Susana, and his ministers of fisheries and of agriculture went on television eating ceviche, a dish prepared by marinating raw fish in lemon juice. Trying to revive tourism, the President also played host to 20 foreign correspondents for a lunch of ceviche and sashimi at a beachfront restaurant.
Within days, hospital admissions for cholera soared. One patient reportedly was the Fisheries Minister, Felix Canal, who spent a week in a military hospital. Through a spokesman, the minister denied that he had fallen ill with cholera, saying he had a bad case of laryngitis.
 
'Ceviche War' Breaks Out
 In what became known as the "ceviche war," Health Minister Carlos Vidal Layseca resigned in mid-March, charging, "There is one ceviche for the rich, and another ceviche for the poor."
With confusing messages coming from the authorities, the epidemic took on a second life during the Easter Week holiday here, when people traditionally eat fish and travel through the country visiting relatives.
In March the epidemic took root in the central Andes, and in April it started to descend into Peru's Amazon. In Iquitos, the largest Amazon city, there have been 418 cases and 18 deaths.
 
U.S. Case Linked to Peru
 In the United States, one case of cholera has been traced to the epidemic in Peru, the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said. An American physician visiting Lima contracted the disease this month after eating undercooked crabmeat and drinking contaminated water. Two cases of severe diarrhea in Miami among people who recently visited South America are being investigated by the centers, but cholera has not been confirmed.
"I would not be surprised to see a number of cases of cholera in Americans traveling to South America, but I don't expect really large numbers," said Dr. Paul Blake, an epidemiologist at the centers.
He said travelers should not drink untreated water and should eat cooked foods while they are still hot. Ice cubes should also be avoided.
"It is very unlikely that cholera will reach epidemic proportions in the United States," Dr. Blake said, "because although our water and sewer systems are not perfect, they are good enough to make us unreceptive to mass transmission of the disease."

A cholera patient was taken into the emergency room at Dos de Mayo Hospital in Lima, where cholera admissions have climbed to as many as 162 a day. (Vera Lentz for The New York Times)
