HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Tumble

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Suggestions that the steady rise in unemployment may be slowing and a press report that the Federal Reserve Board decided last month to stop easing monetary policy sent prices of Treasury securities down sharply yesterday.
The report on the Fed appeared in The Washington Post yesterday. 
 "That got the market jittery," one trader said, "and when the claims numbers came out, that was the catalyst to sell."
The Labor Department reported that initial unemployment claims fell by 22,000, to 451,000, in the first week in April. It was the second straight week that initial claims figures, a statistic that is often an accurate indicator of movement in the unemployment rate reported each month, had declined.
"I am not going to try to over-analyze these numbers," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "But if they stay down at these levels for another couple of weeks, we may have something."
Although traders reacted to The Washington Post article by selling short-term securities like Treasury bills, analysts said the report added little to recently published reports suggesting that Fed governors are divided over the future course of monetary policy.
The analysts added that the Fed's recent actions made it plain that for the moment the Fed has no plans to ease monetary policy.
"The Fed's actions on Monday made it obvious that they had voted against ease," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But it could just as easily be true that if the next set of economic data are weak, the Fed will ease policy again. I am a little surprised that the market reacted the way it did."
 
Bank Reserves Drained
 On Monday, the Fed doused expectations that it was about to lower short-term interest rates when it entered the open market for Treasury securities an hour earlier than normal and drained reserves from the banking system by selling Treasury issues.
Once the Fed took that step, most analysts said the Fed was unlikely to revisit the issue of whether to cut its discount rate and the overnight Federal funds rate until the middle of May. By then, the Government will have delivered reports on how employment conditions and important inflation measurements fared in April.
"I doubt very much they will do much before the next meeting of the Open Market Committee, which is on May 14," Mr. Liro said. "If we get a set of numbers that match the ones we saw from March, a development I expect, I would think the Fed would take another pop."
Market participants were nevertheless fairly big sellers of Treasury issues yesterday.
By late in the day, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 21/32, down 25/32, to yield 8.17 percent, up from 8.10 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 6/32, down 15/32, to yield 8.01 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 10/32, down 5/32, to yield 6.94 percent.
With the prospect of a quick move by the Fed to lower short-term rates all but obliterated, Treasury bill rates, which had declined in anticipation of such a move last week, rose sharply.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.70 percent, up 16 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.71 percent.
In other developments, the the RJR Nabisco Capital Corporation priced and sold a $1.5 billion offering of seven-year senior notes in the high-yield "junk bond" market.
The size of the offering was twice what had initially been projected, but investment bankers at Merrill Lynch & Company, one of the lead underwriters, said demand for the issue was so strong that it was oversubscribed at the $1.5 billion level.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended April 8. M-1, the narrowest measure, fell by $10 billion.
The money supply report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Narrows to 7-Year Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Paced by a big drop in the bill for imported oil, the nation's trade deficit shriveled to $5.3 billion in February, the smallest in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.
Although exports fell slightly, imports fell three times as much to chop the deficit -- the amount by which the country's purchases of foreign goods exceed its sales abroad -- by $1.8 billion, or 26 percent. 
 Private economists joined the Bush Administration in hailing the improvement, even though the report did little to dispel uncertainty about when the economy would begin to pull out of recession. Trade figures not only move erratically but are also reported with a greater lag than most indicators.
 
'Very Satisfying' Numbers
 "These numbers are very satisfying," said James Annable, chief economist for the First National Bank of Chicago. "We're reducing imports and that's what ought to happen" in recession, he said, adding that exports remained relatively strong.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher issued a statement that while oil was a major factor in the improvement -- accounting for about 60 percent of the reduction in the gap and 40 percent of the decline in imports -- "continued high levels of exports reflect favorable longer-run developments" in support of economic growth.
The trade sector has clearly been cushoning the recession, Mr. Annable also declared, noting that without trade improvement, the gross national product would have fallen at a 5 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter of 1990 instead of the 1.6 percent decline that was recorded with it. The Government's first estimate of first-quarter G.N.P. is to be published next Friday.
 
Analysts Begin to Fret
 Some analysts, however, are beginning to fret about what may be a softening in exports, which are being counted on to help revive the economy later this year.
They noted that, on a three-month moving average, exports fell for the second straight month in February, to $33.7 billion, after climbing to a peak of $34.2 billion in December.
"Growth in exports has really been flattening out," said Jeffrey J. Schott, a research fellow at the Institute of International Economics. He noted that not only was growth slowing abroad but that the dollar was also rising in world currency markets, factors that would tend to inhibit future export sales.
Rimmer de Vries, chief economist for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said that while he was generally encouraged by converging trends in trade -- shrinkage both in German and other European surpluses and in American deficits --the United States should not count on selling increased amounts of goods overseas.
"We are not going to have robust exports," Mr. de Vries declared.
The $800 million decline in February exports, to $33.5 billion, included an $800 million drop in capital goods and a $600 million decline in motor vehicles, parts and engines. This was partly offset by a $500 million increase in exports of foods, feeds and beverages and a $300 million increase in industrial supplies and materials.
The import drop of $2.6 billion included a $1.9 billion drop in industrial supplies and materials -- $1.1 billion of which represented smaller volumes and lower prices for imported oil. The country bought 153 million barrels at an average of $18.58 each in February, down from 170 million barrels at $22.98 in January.
 
Big Drop in Car Imports
 Imports also included a $500 million decline for motor vehicles, with about 10 percent of the decrease coming in new cars from Japan.
Oil accounted for some 53 percent of the February deficit, down from 55 percent the month before, the figures also showed.
By geographical area, the nation's trade surpluses with Western Europe and Eastern Europe widened in February by $250 million and $200 million, respectively, while its deficit with Japan narrowed by $300 million, to $3.2 billion. The deficit with Canada, the biggest single trading partner, widened $30 million.
The American position improved against all four of the newly industrialized countries of the Far East, with the aggregate deficit cut almost in half to $560 million. The United States swung into surplus with both South Korea and Singapore and cut the deficit with Hong Kong to $25 million. The deficit with Taiwan contracted nearly $200 million, to $675 million.
The nation's trade surplus in advanced technology products, however, eroded $800 million, to $2.4 billion, with lower exports accounting for more than half the deterioration. For the first two months of 1991, exports of these important products are barely ahead of the comparable period of last year -- $14.7 billion against $14.6 billion, the report showed.
Before seasonal adjustment, the overall deficit last month was $4.5 billion, a 36 percent improvement, compared with the 26 percent improvement in the deficit when adjusted for recurring seasonal factors.
On a three-month average, the deficit fell to $6.3 billion at latest reading from $7.5 billion in January.
The $5.3 billion February deficit was the smallest since September 1983 and was just below the gap for last June, which had previously been revised. In constant 1987 dollars, the gap was $4.4 billion, down from $5.3 billion the month before and from $6.1 billion in February 1990.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
American Express Reports $264 Million Quarterly Profit

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Hurt by a deteriorating economy and a falloff in travel, the American Express Company yesterday reported earnings of $264 million, or 55 cents a share, for the quarter just ended. The company lost $620 million in the first quarter of 1990, reflecting record losses at Shearson Lehman Hutton, its brokerage unit that is now called Shearson Lehman Brothers.
The company's quarterly revenues were up 6.4 percent, to $6.29 billion, from $5.91 billion. 
 In a sign of its difficulties, American Express said it was adding $50 million to provisions for credit problems in its Travel Related Services unit, the heart of the company, which manages its familiar charge card.
"American Express serves the affluent part of the American economy, and it looks like the affluent are really in recession now," said John Keefe, an analyst with the Lipper Analytical Securities Corporation.
To combat falling revenues from its charge-card business, American Express is planning to lower the rates paid by restaurants that accept the card, people who have been briefed on the company's plan said yesterday. The cut, expected to be announced by the company this quarter, would be available only to restaurants that report charges to the company through new electronic systems instead of the traditional paper slips. Consumers will still receive paper receipts.
Analysts also said the performance of Shearson was also relatively poor, given increased activity by individual investors. But both IDS Financial Services -- which sells mutual funds, investment certificates, life insurance and other financial products -- and the Information Services Corporation data-processing unit had record quarterly earnings.
American Express's share price ended yesterday at $29.25, off 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Travel Related Services reported income down 24.7 percent, to $162 million from $215 million.
James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of the company, blamed the division's performance on the Persian Gulf conflict and a domestic slowdown. "Travel and tourism were severely disrupted by the war," Mr. Robinson said, "and the recession took a toll on consumer spending. "Rising unemployment pushed up credit losses."
 
Increase in Unpaid Debts
 The company said rising unemployment, business failures and personal bankruptcies increased unpaid debts at the Travel Related Services division, leading to the increased credit provisions. The unit's quarterly revenues of $2.4 billion rose 7.3 percent from last year, primarily because of higher revenues from finance charges on the company's Optima cards and consumer lending.
The company said it expected weak consumer spending and other factors to leave the travel unit lagging "below traditional growth rates."
Shearson earned $51 million in the first quarter, compared with a quarterly loss of $915 million last year. The investment firm's revenues were $2.8 billion, up from $2.6 billion a year ago. The firm's total expenses were $2.7 billion, unchanged from a year ago; its fixed expenses fell to $620 million, from $710 million.
American Express reported that its IDS Financial Services division had record earnings in the quarter of $51 million, up 18 percent from the first quarter of 1990. The unit's assets under management reached $32 billion, compared with $27 billion in the first quarter of last year.
The company's Information Services Corporation earned a record $25 million, an increase of 17 percent over the first quarter of 1990.

HEADLINE: In New York City, Altering School Aid Insures a Fight

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Any effort by President Bush to change the formula for allocating Federal aid to poor students -- known as Chapter 1 funds -- is sure to inflame passions in New York City.
For one thing, the program is a major source of educational financing -- $334 million out of a $6.5 billion budget. It pays for many, if not most, of the city's remedial English and mathematics teachers, as well as many of its bilingual teachers, guidance counselors and paraprofessionals. It also pays for a summer program for elementary school students. 
 Every school wants a piece of the pie, and so the formula has been a perennial subject of debate. In recent years, advocates for the poor have argued that the money has been spread too thin and has ended up helping poor students in largely middle-class schools when it should be concentrated in the schools with the most needy students.
A compromise was fashioned last year, somewhat narrowing the number of schools that receive Chapter 1 aid. But many advocates are still not satisfied. Chapter 1 money is allocated to individual schools that qualify. In New York City, 626 out of its 984 schools receive such money.
At a news conference yesterday, the Secretary of Education, Lamar Alexander, said he would introduce legislation to enable Chapter 1 money to follow a poor child if the child transferred to another school, even if it was a private or parochial one. He said this would be part of his plan to give parents greater choice over their children's schools.
A proposal to let Federal dollars follow students to private schools could strip the city's school system of substantial funds at a time when it is already reeling under proposed cuts of $505 million in state and city money.
"Of course we would oppose it," said James S. Vlasto, press secretary to the city's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, referring to such a plan.
 
A Free-Lunch Standard
 Mr. Vlasto said that at present, any school can receive Chapter 1 money if 54.1 percent of its students qualify for a free lunch or receive welfare payments under the Aid for Dependent Children program. The money must be spent only on classes and services for children who qualify unless a school's poverty rate exceeds 75 percent. In that case, the school can spend the money on programs for all its children.
David Jones, president of the Community Service Society, an advocacy group for the poor, said he would oppose any effort to have money follow individual children, particularly to private schools. He argued that money must be targeted at the worst concentrations of poverty so it can help attack problems like unemployment and family disruption that seem to spread throughout a community.
"There's a real potential to siphon off money from school districts that are already suffering extraordinary problems," he said. "I have a million children in the public school system, and sure I want a couple to end up at Choate. But that doesn't deal with the hundreds of thousands of children in the South Bronx."

HEADLINE: For Unions, Small Gain and New Worries in Rail Strike

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
President Bush wanted the Democratic leadership of Congress to stop the railroad strike before it began. The leadership, honoring organized labor's right to strike, refused.
 But for labor, it was the slimmest and least satisfying of victories. Congress stopped the strike Wednesday night after just one day, while the paint was still wet on the picket signs and before the unions could force concessions from management. 
 "We prefer that Congress not get into the picture and let us fight it out," said Richard I. Kilroy, president of the Transportation Communications Union and chairman of the Railroad Labor Executives Association, a lobbying group of union leaders. "It didn't happen, but it was not totally unexpected."
Since President Ronald Reagan's first term, support of organized labor in Congress, not just the White House, has eroded, and the abbreviated strike against the nation's freight railroads demonstrates it anew.
 
Labor Unhappy Over New Board
 Congress stopped the strike, but it did not settle it. It created a special three-member board and empowered President Bush to appoint the members from a list recommended by the nonpartisan National Mediation Board. The new board will take over from a Presidential emergency board, which in January recommended solutions to the disputes that have divided the railroads and their workers for three years and in some cases longer. After hearing their differences, the new board is to impose a settlement in 65 days.
What galls labor is that the new board must use the recommendations of the old board as the guidelines for the settlement. The unions contended that the old board's recommendations were tilted toward management. While railroad officials said they had wanted more than they got from the old board, they were clearly happier with the recommendations than labor was.
Unions today refrained from blaming Congress directly for the rules it set for the board or for moving so quickly to stop the strike. The locomotive engineers union charged that management created unnecessary public anxiety about the strike by stopping Amtrak's passenger service on long-distance lines. Such management action and White House collaboration left Congress no choice but to act, union leaders said. "We believe that Congress all along wanted, as we did, a negotiated settlement, but management would not allow it," said Larry D. McFather, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.
Mac A. Fleming, president of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, called the legislation stopping the strike "vastly disappointing and unfair."
 
Strikes Hold Big Risks
 "It is a process which the railroads have been able to manipulate in order to drive what should be our private collective bargaining issues into the public lap of Congress," Mr. Fleming said.
Congress or the White House almost always intervenes in large railroad strikes because of the risks they can pose for the economy in halting as much as 37 percent of all freight transportation.
"The argument that the strike would have been extremely harmful to the economy is pretty self-evident," said Representative Al Swift, a Washington Democrat who is chairman of the House subcommittee that prepared the legislation to end the strike. "That was a driving force behind it."
But a reason they were able to move fast is that organized labor's influence over Congress has diminished, as the share of Americans who are union members has declined, to 16 percent now from about 25 percent in the 1950's.
"I consider myself to be a representative of the blue-collar workers of America," said Representative Jim Slattery, a Kansas Democrat who is a member of the House subcommittee that wrote the bill to stop the strike.
 
Decline of Labor's Power
 "But there are two basic factors to keep in mind," he said. "One is that the number of workers who are members of labor unions has dramatically declined. In many Congressional districts there are more small businessmen and women than there are members of labor unions.
"Second, in the last ten years, with the emergence of political action committees, the Democratic Party is less dependent on the contributions of organized labor than it was 15 years ago."
Mr. Slattery also noted that he could not ignore the interests of the struck railroad that plies the Kansas cornfields, the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe. "Forty percent of the Santa Fe's business is sensitive to truck competition," he said, and in a strike that business, and the railroad's jobs, could be permanently lost.
Off the record, other Democrats cite another reason for moving quickly -- the 1992 election. They hope the economy and the Republicans' management of it will give them a winning issue. "But if we have permitted a big strike the President could blame us for the damage to the economy," said a Democrat who was involved in the negotiations about the legislation. "We want to avoid falling into that trap," he said.
 
Rail Strikes Are Different
 Railroad strikes, like strikes by police officers and hospital workers, are different from other strikes because of their effect on uninvolved people, so Government intervention is often necessary. President Bush refused a Congressional request to intervene in another strike, the one that ultimately helped bring the collapse of Eastern Airlines, in part because people could use other airlines.
With the railroad strike stopped, organized labor can look to another big issue for a test of Congressional loyalty. The top item on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s legislative agenda this year is a bill to stop employers from permanently hiring people to replace strikers, leaving the workers on the street even after the end of a strike.
That practice, used by companies like Eastern Airlines, Greyhound Lines and the International Paper Company, terrifies unions because it deprives them of their mightiest weapon, the strike, in much the same way that Congress's intervention in the railroad walkout did.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: JAPAN-SOVIET PACT ON ISLANDS ELUSIVE

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 19

 BODY:
In marathon negotiations that churned until nearly midnight, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan failed on Thursday to resolve a territorial dispute dividing their countries since World War II.
The two leaders finished their three days of talks with praise for each other's sincerity, pledges that progress might be made in the future, and promises of future cooperation -- but nothing near the breakthrough which Mr. Kaifu, at least, had said he sought. 
 The two leaders concluded their meetings by signing 15 agreements on subjects ranging from trade fairs, establishment of cultural centers, air rights, fishery accords and other minor matters. Conspicuous by its absence was any talk of large-scale Japanese economic cooperation.
Mr. Gorbachev did make a few small concessions on the issue of a group of islands in the Kurile chain north of Japan. He formally agreed that the islands, which the Soviet Union seized in the closing days of World War II, were a proper subject of accelerated talks.
In addition, the Soviet leader agreed to reduce military forces on the islands, estimated by Japan at about 10,000 troops, and to recognize indirectly Japan's claim to the smallest islands in the group.
But basically, the leaders of two of the most powerful countries in the world showed themselves unable to muster the political strength to untangle a disagreement over a microscopic bit of territory of negligible strategic value to either country.
Their disagreement meant that Tokyo and Moscow would continue to stay at odds in spite of the "new world order" hailed in Washington. Mr. Gorbachev was seen as unable to compromise because of fears of encouraging secessionism or angering the military.
 
Ties to Moscow
 Mr. Kaifu, on the other hand, faces overwhelming support in Japan for getting the islands back, underscored by a lack of popular urgency for improving ties with Moscow. Especially eager to get the islands are rightists who are a vital constituency of the governing Liberal Democratic Party.
Early this morning, both leaders held separate news conferences declaring they had deepened their mutual understanding but admitting they had a long way to go before they could sign a peace treaty or contemplate major Japanese economic aid and investment in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gorbachev, sounding restrained and somewhat frustrated, said he was "quite satisfied at the effort that has been done here" but that "everything is still ahead of us."
 
Obscure Issue, Big Effort
 The Soviet leader also noted that he and Mr. Kaifu had spent 12 hours face-to-face since his arrival Tuesday, most of it on the territorial issue, and that he could not remember any negotiation so arduous and extensive on such a technically obscure topic.
Mr. Kaifu and Japanese officials sought at their briefings to make the point that in small ways, the Soviet Union had moved away from its earlier intransigence in insisting on retaining sovereignty over three islands and a group of islets north of Japan seized by Moscow at the end of World War II.
In particular, Mr. Kaifu said it was significant that a joint statement by the two leaders referred specifically to all the islands -- Etorofu, Kunashiri, Shikotan and the Habomai group of islets -- as a subject for negotiation.
Moreover, the Soviet Union agreed to a favorable reference in the joint statement to a 1956 accord between the Moscow and Tokyo that recognized Japan's sovereignty over Shikotan and the Habomai group. Moscow later rescinded this view when Japan signed a security treaty with the United States.
"I believe that the reference to these matters is itself a matter of achievement," Mr. Kaifu told reporters this morning. "Names that had never been printed before were recognized as an issue that does exist."
But before the meeting had began, many Japanese diplomats said that if the entire current exercise had simply reiterated the old 1956 accord, the meetings themselves could not be considered a success.
 
Assertion of Progress
 A Foreign Ministry official, asked if Japan was disappointed, replied: "I don't think there is disappointment because the problem is very clearly identified. And what has become clear is that President Gorbachev is indeed very seriously trying to grapple with this issue."
Mr. Gorbachev was supposed to have seen more of Tokyo today, but instead he canceled his public appearances and worked through most of the day at the State Guest House.
Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, are scheduled to wind up their visit to Japan today with a ride on the bullet train to the western city of Kyoto. Then the Soviet leader is to fly to Nagasaki to visit graves of Russian sailors.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
3 of 4 Bell Companies Post Drop in Earnings

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Four more regional telephone companies of the eight created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 reported first-quarter earnings yesterday suggesting that the recession had stunted their growth. The reports were in line with the trend established earlier in the week.
The Nynex Corporation, which serves New York and the New England states, was the hardest hit. Net income slipped 7.5 percent, disappointing analysts, and revenue was up only because of rate increases. 
 The Bell Atlantic Corporation, which serves the Atlantic coast states from New Jersey to Virginia along with West Virginia, was the only one of the four companies whose earnings, which dipped a bit, were in line with Wall Street projections.
The BellSouth Corporation, which serves nine Southeastern states, said its net income declined 4.9 percent, more than forecast, under pricing pressure from regulators and because of acquisition costs. U S West Inc., which serves 14 states from the Northwest to Minnesota and down to Arizona, said that its net income rose 5.1 percent because of gains in its non-telephone businesses. That was at the lower end of analysts' projections.
"It's more of what we saw in the fourth quarter 1990 earnings," said Jack Grubman, who follows the phone companies for Paine Webber. "They are more sensitive to the economy than people thought before then."
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Bell Atlantic
Bell Atlantic said that it had a net income in the first quarter of $353.6 million, a shade lower than the $355.3 million it earned a year ago. Earnings per share edged up 1 cent, to 91 cents, because of an accounting technicality related to dividends paid to shares held in the company's employee stock ownership plan. Revenues for the quarter were also essentially flat at $3 billion, compared with $3.02 billion a year ago.
The Philadelphia-based company said new Federal price cap regulations reduced income by $45 million. Bell Atlantic's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $49, in trading on the Big Board.
 
BellSouth
BellSouth said that its net income declined 4.9 percent in the quarter, to $402.3 million, or 83 cents a share, from $423.2 million, or 88 cents a share, a year ago, partly because of regulatory changes that would continue to affect earnings throughout 1991.
The company said that the Federal price cap rules shaved $14 million from its revenue in the quarter, while rate reductions ordered in Georgia, Tennessee, and Mississippi reduced revenue by $42 million. The company's share price fell 87.5 cents, to finish at $51.25, in trading on the Big Board yesterday.
 
U S West
U S West said that net income grew 5.1 percent, to $285.9 million in the first quarter, from $271.9 million a year ago. However, earnings per share were unchanged at 73 cents because the number of shares outstanding increased by 16.1 million. Revenues rose nearly 1 percent, to $2.45 billion, from $2.43 billion a year ago.
"Revenue from our telephone operations was essentially flat," said Richard McCormick, president and chief executive, citing rate reductions. But cellular and paging business grew strongly.
The company's share price finished unchanged, at $37.875, in trading on the Big Board.
 
Nynex
Nynex reported net income fell to $269.5 million, or $1.34 a share, from $291.4 million, or $1.46 a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 1.2 percent, to $3.36 billion, from $3.32 billion in the first three months of 1990.
Nynex said that the recession was especially tough on its telecommunications businesses, including New York Telephone, New England Telephone, and on its cellular operations. Operating income for the telephone companies declined 2.9 percent, to $607.1 million, from $625.5 million a year ago. Revenues were flat at $2.7 billion and would have declined 2 percent, if rate increases had not been allowed by New York State.
Nynex, which is based in White Plains, was the only Bell company to report a decline in cellular income, which fell 38.8 percent, to $9.3 million, from $15.2 million a year ago. The number of cellular customers grew 16.7 percent but use expanded only 4.1 percent, reflecting a sharp drop in use per customer.
Nynex's share price fell 37.5 cents, to close at $73.25 in trading on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Poles Get $2.48 Billion More In Loans From the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund today approved an additional $2.48 billion in loans for Poland over the next three years. The decision coincided with concern at the agency that Eastern Europe's economic problems are more severe and less tractable than initially thought.
The region's economies are shrinking faster than predicted, inflation has stayed high and little foreign investment has materialized, I.M.F. officials said. Trade within the region, which was expected to fall sharply, has plunged. And a shortage of functioning banks and other financial institutions is making it difficult for private businesses to replace inefficient, state-owned monopolies, they said. 
 As a result, it will take two or more years before the economies of Eastern Europe even regain the size they had at the beginning of last year, said an I.M.F. official, who, like other officials, spoke on condition that he not be identified. He said the fund remained convinced that the region needs radical programs to replace central planning with markets.
 
'Comprehensive Approach' Urged
 "You do need to have a comprehensive approach, what has been called a 'big bang"' he said. "Piecemeal reform does not work."
The Polish package would bring the loans approved by the I.M.F. since the beginning of the year to a total of $8.4 billion for Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania.
Poland suffered one of the worst setbacks last year, as total economic output, adjusted for inflation, dropped 12 percent, I.M.F. officials said.
The Polish loan package includes $1.66 billion to help pay for changes in the economic structure, $220 million to cover the higher cost of oil since last September, and $600 million to pay for oil imports during future periods of high oil prices.
The Polish Government agreed in turn to limit its budget deficit and the expansion of credit, reduce inflation with a target of 1 percent a month later this year and to keep interest rates higher than the inflation rate.
"We have agreed on the program, and we had expected it to be approved because there were not many controversial things," said a Polish official who insisted on anonymity.
The agreement followed by a month the decision of the Paris Club, a group of Western creditor governments, to forgive half of Poland's $33 billion official debt, and Washington's decision to forgive 70 percent of the $3.8 billion debt owed to the United States. Those moves, however, were contingent on Poland's reaching an agreement with the I.M.F.
The I.M.F. approved a $700 million loan last year for Poland, but much of the money was never disbursed because inflation was 17 percent in the fourth quarter, which exceeded the I.M.F.'s target.
William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, said the drastic steps Poland had already taken to reduce Government control over the economy were making it easier for the country to obtain loans. "It's pretty clear they've taken forceful, aggressive measures," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Global Oil Giants Expected to Surge

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
BIG international oil companies, including Exxon, Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell, are expected to report a surge in first-quarter profits next week, but analysts say others that operate mainly in North America are likely to be less fortunate. ARCO and Unocal, among others, will probably post modest declines, they said.
Unlike the last three months of 1990, when war fears pushed crude prices up to an average near $30 a barrel and oil production units posted big earnings gains, profits in the exploration and production sector will probably be little changed for the first quarter from a year earlier. Oil producers received about $21 a barrel for their crude oil in the quarter, about the same as a year earlier. 
 But the Persian Gulf war's indirect impact on the global oil giants was potent because of the huge orders that Saudi officials placed with refiners to stockpile jet fuel, gasoline and other critical petroleum products before and during the war against Iraq, analysts said.
They project that overall profit gains for the big international companies will average more than 40 percent, mainly because their refining and marketing units in Europe, Singapore and Asia reaped a bonanza from military purchases.
Weather was also a factor, with colder temperatures gripping Europe, in contrast to a remarkably mild winter in most of the United States. The weather added to a run-up in natural gas prices that was already under way in Europe. Natural gas demand and prices plunged in the United States because of the warmer weather. Market values for global oil companies have increased nearly as much as the Standard & Poor's industrial index, which has risen 20 percent this year. From Jan. 1 through Wednesday, Exxon was up by 16 percent, Mobil by 17 percent and Texaco by 14 percent on the Big Board. Meanwhile, the stocks of ARCO and Unocal, both domestic refiners, were up by 7 percent apiece.
Fareed Mohamedi, senior economist at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm, said the Saudis had accumulated at least 300,000 barrels of jet fuel for an air campaign projected to last three months against Iraq and gasoline supplies to keep tanks and other vehicles operating for a monthlong ground war.
Saudi orders pushed the profit margins for the big oil companies' refineries in Singapore above $20 for the equivalent of a barrel of gasoline, jet fuel or other petroleum products, compared with margins of about $2 a barrel before the gulf crisis erupted last August. At that time, Kuwait supplied about 4 percent of the world's refined crude products.
Michael Mayer, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, in San Francisco, said some refining and marketing units posted staggering profit margins in Europe, Japan and the Middle East and could set records for operating income in those sectors for Exxon, Mobil and Texaco.
In his view, Exxon's profits from all global operations will rise 44 percent, to $1.40 a share, from 97 cents in last year's first quarter. Mobil's operating income will jump by 63 percent, to $1.63 from $1.01, and Texaco's by 35 percent, to $1.55 from $1.15, he said.
George F. Friesen, an analyst at the Deutsche Bank Group, was even more bullish on Exxon and Mobil, putting Exxon's increase at 55 percent, and Mobil's at 68 percent. Exxon sold far more refined products in Europe than in the United States last year. Combined sales in Europe and Asia provided 55 percent of its total revenues.
Mobil, with several refineries in France, Germany, the Britain, Singapore, Japan and Australia, also sells more fuels in Europe and Asia than in the United States. Mr. Friesen projected that the profits of two other big suppliers for Europe and Asia, Royal Dutch/Shell and British Petroleum, would rise by 54 percent and 50 percent, respectively.
"The higher profits had to be expected," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an energy specialist at the Institute for International Economics, in Washington. "It's just the ordinary functioning of the market. It's not profiteering."
The profit profile for companies that market mainly in North America is not so buoyant. Frederick P. Leuffer, senior oil analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc., in New York, said ARCO's operating earnings for the first quarter would fall 31 percent. Gasoline price wars on the West Coast, where ARCO leads others in market share, have been hurting its refining profits. In addition, ARCO is feeling the pinch of declining natural gas prices, which are about 20 percent lower than a year ago.
Profits from operations at Amerada Hess will be off by 38 percent, and by 9 percent at Pennzoil and 6 percent at Unocal, Mr. Leuffer said.
Chevron and Amoco should post modest increases, Mr. Leuffer and other analysts say. These companies are large oil producers abroad, but they are not as active there in refining and marketing. Their profit growth was also restrained in the quarter because they are large natural-gas producers.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Digital Gains More Than Fourfold

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its quarterly profits had increased more than fourfold, and the shares of the nation's No. 2 computer maker jumped $4, or 6 percent, to $70.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the third-most-active Big Board stock, with 2.3 million shares changing hands.
The earnings were slightly below Wall Street's expectations, but Digital's stock rose as high as $74.25 in early trading, apparently because investors were pleased by the progress the company had made in restructuring its business and cutting costs. During the quarter, more than 2,200 people left the company, through layoffs and attrition, out of a work force of about 120,000. 
 After I.B.M. posted a large loss last week, investors were nervous that other large computer makers would report disappointing results. "People were braced for a very bad quarter for Digital," said Richard Chu, an analyst with Cowen & Company in Boston. "The worst simply did not materialize."
Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said it earned $116.6 million, or 94 cents a share, in its third quarter, compared with $24.9 million, or 20 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Last year's results included a $150 million restructuring charge.
 
Revenues Advance by 8%
 Revenues for the quarter were $3.52 billion, up 8 percent from $3.26 billion last year.
The quarter's results were reduced by the effects of the consolidation of Digital-Kienzle, a Germany company in which Digital recently acquired a 65 percent stake from Mannesmann A.G. for $230 million. Digital said that without the consolidation, earnings would have been $1.14 a share. Digital also paid $62.7 million in income taxes for the quarter. Last year, the company paid no taxes in the quarter.
Still, the makers of large computers will continue to be affected by the sluggish economy. "The difficult economic environment of the past several quarters is still with us," said John F. Smith, Digital's senior vice president for operations. He said customers were delaying investments in technology, particularly in large systems.
The company said its work station business doubled in the last year, while the weak economy hurt orders for its larger VAX 9000 computers.
The company has shipped about 250 systems so far, a number far below analysts' expectations.
While analysts question how successful the line of computers will be, Digital said orders for its high-end machines would improve along with the economy. Mr. Chu, the analyst, said, "You will find a large degree of skepticism on that point."
Mr. Chu said the most positive feature of the quarter was that Digital's revenue growth outstripped growth in expenses for the first time in memory.
"While there are significant questions about the demand outlook, they are at least on top of the cost curve, which has not been the case until recently," he said.

THE ECONOMY
U.S. banks, quick to lower rates to depositors, have been slow to cut loan rates. The "spread" is the widest in years. [Page A1.]

 Sematech is beginning to bear fruit, after three years of turmoil and controversy -- and several changes in management. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Caught in Crossfire: Rising Toll in Streets

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
For a teen-ager in the Bronx Wednesday night, death came as he helped his mother move out of a neighborhood she feared. For a 34-year-old woman in Brooklyn a night earlier, it came during a trip to the neighborhood bodega.
What linked them was that they were hit by bullets meant for others. They are among seven bystanders caught in the crossfire of gunfights since Tuesday afternoon. Two died; five were wounded. Five children were among them. 
 The city's Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, said yesterday that there was no explanation for the string of such shootings. But the effect on the public's perception of danger could be profound, as it was last summer, when public pressure after similar shootings led Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mr. Brown to promise to put thousands more police officers on the streets.
The pressure from the recent violence was already being felt yesterday at City Hall, where Dinkins administration officials said they would announce plans today for summer youth programs aimed at stemming violence. The announcement was pushed up a month after the shootings.
Mr. Brown said the underlying causes for the shootings were simple: drug turf wars, the proliferation of guns on the streets and the eroding moral values of young people who choose to carry the weapons.
"Some young people's perception about the worth of human life is not what it used to be," the Commissioner said. "We're dealing with morality and values that have degenerated over a period of time. Taking a life doesn't mean to some young people what it meant to me when I grew up."
The shootings took place on streets like many in the city where law-abiding people struggle to live amid the danger of the drug trade. The victims were ordinary people trapped by economic circumstances in terrifying conditions.
Ralphie Roopchand, 15, a student who liked Nintendo and wanted to be an accountant, was fatally shot in the neck and side on Wednesday as he loaded his mother's bedframe on a van in the Tremont section. Maribel Nieves, who had two children and worked as a home attendant, was shot in the head and killed the day before on her way to a bodega called Lucky's in Brownsville.
P'are Sharpe, 14, who liked dancing and wanted to be a lawyer, was wounded in the right leg in the same shooting that killed Ms. Nieves. As he lay in bed on Wednesday watching "Fantasy Island" on television with friends, his mother, Johnnie Mae Sharpe, 42, who had taken the day off from the security company where she works to take care of him, spoke of the anxiety of living in neighborhoods where drugs and guns are plentiful.
 
'Always Worried'
 "I'm always worried -- I'm always worried," said Mrs. Sharpe, a single parent who has another son in high school. "I work 10 hours a day. When I get up in the morning, I have to leave before my kids do. All I can do is say a prayer, that's about it. Because you never know if you're going to come back alive, and you come home and they're going to be alive."
"You'll be in your house and people will be shooting through your damn window," she said. "You stick your head out your window, somebody blows your brains out."
The other victims were a Brooklyn girl, 7, grazed by a bullet fired through her bedroom window Wednesday night; a Bronx woman, 20, who was eight months pregnant and was critically wounded when she walked into a drug shootout that left two women dead early Wednesday, and two Brooklyn girls shot Tuesday night -- one, 11, shot in the chest in Carnarsie, and one, 13, shot in the arm while walking home from school in Fort Greene.
Dr. Lawrence Sherman, a professor of criminology at the University of Maryland who has studied shootings in which bystanders were hit, said most of those struck were victims by nature of where they lived, rather than what they do or who they associated with.
 
Wrong Place at Wrong Time
 "The great myth about ghetto poverty is that most of the people who live in them are criminals or are lazy," he said. "Most of them just happen to be at the wrong place at the wrong time. They are just trying to maintain a normal life in Beirut-like conditions."
Life looked promising for Ms. Nieves, who had recently got a full-time job as a home attendant. She had been taking care of an ill woman only on weekends, so the new job meant she was working seven days a week.
At 8:45 P.M. on Tuesday, she was between her apartment at 375 Sumpter Street and Lucky's Mini-Market around the corner on Rockaway Avenue, where she was going to chat with a friend who worked there.
Suddenly, two men at the corner sprayed the street with 29 rounds from two 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistols. They were aiming at a man they had fought with over who would be allowed to sell drugs at a house on Sumpter Street, the police said. The bullets missed the intended target, but one struck Ms. Nieves in the head, killing her instantly.
 
Collapsed Near House
 P'are Sharpe said he was coming out of Lucky's when the intended victim ran by. He ran too, he said, and felt the "shock" of a bullet passing through his right calf. He passed Ms. Nieves's body and finally collapsed near her house.
The police arrested Torres Benedict, 20, of 2904 Atlantic Avenue, and said they were seeking another man.
Ms. Nieves's daughter, Ilia, 15, a student at Maxwell Vocational High School, was doing her homework when she heard the shots. She looked out the window and saw P'are on the ground. Her sister, Kaira, 11, a student at Public School 73, was watching television. Ms. Nieves's mother, Ida, who was watching the children, ran out of the house and found her daughter dead.
At the bodega, Ms. Nieves's friend, Anna Jaquez, 41, said: "She was happy because she had two jobs. She said she was going to buy a new bathroom set. A shower curtain, you know."
On the sidewalk yesterday where Ms. Nieves died, near the iron gate of a burned-out crack house and across from her youngest daughter's school, someone had written in paint that was still wet: "4-16-91 / R.I.P. Green eyes."
At 8:20 P.M. on Wednesday, Ralphie Roopchand, a student at Junior High School 22 who wanted to study accounting, had just loaded his mother's bedframe on a van that was double-parked outside her apartment at 274 West 173d Street. Afraid of the neighborhood, she was moving to Queens.
A man quickly appeared, spun the boy around and held him while another man shot him in the neck and side. One of his uncles, Suresh Laloo, 26, heard the shots and came running. "I saw him on the ground," Mr. Laloo said. "I lifted him up. He was trying to breathe, so I tried to give him mouth to mouth. I said, 'Ralphie, don't die on me.' "
 
Argument Over Debt
 Detectives said the teen-ager's death was a case of mistaken identity. The gunman thought the youth was a member of a group they had fought with after an argument over a debt owed for fixing someone's car, the police said.
"It's senseless," said Frederick Ragoonan, 29, another uncle of the boy. "He didn't have a chance to understand why he was being killed."
Mr. Ragoonan, a shipping clerk, recalled how the teen-ager had protected Mr. Ragoonan's three young children. They regarded the youth as a big brother, Mr. Ragoonan said.
"This makes no sense at all; these guys just wanted to kill somebody," his uncle said. "All these people walking around with guns."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a 48-hour period in the city, seven people -- five of them children -- were shot in crossfire. Johnnie Mae Sharpe adjusted the bandage on the leg of her son, P'are, who was shot in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn by the same gunmen who had killed a woman by mistake moments earlier. Visiting him were friends, Najah Philpot, left, and Ike Gonzalez. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Vows All-Out Bid to Avoid Fiscal Takeover of New York City

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, with Mayor David N. Dinkins at his side, vowed yesterday that he would do whatever was needed to keep the Dinkins administration from losing control of New York City's budget and finances to the state.
The Governor and the Mayor refused to provide any but the sketchiest details of how they planned to prevent the intervention of the state Financial Control Board, which under law and bond covenant could take over city finances if Mr. Dinkins cannot bring a gap of several hundred million dollars in the current budget down to $100 million.
 
Might Speed Payments
 Mr. Cuomo suggested that the state might speed up some aid payments, and city officials said they hoped yesterday's public show of support from the Governor would clear the way for them to negotiate concessions from municipal unions. 
 The statements from Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins marked a sharp turn in the political landscape of the city's fiscal affairs, with the Governor committing himself publicly to do what was necessary to prevent a state takeover. Some of his advisers have been arguing the merits of such action.
The Governor's interventon could buy Mr. Dinkins time to tackle the problems in the city's current fiscal year, which ends on June 30. But it still leaves him with a $3 billion hole in next year's budget.
He has been stymied in efforts to close it through concessions from unions, and will have to raise new taxes from the City Council and the Legislature and make cuts from his own agencies.
Any help the state offers the city would probably require approval from the State Legislature or City Council.
Striking a tone quite different from earlier this week -- when he said in an interview in Newsday that he was not sure he could prevent a takeover of the city's troubled finances -- Mr. Cuomo declared:
"What is needed, and I speak now as the Governor, is the cooperation of everyone involved. What is not needed is control by the state. As the chairman of the Financial Control Board, I wish to make clear that I believe the City of New York should have from the state not control, but cooperation."
Mr. Cuomo's stance earlier in the week had contributed to a slide in city bonds as investors worried that the Governor would try to prevent a takeover by raising the $100 million trigger, rather than by really closing the gap.
Mr. Cuomo said that with cooperation from Albany, it was "the unanimous view of the legislative leaders and of the Governor that the city is perfectly capable of managing the situation by itself."
After a two-and-a-half hour meeting in Mr. Cuomo's New York City office, the Governor and the Mayor agreed to set aside some smoldering antagonism and said their goal was to work together.
 
'We Are Confident'
 "We are confident, the Governor and I, that we are going to be able to meet our problems of fiscal year 1991, and there is no concern that a control board will take over and govern our city," Mayor Dinkins said in a news conference at Mr. Cuomo's office in the World Trade Center.
Despite their obvious pains to show cooperation, it was far from clear that the Mayor and Governor had settled the many differences between them.
The Mayor's top aides, after meeting continuously among themselves, with the Governor's aides and with city union leaders, slouched glumly in chairs flanking the podium as the Mayor spoke.
Governor Cuomo added, "We have ample time between now and the end of the year to plug that hole."
The leaders noted that the city would be required to disclose its plan to close its budget gap in an official offering statement being prepared in conection with a $1 billion note sale planned later this month in order to make up for state aid postponed because of a delay in the adoption of a state budget.
Mr. Cuomo said the city's problems were "simple" but later explained that this did not mean the solution would be easy. "It's not complicated," Mr. Cuomo said. "We're short of money and we have to find money."
The Mayor and the Governor said they did not want to disclose details of their discussions because they might be embarrassed if some of the ideas turned out to be unworkable, like the Governor's suggestion that the control board rules be changed, and because the details would be the subject of arduous negotiations.
It became clear during their statments and in later interviews that the Governor and Mayor were still looking for one-time payments, like the proceeds from a bond refinancing by the Municipal Assistance Corporation. But at least one new idea emerged.
Mr. Cuomo suggested that the state could speed up state aid now scheduled to be paid to the city next year, and pay it this year instead. Under city accounting rules, the city could count the aid in its current budget, even if the cash was not delivered until next year.
Some $70 million could be moved through this mechanism, one official familiar with the talks said.
 
Stumbling Block
 The city could also be helped by winning $60 million in wage concessions, ending unnecessary spending and using $110 million in reserve funds, the official said.
Asked later in a radio interview in Albany whether the state was prepared to send money to the city, Mr. Cuomo said, "As part of the discussion today we found an opportunity for some millions of dollars."
City officials said they welcomed the state advance, if it was acceptable under the city's accounting rules and did not make the city's problems next year worse.
The $70 million advance would exactly make up for state aid cut this city fiscal year.
It was not clear whether an important stumbling block betwen the Mayor and the Governor had been removed by yesterday's talks.
 
No Conditions
 Mr. Cuomo had steadfastly refused to help the city, city officials said, unless the city first wrested concessions from its work force. The Governor has frequently complained that the Mayor gave city workers a raise this year while the state could not afford to do so. The state had planned to lay off 10 percent of its work force.
Asked if there were conditions on any help the Governor might give, the Mayor said no.
"Whatever contribution labor makes is not necessarily linked to what else occurs," Mr. Dinkins said.
The Governor suggested there were no conditions, but reiterated that all parties would have to cooperate, and suggested once again that he could not help city union workers at the expense of state ones.
City officials said they hoped this would be enough to get stalled talks with municipal labor leaders moving. The city is seeking a three-day furlough of city workers and deferrals of raises.
 
'Making Progress'
 Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who angrily denounced the Governor earlier this week and ruled out furloughs, said yesterday that the city and unions were now "making progress."
"But that doesn't mean we are agreeing to any givebacks," he added.
If the Mayor is able to reach agreements with the Governor and the unions, and tax collections do not fall dramatically, the city could squeak through the current fiscal year.
But an agreement would only buy time and not much of it. The city is facing a budget gap that already totals more than $3 billion next year and is likely to get worse as the result of a continuing decline in the economy. Within weeks Mr. Dinkins must present a plan showing how he will balance that budget.
Both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins said the Mayor had not made any commitments to support the Governor in his impasse with the Assembly and the Senate over the adoption of a state budget.

HEADLINE: BUSH SCHOOL PLAN WOULD ENCOURAGE CHOICE BY PARENTS

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
President Bush today began his campaign for improving American education, calling not only for national tests and a new kind of school, but also for a redirection of Federal money to help disadvantaged students who choose to go to private and parochial schools.
While President Bush has long backed the idea that parents should be able to choose the school their children attend, the plan unveiled today would commit both the Federal Government's money and moral suasion to the idea that parents should be able to use state and local tax dollars to pay for public, private or parochial schools.
 
'Death Sentence,' Senator Says
 Describing his 34-page plan to a White House audience of educators, business leaders, governors and members of Congress, the President said, "To those who want to see real improvement in American education, I say: There will be no renaissance without revolution." 
 Congressional concerns about already struggling public schools and about the need to maintain the separation of church and state required by the First Amendment pose large obstacles for the Administration proposal.
An early warning shot came today from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources. The panel would have to approve any revisions in the laws governing Federal support for education.
"The important idea of educational choice should not become a death sentence for public schools struggling to serve disadvantaged students," Mr. Kennedy said.
 
Encouragement for States
 Education Secretary Lamar Alexander said the President would encourage states and local districts to change their rules so that parents could apply their state and local tax dollars to send their children to either public or private schools. In turn, he said, he will propose that Congress change laws that limit the amount of Federal aid that goes to children in private and parochial schools.
Chapter I, formally known as Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, is one of the largest sources of Federal money for education, financed at about $6 billion this fiscal year. Under it, a school receives money if a large proportion of its students qualify as needy. The money must be spent on remedial classes and services for those children, unless a school's poverty rate exceeds 75 percent, in which case Chapter I money can be spent on schoolwide programs.
Mr. Alexander said the Administration wanted to change the law so that, in districts that have choice programs, the money could in effect follow individual disadvantaged students wherever they choose to go to school.
The package of proposals unveiled today offers the clearest statement on how Mr. Bush proposes to make good on his campaign pledge to be the 'education President' and what steps he thinks Americans must take to lead the world in educational achievement. The President and the nation's governors set that target in six national educational goals he announced last year.
Mr. Bush has been widely criticized by Democrats as failing to deliver on his campaign promises about education, and they hope to make his record a major issue in the next Presidential and Congressional elections. The Administration proposals appear designed in part to blunt the Democratic strategy by demonstrating that Mr. Bush has not neglected education.
'For the sake of the future, of our children and our nation, we must transform America's schools," President Bush said. "The days of the status quo are over."
Mr. Bush spent most of his day promoting his new education plan. From 10 A.M. to well past 2:30 P.M., he met with governors, business leaders, lawmakers and educators. He was the host at an education lunch and delivered a national address from the East Room.
The plan relies more on the President's bully pulpit than the Government's purse. The measures would commit at least $690 million in new money for education, and a group of business leaders has pledged to raise at least $150 million to pay for research to invent a better American public school. But President Bush and Mr. Alexander said the publicity and leadership a President could provide was more important than money. "Dollar bills don't educate students," the President said.
 
National Tests and New Schools
 The plan calls for a broad range of measures involving not only the states but the nation's Governors, business leaders, and educators. Among the central points in the President's plan are these:
*Voluntary national tests, to be called American Achievement Tests, in mathematics, science, English, history and geography, so that students and schools can see whether they meet new national standards in these fields.
*Fund-raising by businesses, of at least $150 million, for design of 535 innovative new schools to serve as national models of excellence, and action by Congress providing grants to the communities that develop those schools.
*Rule changes by states and municipalities to let parents send children to any school they choose, in hopes that competition will force ailing schools to improve or face a student exodus.
*Lists of necessary skills to succeed in each industry, and national skill clinics so that workers can judge what new training they might need.
 
Dispute Over Choice
 The proposal to promote school choice will probably encounter the most opposition. Mr. Bush has long endorsed the idea that competition for students would spur schools to improve. Indeed, many schools hailed as among the best in the country, including some urban magnet schools and Deborah Meier's Central Park East schools in East Harlem, are public schools chosen by parents, students and teachers.
But by expanding the idea of choice to private and parochial schools, Mr. Bush would seek to undo the compromise that resulted in the first general Federal aid to education in 1965. He would reopen the debate by raising the possibility that public tax money would flow away from public schools to private and parochial schools, thus blurring the line between church and state. Some state choice programs, like one in Milwaukee, are already being challenged in the courts.
The Administration proposal marks the first time that the Federal Government has proposed supporting parental choice by redirecting a large block of Federal money. More than 90 percent of education aid comes from states and municipalities, so states and local governments remain the major players in any discussion of choice.
Whether or not Federal money can be permitted to flow to children in parochial schools under current law is not clear. In some cases, said Bruno Manno, acting Assistant Secretary of Education for Research and Improvement, parochial school students are receiving remedial tutoring paid for by Chapter I funds, but they receive it outside the physical plant of the parochial school.
 
Knowledge Standards
 Mr. Alexander defended the idea of choice as one that reflects deep American values. At a news briefing after the announcement, he said, "If they choose to go because that school serves them better, why shouldn't public money follow the child to this school?"
President Bush's plan also envisages other dramatic changes in American education. For the first time, the country would draw up national standards, defining what all American students should know in five subjects -- English, mathematics, science, geography and history. National tests geared to these standards would be offered in fourth, eighth and twelfth grades.
Mr. Bush also seeks to harness the outpouring of concern about America's educational ills from business leaders, who have complained for years that their workers cannot read, compute and think well enough to match workers from competing nations.
In the plan, a group of business leaders led by Paul H. O'Neill, the chief executive of Aluminum Company of America, have pledged to raise at least $150 million to finance several research and development teams to invent new kinds of American schools. These schools could stay open longer, use new technology or teaching methods or be organized differently from current schools. The only requirements would be that schools turn out students who meet the national educational goals and that the schools not cost more to operate than existing schools.
Mr. Bush calls for 535 such schools to be established by 1996. He will ask Congress to appropriate at least $1 million to establish each school. The schools will be selected by advisory panels after consultation with Mr. Alexander and the governor of each state.
 
'Too Little'
 Some educators and state officials questioned the wisdom of spending so much to develop new school models when several groups have innovative models in place.
"It's too little and it's in the wrong place," said Linda Darling-Hammond, an education professor at Columbia University and an expert on education reform.
Others disagreed. Theodore R. Sizer, a professor of education at Brown University who heads the Coalition of Essential Schools, an organization promoting more than 150 innovative public schools nationwide, supported the focus on research.
"The scale of our work isn't big enough," said Mr. Sizer, who said the coalition this year raised, with some difficulty, $5 million in donations. "It's not that we don't have a lot of experience with innovation, but we need a variety of efforts out there with enough funding."
Several business leaders reacted positively to the plan, although others said it may be difficult to raise the suggested money, given the recession and the fact that corporations already contribute about $225 million to $250 million to public schools.
Finally, the Bush plan also seeks to use Presidential leadership to convince Americans that educational excellence is important and that good students should be rewarded, not ridiculed. Mr. Bush would award citations to good students and good schools. To enlist the American public in the battle, Mr. Bush proposes creating 'America 2000 Communities' -- communities that draw up plans to improve local education.
To show the way, President Bush said that he, too, had decided to study something new: how to use a computer.
'I want to be computer-literate and I'm not," he said. 'I want to learn and I will. "
 

GRAPHIC: Chart: Bush on Education: Highlights
 
Choice: Incentives to states and local districts to let parents choose public or private schools for their children, and in those districts redirect Federal money to poor students who choose private schools.
 
New schools: Development of 535 new schools by local communities. Congress will be asked to provide one-time grants of $1 million to each school. American business and other donors will be asked to give money to a new research organization to help develop the schools.
 
Monitoring students: State-by-state assessment of student progress in grades 4, 8 and 12 in five core subjects.
 
Differential teacher pay: Schools will be encouraged to increase pay for those who teach well, who teach core subjects, who teach in dangerous or challenging settings, or who serve as mentors for new teachers.
 
American Achievement Tests: Voluntary nationwide examinations in English, math, science, history and geography, for use in college admissions and the job market.
 
Skills standards: Business and labor will be asked to establish a list of job-related skill standards.
 
Source: Associated Press

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
A Child's Innocence Fights Bias

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
The wonderful thing about children is that they believe everything is possible. What makes Lynda Barry's first play a happy occasion is that she captures the innocent abandon of childhood with the wit of a mature writer but without letting go of the uninhibited child still lurking deep within herself.
Ms. Barry's uneven but highly promising comedy at the Second Stage, "The Good Times Are Killing Me," is about Edna Arkins, a pre-adolescent girl of the mid-1960's who believes, for the duration of elementary school anyway, that miracles like movie stardom and racial harmony are to be had for the asking, no matter what obstacles parents might place in the way. Ms. Barry, a syndicated cartoonist whose strip, "Ernie Pook's Comeek," appears in The Village Voice in New York, is just as free-spirited as her heroine in her first effort at writing for the stage. Like Edna, Ms. Barry at her best would rather hop, skip and jump than walk a straight dramatic line between any two points. She does not feel obliged to honor any dreary adult rules of the theater until her second act, at which time the play and Edna alike begin to settle into a conventional, lackluster maturity. 
 Until then, the evening has the rambunctious style if not the campiness of John Waters movies like "Hair spray" and "Cry- Baby" in which the rituals of growing up, the increased racial segregation of rock music and the accelerating civil rights movement all converge on the streets of a changing blue-collar urban neighborhood. Edna sets the tone right away by telling the audience that her once all-white block is in a state of traumatic demographical transition and that music is the center of her life. As her story progresses, sociological sea changes and intimate familial episodes are both defined by pop songs, whether the singers be Johnny Mathis, Paul Anka, James Brown, Elvis Presley or in one loopy interlude Julie Andrews in "The Sound of Music."
Mark Brokaw, the production's impressive young director, is in perfect tune with the playwright's jukebox approach to the traditional memory play. As Edna remarks that a song can make "the past rise up and stick in your brain," so old songs (and at times old "American Bandstand" or "Soul Train" dances) rise up in fragrant patches to accompany the script's remembered anecdotes about variously beloved and thorny relatives and neighbors. The writing and staging are both so fluid that "Good Times" sometimes seems to be touring the early chapters of its heroine's biography with the same ease with which one might pass in and out of distant radio stations while turning a dial. Upbeat episodes like Edna's budding friendship with a black girl next door, Bonna (Chandra Wilson), are as gracefully and economically revisited as such heartbreaks as a father's desertion or a child's accidental death. Life, by turns romantic and bitter, just keeps popping in and out of the doors that line the set's row-house facade.
As acted by Angela Goethals with a fetching precocity that never turns bratty, Edna is a winning guide to her wonder years. Her observations about teen-agers and adults are funny, especially when they are fleshed out by such pungent actors as Ruth Williamson (as a perpetually put-upon aunt given to making "tiny little faces"), Jennie Moreau (as both a patronizing older cousin and a ruler-banging music teacher) and John Lathan (as the hippest black male on the block). Ms. Goethals is moving, too, when she and her sad-faced kid sister (Lauren Gaffney, another fine child actor) turn their house's basement into a "Record Player Nightclub" that, though conceived as a joyous imaginary refuge from their parents' marital travails, becomes a mausoleum for lost love.
While not as fully written, the story of the black family next door is just as well acted, particularly by Ms. Wilson, whose Bonna eventually becomes a feisty co-narrator of the play, and by Kim Staunton, whose portrayal of Bonna's mother grows from a buoyant young woman singing "I Could Write a Book" while doing household chores to a wizened specter of middle-aged disappointment. Even when the writing lacks fine detail, one still feels Ms. Barry's kinship with black characters whose deferred dreams are touched by but not really redeemed by such revolutionary phenomena as "A Raisin in the Sun," "To Kill a Mockingbird" and the Black Panthers.
"Good Times" begins to dwindle when the author takes the issue of race relations head on rather than elliptically. Act II devolves into a diagrammatic tale of the gradual parting of Edna and Bonna during the seventh grade, and the girls' story all too heavily symbolizes the larger tale of racial separatism on the eve of the riots of the late 60's. Suddenly a previously free-form play leans on a contrived plot twist -- an exclusionary teen-age party -- and takes to making points didactically: Edna's uneasy participation in a black family ritual (a gospel church service) is laboriously contrasted with Bonna's participation in a quintessential white counterpart (a camping trip). It's almost as if the playwright, like the girls on stage, had abruptly decided she had to grow up and trim her wings. By the final half hour, her writing has become as formulaic and glib as the television specials on racial tolerance that the play has previously mocked.
Young audiences -- and this is a play sure to earn the respect and laughter of young audiences -- will not mind the faults of Act II too much, for the author never patronizes her young characters even when her storytelling becomes a bit numbing to those of parental age. While the failings of "The Good Times Are Killing Me" (its awkward title included) are real, they are those of breadth, not depth. Lynda Barry's engaging debut as a playwright is anything but cartoonish.
