HEADLINE: The Bell Tolls for Rain Forests

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
IT now takes less than 40 years for the human race to double, and there are few consequences of the population explosion more striking than the obliteration of the world's rain forests. The American Museum of Natural History has opened an exhibition dedicated to the natural treasure we are rapidly losing.
Most Americans are at least vaguely aware that the global appetite for beef, lumber and land is cutting into rain forests at an almost unbelievable rate. According to United Nations statistics, an area of rain forest five times the size of Manhattan is felled every day -- a rate that would eliminate all rain forests by the year 2081. 
 The new show, "Tropical Rain Forests: A Disappearing Treasure," running through June 2, was organized by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibitions Service in cooperation with the World Wildlife Fund. While the organizers of the exhibition deplore the destruction of rain forests, the displays are essentially tutorial and evenhanded. The points of view of various classes of people involved in the depletion of the Amazon rain forests are effectively presented by short recorded statements from a forest Indian, a jungle colonist, a rancher, a banker and a naturalist. A computer display asks the visitor to choose one of several strategies for saving rain forests, then responds by explaining the pitfalls of whatever choice is made.
Whatever justification various economic groups may find for cutting into the rain forests, their activities are costing the world's pool of animal and plant species dearly, as the exhibition underscores; lemurs, kinkajous, jaguars, Bengal tigers, various chameleons and many birds are among the tens or hundreds of thousands of species facing extinction because of their loss of habitat.
Diagrams, dioramas and photographs demonstrate how the damage can extend far beyond the dying rain forests themselves. Destruction of forests causes soil erosion and the silting of rivers and their deltas, for instance, and the silt is carried offshore and kills coral reefs, which are the habitats for many marine animals. The loss of rain-forest species may rob future scientists of clues to the design of new drugs with important therapeutic properties, the exhibition shows; among the pharmaceuticals that already owe their origins to natural products of the rain forests are heart medicines and tranquilizers.
Perhaps the most devastating long-term effect of loss of rain forests will be climatic. Rain-forest vegetation is a voracious consumer of atmospheric carbon dioxide, which is increasing at a troubling rate. Many scientists say most of the increase is a direct result of the population explosion and the increased burning of organic fuels (oil, coal, gas and wood). Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas because it traps the energy of sunlight and heats the atmosphere.
If, as many scientists believe, this warming is inevitable, global agriculture could be radically affected, possibly precipitating mass famine. One of the few natural buffers easing the rapid increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is the global system of rain forests, which consume carbon dioxide to manufacture the carbohydrates of plant material.
But as the rain forests are killed off, this buffer is disappearing. Even if President Bush's "America the Beautiful" proposal for planting 10 billion trees in the next decade is successful, the effects of the destruction of the world's equatorial rain forests would be scarcely diminished.
 
The Intangible Loss
 One of the losses sometimes overlooked in discussions of the rain-forest problem is that of the beautiful mystery that haunted the world's artists in another era -- an aura that the museum exhibition suggests.
The "back to nature" artistic movement that flourished in England early in this century focused on tropical rain forests and inspired some of the most luminous literary description of the period. W. H. Hudson's romantic fantasy "Green Mansions" and Arthur Conan Doyle's "Lost World" were set partly under the cathedral-like arches of Amazon rain forests, and Joseph Conrad's evocative "Heart of Darkness" was based on the author's experiences with rain forests in the Congo.
Well into the 20th century a hint of somewhat sinister mystery pervaded the great rain forests; within living memory, headhunters roamed the Peruvian forests from which the Amazon springs, and even today vestiges of forest Indian culture survive in Brazil and elsewhere in South America. But in the face of bulldozers and chain saws, the culture and mystery are evaporating.
The museum show highlights some of the beauty that is dying out. A visitor entering the third-floor exhibition area passes a magnificent life-size model of the base of a gigantic buttressed fig tree, one of the principal anchors of rain-forest ecology. Hidden speakers broadcast the exotic sounds of forest birds, frogs and insects, and there are lush floral displays and representations of beautiful endangered animals.
There are also before and after photographs and dioramas of rain forests as they were in their pristine state, as they were during the few years cattle grazed where the trees were felled, and in their final state: empty, eroded deserts, virtually devoid of life and ruined by man for any useful function.
 
Where and When
 "Tropical Rain Forests: A Disappearing Treasure" will be on view at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, through June 2. Sydney Horenstein, the museum's coordinator of environmental public programs, conducts special group tours of the exhibition for teachers and environmental associations; tours can be arranged by calling the museum at (212) 769-5726.
Eight short films on rain forests around the world run from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Sunday. Free with museum admission; suggested contribution, $5.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:

Outdoors on the Fifth Floor
One of the more serene outdoor cafes in town, high above the fumes and frenzy of Fifth Avenue, is the Terrace at Trump Tower, on the fifth floor of the building, between 56th and 57th Streets. The cafe was recently reopened by the owners of I Tre Merli and Barolo, both in SoHo, and La Focaccia in Greenwich Village. They also took over the DDL Foodshow on the main level of Trump Tower and renamed it I Tre Merli Bistro, serving salads and pastas.
 The Terrace's ivy-draped cafe has four tables with views down Fifth Avenue. The cafe offers a simple lunch menu of salads, grilled entrees and pastas. On a recent visit, a salad of julienned raw artichoke with lemon and Parmesan cheese had the consistency of straw but was refreshing and tasty ($7). An entree salad of watercress and tender grilled duck salad in a balsamic vinaigrette was pleasing ($12). Meat-filled ravioli in a tomato and basil sauce was satisfying, though not exceptional ($9.50). Desserts, however, are exceptional, particularly the creamy ricotta cheesecake and the raisin-apple bread pudding (both $6).
 
 The Terrace serves lunch only, 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday to Saturday; closed Sunday. Major credit cards accepted. Telephone: (212) 319-5341.
 
$10 Lunch at Quatorze
 How far can restaurant downscaling go in this era of budget-consciousness? Quatorze, the handsome bistro at 240 West 14th Street in Manhattan, is offering a $10 prix fixe lunch.
 Don't expect fois gras and Sauternes. But the lunch I had recently was more than adequate. It started with a cup of sturdy minestrone, followed by a tartine (open-face sandwich) of chunky pork pate with brown bread and mustard. It also came with a small green salad.
Aside from the prix fixe menu, other economical lunch entrees include the omelet of the day ($8.50), and a salade nicoise ($10.95). I have to admit that after confirming that a $10 lunch can be pleasing, I splurged on the heavenly individual apple tart, one of my favorites here ($6.50).
While the $10 lunch is a welcome idea, Quatorze's regular lunch entrees are relatively pricey. They range from $16 for sauteed brook trout to $22 for grilled salmon.
 Quatorze is as comfortable and Parisian in feeling as it was when it opened in 1985, with beige-yellow walls holding mirrors and giant framed posters, and a marble-top bar.
Quatorze serves lunch noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Saturday; dinner 6 to 11:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday and 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sunday. American Express accepted. Telephone: (212) 206-7006.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
Gascony, the pastoral French province of foie gras, confit, game and Armagnac, is renowned for robust good eating. It's no wonder that the ancient Romans dubbed it the "granary of the Gauls."
 The lusty cooking of this region, based on goose and duck fat rather than butter or oil, hardly fits today's health-conscious dining habits. Yet several innovative chefs are integrating Gascon specialties into their menus in ways that do not have diners scurrying for cholesterol counts after dinner. At Gascogne in Chelsea, Pascal Coudouy, the chef and co-owner with his wife, Carol, is one who is doing an exemplary job.
 
 This 13-month-old venture is an enchanting and economy-minded spot -- no entrees exceed $20. It resembles a country farmhouse in France with its rough sandstone walls, partly exposed brick and walled-in outdoor garden. Mr. Coudouy worked at the Ambassador Grill during its tenure as a Gascon outpost; before that he worked in France under the esteemed Andre Daguin at the Hotel de France in Auch.
 If you want to start the meal in an authentic manner, begin with some duck foie gras, either sauteed with various fruit-based sauces, or in a velvety cold terrine flavored with Armagnac. Typical of the chef's leaner dishes is a winning combination of well-seasoned salmon and sliced potatoes with onions and sour cream. A big hit at my table were the rolls of thinly sliced prosciutto rolled around warm white beans with a gribiche sauce (capers, cornichons, hard-boiled eggs) with mixed greens around. The prosciutto did little, though, for baked oysters -- the oyster flavor was obscured. Better choices are the thick lentil soup with a succulent confit of duck wing in it, and a special of minced smoked duck breast in a ball of mild goat cheese, all encased in phyllo and served warm with mixed greens. A tasty little sampler plate includes slices of air-cured duck breast, smoked duck, confit of duck gizzards and confit of crispy chicken legs.
 Gascogne has a limited but interesting regional wine list. This is a good place to try some of the region's better offerings, like Cahors, Madiran, Buzet and Luberon. An exceptionally good buy is the light and fruity 1985 Cahors Haute-Serre ($24).
 Among main courses, an entree portion of duck leg confit comes with a ragout of peas, bacon and onions. One expects confit to be well salted, but this one was excessively so. Two recommended selections are a grilled baby chicken with shallots confit and a sauce of Madeira and rosemary; and juicy pink loin of lamb stuffed with mixed vegetables in tarragon-scented pan juices. Steak au poivre, a special, was tender, beefy and aggressively hot, garnished with crunchy deep-fried leeks. Another special, cod swathed with tapenade and mired in a thick sauce of peppers, onions and tomato, was not so appealing -- neither garnish had any distinction.
 Cassoulet weather may have passed, but if we get an unexpected cold snap and the dish returns as a special, the version here is worth trying: a succulent melding of duck confit, pork sausage, gizzards and beans. Breast of magret (from fatted ducks that are bred for the production of foie gras) is served garnished with grapes and Armagnac. The combination had plenty of flavor going for it, but the duck was served so rare, in the French style, that I could hardly chew it. Aficionados of rabbit will enjoy the version here, roasted and garnished with pancetta and sauteed cabbage.
 Desserts alone are worth a trip to this Chelsea outpost. A trio of prune selections includes airy prune pudding over a thick slice of bread, prunes in puff pastry, and ice cream with Armagnac-marinated prunes. The pear trio is equally good: pear Tatin, pear mousse in a tuile cookie, and pears poached in red wine. Creme brulee, too, is picture perfect. Only the Grand Marnier crepe was too sweet to handle.
 Bringing a little bit of Gascony to Eighth Avenue would be a challenge under any circumstances, more so during the difficult past year for restaurants. Carol and Pascal Coudouy deserve plaudits for their pluck, and patronage for their enticing food.
 Gascogne
*
158 Eighth Avenue, between 17th and 18th Streets, in Manhattan, (212) 675-6564.
Atmosphere: Reminiscent of a farmhouse in the French countryside; outdoor garden. Low noise level.

Wine: Good selection of regional wines.
Price range: appetizers $6 to $9 (foie gras daily special $18); main courses $16.50 to $20.

HEADLINE: The Dow: Less Than Meets the Eye

 BODY:
Wednesday's record close for the Dow Jones industrial stock average doesn't mean that the recession is coming to an end or that the banking crisis is solved. Indeed, the Dow average finished below 3,000 yesterday. The ups and downs on Wall Street matter to the 50 million Americans who own stock, but don't mean much of anything to the national economy.
Some observers say that the Dow closed above 3,000 for the first time ever because investors think the recession will soon be over, or because they expect the Federal Reserve Board to knock down interest rates or because they expect oil prices to fall. But whatever investors may have been thinking, they have no special insight and achieve no such consensus on economic trends. 
 Stock prices have soared because some investors believe other investors believe stock prices would rise -- so why not get in first? Such sentiments respond to surprise information, like unexpectedly high or low inflation figures, but more often reflect sheer guesswork. Stock market averages, as predictors of recession and recovery, tend to be wrong nearly as often as they are right.
This said, a rising stock market does make shareholders wealthier, spurring consumption. That's good news for department stores and travel bureaus. But it is easy to exaggerate the impact. In October 1987 the Dow plunged more than 500 points and the national economy barely sagged. Historians are far from sure that the 1929 stock market crash caused or much worsened the Depression.
The important point is that Wall Street wields only minor influence over Main Street. Whether the Dow rises or falls by 50 points, across America the same people work at the same jobs with the same equipment to churn out the same products.

HEADLINE: Dr. Axelrod's Courage

 BODY:
Dr. David Axelrod, forced by sudden illness to retire this week as New York State's Health Commissioner, was an extraordinarily principled chief health officer who will be difficult to replace.
In a job that all too often reflects the narrow interests of the medical profession and its institutions, Dr. Axelrod saw the state's whole population as his patient. He treated it with uncommon compassion, vision and courage. 
 His 12-year tenure included notable achievements. He pushed for measures now in effect to ban smoking in public places. He imposed rules establishing better supervision and working hours for hospital interns and residents, thus curtailing the hospitals' exploitation of the young doctors. He worked to protect the privacy of AIDS patients. And he confronted doctors on issues of malpractice.
Most important, he waged a vigorous campaign to make health care broadly available, and affordable. During the 1980's, persistent inflation of medical costs exhausted public budgets, even as festering social problems swelled the numbers of patients with no way to pay medical bills. Especially in New York, epidemics of drug abuse and AIDS put critical pressure on the health care system.
Facing such strains, Dr. Axelrod sought to force efficiencies on hospital administrators and physicians unused to skeptical oversight. And he insisted that austerity should not mean the sacrifice of health care for the poor.
Thus he argued last year against a major health care bill widely supported by the state's medical establishment; the commissioner felt it provided too much for big hospitals at the expense of neighborhood clinics and poor children.
And when he proposed a universal health insurance plan similar to one in Massachusetts, he added provisions to give Albany sweeping control over fees hospitals and doctors might charge. The proposal remains a proposal, but it stakes out a bold position for state regulators.
Such moves did not always endear Dr. Axelrod to the health care community; New York's Medical Society called for his dismissal in 1989. That did not reflect any failure so much as it did his stubborn sense of duty to all the state's citizens, not just its doctors.
In fact, few public servants demonstrate so much integrity in office for so long. Dr. Axelrod's departure is a stunning loss.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Despite Recession, New York Remains World's Best Dining City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Day the Eating Stopped" (editorial, April 2), you suggest that the restaurant industry in New York is in real trouble, notably because people are bored by eating out, even embarrassed to be seen in good restaurants. As someone in the business of surveying New York City diners -- more than 5,500 this year -- I suggest you haven't been in many New York restaurants recently. 
 Despite the recession, many restaurants are bursting at the seams with patrons. Try visiting Aureole, Bouley, Cafe des Artistes, Carmine's, Coco Pazzo, Gotham Bar & Grill, Il Mulino, Jour et Nuit, Le Cirque, Le Comptoir, Le Madri, Les Halles, Mesa Grill, the Palm, Park Bistro, the River Cafe, Sparks or Union Square Cafe. You can add a host of lesser-known, inexpensive neighborhood pasta places and ethnic restaurants throughout the city.
Our surveys reflect that consumer interest continues to be high and that the New York restaurant industry has been outdoing itself to provide good, affordable dining in what most informed observers believe is the world's best dining city.
 
TIM ZAGAT
New York, April 5, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Weyerhaeuser Head Plans to Retire in July

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
George H. Weyerhaeuser, the chairman and chief executive of the Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday at the company's annual meeting that he would retire when he turned 65 in July and that he would turn over the post to John W. Creighton Jr., the president. The move was expected.
Mr. Creighton will be the first chairman of the 91-year-old forest products company who is not a member of the founding Weyerhaeuser family. Mr. Creighton, who is 59 years old and has been with the company since 1970, was elected a corporate vice president that year. In 1985, he became executive vice president with specific duties in the real estate and financial services area. 
 Weyerhaeuser, based in Tacoma, Wash., has been criticized by analysts, who have long contended that the company has not worked sufficiently to improve its performance and to undertake an effective cost-cutting plan. The company also said that its earnings for the first quarter had plunged by 57 percent.
To cut costs and eliminate businesses outside of its forest products core, Weyerhaeuser has in the last two years divested $400 million in operations, including its hardwood plant in Chesapeake, Va., a beauty-aids center in St. Louis and a gypsum plant in Briar, Ark.
"We are now well into the second and more important phase of the company's refocusing program, implementing and tracking operating improvement plans for each business unit," Mr. Creighton said in a statement. "Momentum is building, despite the recessionary problem. Our financial condition was strong as we went into this recession, and we will be in the same strong financial condition coming out of it."
He added that Weyerhaeuser was evaluating whether to make further curtailments.
Daniel F. Nelson, a forest products analyst with Ragen, MacKenzie in Seattle, said Mr. Creighton would inherit critical challenges.
"He will have to bring life to a company that has underperformed for much of the last 10 years," he said. "The company historically has been overstaffed and has been run paternalistically, and some of the hard decisions have been side-stepped from time to time, such as how to sufficiently trim labor costs and operating costs."
Mr. Nelson added: "I don't think they have spared any expense in developing the yield on their forest lands. But getting a good economic return on that has been elusive."
Mr. Creighton holds bachelor's and law degrees from Ohio State University and an M.B.A. from the University of Miami. He is married and has three children.
Before coming to Weyerhaeuser, he worked with Mortgage Consultants for four years and with the Arvida Corporation from 1959 until 1966. Earlier, he spent two years with Arthur Andersen & Company.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
How to Prepare for Loss of a Job

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With waves of layoffs and offers of early retirement rolling through corporate America, all employed people should be putting their finances in shipshape condition, experts counsel. They also offer advice for those already adrift.
"Build capacity," said George E. L. Barbee, who is in charge of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse and is based in Waltham, Mass. "Reduce consumer debt -- that's the first priority -- and create an emergency fund." 
 Historically an emergency fund of cash and cash equivalents like Treasury bills should have been equal to three to six months' income, he said, but now he is advising people to extend that by six to nine months. "Someone who is out of a job nine months to a year can easily burn up $50,000 to $75,000," he said.
Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York and the firm's director of employee benefits and executive compensation, said, "As a rule of thumb, figure it could take a month to find a job for each $10,000 of income -- a year for an executive earning $120,000."
Tamara G. Telesko, a lawyer and vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, advised people to "do a really good cash flow, and look at your employee benefits and see how much it would cost to replace them" in planning for an emergency fund or for a future away from the company.
Ms. Telesko, who advises private banking customers in New York, said most people would need an accountant's advice on the tax impact to make an accurate projection in the benefits area, which could include life, health and disability insurance, child-care benefits and pension and retirement plans. The loss could be far greater for people not yet vested in pension plans.
She advises employees who are given incentive stock options to exercise them, then sell the stock and move into a diversified portfolio of other stocks and tax-exempt bonds. Too much of an employee's financial well-being is linked to the employer's health to compound the problem by having the bulk of one's assets in the company stock.
"Have a strategy in place, and don't be caught at the whim of the market," by holding a lot of unexercised options or a big block of stock in one company, she added. It is particularly important for those who are evaluating offers of early retirement or who are let go and given a severance package to consult an accountant about the tax planning involved in structuring those payments. Decisions must be made about whether to take a lump-sum payment, and if so, whether to use 5- or 10-year averaging, if eligible, or roll over pension money into an I.R.A. or whether to defer payments. The answers will depend on individual circumstances. Mr. Barbee is counseling people in the current recessionary environment to take a defensive financial stance that allows them "to become increasingly self-reliant."
People who have put together a good cash cushion should "spread it around among institutions," Mr. Barbee added, to protect themselves against assets being frozen in the event of an institution's insolvency, putting some in bank C.D.'s and some in money market funds. Consumers should choose top-rated banks and brokers, he said, rather than going for the last tenth of a percentage point they see advertised.
"People better not wait until they have lost a job to seek a home-equity line," he added. Arrange for such a line of credit while employed, but draw on it only in emergency, he said, using cash first.
Mr. Neumark advised people who are given notice to negotiate with their employers to continue their health insurance coverage as long as possible. Under Federal law dismissed employees are entitled to pay their own premiums and continue the group coverage generally for 18 months, he noted, but they would not begin paying until the employer quits paying.
Health insurance can cost $400 to $500 a month for a family under a group policy, he said, and may be more if it must be purchased privately.
People who have lost their jobs should draw up a realistic budget, Mr. Neumark said, that allows them to "live comfortably but not luxuriously," perhaps eating out less often or at less luxurious restaurants, or occasionally substituting a video for a movie, but not staying home altogether.
"If you are going to cut yourself down to the bone, it will affect you psychologically," he said. "The best way to get a new job is to remain visible and active -- don't go around with a bad attitude." Mr. Neumark had one final tip for those looking for a new job: "Get a roll of quarters -- you'll be making more calls from public telephones than you've ever made in your life."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Confidence in U.S. Economy Grows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged again on world currency markets yesterday as confidence grew that the economy was ready to climb out of recession.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $356.70 a troy ounce, down $1.20 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1 an ounce, to $356.50. 
 The dollar began advancing earlier in the week. The gains were supported by indications that unemployment might be bottoming out and by the absence of any movement on interest rates by Germany's central bank or the Federal Reserve.
Many analysts had expected a Bundesbank rate increase in tandem with a Fed move to ease credit, a combination that could have hurt the dollar.
While there was virtually no fresh news to propel the dollar higher yesterday, traders said the general view of the American economy had improved significantly.
John Marchese, chief economist at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said perceived improvements in the economy had given foreign investors an incentive to buy dollars. "With the German economy having a bit of a problem," the dollar is the most likely alternative for investment, he said, adding that the dollar put in its best performance against the German mark and the British pound.
Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said the dollar went "up to the sky and broke" through several key barriers. "This is for real," he said, in contrast to recent technical moves.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.63 yen, to a closing 137.90 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 138.40 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 138.35 yen, up from 137.80 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound sank to $1.7204 from $1.7715 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7205 to buy 1, less expensive than Thursday's $1.7520.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7360 German marks, up from 1.7052; 1.4679 Swiss francs, up from 1.4570; 5.8575 French francs, up from 5.7615; 1,282.00 Italian lire, up from 1,262.00, and 1.1550 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1523.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.50 a troy ounce, from $358.50 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $356.10 from $358.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.56 to close at $357.99 bid.

HEADLINE: Guam, Against the Tide, Wants Air Base Closed

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
Like many in Congress, Ben Blaz of Guam is applying pressure on the Pentagon about the status of the military base in his district. But unlike his Congressional colleagues, Mr. Blaz wants the base in his district to close.
Mr. Blaz, a Republican and a former Marine Corps general who is a nonvoting delegate to Congress, has found himself struggling against the tide in his efforts to close the Agana Naval Air Station so that it can be used in the expansion of a commercial airport. But the Pentagon considers the base too valuable to military operations in the Pacific. 
 Last week, when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said no bases would be closed if it were up to members of Congress, Mr. Blaz fumed.
 
'Not Reading My Mail'
 "I think to myself, 'Somebody's not reading my mail,' " said Mr. Blaz, who has appealed to no avail to Mr. Cheney and to H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, the Secretary of the Navy.
Mr. Blaz and Joseph F. Ada, the Governor of Guam, have asked the Defense Department to vacate the Agana naval air station and turn the property over to the local government at no cost. Guam officials would then be able to move forward with plans to use the 2,200-acre base to expand the neighboring Guam International Air Terminal, the island's major commercial airport.
Mr. Blaz said he had taken his request to James A. Courter, the chairman of the Defense Base Realignment and Closure Commission, which will make the final proposals this summer for Congressional consideration.
Mr. Courter said he considered Guam's request legitimate and worthy of further investigation. But he stopped short of guaranteeing a decision to include the Guam base on the final closure list.
 
Relocation of Base Urged
 Mr. Blaz would like the Navy to relocate Agana's operations to the larger Andersen Air Force Base on the northern tip of the island.
But a General Accounting Office study made public late last year found that the Navy would have to spend $229 million to move the installation. It was estimated that it would take more than 100 years for the savings from the consolidation to reach that level.
By contrast, Mr. Cheney's base-closing recommendations are expected to begin saving money by 1997. The Pentagon estimated the cost of closing the recommended bases at $5.7 billion over the five years it would take to close them. But it said the military would save $6.5 billion in operating costs over the same period.
Lieut. Dane LaJoie, a Navy spokesman, said the Agana base was not selected for closing because troops deployed in the western Pacific still rely on the airfield. "The Navy mission remains unchanged in Guam," Lieutenant LaJoie said.
 
Emotional Attachment Cited
 About one-third of the land on Guam, a self-governing United States territory, is controlled by the Federal Government. More than 22,000 military personnel and their dependents live on Guam, accounting for nearly one-fourth of the island's population.
Guam's repeated requests that the military abandon Agana are rooted in history, emotion and the territory's quest for the sort of international economic development that an improved airport could provide.
Mr. Blaz, who was forced as a 15-year-old to help clear the fields to build the airport for Japanese forces that occupied the island in World War II, said many Guam natives had an emotional attachment to the site. He said a memorial should be incorporated into the airport expansion on that site.
But the most compelling argument is the one that is rooted in dollars and cents. Expanding the commercial airport, officials say, will further strengthen the island's booming economy by increasing tourism and turning the airport into a hub for trans-Pacific flights.
 
Looking to Middle Ground
 Mr. Blaz said he would be willing to find a middle ground in which Guam would compensate the Navy for the cost of relocating the base. "We could modernize that base, get all of it or just part of it," he said. "But we can't even get to the table to discuss the things we could do."
Of the options proposed by Mr. Blaz, Lieutenant LaJoie said there had been no discussions with the Air Force about whether it would be possible to combine operations on Guam.
Mr. Blaz acknowledged that up to now going "hat in hand" to Congressional committees and Cabinet departments to try to persuade them to close the air station has yielded few results.
"The problem with a little fry like me is, there are not too many listeners," he said.

HEADLINE: $32 Million Loss for Quarter Is Reported by Caterpillar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the giant bulldozer and excavating equipment maker, yesterday reported a $32 million loss in the first quarter, attributing the results to weakened demand brought about by the recession.
The loss compared with net earnings of $99 million, or 97 cents a share, in the first quarter of last year. The company's revenues dropped 9.8 percent, to $2.59 billion from $2.87 billion. 
 The company, which is based in Peoria, Ill., said sales of its equipment abroad had weakened by about 1 percent in the quarter. But Caterpillar reported a particularly strong decline within the United States, where sales dropped 20 percent.
 
 $21 Million Write-Off
 The results included a previously announced $21 million pretax charge in relation to the consolidation of the North American operations of its building construction products division. Under that consolidation, a plant in Ontario is to be closed later this year and some of its 380 workers laid off. The operations are to be relocated to a plant in North Carolina.
The company announced in February that it might report a loss because of the economic downturn.
"During this difficult time, we are taking appropriate measures to reduce costs while implementing our reorganization into profit centers and, at the same time, carrying out our factory modernization," Donald V. Fites, the chairman, said yesterday in a statement.
 
 Construction Activity Depressed

Caterpillar said domestic sales were hurt by depressed construction activity that caused steep declines in machine sales. Lower commodity prices also contributed to the sharp declines in demand for machines used to haul everything from forest products and gravel to agricultural products. In addition, the company said, lower demand for truck engines hurt sales of diesel engines.
Although volume fell in sales to foreign customers, that factor was offset by higher prices and the strength of European currencies. But high interest rates and weakening economies "caused dealer machine sales to decline sharply in most industrialized countries," the company said.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Caterpillar's share price fell $1 yesterday, closing at $49.50.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Corn and Soybeans Climb; Soviets Seek Export Credits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Corn and soybean futures prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations that the Bush Administration will grant new export credit guarantees to the Soviet Union. Other grain futures also finished higher.
The Agriculture Department disclosed early yesterday that the Soviet Union was seeking $1.5 billion in export credits to buy food, confirming rumors and reports that had circulated in the markets all week. 
 The Soviets have nearly exhausted $1 billion in American export credits granted in January.
Traders expect the Adminstration to offer at least $500 million in export credits, at least some of which the Soviets are expected to use to buy corn and soybean meal for livestock feed, said William Biedermann, research director at Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage firm. "Their poultry industry is in dire shape," he added. "They need two million to three million metric tons of corn immediately."
United States and Soviet officials are meeting this weekend in Washington to discuss Moscow's request.
Analysts said the price action also reflected a longer-term view that the the Soviets will need much more food aid in the future if their economic situation continues to deteriorate.
Corn futures settled 2 cents to 3 1/4 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $2.56 3/4 a bushel; soybeans were 8 1/4 cents to 10 cents higher, with May at $5.90 1/4 a bushel; wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher, with May at $2.78 3/4 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1 1/4 cents higher, with May at $1.23 a bushel.
Cattle futures settled mostly lower and pork futures ended narrowly mixed ahead of a quarterly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report that confirmed perceptions that the beef cattle supply was expanding.
The Agriculture Department said there were 10.9 million head of cattle on feedlots in the 13 largest cattle-producing states on April 1, which was 8 percent more than a year ago and the largest herd size for that date since 1973.
The market had expected a slightly larger increase, so analysts said the report could prompt some buying of cattle futures on Monday.
Live cattle were unchanged to 0.20 cent lower, with April at 79.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.05 cent to 0.30 cent lower, with April at 89.97 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.05 cent lower to 0.57 cent higher, with April at 52.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.47 cent lower to 0.20 cent higher, with May at 61.27 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

 
 
Faithful to God and I.R.S.
 It is hard to say whether a finding like this will make people run to church or run the other way, but a new survey shows that the more that people attend church, the less likely they are to cheat on their income taxes. 
 The study found that among those who go to church at least once a week, only 7 percent are inclined to cheat at tax time. The number goes up to 15 percent among those who attend one to three times a month and doubles again, to 30 percent, for those who do not go to church at all.
The results are published in the current issue of The Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion and are based on personal interviews with 316 adults in Oklahoma City in 1989 by researchers at the University of Oklahoma.
The survey also found a strong link between religious affiliation and cheating on taxes. Of those who identify with a denomination, only 15 percent said that they were inclined to cheat. The number was nearly 50 percent among those who were unaffiliated.
While the article does not argue that the Oklahoma survey reflects attitudes in the nation as a whole, one of the authors, John Cochran, said that "one can safely generalize" that the results would be the same throughout the Bible Belt region.
 
 Interfaith Harmony
 Trying to patch up their discord over the Persian Gulf war, liberal Protestants and Reform Jews have issued a joint statement on the conflict that acknowledges differences but finds much common ground.
In the weeks before the war began, liberal Protestant leaders, speaking through the National Council of Churches, condemned any use of military force in the gulf, while the Reform congregational organization declared use of military force against Iraq "an acceptable moral option."
The joint statement, issued this week and signed by officials of the National Council of Churches and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said, "We are relieved that the armed conflict in the gulf region has ended, but we must state categorically that there is little cause for jubilation."
Thousands of civilians have died, the statement said, "thousands have been made homeless, and property has been destroyed not only in Kuwait and Iraq but also in Israel, Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Enormous economic dislocation has taken place. Damage to the environment will take years to heal."
The statement also calls on Arabs and Jews to seize the opportunity for peace in the Middle East. But it acknowledges differences between the Jewish and Christian groups on whether the Palestine Liberation Organization should be permitted to negotiate on behalf of the Palestinians.
Finally, the statement calls on the United States Government in the aftermath of the war to work "with equal determination and will" to eliminate American homelessness, poverty, hunger and lack of adequate health care.
The statement calls on all Christians and Jews to "join hands" and "work to make this world into the world that God commanded it could and should be."
 
 Intrafaith Cacophony
 While the joint Christian-Jewish statement achieved an interfaith high note, the reaction to the gulf war left two Jewish groups at each other's throats.
Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Reform group and a signer of the interfaith statement, sharply criticized a postwar declaration by the head of the Lubavitch Hasidic movement, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson.
The Hasidic rabbi's statement, published last month as a full-page advertisement in The New York Times and other newspapers, hailed the allied victory, with "casualties amazingly few," as "miraculous."
In his response, the Reform rabbi said the statement was "a stain on the Jewish soul." Acknowledging that he had taken a public stand in support of the war, Rabbi Schindler added that "my joy is muted" by the thousands of Iraqi dead and wounded. "Are they not God's children, too?" he asked.
Responding to the remarks, Rabbi Manis Friedman, the dean of a Lubavitch school in St. Paul, said Rabbi Schneerson had also expressed compassion for the victims of the war but believed that they too were part of God's plan.
"The thing I don't understand," Rabbi Friedman continued, "is what Schindler does with the entire Bible, with the 10 plagues. When the righteous are victorious over evil, there is something to celebrate, unless Schindler believes there is no evil. In which case, why did he support the war?"

HEADLINE: Holtzman Sees Big Job Loss From Tax Effort by Dinkins

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman warned yesterday that tax increases proposed or adopted by the Dinkins administration could mean the loss of 265,000 jobs in the city and delay recovery from the deep recession.
A study released by economists in Ms. Holtzman's office said the combination of a $822 million tax increase in fiscal year 1991 and the $1.2 billion increase proposed for the next fiscal year would catch up with the city by 1994. Each $100 million increase in the local tax burden could lead to a loss of as many as 10,800 jobs, the study said. 
 The study did not analyze the consequences of not raising taxes and instead making the service reductions that the gap in revenues might necessitate. Such cutbacks, the study said, might well contribute to further job loss and the continuation of the recession.
Ms. Holtzman said she would not take a position on whether the city should raise taxes and neither did the study. She said that while the study did not assess or analyze alternatives, she hoped it would be the beginning of a more informed dialogue about the impact of the city's fiscal policies.
The administration is struggling to reduce a $465 million budget gap for the fiscal year ending June 30.
The City Council has opposed the amount of the proposed tax increase. Peg Breen, the spokeswoman for the Council, said yesterday: "We're glad the Comptroller agrees with us about the size of the Mayor's tax proposal. That's why we've recommended virtually cutting his tax proposals in half."
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, called the study simplistic and the numbers inflated. "The question is, how much of the job loss is through tax increases and how much is the economic environment?" she said.
Commissioner of Finance Carol O'Cleirecain criticized the study as a "crude piece of work" that raised more questions than it answers.
"This is a complicated issue," she said. "What is the mechanism of disincentive here? Where are the job losses supposed to be? If it cannot be used to oppose a local tax increase then what can it be used for?"

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. Is Prepared to Aid Kurdish Refugees in Iran

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The United States is prepared to make a substantial contribution to the effort to help feed and shelter Kurdish refugees fleeing from Iraq to Iran, Administration officials said today.
Discussions between Washington and Teheran, conducted through Swiss intermediaries, have advanced in recent days from cautious feelers to a formal request from Iran for American assistance and an American response asking for a breakdown of aid that is needed. 
 State Department officials said the White House was prepared to move ahead when Iran responds, probably working through the Iranian Red Crescent Society, a private humanitarian organization that is Iran's equivalent of the Red Cross. They stressed that such discussions did not signify an improvement in relations, but that they could conceivably strengthen the hand of moderates in Teheran who are urging openings to the West.
"There is no decision on how far we will go," a State Department official said. "But we are in a responsive mode."
 
'We Need a Specific List'
 It is not clear whether Iran will seek relief supplies or financial assistance. Officials said it was too early to say how much the United States would be asked to donate, but they suggested that the scale of the aid would be far smaller than efforts to help refugees who have fled to Turkey.
The Agency for International Development estimates that more than a million Kurds have already crossed into Iran, and that another 500,000 are heading toward the Iranian border. European governments, working with Teheran, have been the primary source of assistance for the refugees streaming into Iran, while Washington has devoted almost all its attention to dealing with the estimated 820,000 Kurds who have entered Turkey or gathered along the Turkish frontier.
On the Iranian aid request, Andrew S. Natsios, director of the Office of United States Foreign Disaster Assistance, said, "We need a specific list of what they need."
The United States could either make a direct money donation to the Red Crescent Society, or airlift tents, blankets, water containers, plastic sheeting, and generators from warehouses in Guam and Singapore. Such aid would most likely be distributed by international and private aid organizations.
Depending on Iranian Government requests and political considerations, the Administration could either hire private planes to ship the aid to Teheran, or request that the International Red Cross and United Nations use their air fleets to do the job. Officials said it was unlikely that the United States Air Force would land in Iran.
The United Nations has reported that Iraqi refugees in Iran need tents, blankets and food. Including Afghans and Iraqis, Iran currently has about four million refugees, more than any other country in the world.
The United States has previously said it would assist international aid organizations that are trying to help the Kurds in Iran, but has hesitated to offer anything more than token support. No American aid officials are currently stationed in Iran. Since the war, Washington has granted $6 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and $2 million for the International Committee of the Red Cross for refugee assistance for the entire Iraqi refugee crisis. Of that money, American officials could not say how much has gone to Iran.
With the exception of a planeload of blankets supplied last week by Americare, a private relief group, there has been virtually no direct American aid to Iran. Private relief officials said they had virtually no infrastructure inside Iran because they have been made to feel unwelcome by Teheran in recent years.
 
Hostages and Ties to U.S.
 The European Community decided Thursday to send four C-130 planeloads of tents, beds and blankets to Iran. The International Red Cross has the largest program in Iran, fielding 6,000 people to administer 29 refugee camps with 250,000 people, and prepare another camp for an additional 40,000 refugees.
Administration officials said the prospect of a more direct American role in helping Iran would not translate into improved relations with Iran unless Teheran follows up by helping to arrange the release of American and other Western hostages held in Lebanon. The Iranians, for their part, appear to be uncertain whether to try to capitalize on the opening with Washington, and officials here report disagreement in Iran about whether to seek improved ties with the United States.
The officials speculated that President Hashemi Rafsanjani, whom they consider a moderate, could use the crisis to gain influence over radicals who wish to sustain the policies of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic fundamentalist Government of Iran.
Washington has not had diplomatic relations with Iran since April 1980, five months after the United States Embassy in Teheran was seized by Iranian militants and its American occupants taken hostage. The occupation lasted more than a year. Relations did not improve measurably last year, when Washington provided $685,000 in relief to Iran after an earthquake. Iranian officials later asserted that American aid was paltry.
 
Pressure From Aid Groups
 Members of Congress and officials of American humanitarian organizations are pressing the Administration to do more to help the refugees in Iran.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democratic of Massachusetts and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Immigration and Refugee affairs, issued a statement today saying: "A U.S. helping hand extended to Iran in this enormous crisis could be a golden opportunity to heal the divisive issues between our nations. There should be no further delay while people die."

GRAPHIC: Photo: More than a million Kurds are estimated to have crossed into Iran and another 500,000 are believed to be heading toward the border. A group of Kurds rested outside tents at a refugee camp in Zifa, Iran. (Don Heiny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bill Rates Mixed as Bond Prices Fall

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds plunged and long-term interest rates soared late yesterday. But bill rates and other short-term Treasury debt issues remained narrowly mixed.
Dealers said prices of the longer Treasury issues had meandered in a narrow range until the Chicago bond futures market closed at 3 P.M.; then they began to tumble. As a result, the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing February 2021, were offered at 95 29/32, down 24/32, or $7.50 for each $1,000 of face value, in late dealings. The price drop sent the long bond's yield up to 8.24 percent from 8.17 percent the day before and 8.14 percent a week ago. 
 On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the pivotal spot June Treasury bond futures contract finished at 95.22, down 19/32 on the day.
 
 Decline for Long Notes
 Meanwhile, the Treasury's long notes, the 7.75's of 2001, dropped by 18/32, to 97 21/32, while their yield climbed to 8.09 percent, from 8.01 percent the day before and 7.96 percent a week ago.
"While market analysts may speculate over whether or not the Fed will soon ease credit, dealers, investment managers and others making buy-sell decisions are more concerned about the supply of new Treasury paper due in the next few weeks," said Steven R. Richhiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc.
Next week, for example, the Treasury plans to hold its monthly auction of two- and five-year notes, selling $21 billion worth. Mr. Ricchiuto said, "The poor auction results of the seven-year notes sold April 10 caused a bit of concern about next week's auctions of the shorter notes."
On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $12 billion of new two-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.04 percent, up from 7.02 percent the day before. On Thursday, $9 billion of five-year notes go on the block, and the when-issued yield on this issue rose to 7.79 percent, from 7.75 percent the day before.
An even larger series of auctions will take place May 7-9, when the Treasury holds its next quarterly refunding. An estimated $35 billion of notes and bonds will be auctioned.
As for the Federal Reserve, it did not intervene in the credit markets, probably because Federal funds traded well below the Fed's perceived target of 6 percent all day. The funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, is viewed as the basic cost of credit from which all other interest rates graduate upward. The funds traded at 5 13/16 for most of the day before closing at 5.75 percent.
Meanwhile, the discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills, which are most sensitive to the funds rate, rose a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent; six-month bills rose 2 basis points, to 5.77 percent, but the one-year bills fell 3 basis points, to 5.91 percent.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, Tele-Communications Inc., priced $1 billion of zero-coupon convertible debentures, due in 2008, through Merrill Lynch & Company. The debentures were priced at $297.99 per $1,000 of face value, and if held to maturity would yield 7.25 percent a year over the life of the issue.
 
Convertible at $18.06 Price

Moreover, the issue is convertible into common stock at a price of $18.06. Tele-Communications' share price closed yesterday at $16 on the Nasdaq.
The underwriters said the debentures were rated Ba-23 by Moody's Investors Service and BBX by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Caterpillar Inc. priced $300 million of 9 percent noncallable debentures, due in 2006, at 99.983, which would yield investors 9.125 percent. Lehman Brothers is the underwriter. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.
And the Student Loan Marketing Association priced $300 million of 7.35 percent notes, due in 1994, through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The Sallie Mae notes will be offered to investors at various prices from time to time, the underwriter said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Orders Write-Offs By Big Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
American bankers were told by Federal regulators earlier this week to write off 20 percent of their loans to Brazil and 10 percent of their loans to Argentina as losses, bankers said yesterday.
The write-offs are not expected to hurt bank earnings because banks set aside billions of dollars in reserves in 1987 and 1989 to cover such losses. Bank profits are reduced when funds are set aside in the reserve for loan losses, not when a loan loss is declared and the reserve is reduced on the books. 
 "The loans to less-developed counties are now a potential problem for only a handful of banks," noted Mark Gross, a banking analyst at I.B.C.A. Ltd., a bank rating firm. He noted that Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, and BankAmerica had reserves of less than 50 percent of outstanding medium- and long-term loans to less-developed counties. Those reserves may need to be increased in future years, he said, though recent improvements in the economies of several Latin American countries have improved the outlook for debt repayment.
Citicorp, the largest American bank lender to the two countries, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would subtract from its loss reserve $715 million, an amount equal to the loans it must charge off. At the end of the first quarter, Citicorp had $2.3 billion of reserves for $7.5 billion of medium- and long-term loans to less-developed countries in financial trouble. About $3.4 billion of those loans were "cash basis," meaning that the countries' financial troubles were severe enough that interest is recorded only when it is received, not when accrued.
The write-offs, which come when both countries are far behind in interest payments, are a formal recognition by regulators that banks are never likely to collect full payment on the loans. In July, banks were told to write off 20 percent of their loans to both countries. American banks have now been required to write off 40 percent of their Brazilian loans and 70 percent of Argentine loans.
Traders of defaulted bank loans to Brazil and Argentina said yesterday that the action by American regulators had been widely anticipated and did not cause much change in prices of either country's debt. Brazilian loans were offered yesterday at about 28.125 cents on the dollar, not much changed from the beginning of the week, and Argentine loans were offered at 22.5 cents on the dollar.
Both Brazil and Argentina have recently been making partial interest payments. The two countries are suffering sharp downturns.

HEADLINE: Apartment Dwellers Prepare for Service Workers' Strike

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Negotiators began round-the-clock talks for a new contract yesterday as apartment owners completed preparations to do their own building chores while a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. Sunday drew near for 25,000 doormen, porters, elevator operators and other service workers.
Residents in co-op and condominium buildings will have to watch their own lobbies, take out their buildings' garbage and help one another with minor repairs. Owners of rental buildings have to make other arrangements for their tenants. 
 Britten Kent, president of the board of her co-op building at 155 East 73d Street near Lexington Avenue, said residents had stocked up on garbage bags and topped the oil tank because fuel delivery drivers may not cross picket lines if a strike comes.
"Everybody pitches in and supports each other," she said. "We have sent out a general alert to tenants to be aware that they must be security-conscious and that they may be slightly inconvenienced."
 
The Issue Is Money
 James F. Berg, who directs the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, the owners' bargaining group, said the unresolved issues were economic.
"They have a long list of demands, but I think the central core is economic: more pay, costs of benefits," he said, declining to go into detail. His association has 2,800 co-op, condo and rental buildings in all the boroughs except the Bronx, and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Gus Bevona, head of Local 32B-32J of the Building Service Employees International Union, did not respond to repeated requests made since last week for comments on the talks. The law firm of Manning Raab Dealy & Sturm, which represents the local, also did not return calls.
Doormen, elevator operators, porters and other service employees receive $462.73 a week under the current three-year contract, which took effect in 1988 and ends on Sunday, according to the Realty Advisory Board. Handymen make $503 a week and superintendents, who belong to the same union but whose contract does not expire until June 20, receive from $500 to $650 a week, plus housing and utilities if they live in their buildings. The Advisory Board contract generally sets the pattern for nonmember buildings as well.
Wages have been increasing by about 5 percent a year, Mr. Berg said, reflecting the relatively prosperous state of the city's housing market when the contract was signed three years ago. Since then, the market has turned downward, and owners also face the prospect of sharply higher taxes and other expenses.
The last two strikes by the service employees, for a week in 1979 and for 12 days in 1976, came at times when the real-estate market was similarly weakened. There was no consensus among board members and building managers as to the likelihood of a strike.
But Mr. Berg conceded that building owners' economic conditions were a factor at the bargaining table.
 
The Benefit of a Strike
 "The city has already proposed to increase taxes by a large amount, and there are other problems with financing and problems with meeting current maintenance payments by co-operators," he said. "In rental buildings there are even difficulties in renting vacancies, something we have hardly ever seen in New York City before."
Paul Brensilver, head of Streamline Management, said the owners of some buildings his company manages think a strike will save them money.
"They're looking at this in a positive way, as a way to close their maintenance gap," Mr. Brensilver said. "They are actually looking forward to an eight-week strike because it would solve their budget problem."
Co-op owners will generally have to carry their own garbage to the curb if there is a strike, share duties as lobby-watchers and go down to receive deliveries themselves, said Mary Ann Rothman, director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, an apartment owners' group.
The council has also advised buildings to line up security services to watch the lobby during hours that the apartment owners will not, generally the night shift.
Gordon Hough, president of his co-op at 255 West End Avenue near West 72d Street, was philosophical about the prospect of co-op owners having to dirty their hands.
"It all depends on how you view it," he said. "If you think it's something that needs to be done, you can handle it. But if you think taking out your garbage is an intolerable burden, it will be harder for you."

HEADLINE: Cocaine Use and Infant Mortality Decline Together in New York City

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
A decline in the use of cocaine by pregnant women and improved prenatal care last year helped significantly reduce infant mortality in New York City for the first time in four years, city and state health officials said yesterday.
The decline in the infant death rate for 1990, based on preliminary tallies by the State Health Department, is a relief to health officials, who had watched two decades of progress erode as crack, homelessness, AIDS and deepening poverty devastated poor families. 
 But the city's preliminary infant mortality rate for last year is still 25 percent higher than the national rate, which continued to fall in the years that New York City's rate climbed. On average, five babies a day died in the city before their first birthdays in 1990.
 
In Poor Areas, High Death Rates
 Infant mortality also continues to be a stark measue of the chasm between economic classes and racial groups in the city, according to a report released this week by the Greater New York March of Dimes and the United Hospital Fund of New York.
Infants in the 10 poorest neighborhoods of the city died at twice the rate of babies in the 10 wealthiest areas, the study found. Black babies died at two-and-a-half times the rate of white babies. The conclusions were based on city data from 1987 through 1989, the most recent information available by race and neighborhood.
The city's infant mortality rate worsened in 1987 and 1988 and leveled off in 1989. Last year, it declined to 12.1 deaths in 1,000 live births, from 13.1 in 1989, according to projections by the State Health Department.
Karla Damus, the research director for family health services in the city Health Department, said a study of more than 120,000 of the 142,000 birth certificates in 1990 found that the rate of cocaine use among pregnant women also fell significantly, part of what she said was the larger trend of lower cocaine use in the city. The city collects information about drug use on the confidential portion of birth certificates.
"Crack exposure is beginning to turn the corner," Mrs. Damus said.
Babies whose mothers used cocaine during pregnancy in 1989 had a mortality rate more than three times the average rate. The babies were at higher risk not only because their mothers used cocaine, but also because the women were likelier to be poor, homeless, malnourished, sick and battered by their spouses, and less likely to receive prenatal care, said Stephen Kandall, the chief of neonatology at Beth Israel Medical Center.
 
Signs of Decreasing Crack Use
 Though experts say crack is still ravaging many families, there are other statistical signs that its use in the city is decreasing.
Child abuse reports, which rose to 59,353 in 1989, from 41,454 in 1986, dropped to 55,158 in 1990 and are expected to decline further this year, according to city child welfare statistics.
"There is anecdotal evidence that crack use is down among women having children," said Sheila Jack, the spokeswoman for the city's Human Resources Administration.
Cocaine-related emergency room admissions in the city were also down in 1990, as were cocaine-related drug arrests, according to the State Division of Substance Abuse Services.
 
Crack 'Peaked in 1988'
 "You've run the course of the epidemic," said Dr. David A. Bateman, chief of newborn services at Harlem Hospital. "Initially, there were a lot of new recruits to crack. It was fashionable. It peaked in 1988. There haven't been as many new people attracted to the drug. We see the same people over and over."
Tim Smith, senior biostatistician in the State Health Department, cautioned that the city's infant mortality rate for 1990 would probably be somewhat higher when the final tally of births and deaths was completed. "But I'm sure it will be down," he said. "It dropped quite a bit."
Another factor cited by Federal Government statisticians in the decline of infant mortality nationally last year was the introduction of a new drug that helps prevent deaths of premature babies from sudden respiratory failures.
But Dr. Bateman and Dr. Leonard Glass, a neonatologist at Kings County Hospital Center, minimized the role of that medical advance.
 
The Difference of Prenatal Care
 "Possibly that helped me save a couple of babies. But it wouldn't account for a major drop. It's a little blip," Dr. Glass said.
Improved prenatal care helped save the lives of some infants, Mrs. Damus said. In 1990, the state extended Medicaid coverage to more poor pregnant women. The city's infant mortality initiative, which began in 1988 by serving fewer than 1,000 women, is now in full swing, she said. More than 4,000 women received comprehensive prenatal care and follow-up care for the first year of their babies' lives through the program in 1990.
Prenatal care makes a big difference, according to the March of Dimes analysis of city data. The babies of addicted women who received prenatal care were a third less likely to die in infancy than drug-exposed babies whose mothers received late care or no care. One in seven pregnant women in New York City received late or no prenatal care in 1989, the March of Dimes report found. Similar information is not yet available for 1990.
An obstetrician and gynecologist at New York University Medical Center, Dr. Machelle Harris Allen, tried to explain the importance of prenatal care to 30 philanthropic organizations who gathered on Thursday for the presentation of the March of Dimes-United Hospital Fund report, Infants at Risk: Solutions Within Our Reach.
Dr. Allen treated 45 pregnant addicted women in 1989 and 1990 at Bellevue Hospital Center. All but one gave birth to healthy full-term babies, she said.
 
Drugs, Alcohol and AIDS
 One woman she treated smoked crack, sipped rum and tested positive for the AIDS virus. About halfway through her pregnancy, she stopped using drugs and was admitted to the hospital for 10 days when Dr. Allen discovered she had syphilis, a disease that a woman can pass on to her fetus.
"She gave birth to a healthy baby at term. She got a two-bedroom apartment and went home with her baby," Dr. Allen said.
But the story has a sad ending. The intensive attention that Dr. Allen gave the pregnant woman did not continue when she became a new mother. The woman returned to drugs and drink and lost her baby to foster care.
There are still only a handful of residential drug-treatment programs in the city that allow women to keep their children, said David Condliffe, director of the Mayor's Office of Drug Abuse Policy. The city is reviewing 32 proposals for new treatment programs intended to help pregnant women and mothers of young children get off drugs, and will award $5.5 million in contracts for such programs, unless the fiscal crisis results in cuts in financing, he said.
Improved drug treatment and better prenatal care are essential elements in reducing infant deaths, Mr. Condliffe said. "The problem isn't that these women don't know about Piaget's theories of child development," he said. "It's that the refrigerator was empty because the mother was feeding her addiction, not her kid."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: All Walks of Life Now Converge In New York City's Jobless Lines

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The slide that began three years ago on Wall Street has now ricocheted throughout the city's economy, claiming jobs in everything from banking to auto repair. As the recession continues to deepen, tens of thousands of New Yorkers are discovering its pain, finding themselves in unemployment lines that are growing longer and ever-more democratic.
More than 100,000 people lost their jobs in New York City in the last three years, government analysts say. And the number of people who were laid off and applied for unemployment insurance reached an eight-year high in the last month. 
 Even jobs that are sometimes viewed as a last resort for New Yorkers struggling to make it through hard times -- jobs like waiters and waitresses, sales clerks, office temporaries -- are in very short supply.
Dawn Salvesen, who has worked for 10 years as a waitress in Manhattan pubs, lost her job the day after Christmas and has been looking for a new one ever since.
 
'There Is Nothing Out There'
 "The last few ads I answered, there were 50 people there for the job," said Ms. Salvesen, who is 30 years old and lives in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. "There is nothing out there."
Nationally, the number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits climbed to 543,000 in late March, the highest level since January 1983. The number of new claims plunged during the following two weeks, suggesting to some economists that the end of the national downturn may be in sight.
In New York City, though, the number of new unemployment claims reached an eight-year high in late March and has remained at that level, about 10,000 each week, according to the State Department of Labor.
"This is not your typical, run-of-the mill recession," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In a typical recession in New York, he said, about two-thirds of the jobs lost are in manufacturing. This time the impact is much broader.
The human suffering that accompanies a recession is often unseen. But a week of interviews with dozens of unemployed New Yorkers at offices of the State Department of Labor in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn demonstrated that the pain is pervasive.
A fine-arts auctioneer, let go last November after 10 years at a Manhattan auction house, talked of his anxieties: His severance pay has run out, there are no openings in his field and he is fighting eviction from his apartment.
A 33-year-old woman who was laid off last January from her job as an office clerk wondered how she and her husband would pay their bills. They have five children.
A 68-year-old retired employee of the Social Security Administration lost her part-time job as a telephone marketer in Queens. The loss of that income -- about $125 a week -- has forced her to eliminate all luxuries.
 
People of All Kinds
 If nothing else, the financial fallout is democratic. The crowds seeking unemployment insurance include people of all races, ethnic backgrounds and social classes -- from messengers and maintenance men in jeans and T-shirts to accountants and lawyers in pin-striped suits. How the recession is affecting each varies widely, depending on everything from personal savings to marital status to state of mind.
Ms. Salvesen, the waitress from Brooklyn, wore green fatigues when she bicycled last week to the State Labor Department's office on Kings Highway in Bensonhurst to file her claim.
Although Ms. Salvesen lost her job more than three months ago, she waited to apply for her unemployment benefits because she never expected to have trouble finding a job. There was another reason, too. "It's pride, I guess," she said.
But Ms. Salvesen, who is married to a city police officer, said she had used up her savings and could no longer afford the luxury of pride. She said she spends three days a week walking Manhattan neighborhoods, asking about work at restaurants.
"It's driving me crazy," she said. "I'm bored. I need to keep busy. I'm just going to keep looking until I eventually find something."
But as the number of layoffs builds, the unemployed are finding it harder to find work. The average time that people remain on unemployment insurance has climbed to nearly 20 weeks, also an eight-year high, according to the State Labor Department. Many workers who have pounded the pavement longer than Ms. Salvesen say their morale is sinking.
Al Perez, a 31-year-old laborer from Corona, Queens, was among 80 people laid off last September by a large computer-assembly plant in Brentwood, L.I. His 26 weeks of eligibility for unemployment insurance has expired; he got his final check last week. He has no idea where or when he will find work. He said there are no factory jobs available. He is willing to work in a restaurant -- he was once a waiter and busboy -- but there are no openings.
"Everyone says, 'Wait, we'll call you,' " he said. "But it's all promises, promises."
Some people feel desperate. A 40-year-old man, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he had been searching for six months for a job as a restaurant manager. Fluent in French and Spanish, he said he had run dining rooms in major hotels for 15 years. He had never been out of work for more than a month.
 
Under the Suit, Desperation
 Dressed in a beige summer suit with a blue shirt and a red knit tie, and carrying a brown briefcase, he looked through computerized job listings at the Labor Department office on West 20th Street at the Avenue of the Americas. But his attire and surface calm belied the anxieties that he said had overtaken him.
"My unemployment is running out in two weeks," he said. "My savings are gone. I don't know what I am going to do. I need a job immediately."
He has had countless interviews, but only three involved actual openings. He is divorced, with a son to support, and he pays a high rent in Manhattan.
"It's scary out there," he said.
Older people with family responsibilities often feel a heavier burden than those who are young or single. People cushioned by savings can be more patient than those without.
Michael Posner, 34, is a Manhattan resident with a bachelor's degree in marketing and 10 years experience working for clothing manufacturers. He was laid off last May, a victim, he said, of the falloff in retail sales and the competition from imports. It is his first time out of work, Mr. Posner said, and he is trying to take the long view.
"I decided not to freak out over it," he said. He works a few days a month for a friend in the travel business and spends a lot of time at a gym or in museums when he is not looking for work. He ran out of unemployment benefits months ago, but he is getting by on his savings and the occasional work. He keeps his equilibrium, he said, by reminding himself that the economic forces that produced his unemployment should also eventually provide him with a job.
"I'm just a statistic of the times, I think," Mr. Posner said. "I don't look at myself as the problem, but as the result of the shrinking of the industry."
"I think this is a cycle, and I think it will pass," he added.
As the recession has worsened, it has touched more and more blue-collar workers, who often lack the savings -- and the confidence -- that are propping up people like Mr. Posner.
Phil Pasquale, a stocky auto mechanic from Bay Ridge with a crewcut and an open, friendly demeanor, has been buffeted by the economy in the last few years. He has been laid off twice by auto dealers in Brooklyn, most recently a year ago. He then worked as a fill-in driver for the United Parcel Service. He would report for work in Queens at a daily "shape-up." If he was needed, he would be given a route; if not, he would be sent home without pay.
Mr. Pasquale was lais off from that job two weeks ago. "It's like you come to the realization that the world goes on without you," he said, as he waited to apply for unemployment insurance in Bensonhurst.
Mr. Pasquale said he did not know how much he would get each week; the maximum is now $280 a week, more than he expects to receive. To get by, he said, he would have to sell his car, a 1979 Cadillac that he fixed up himself. Mr. Pasquale hopes to sell the car for $6,000, or twice what he paid.
After working nearly five years as a mechanic, Mr. Pasquale is bitterly disappointed to be unemployed.
"I figured if I had a skilled trade, I'd be able to get ahead," Mr. Pasquale said. "It's a cruel world."
Part-time and temporary workers have been among those hit hardest, as have young people trying to start their careers. Marilyn Davis, a 40-year-old mother of two from Manhattan, worked for 10 years as a secretary on Wall Street. She started working as a temporary secretary three years ago.
 
One Day in Three Months
 "I think I've worked one day in the past three months," Ms. Davis said as she waited in line at the Manhattan unemployment office on West 20th Street. "With the recession, temps are the first to be let go."
She said she had been looking for a job, either temporary or full-time, for months. She responds to advertisements, has had many interviews, but has received no offers.
Meanwhile, she and her husband, a schoolteacher, struggle to get by. "It's really hard now," she said. "You juggle your bills."
"Does it depress me?" she said. "Here I get $250. When I work, I get $600 a week. I need to work."
So does Greg Cozine, a 23-year-old from Westhampton Beach, L.I., who graduated last year with a major in business from the University of Delaware. He has been looking for a banking job ever since.
Standing in line at the West 20th Street office, Mr. Cozine was dressed as if he already had a banking job, wearing a blue suit, a white button-down shirt, a red tie and black loafers. He said he wears the suit to visit employment agencies; he had been to 15 or 16. But it is likely to go back in his closet for a while. Few if any jobs are available in banking, and he fears he may have to go back to summer gardening in Westhampton Beach.
