HEADLINE: Summer Goal Is Keeping Youth Safe

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Seeking to head off a summer of boredom and potential violence as children are caught in gunfire and their parents face the economic pressures of a recession, the Dinkins administration yesterday detailed its plan for summer jobs, counseling and school-based programs for young people.
The $8 million program, financed in part by the Mayor's criminal-justice plan, includes tickets to recreational events, lessons in dispute mediation and academic counseling. 
 "Every summer our children are caught in the crossfire of the dealers and the muggers -- their hopes and dreams shattered in the spray of stray bullets," Mayor David N. Dinkins said.
City officials said they moved up announcing the program, Youth Futures, Safe Summer '91, by a month because of three days of unrelated incidents in which eight bystanders were caught in the crossfire of gunfights. Two died; six were wounded. Six children were among them.
 
Comparisons With Last Summer
 In the most recent bystander shooting, a 13-year-old boy playing pool inside a Bronx social club Thursday night was shot in the leg by someone driving by in a car.
More than a dozen children have been hit by bullets in the last month in shootings in which they were the intended victims or were bystanders, according to police reports. Recently, Mr. Dinkins visited the hospital bed of a Brooklyn boy wounded as he stood a few feet from where the police fired on people alleged to be drug dealers.
"They're not kids anymore when they have to live like this," Richard L. Murphy, the Youth Services Commissioner, said yesterday.
The recent shootings have led to comparisons with last summer, when 29 children were shot and eight of them killed over three months. After that violence and demands that the Mayor do something, Mr. Dinkins announced his criminal-justice plan to hire thousands more police officers and provide comprehensive youth services.
 
Jobs, Activities and Outreach
 "I know that some believe we should deal with crime through police and the criminal-justice system alone," Mr. Dinkins said. "But I reject that notion. That sort of one-dimensional approach offers no alternative to the growing allure of crime and drugs."
At a City Hall news conference yesterday, the Mayor and other city officials described new programs.
Among them, a Neighborhood Youth Alliance for 5,000 youths from 11 to 21 years old is intended to address a variety of communication skills. In another program, street outreach workers from several city agencies will seek out young people and try to involve them in school-based activities and drug-prevention efforts.
The Department of Employment will offer jobs in libraries, hospitals, day-care centers and offices to 27,000 people from 14 to 21. Ten schools will be open 16 hours a day every day to offer programs intended to reduce drug use and help communities get organized. Tickets for plays, ball games and other activities will be distributed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Gasoline prices are likely to rise by 10 to 15 cents a gallon at the pump by mid-May, to an average of $1.20 to $1.25, analysts say. The nation's gasoline stocks have fallen to the lowest level in 16 years, and imports this month remain below normal levels with the summer driving season approaching. [Page 33.] 
 An effort by corporations and civil rights groups to draft a job discrimination bill collapsed in the face of strong opposition from the White House and small businesses. [1.]
The slide that began three years ago on Wall Street has now ricocheted throughout New York City's economy, claiming jobs in everything from banking to auto repair. [1.]
 
Markets
Stock prices fell steeply. The Dow, which broke through 3,000 this week, tumbled by 33.67, to 2,965.59. The gain for the week, though, was 44.80. [33.]
Prices of Treasury bonds plunged and long-term interest rates soared late in the day. But bill rates and other short-term Treasury debt issues remained narrowly mixed. [36.]
The dollar soared again as confidence grew that the economy was ready to climb out of recession. Gold prices declined. [42.]
Corn and soybean futures prices surged amid expectations that the U.S. would grant credit guarantees to the Soviet Union. [42.]
 
Companies
BankAmerica is poised to make itself a major presence on the East Coast if it wins the bidding for the Bank of New England. And even if the bank is not chosen, other expansion opportunities await the San Francisco bank, No. 2 behind Citicorp. [33.]
McDonnell Douglas reported a strong earnings gain, helped in part by an increase in deliveries of MD-11 jetliners. [34.]
Caterpillar reported a $32 million quarterly loss, attributing the results to weakened demand brought about by the recession. [33.]
A jury awarded a small New Jersey company, Industry Network Inc., $246 million in damages from Armstrong World Industries in a civil antitrust conspiracy and monopoly case. [34.]
Carter Hawley Hale is expected to announce next week the consolidation of two of its California department store chains. [35.]
The former president of Cubic Defense Systems was sentenced to 18 months in prison for theft of Government property. [35.]
 
International
 Resolving an 11th-hour dispute, Volkswagen has closed what appears to be the biggest Western investment deal in Eastern Europe by buying a majority share in Skoda of Czechoslovakia. [33.]
Yugoslavia's economy is a visible casualty of the feuding among the nation's six republics. [33.]
American bankers were told by Federal regulators to write off as losses 20 percent of their loans to Brazil and 10 percent of their loans to Argentina. [34.]
Divisions in the Administration over past American exports to Iraq widened when the top investigator of the Customs Service said his agency would defy the Commerce Department and investigate some companies that applied for export licenses. [45.]
 
Today's Columns
As layoffs spread, all employed people should be putting their finances in shipshape condition, experts counsel. Your Money. [34.]
A way to breed seeds for seedless watermelons that is said to be far quicker and cheaper than methods in use has been patented by researchers at the University of Florida. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: New Jersey Schools Warn Parents on Cuts

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAWRENCE, N.J., April 19

 BODY:
Grappling with the effects of a tax revolt, school districts around the state are warning parents to expect serious cuts in services in the next school year.
Critics in Trenton say such warnings are just the keening of bureaucrats, who refuse to cut budgets layered with fat. But anxiety and bitterness are rife in places like Lawrence High School, part of a district that the state classifies as relatively affluent and that is proud of its academic achievements. 
 "There is a sinisterness to all this," William Tucker, a 43-year-old history teacher, said. "If they can't make all schools the same by bringing the lower schools up, they must bring the upper schools down."
After the Legislature placed tight caps on school spending last month, the Lawrence district announced cuts in high school teacher positions, summer school, sports and the purchase of textbooks.
Administrators said they feared that even that scaled-back budget might be rejected in voting on April 30.
In five years Lawrence is scheduled to lose more than $3 million in state aid for pension and Social Security costs as a result of the Quality Education Act. The act, together with a State Supreme Court decision last year, was intended to shift aid to poorer and middle-income districts, to make spending more equitable across the state.
As a result, teachers, students and parents here are focusing on two central questions: How far can the district cut without harming education? And does a plan to help poorer districts have to harm richer ones?
 
'I'm Being Penalized'
 "I'm being penalized for attending a good school," Tom Haller, 17, a junior, said. "Its outrageous."
The concern began to rise last year when Gov. Jim Florio and Democrats in the Legislature pressed into law the Quality Education Act, which intends to raise $1.1 billion from increased income taxes for school aid and property-tax relief. Under the plan, major parts of the aid for the wealthiest districts will taper off after five years. Wealthier districts like Lawrence would then have to choose between cutting expenses and raising property taxes.
After the election in November, when voters expressed rage at the tax increases, the Democratic president of the Senate, John A. Lynch of New Brunswick, pushed through legislation shifting $360 million from school aid to property-tax relief. The legislation, which Mr. Florio signed month, places caps of 7.5 to 9 percent on spending increases in most districts, except some poorer ones. Those are allowed increases of up to 20 percent.
Since then, administrators from many of the 616 districts in the state have complained that the caps do not permit their schools to keep up with sharply rising costs, including labor contracts and insurance.
In Cherry Hill, officials say 44 employees, including 25 teachers, will be eliminated. In Princeton, the superintendent says she plans to eliminate 10 teaching positions and increase the average class size to 22 or 23 from 21.
Even administrators in some poor districts like as Newark and Jersey City say the new caps mean much of their increased aid will go to property-tax relief, forcing them to delay plans for preschool programs and smaller classes. Under the Lynch bill, $82 million of the $288 million of increased aid promised to the 30 poorest districts now has to go to ease property taxes.
 
Pressure Against Caps
 "The most damaging thing has been the psychological impact of the tax revolt, not just the dollars alone," said Superintendent Fred Stokley of Ridgewood, where voters defeated a school bond issue, 2 to 1, in December. "Schools have become the target."
An education aide to Mr. Florio, Thomas Corcoran, said many school boards were trying to use shock tactics to scare voters into approving their proposed budgets. After a decade in which school budgets rose more than 10 percent a year, he said, the districts, like the rest of government, have to adapt to a new austerity.
School districts are receiving $4.5 billion in aid this year, including more than $500 million in increases. Nonetheless, 97 districts asked the State Education Department for permission to spend more than their caps allow. More than 50 other districts plan to ask the permission of voters to do so on April 30.
"We urge the public not to be duped by any school bureaucrat with a six-figure salary who says the only way to save the football team is to let the school board exceed its state-mandated caps," Mr. Lynch said.
 
Courses and Extracurriculars
 On a recent day in Lawrence High School, the voices of a choral group singing madrigals wafted through the halls. A sign near the entrance boasted of a student who had won a national music competition in Florida. Another sign asked for volunteers for a production of Dylan Thomas's "Under Milkwood." A few doors away, students typed on some of the 18 computer terminals in the writing laboratory.
Superintendent Barry L. Gleim said that after officials in Trenton had informed him that he faced a 7.75 percent cap on increased spending, he cut $1 million from a budget of more than $31 million. The district employs 506 people.
The district plans to cut back on elective courses, which include honors Latin, genetics and aerospace technology. Several teaching positions will disappear in the high school, he said, as will a substance-awareness coordinator and coaches for activities like football, basketball and cheerleading and the color guard.
The problem, Mr. Gleim said, was that 80 percent of the district costs were fixed for the year, including a 28 percent rise in insurance premiums and the third year of a teachers' contract with 10 percent raises. The starting salaries for teachers is $24,500 a year. Mr. Gleim is paid $102,000.
 
In Case of Failure
 "These contracts were signed years ago, when the economy was healthy," Mr. Gleim said. "Education has been playing catch-up for an awfully long time."
Mr. Gleim said he feared that voters would a budget that would raise property taxes 5.8 percent. In February they defeated a referendum for $17 million in bonds for a new school by more than 2 to 1. If the budget fails, it would be left to the Township Council to work out a new one.
An 11th grader, Susan Suh, 16, said the student body was rife with rumors that sports and advanced-placement courses would soon disappear. Academic achievement, she said, is a central concern for her family, including her father, who arrived from Korea in poverty 17 years ago and became a vice president at the Bank of New York.
Miss Suh said she had signed up for four advanced-placement courses next year, which she hoped would improved her chance of being admitted to Princeton University. But, she added, she fears that by the time she becomes a senior the college-level courses will disappear and that she will be at a disadvantage in competing with top students from other schools.
"Without them, I wonder how colleges would look at me," she said. " It's not fair. It's not my fault."

HEADLINE: Haitian Music From Another Era

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Some minutes after the appointed time, 10 P.M., Le Manoir was still half-empty. Back from the dance floor, men in suits and open-necked shirts crowded the bar, calling in Creole for their next Heineken, their next Black Label and turning smiles on the women behind them.
The club owner, Lesly Mirville, glanced at his watch. Ignoring the empty tables, he smoothed the front of his blazer, a double-breasted number that funneled his large torso into an improbable V. Outside, the strip of Nostrand Avenue that is a main drag of Haitian Brooklyn was not yet double-parked. 
 With the humility of a local dance band, the Orchestre Tropicana d'Haiti started up anyway.
As if beckoned by the lilting sound, big cars clogged the street outside. Bouncers came to attention and the doors began flapping open, letting in more men in dark suits, led by more women in bright dresses. Mr. Mirville spread a pair of satisfied fingers over his pencil mustache and smiled.
 
Something Special Indeed
 Elsie Boursiquot, who had arrived early, came alive in her seat.
"This is very special!" insisted the 25-year-old woman, a lab technician from Cap-Haitien and Flatbush. "Every time they come I miss Haiti."
In a world as vibrant as that of Haitian music in New York, "special" is a tag of some consideration. On this Sunday night, like every weekend night, other clubs in Brooklyn, a couple in Queens and Manhattan and perhaps another in New Jersey were filled with "mini-jazz," the driving, electrified dance music that has moved Haitians here -- and Haiti from a distance -- since the 1970's.
But a performance of Orchestre Tropicana is something that happens in New York maybe once a year, maybe twice.
Amid the frantic synthesizers and fast guitars of smaller bands that play a form of Haiti's traditional roiling, effervescent rhythms -- referred to as "compas direct" -- but have come of musical age while living and working in Brooklyn, Tropicana echoes from an age gone by. Like its younger counterparts, the 19-piece orchestra weaves a complex fabric of discrete, steady rhythms. But its music freezes a time of big bands and big dances when a fast dance could still be a close one and plaintive baritones and swinging horns were still exciting, romantic stuff.
 
The Distant Roots
 Compared with the guitar-driven compas arrangements that New York-based groups like Tabou Combo, System Band and Skah Shah have patiently made popular outside the Haitian community, Tropicana's music is so gently paced as to seem rooted in another country. And in some ways it is.
In Miami, Montreal and especially Brooklyn, younger Haitian musicians have spent the last decade or so soaking up contemporary African rhythms, American pop and instrumental jazz as well as other music from the Francophone West Indies. Tropicana, which remains firmly based in Cap-Haitien, on Haiti's northern coast, on the other hand, remained a repository of Caribbean sounds without regard to their linguistic origin.
During two of its recent five-hour nights in Brooklyn (the band will play tonight at St. Joachim and Anne Church in Hollis, Queens, and tomorrow at the Days Inn in Nanuet, N.Y.), Tropicana moved through the merengue of its Dominican neighbors, salsa from Puerto Rico and cumbias from Colombia. Aficionados -- what the Haitians call les vrai melomanes -- would explain this as evidence of the breadth and suppleness of real Haitian compas rhythms. (They might also look askance at the eclecticism of bands like Tabou, which in a single song might refer to everything from the zouk music of Martinique and Guadeloupe to West African soukous to the theme from "My Three Sons.")
 
Playing to the People
 Haitians sometimes refer to Tropicana's as the old style. "Tropic," as the band is called, would prefer to be thought of as an institution.
"If there is any corner of Haiti that we don't play, it's because of some problem, like bad roads," said Cinna O. Charles, the band leader known as Ti Blanc. "But even in those places, they know Tropicana."
The pride of veteran band members refers to more than their having endured the political and economic hardships that other Haitian musicians fled. By the time members of L'Orchestre Caraibes reincarnated themselves 28 years ago as the L'Orchestre Tropicana, many of them had already been struggling for years to keep together.
The Orchestre Septentrional, Haiti's oldest big band, was already well established in Cap-Haitien, Tropicana's hometown. To Tropicana fans, anyway, Septen was the upper-class favorite, the band that Government bureaucrats, landowners and shopkeepers would see at the Rhumba Night Club -- and that poorer people saw only during street carnivals.
Tropicana, which found a home at a dowdier spot called the Vanvalou, counted some of the best early compas composers among its alumni. But that honor roll, which includes names like Namours Jean-Baptiste and Weber Sicot, could also be a list of those who grew desperate at Tropicana's tough straits and left to work elsewhere.
 
The Victory of Surviving
 "In a small town, the competition was fierce, and it was very, very difficult for two bands to survive," recalled Pierre Joachim, a Consolidated Edison accounting manager who grew up a Tropicana fan in Cap-Haitien. "It's some sort of victory that Tropicana is still playing."
Though the band no longer worries about feeding its members, its schedule shows no evidence of new comforts. Many of its shows are still the major events of small towns and villages, which reserve their turns a year in advance. (Tours of the United States generally wait until Easter time, when the work in Haiti slows.)
After years of lyrical fun at Septentrional's expense, Tropicana's songs are now more likely to revel in the band's own popularity. One of them, "Serum," gave half-serious voice the other night to fictional fans who sang in Creole, "Tropicana we love you/ You are the serum/ That treats all our ills."
Even more than the next generation of Haitian bands, whose political music generally touches only obliquely on the Haitian turmoil of the moment, Tropicana considers its serum strictly social.
"We are musicians, therefore we are apolitical," Mr. Charles insisted. "If the people are suffering, if the people are hungry, we sing about that. If the country needs a change, we ask for that change."
 
New Choice, Tough Choice
 A current hit, "Nou Refize Gran Moune," which roughly translates from Creole as "We Refuse to Grow Up," is the sort of composition Mr. Charles is talking about. "Our brothers are suffering," warns the song, which urges Haitians to come together. "They are dying of hunger/ Because you are eating every day."
At Le Manoir and the Rivoli, another Haitian club on Flatbush Avenue that also seemed to draw an all-Haitian audience, such Tropicana lyrics seemed to evoke more than the usual quotient of nostalgia.
"When we first came here in 1973, we had even more of a sense of that nostalgia," Mr. Charles said. "Many people didn't have their working papers, so they couldn't go home. And when they came to a dance, they were seeing Haiti through us."
But to some of Tropicana's audience, the reminders seemed more difficult at a moment when Haiti's political turmoil appears finally to have ended and the democracy for which so many hoped is in place. Now, many said, the exiles who dreamed of going home are having to confront the question of whether repatriation is worth the sacrifice of comforts that are still unavailable there.
"This gives me terrible nostalgia," said Yves-Rose Jean-Jacques, a student from Cap-Haitien and Flatbush. "I want to go back so much. And we will, some day."
For the moment, though, Miss Jean Jacques said, she would settle for Tropicana.

HEADLINE: Timely Help for Nicaragua

 BODY:
Gallantry abounded this week when Violeta Chamorro made the rounds in Washington, a year after her inauguration as President of Nicaragua. President Bush extolled her "exhilarating victory" over the Sandinistas. After she addressed Congress, a California Republican called her "a miracle in the Western Hemisphere." But her people can't eat bouquets, and the best news was Mr. Bush's offer to lead an international effort to help Nicaragua raise $360 million to make overdue payments on a crushing $9.4 billion foreign debt.
It's the least Washington can do. Nicaragua's economy shrank last year, while inflation soared. After a decade of Sandinista mismanagement and a U.S.-instigated contra war, Nicaragua sorely needs international help. It's embarrassing that Washington has disbursed only $207 million of $541 million pledged to a democratic regime that honors human rights and seeks economic reform. 
 Some American conservatives ungallantly fault Mrs. Chamorro's decision to retain Humberto Ortega, brother of the former President, as armed forces chief. Their grumbling is doubly unfair. It gives no weight to her success in reducing the army from 80,000 to 28,000, with further cuts promised. And it ignores the political reality that the Sandinistas lost an election, not a war. A similar need for reconciliation induced a democratic Government in Chile to retain a former right-wing dictator, General Pinochet, as armed forces chief -- without complaints in Washington.
Mrs. Chamorro's most formidable asset is her popularity; she is a healer, not an avenger. Everyone knows that the divisions in her country are mirrored in the conflicting politics of her children: one of her sons is editor of the Sandinista newspaper, Barricada, while another heads the family-owned and resolutely anti-Sandinista paper La Prensa.
She is opposed by die-hards at both extremes, either of which could have caused the unsolved murder of Enrique Bermudez, the former contra commander. Habits of violence persist, as does the winner-take-all view of politics. Striving for a better way, Mrs. Chamorro has earned American affection and international support.

HEADLINE: BankAmerica's Eastward Push

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19

 BODY:
When the BankAmerica Corporation was reeling from losses a few years ago, executives renounced their global ambitions and said they would concentrate on retail banking in California and the West.
The bank's executives still say that, only now they joke that "West" means anything west of Bermuda. That is because BankAmerica is poised to make itself a major presence on the East Coast if it wins the bidding for the insolvent Bank of New England. 
 Even if BankAmerica is not chosen by Federal regulators, who are expected to announce their decision by Wednesday, bank executives and analysts say there will be other expansion opportunities for the San Francisco-based bank, the nation's second largest, after Citicorp.
 
 The Laughter Ends
 Only five years ago, BankAmerica, the parent of Bank of America, was the laughingstock of the industry. But through divestitures, employee layoffs and management changes it has made a breathtaking recovery and is now far stronger than most of its main competitors.
So, while the big New York banks and some California rivals nurse problems caused by a stack of bad real estate loans, BankAmerica is in a unique position to move to the forefront in the effort to create the first truly nationwide retail bank.
"The Bank of America could emerge as one of the few American banks that has got key critical market shares," said Thomas Hanley, banking analyst at Salomon Brothers. "If you give them another two to three years, they will truly be nationwide in scope."
BankAmerica has already spent about half a billion dollars for 12 institutions in the last 18 months, most of them insolvent savings and loans bought with Federal assistance. The acquisitions brought BankAmerica 373 new branches and $14 billion in deposits and expanded its network from California and Washington into six other Western states.
For a bank that had its own near-death experience just a few years ago, such a rapid expansion might seem foolhardy. The moves could risk diluting management and exposing BankAmerica to uncertain economies in New England and Arizona at a time when California's own economic outlook is uncertain.
Some industry executives and analysts have questioned in particular BankAmerica's bid for the Bank of New England. Even if BankAmerica gets a bank without bad loans, the bank still might not make money, they say. And managing an institution across the country might be hard.
Frank N. Newman, BankAmerica's vice chairman and chief financial officer, said BankAmerica thought the New England economy would eventually recover. He also said BankAmerica's international business gave it experience in running banks far afield. He said BankAmerica planned to keep many of the Bank of New England's managers, who are new and not considered responsible for the bank's failure.
Mr. Newman also said that the way the acquisitions were being handled, with regulators removing the bad loans from the failed institutions, removed much of the risk for the new owner. Indeed, buying failed institutions is turning out to be such an attractive way for banks to expand that Congress has started to criticize regulators for arranging deals that some lawmakers contend are too sweet.
 
A National Vision
 Mr. Newman said BankAmerica was being driven by a vision that "in the long run, national banking was just going to make sense for this nation and the decade of the 90's was when it's going to occur."
The bank had not been thinking of expanding elsewhere so soon, but as its New England bid shows, it is willing to jump if the opportunity presents itself. BankAmerica is believed to be interested in Illinois, the Mid-Atlantic region, and in Florida and other parts of the Southeast. But it is not particularly interested in New York, where the retail banking market is extremely competitive.
"We're trying to be careful about not getting caught up in manifest destiny," Mr. Newman said in an interview.
 
A Company Tradition
 Manifest destiny, as reflected in the name Bank of America, is part of the company's tradition, dating back to A. P. Giannini, who founded the bank in 1904 and built a multistate empire. But in 1958 the Federal Government forced the divestiture of banks outside California into what is today the First Interstate Bancorp.
Later, even though interstate banking laws kept it from buying branches in most states, BankAmerica tried to establish a nationwide presence in financial services by buying a consumer finance company and the Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage.
But BankAmerica had to sell those units and part of its overseas operations to stave off financial collapse in the mid-1980's. The bank lost $1.8 billion from 1985 through 1987, largely because of bad loans in real estate, energy and agriculture and because of bloated expenses.
 
Broad Management Shifts

The divestitures, large layoffs and a nearly complete turnover in top management led to the bank's recovery. The bank concentrated on its California retail operations, which were revived under Richard M. Rosenberg, now the chairman and chief executive.
BankAmerica's common equity at the end of 1990 was 5.24 percent of its $110 billion in assets, one of the highest ratios among the large banks. BankAmerica's stock has also been strong, reaching a record high of $39.50 on Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock closed today at $38.25, down 32.5 cents.
Last year BankAmerica earned a record $1.1 billion and analysts expect some growth this year, while most other banks will show declines. First-quarter earnings reported Thursday were about even with the period last year. The bank's profitability was held back by bad loans in real estate and for leveraged corporate takeovers.
But BankAmerica has fewer real estate and leveraged buyout loans than many big banks, partly because its weakness in the mid-1980's kept it from competing to make many of those loans. In a way, its problems then are responsible for the bank's strength now.
"The best thing that happened to Bank of America is it got hit by a 2-by-4 five years ago," said an official at a rival California bank.
In its current expansion binge, BankAmerica has been criticized at times for paying too much. When it bought the Benjamin Franklin Federal Savings and Loan Association in Portland, Ore., its $162 million bid was $50 million more than one from the Security Pacific Corporation.
But the real determination of whether the price was too high depends on how successful Bank of America is in turning the acquired savings institutions into commercial banks. Banks have feared that savings and loan customers were attracted only by the high interest rates those institutions offered and would leave once the rates were lowered.
But Bank of America is apparently keeping a vast majority of the customers. It will not say exactly how many because it considers that competitive information.
To hear Mr. Newman explain it, BankAmerica has made a science of digesting failed savings and loans. First it puts its name on the institution. It installs its own credit policies and banking products. It processes mortgage and consumer loan requests in special California processing centers and begins commercial lending services.
So far, the acquisitions have not strained BankAmerica's resources. Nor have they made much of a difference in earnings because the institutions, taken together, are still a fraction of the size of BankAmerica.
Even the Bank of New England, which would come with about $15 billion in assets after the bad loans are removed, would not make that much difference for BankAmerica. "For us to add another $2 billion S.& L. is not a major undertaking," Mr. Newman said.
 
The Strongest Bidder
 BankAmerica is clearly the strongest bank bidding for the Bank of New England, and could most easily supply the $750 million or so in capital that Federal regulators are expected to require of the winning bidder. But BankAmerica faces competition from two local bidders, the Bank of Boston and the Fleet/Norstar Financial Corporation, a Rhode Island banking company that is bidding in combination with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists.
The Bank of Boston has argued that a local owner would be better. If that bank won, it could eliminate overlapping branches with the Bank of New England, achieving great cost savings.
But the Bank of Boston is itself losing money and might not be able to handle the acquisition. It recently strengthened its bid by arranging to sell $1 billion in new stock if it wins.
Fleet/Norstar argues that Kohlberg, Kravis will bring fresh capital into the banking system, whereas BankAmerica will only shift it from one region to another.
The issue is complicated. If BankAmerica wins, it could strengthen banking in the region and alleviate a credit squeeze. But if it uses its strength to gain too much market share from weakened local banks, it could contribute to more banking failures in the region.
Even if BankAmerica loses, there will be more Bank of New Englands in the future. Having seen its global ambitions cut short before, BankAmerica aims not to fail again.

HEADLINE: A Way Out of the CUNY Impasse

BYLINE: By Jerald Posman; Jerald Posman was vice chancellor of budget and finance at the City University from 1977 to 1984.

 BODY:
One of the most painful signs of New York City's fiscal crisis is the proposed tuition increase at the City University. In protest, students have occupied buildings at most of CUNY's 18 campuses. But there is no guarantee that a large tuition increase will raise revenue if it decreases enrollment among students of modest means.
For the poor and lower middle class, there is no better long-term investment than the cost of tuition at the City University. And for the state and city, there is no better long-term investment than to subsidize the costs of the City University. 
 This is not fantasy. This is the history of higher education in New York City for more than 150 years. College graduates in their lifetimes will earn, at least, two to three times more than those finishing high school, and the great majority of CUNY's graduates will continue to live and work in the city. No other government program does as much to make the city economically competitive and to break the relentless cycle of economic and social dependency.
Fifteen years ago, because of an unparalleled fiscal crisis, tuition was imposed at CUNY. Seventy thousand students left the university -- 30 percent of enrollment. The cost of that decline was immense.
Enrollment has increased some in the past few years with individuals and families making the hard but farsighted choice to invest in their futures. But since 1976, tuition has edged up to $1,450 per year, somewhat lower than many public universities but extremely costly given the situtation of most CUNY students.
Financial aid programs assist the most needy, but part-time working students are seldom eligible, and subsidies for those above the poverty line fall off sharply. And now the state and city are proposing that tuition be increased by $500 next year, on top of a $200 increase this semester.
What is needed to both solve today's fiscal problems and invest for tomorrow is a program of "tuition service credits" that allow students to provide government service instead of paying the tuition increase.
Full and part-time tuition would be frozen at $1,450 and financial aid programs would be kept intact. The tuition increase would be translated into hours of government service at $5 per hour. Instead of paying a $500 increase, a full-time student would perform 100 hours, or two and a half weeks, of government service.
Students could work their hours over time or all at once during the summer. Government agencies would record the hours worked and report to the college bursar when service was completed or at the end of the semester.
If service hours were not met, students would pay for the time not served or be unable to register the following year or graduate. If a student chose service one year but did not complete it and wanted to try again, he would pay the tuition increase up front and get reimbursed when service was completed.
If 100,000 students -- half the CUNY population -- took advantage of this program, it would generate 10 million hours of work, the equivalent of adding 6,000 employees to the city's depleted work force. The primary beneficiaries would probably be schools, parks, libraries, hospitals and recreational facilities. The program could also be the vehicle for developing internships that generate academic credit and careers.
This program is not cost-free. CUNY would lose revenue from students who elect service instead of a tuition increase. But the bulk of these funds could be made up from reduced financial aid and the savings realized in state and city budgets from the students' work.
In 1976, the city lost the potential of a generation of college graduates. Tuition service credit would avoid this fate for a new generation.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Discount Clubs Proliferate in Connecticut

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A FEW decades ago, "I can get it for you wholesale" was a refrain that sometimes presaged a rip-off, but often resulted in a terrific deal on anything from a sofa to a fur coat. But to get a deal, you needed a connection.
 Now all you need is transportation to the nearest factory outlet, discount store, or one of the mammoth wholesale clubs proliferating around the country. 
 The Northeast, perceived as a particular victim of the recession, has been targeted by wholesale-club companies as a fertile market for cash-and-carry discounting, and Connecticut, where four such stores have been established since 1987, can expect at least 10 more by 1993.
 One of the four is B.J's, based in Natick, Mass. It will open a store Thursday at Bullard Square in Fairfield. The 120,000-square-foot, no-frills mart off exit 24 of I-95 was converted from an enormous old brick foundry by Rosenshein Associates of New Rochelle, N.Y.
One end of the building will also house several independent shops and a 10-screen Loew's movie theater, which will be completed early next year, for a total of 235,000 square feet.
 Unlike the historic restoration of Bullards's, most wholesale clubs are austere, one-story cement-block buildings on lots of 10 to 20 acres with 750 to 1,500 parking spaces. In Connecticut, some are turning the recession to their advantage by buying up distressed properties that are already zoned properly for their purposes.
 Sam's Warehouse Club, a division of Wal-Mart of Bentonville, Ark., just broke ground in Manchester off exit 62 of I-84. The company is also working through the municipal approvals process for another store in Cromwell.
Arnold Peck, a Connecticut developer who has experienced some financial difficulties, owns the Cromwell property and a site in Orange.
"Sam's has contracted to buy both sites, contingent on each town's approving their plans," he said. "They will file an application in Orange May 17."
 Brenda Lockhart, spokeswoman for Sam's, said that the Manchester store would open by early 1992. The company has 178 stores in 30 states, with each having up to 10,000 business memberships and up to 35,000 individual memberships. "It's not uncommon for people to come from a radius of 100 miles," she said.
WHAT all wholesale clubs offer is a range of merchandise keyed to the region, stacked in bulk quantities on plain racks and sold at an average markup of only 8 percent. The annual membership fee is $25. Business owners, their employees and most individuals may obtain cards under criteria that vary from company to company. Some of the clubs occasionally waive the $25 fee but charge an extra 5 percent on purchases.
 Name brands of major appliances, electronics, computers, office and automotive supplies, generators, pet supplies, industrial fans, Jacuzzis, fresh and frozen foods, jewelry and clothing are among the items sold.
 Pace Membership Warehouses, a division of K-Mart of Troy, Mich., has submitted an application for a new store opposite Sam's in Manchester. Last year Pace built a store in Enfield and renovated a building in Berlin. The company operates 78 stores nationwide.
 "Properties that we buy run between $4 million and $6 million," said Charles Steinbrueck, president of Pace. "Construction runs around $4 million to $4.5 million. We try to form partnerships with developers who have strong financing abilities, but sometimes we look to self-development through K-Mart," he said.
Homart, the shopping center developer based in Chicago, and the Woodmont Group of Seattle are his partners in the Manchester venture.
Mr. Steinbrueck believes that wholesale clubs will inevitably invade midtown Manhattan and the retail precincts of other major cities.
"Property values are considerably higher than we can afford right now," he said, "but as shopping patterns continue to shift toward the suburbs, property costs will moderate and opportunities will arise."
 Sam's and Pace are additions to a burgeoning shopping enclave in Manchester. A Home Depot is under construction and a similar chain of building supply discounters called Builder's Square has applied for a building permit.
Up the hill on Buckland Hills Drive overlooking Route 84 is the Pavilions, a 900,000-square-foot mall that Homart opened in March 1990. Alongside the Pavilions is a 932-unit rental apartment development soon to be completed by Trammell Crow of Dallas.
 "There may be a little too much going on," said Mark Pellegrini, town planner for Manchester, "but there has been considerable population growth in the area." The Capitol Region Council of Governments notes that in the 10 square miles east of Hartford the population has increased by 13 percent, to 210,000, or more than 20,000 people in a decade.
 There has been none of the resistance to wholesale clubs that other large, traffic-generating projects usually inspire at the local level. Their location in nonresidential areas adjacent to highways minimizes congestion, and the lure of bargains in hard times is irresistible.
THE Price Club, oldest in the country, "from whom all the others were cloned," according to its president, Robert Price, bought a 17-acre shopping center in New Britain for $3 million last month. The buildings will be demolished to make way for a 166,000-square-foot facility scheduled to open in the fall of this year. Jeffrey Dunne, the broker at Coldwell Banker Realtors who handled the sale, is negotiating for Price on another site off I-95 in Bridgeport.
 Founded in San Diego in 1976 by Sol Price and his son Robert, the company was the first to come to Connecticut in 1987, with a store in North Haven. "We are unique in that we own without encumbrance all our land and buildings," said Robert Price. "We develop shopping centers adjacent to the store, generating substantial capital."
Sales in 1990 reached $6 billion among 58 stores in the United States and Canada.
 Costco, based in Kirkland, Wash., is the nation's fourth major company with Sam's, Price, and Pace. It is negotiating for four Connecticut sites and expects to complete construction by 1993. Jeff Brotman, company chairman, welcomes the competition.
"Wholesale shoppers will find themselves acquiring preferences for certain clubs just as retail shoppers choose the stores they like," he said.

HEADLINE: Avery Corman Examines Date Rape

BYLINE: By BARBARA LOVENHEIM

 BODY:
WHEN a college tennis star from an affluent family insists on having sex with a coed who tries to fight him off, can she sue him for sexual harassment?
If he succeeds, can she sue him for rape? 
 If he doesn't succeed, does she still have a case?
If they were necking before the seduction occurred and she was drinking, does that exonerate him, and implicate her?
If she was willing to go some of the way, is she still an innocent victim -- or a tease?
Does rape have to be accompanied by the threat of physical force? And what kind of physical force?
These are some of the thorny issues that Avery Corman, known for "Kramer v. Kramer," tackles in "Prized Possessions," a novel published by Simon & Schuster, about a freshman from a wealthy Manhattan family who is raped on a first date by an upperclassman from an even wealthier family.
 
'A Great Many Complications'

"It's a fascinating subject and goes to the heart of where we are in our culture in terms of the women's movement," Mr. Corman said in an interview in his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "How far have we come if this is still a problem?
"The sexual revolution has spun off a great many complications -- coed housing, women who are not supposed to be virgins beyond a certain age, sexual freedom -- that are bound to be troublesome. But are we going to have more crimes?"
In preparation for the novel, Mr. Corman, who has owned a second home in Water Mill for 13 years, visited the State University at Stony Brook, where a report of a rape in 1989 led to demonstrations.
He also interviewed young men and women who converged in the Hamptons in the summer.
The story revolves around Elizabeth Mason, a freshman at an Ivy League college, who is violated sexually by Jimmy Andrews, an egotistical upperclassman, on a date in her first week on campus.
For several months she represses the incident. Eventually her rage surfaces and causes her to expose Jimmy in a series of fast-moving trials that wind up in a courtroom drama. When it becomes apparent that Elizabeth will triumph, she drops the charges.
Reviewers have praised the book, and Warner Brothers has optioned the screen rights. Mark Medoff, writer of "Children of a Lesser God," has been commissioned to write the screenplay.
But in a review in The New York Times Book Review on Jan. 13, Susan Fromberg Schaeffer objected to the ending. She said it seemed inconsistent with Elizabeth's rage and the magnitude of the crime.
Mr. Corman insists that the ending is defensible and consistent with Elizabeth's character and the complexities of the crime.
"I stand opposite people who want to view this subject without ambiguity," Mr. Corman said. "They seem to be looking for a politically correct position, and there is none. Elizabeth's choice at the end of the book is to make herself whole from within, and not from without. 
"If you take the view that all rape is the same, you link all college-age boys with pathological rapists who are raping women out of a perverse criminal mentality. And what is happening on college campuses is something else.
"The only way to make progress in this area is through seminars and orientation programs, which are now being done. If you go on with the view that all rape is the same, you are out to prove that all men are wrong, and you force the traditional view of men as eternal aggressors and women as eternal victims.
"This may be a politically correct position, but it doesn't get you anywhere or solve the problem. If you want to educate college students so they don't commit acts of violence, you have to begin with dialogue."
 
Man's Point of View

This is not the first time that Mr. Corman, a slim soft-spoken man in his mid-50's with a receding hairline, moustache and amiable style, has ruffled feminist feathers by looking at "a woman's issue" from a man's point of view.
In "Kramer v. Kramer," the courtroom drama published in 1977 about a custody battle between a mother who tries to reclaim her son after she had abandoned him, Mr. Corman took the unconventional view that men could be more effective parents than women and that fathers were often unfairly penalized in a legal system that automatically favored mothers.
"It did not make a lot of archfeminists happy," Mr. Corman said. "In an era when we were hearing about women's needs and women's rights, I decided to take a different tack and look at parenthood through the eyes of a father.
"Eventually Gloria Steinem admitted to me the book was a net gain,because it changed things in our culture for the better. After that, joint custody became a reality, and men took more interest in parenting."
Despite the volatile nature of many Corman novels, he does not present himself as a missionary or political radical. He says, tongue in cheek, that he is bourgeois.
He has been married to Judy Corman, director of volunteers for Phoenix House, for 23 years. They have two sons, Matthew, 19, a sophomore at Brown University, and Nicholas, 16, a sophomore at the Fieldston School.
They live in a spacious apartment with countrylike decor, couches upholstered with a floral pattern, glass and wood tables, an eat-in kitchen, plants, books and paintings. Mr. Corman works in an independent office during the week, he said, so he can spend weekends with his family.
The Cormans also try to spend as much time as possible in Water Mill.
"I love the light, the space, the food and the community we belong to," Mr. Corman said. His and Mrs. Corman's friends include writers, several drawn from a Sag Harbor softball team on which Mr. Corman has played short center field for more than 10 years.
He is known for his fast-moving and readable plots, sardonic commentaries on the upper classes and terse dialogue.
His turbulent childhood may be partly responsible for his sensitivity to families in crisis and social changes.
 
'A Fierce Directedness'

Born in New York City in 1935, Mr. Corman's parents were divorced when he was 4. Until the age of 14, he, his mother and sister lived with an aunt and uncle who were deaf mutes. Early on he mastered sign language.
"Deaf mutes have a very telegraphic way of speaking, a fierce directedness with no elegant embroidery," he said. "They rely not on a lot of shorthand symbols, but quite a lot of spelling out of words and a literalness of language. Perhaps that is why I'm more concerned with the emotional furniture of a person's life than the actual furniture."
After attending public schools in the Bronx, he graduated from New York University and intended to pursue a career in advertising. He worked a short time as a copywriter and in his mid-20's began writing educational films.
He also pursued a hobby, songwriting, which he used to do while riding the subway. He teamed up with a friend, intending to write musical comedies.
Eventually they separated, and Mr. Corman wrote two plays. One of them was nearly produced, he said, but "no cigar."
In his mid-30's, Mr. Corman turned one of his comic articles from Eye magazine into a full-length script and sent it to Simon & Schuster.
They accepted it, and, "Oh God," a satire about God's return to earth and his relationship with the press, was published in 1971. It grew into a major success when it was turned into the film starring George Burns and John Denver.
Before "Oh God" was released, Mr. Corman had completed "Kramer v. Kramer."
"When I finished the book, I thought I had done a good job, but I didn't have any idea of how far-reaching an impact it would or could have," he recalled. "It moved me from being a novelist who was a favorite with the underground media to a person people knew. It also ended my economic worries and meant I would not have to do educational films again."
In 1980, he published "The Old Neighborhood," a drama about a man who finds a haven in his childhood neighborhood when his marriage dissolves, and in 1987 he published "50," about a man who is coming to terms with aging.
Mr. Corman is now working on a comic novel in the spirit of "Oh God" and writing a screenplay with Diane Sokolow, a friend and colleague who also summers in the Hamptons.
"When I set out to do a novel," he said, "I like it to have some social significance. My main goal has always been to write books that get people thinking."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Switzerland's Door Cracks Open

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Switzerland's financial world is a rather exclusive place, still renowned for its secrecy. But it is starting to open up, partly in response to changes in stock markets throughout Europe and the world. In the process it is likely that foreign investors will get better treatment.
The prospect of these changes, analysts say, makes Switzerland's stock market an attractive long-term investment. The short-term outlook is more uncertain. 
 "Switzerland has had a protected market," said Donald Wilkinson, president of the Swiss Helvitia Fund, a closed-end mutual fund that invests in Swiss stocks. "Switzerland is a first-class, gold-plated economy with a third-world financial market."
By American standards, the changes do not seem particularly far-reaching. But for Switzerland they are quite radical.
More financial information will be disclosed. For example, Roche, the chemical and drug company, is moving to bring its financial reporting in line with the generally accepted accounting priciples in the United States.
There will also be more liquidity as the country's seven regional stock markets are pared down. By the end of this year, there should be only three markets left: Zurich, Geneva and Basel. And these three are planning a joint computerized trading system.
Beginning with Nestle in 1988, more companies have been opening their registered shares to foreign owners. Most Swiss companies have two or three kinds of shares. The registered shares generally sell at lower prices than the others and give holders more rights. Sandoz, the health-care products company, opened its registered shares to foreigners just last week.
In addition, changes are being discussed in the laws that limit foreign ownership of Swiss companies and in the way the stock exchanges are regulated.
The impending changes are positive, Mr. Wilkinson believes, but they will take time. So he takes the long-term view that investments in Switzerland should be given five years to pay off. That is longer than the Swiss Helvitia Fund has been around.
The Helvitia Fund is the easiest way for the average investor in the United States to get into the Swiss market. One advantage of the fund is that about 50 percent of its holdings are in registered shares.
But investors must remember that this is a closed-end fund, which means its stock price on the New York Stock Exchange is affected by two variables. One is the performance of the securities of the Swiss companies the fund owns. The other factor is the demand for the shares of the fund itself.
If this demand rises high enough, the fund's shares sell at a premium to the underlying value of the stocks in the fund. As the demand falls, the shares can sell at a discount. Buying shares at a premium opens the possibility of a fall in the stock price if interest in the fund wanes even though the prices of the stocks in the fund are stable or rising. The fund closed Friday at $12.875, a discount of 2.2 percent.
But despite the changes that cause analysts to endorse Switzerland as a long-term investment, some analysts hesitate about the immediate prospects.
"What will happen in the short term is difficult to say," said Felix Rovelli, vice president of Vontobel U.S.A. in New York, an affiliate of Bank J. Vontobel, a private Swiss bank. The stock market has already had a good run this year, with the Swiss Performance Index rising 19.2 percent.
One key issue is interest rates. The reports for February and March, which showed inflation rising about 6 percent in the previous year, were not encouraging, especially in the wake of a long period of high interest rates that have slowed the economy sharply. Some forecasters predict growth of just five-tenths of 1 percent this year.
This means the Swiss National Bank may move slowly in lowering interest rates further, said Malcolm A. Clinger Jr., the chief investment officer at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
Still, Switzerland has a host of companies, like Roche, Sandoz, Ciba-Geigy and Nestle, that do much of their business outside of Switzerland and will benefit this year from the sudden rally in the dollar. Last week the dollar rose to 1.4682 Swiss francs, up 19 percent since its low in February.
Many of these companies had flat or declining earnings last year because of the fall of the dollar. Now analysts are projecting that Swiss companies will have percentage earnings increases this year in the mid-teens, and even this could improve if the dollar rises further.
Nevertheless, both Mr. Clinger and Mr. Rovelli also say Switzerland should be regarded as a long-term investment. The opening of the market in the next several years, they say, should combine with the advantages of Switzerland's many multinational companies to bring the investor returns worth the wait.
"We take the long-term perspective because we do not know when this market is going to open up," said Georges L. de Montebello, executive vice president of the Helvitia Fund. "Anyone who wants to make a quick buck should not invest in this market."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1447 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 14-19

BYLINE: By Sallie Hofmeister

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Judging from the rally in banking stocks last week, it would appear that defaults and delinquencies are a receding worry. But not necessarily. Several banks, including Chase Manhattan and some regionals like First Fidelity, posted sharp gains in their first-quarter profits -- a product of cost-cutting, the slowing growth of bad loans and falling interest rates. Falling rates enable banks to make money on the spread between what they pay depositors and what they charge borrowers, whose rates are not adjusted as quickly. These spreads are now their widest in years, bankers say, because they need to earn more on their good customers to make up for all the bad ones. But these benefits didn't buttress all banks. Chemical Bank, NCNB and Manfacturers Hanover all saw earnings slip. And Citicorp suffered the most. Its profits plunged 70 percent in the first quarter, to a bare $70 million. While bad real estate loans were the bane of bankers early in the downturn, souring consumer loans are a worry as the recession matures. They were to blame for the disappointing quarter at Citicorp, the nation's largest issuer of credit cards and home mortgages. So why the stock rally? The earnings held none of the surprises -- dividend cuts and big additions to loan loss reserves -- that accompanied earlier quarters. 

Plastic Ills at American Express
Citicorp isn't the only issuer of plastic that has been sideswiped by rising unemployment, personal bankruptcies and consumer defaults. American Express said it would add $50 million to provisions to cover credit problems. Profits from its charge cards dropped 24.7 percent in the first quarter, to $162 million. Revenues also dipped, prompting a plan by American Express to lower the fees it charges restaurants that accept the card. For the quarter, American Express earned $264 million, saved by a recovery at its Shearson Lehman Brothers unit. A record loss at the brokerage had contributed to a loss of $620 million in the first quarter of 1990.
 
Almost as quickly as they invited Roseanne Barr into their living rooms, American television viewers have started to cast her out. The rating of her working folk's sitcom on ABC, "Roseanne," the top-rated series last year, fell 20 percent in the most recent season, which ended last Sunday. But this time, the hisses weren't for Roseanne alone. The ratings of most established shows drooped and for the first season in memory, no network added a real hit series. The creativity vacuum added to the continuing defection of viewers to cable and to Fox. While the networks' share of viewers slipped another 4 percentage points, to 62 percent, CBS's market share inched up. It still finished third among the networks for the fourth year running.

 In Brief
State insurance regulators seized control of the New York unit of the First Executive Corporation, whose largest unit was seized in California earlier this month.

Finally responding to cost-cutting, Sears, Roebuck was able to narrow its operating loss in the first quarter to $35 million, the most promising news in quarters.

Love That RJR Nabisco 'Junk'
What a difference a year makes. In January of 1990, RJR Nabisco withdrew a $1 billion "junk bond" offering because investors loathed leverage. But appetite was so strong for a scaled-down $750 million plan last week that RJR doubled the offer, which was the biggest for junk bonds since 1989. Still, investor interest was more a matter of RJR's success in slashing debt from its $25 billion leveraged buyout than any new love for leverage.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Ready for the Rebound?
Could Alan Greenspan and the Fed be preparing for a rebound? Despite reports earlier this month indicating that inflation is in check, the Fed drained reserves from the banking system on Monday. That may be a sign that tightening credit and fighting inflation are higher priorities than lowering short-term interest rates to help speed a recovery.

Life After 3,000
Wall Street certainly warmed to the theory that the Fed is in its recovery mode. The Dow Jones industrial average broke the 3,000 barrier for the first time, a psychological milestone it had come close to three times since July. Spurred by lower interest rates here and abroad, stocks worldwide have rallied since the gulf-war chill last fall. That spells relief for Wall Street firms, whose first-quarter earnings were positively buoyant compared with last year, the worst year for securities firms in decades. But evidence that the economy has hit bottom is still shadowy, and institutional investors grabbed the chance to take profits while others rushed into the market on the coattails of the 3,000-mark euphoria. The market ended the week at 2,965.59

Reading the Trade Figures
The falling price of imported oil and the need for less of it in a recession helped narrow the trade deficit in February to its lowest level in more than seven years. The deficit, the amount by which purchases of foreign goods exceed sales abroad, dropped 26 percent, to $5.3 billion. But the trade figures don't necessarily bespeak an imminent recovery. Though imports dropped dramatically, exports, which had been a cushion in this recession, continued to slide from their December peak. The rising dollar and continued weakness of the country's trading partners are likely to reinforce the trend.

Gloomy Economic Statistics
The latest economic statistics are none too heartening. New claims for unemployment fell during the first week of April for the second week, but some economists discounted the fall because it came during the Easter holiday week. March figures give credence to a cautious view. Housing starts, after climbing in February, fell 9 percent in March, to 901,000. Industrial production fell by three-tenths of a percent. While that drop is the smallest of a string of decreases since October, it contributed to a decline in output of 9.25 percent for the first quarter, compared with one of only 7 percent in the final 1990 quarter. "The numbers are very dismal," said Lacy H. Hunt of the Hongkong Bank Group. "Without question, they show the recession is continuing and the recovery is nowhere in sight."

Forget that Blue-Plate Special
Peanut butter or meatloaf are no longer meals fit for a recession. A drought in the Southeast caused peanut prices to double last fall, prompting peanut butter makers to plead for an end to an import ban, a move the Administration is now mulling. A 30-year low in the nation's cattle herd, which shrank during a drought three years ago, has translated into a 6 percent rise in ground-beef prices in a year.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Gorbachev Comes A'Calling
Mikhail S. Gorbachev sees Japan as a sort of kindred spirit. The Soviet economy, he told his Japanese comrades during a visit to Tokyo last week -- the first by a Soviet leader -- is akin to Japan's in 1945. Its industrial base, in shambles, is far better at making weapons than widgets. But oh, how Japan's billions could transform its ravaged landscape. The Soviets, he offered, were ready to convert military plants to jet-making factories and to set up auto and oil joint ventures with Japan. But Japanese officials sent the Soviet leader packing and suggested he first tend to political unrest and pick up the pace of the transition to a market economy at home. Mr. Gorbachev didn't leave entirely empty-handed. In his clutch was the bargaining chip he came with, the Kurile Islands.

 Maxwell to Hit the Market
Robert Maxwell is looking to the public to finance his spending spree. He hopes to raise up to $445.6 million by selling as much as 49 percent of his Mirror Group in the British stock market. The offering could help reduce the newspaper company's debt of more than $1 billion and perhaps enable it to buy the non-British papers Mr. Maxwell owns, which include the The New York Daily News.

A Ticker for Poland?
Market technicians donned the white shirts and red suspenders popular among some male traders on Wall Street. But the look of sophistication and know-how surrounding the opening day of Poland's stock exchange, which resumed trading after a silence of 50 years, defied a fundamental deficiency of the system. The market certainly represents a huge step forward for capitalism in East Europe, promising to provide a vehicle for financing the hundreds of Government entities that are soon expected to be privatized. If only there were capital to spare in Poland. Shares of five state-run ventures, recently privatized, were available for trading. But only a few thousand shares traded hands.

LENGTH: 966 words

HEADLINE: Managing;
Americans Aim To Speak in Many Other Tongues

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Market research told the Ryko Manufacturing Company that selling its car wash equipment in France would be a breeze. But when it tried, potential buyers resisted mightily -- and for a good reason. Ryko's instruction manuals were in English, a language that few car wash operators could read.
So Ryko translated its manual into French, and 1991 sales took off. "Operating in local languages has become a necessary part of competing overseas," said Barbara Wilson, international administrative assistant for the Grimes, Iowa, company. 
 No one has hard numbers to prove it, but language experts insist that more American companies are reaching that conclusion. "The demand may not be a gusher yet, but it is a lot steadier than a trickle or a drip," said Bernard Bierman, editor of Translation News, an industry newsletter.
 All of this is wonderful news for the 4,500 members of the American Translators Association, as well as linguistically talented students who may want to join the profession.
"Our graduates no longer have to go to Europe to find good jobs," said Margarita B. Bowen, head of the division of interpretation and translation at Georgetown University's School of Languages and Linguistics.
Peter Priest, who heads a Russian translation program for engineering students at the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind., has noticed that "Corporate recruiters who used to only care about our students' engineering skills increasingly ask about their translation abilities."
There are many reasons for the upsurge:
* More strategic alliances with foreign companies. "American companies do not want a foreign partner's translation of a contract to be the operating document," said Marilyn Miller, president of Language Services International, a Des Moines translation agency whose volume of corporate assignments has doubled annually for three years.
* The opening up of Eastern Europe to foreign commerce. "Eastern Europeans have no point of reference for phrases like 'stock exchange' or 'leveraged buyout,' so the translations have to be done here," said Ronald J. Patten, dean of DePaul University's College of Commerce.
* More innovation, particularly in pharmaceuticals. "Intensified competition has yielded more research, more patents, and more multinational lawsuits -- all of which means more translations," said Peter C. Richardson, general patent counsel of Pfizer Inc. Anne Saxon, a New York interpreter of Italian, adds that pharmaceutical companies are holding more international teleconferences, requiring oral interpretations of speakers.
* The increased flow of immigrants and tourists to the United States. Spanish-language translators report more assignments to translate textbooks, bill inserts, advertising and other material from English into Spanish, for the benefit of the rapidly growing Hispanic population. American hotels, travel agents and restaurants are translating brochures, menus and such from English into Japanese, German and other languages spoken in thriving economies.
* Increased clamor from overseas distributors of American products for materials in their own languages. Amana Refrigeration Inc., for one, just translated user manuals for its major appliances into Greek and Hebrew, at the request of distributors in Greece and Israel. It is now doing one in Portugese, for its distributor in Portugal. "They say they can sell our product more readily if we stop assuming that everyone speaks English," said Brian K. Parrott, who supervises the production of Amana's customer literature.
Fisher Controls, the instrumentation subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, even wants to match dialects. For its European customers, it has customer training guides in French, Spanish and Portugese. Now it is tailoring those guides to match the way Spanish and Portugese are spoken, respectively, in Columbia and Brazil. "We want to accommodate any culture that uses our equipment," said Joseph M. Morris, a marketing manager in Fisher's education department.
Of course, not all translations are done in the United States. Fisher, and other companies looking for local nuances, generally turn to translators in the country they have targeted. Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange generally have their annual reports translated into Japanese in Tokyo. And companies often let their own overseas offices translate brochures.
"The products we sell overseas, we make overseas, so doing the translations here doesn't make sense," said John Cox, a senior vice president at Avon Products Inc.
Maybe not -- but foreign translators can massacre idioms. One American company just asked Louis Korda, a Hungarian translator in New York, to retranslate several documents. "They got nervous when the Hungarians translated 'blue chip company' as 'maker of blue chips,' " Mr. Korda said.
 
 
 
TRANSLATORS AND ANTITRUST
 Four years ago, the American Translators Association, rankled that its members often got paid just a few hundred dollars for translating complicated documents, began publishing annual guidelines for what translators should charge.
The Federal Trade Commission was not amused. It is investigating whether the practice constitutes price-fixing.
Frank Patton Jr., a New York lawyer representing the association, says that in January his client provided the F.T.C. with the documents it requested and has heard nothing further. But the group is taking no chances on an unfavorable ruling. It has adopted a "specific and defined and tough policy to comply with antitrust requirements," Mr. Patton said. Thus, the 1990 fee recommendations -- $95 per 1,000 words for nontechnical translation, $105 for technical translations -- will be the last.
The F.T.C. would not discuss the case.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
When Bonds Act Like Stocks

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Junk-bond funds behave very differently from their cousins that invest in higher-grade bonds. Returns on high-quality bond funds, which are very sensitive to shifts in interest rates, tend to rise when the economy is in a recession and as interest rates drop -- exactly when junk-bond funds are most vulnerable to a decline.
In fact, junk bonds have lately been behaving more like stocks than bonds. When stock-fund returns fell last year, the returns on junk-bond funds -- the sum of yield plus price change -- also dropped, after a slight lag. When the stock funds began to rally at the end of last year, the returns on junk funds advanced too. 
 The lesson for investors: take this stock-like behavior into account, because price movements on junk-bond funds "may be more than a typical fixed-income investor bargains for," said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.

HEADLINE: Three R's for the Middle East

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security adviser in the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Though I still think that punitive sanctions would have better served America's long-term interests, clearly the military victory over Iraq was easier than expected. However, there is a growing -- but still avoidable -- risk that the war may come to be seen as having precipitated a geopolitical disaster and a moral disgrace.
The increasingly messy aftermath of the war gives rise to two central questions: What are the principal benefits and debits of our triumph? What are the immediate and longer-range implications for subsequent U.S. policy? 
 The benefits are undeniably impressive. First, a blatant act of aggression was rebuffed and punished. An important political and even legal point, central to international decency, was reaffirmed: that the community of nations will not tolerate the brutal use of force by one state against another.
Second, U.S. military power is henceforth likely to be taken more seriously. The technological and strategic virtuosity of the U.S. military performance, as well as the display of personal determination by U.S. decision-makers, is bound to have a chilling effect even as far away as North Korea, a dictatorship reputed to be acquiring nuclear weapons of its own.
Third, the Middle East and Persian Gulf region is now clearly an American sphere of preponderance. Pro-American Arab regimes feel more secure; so does Israel. U.S. access to oil is now not in jeopardy.
Fourth, the Soviet Union, until recently America's principal rival in the Middle East, to all intents and purpose has now been reduced largely to the status of a spectator.
However, some negative consequences must also be placed on the scales. First, the most immediate regional beneficiary of Iraq's downfall has been Iran, a power openly hostile to the U.S. and to America's satellite regimes on the Arabian Peninsula. America's military presence in the region is now imperative. This is not necessarily inimical to U.S. interests, but potentially is a source of new instabilities.
Second, that presence is related to the growing danger that the war's aftermath is intensifying the region's barely suppressed ethnic, religious and tribal animosities. The war against Iraq could become part of a prolonged chain reaction, eventually "Lebanonizing" the region as a whole while bogging the U.S. down in it.
Third, the very intensity of the air assault on Iraq gives rise to concern that the conduct of the war may come to be seen as evidence that Americans view Arab lives as worthless.
The last consideration raises sensitive moral issues. The war was presented to the public as a "just war," made necessary both by the immorality of Saddam Hussein's action and by the scale of the threat he posed. He was portrayed as if he were another Hitler, menacing the whole world. In fact, he turned out to have been much more like Mussolini.
 And that raises the moral question of the proportionality of response. U.S. spokesmen repeatedly stated that the objective was not the destruction of Iraq and that the enemy was Mr. Hussein and not the Iraqi people. However, the air assault against Iraq was heavily directed, doubtless for military reasons, at its ability to operate as a modern society, with adverse consequences for the well-being of innocent people.
This conclusion emerges starkly from the report submitted to the U.N. by the Finnish head of a special investigative mission, Marti Ahtissari. It itemizes the destruction of nonmilitary targets. Some 90 percent of the industrial labor force has been deprived of work and income; the country's "sole laboratory producing veterinary vaccines" was destroyed by bombing; so were its "seed warehouses," with "all stocks of potatoes and vegetable seeds," thereby placing in jeopardy seasonal planting. Because of the deliberate destruction of power plants and other sources of energy, "all electrically operated installations have ceased to function," causing a shortage of water and forcing the population to rely on contaminated water supply. "All modern communications systems have been destroyed," etc.
The mission concluded that the population faced "a catastrophe" from epidemics and undernourishment, unless relief was forthcoming.
The human misery produced by the war has subsequently been compounded by the abortive Shiite and Kurdish revolts. Obviously (though naively) counting on American support, the uprisings have been repressed with massive force and brutality. The resulting flight of the Kurds then created further suffering, with the Kurds subjected to deaths and deprivations on a shocking scale.
All this is relevant to any calculus of the war's benefits and debits. It raises the possibility that the war may have been a classical case of an under-reaction to earlier signs of Mr. Hussein's aggressiveness that later prompted an over-reaction to the eventual act of aggression. This over-reaction may have prompted what might be deemed in moral terminology a "disproportionate" response.
It is important to raise this troubling issue, especially given the emphasis on the idea of the "just war" and the deliberate evocation of Churchillian symbols and rhetoric to gain public support. The fact is the war was not waged against all odds, against an all-powerful opponent -- as had been the case against Hitler -- but it pitted the world's only superpower against a third world country armed with second-best weapons.
What task should the U.S. now shoulder, bearing morality and geopolitics in mind? The point of departure for any answer must be the recognition that the U.S. now has unprecedented influence on the fate of an entire region.
After World War II, Harry S. Truman recognized America's moral and political responsibility for the future of Europe. He rose to that challenge through a firm commitment to large-scale relief, reconstruction and reconciliation. Today, the Persian Gulf and Middle East needs all three. Relief must be undertaken on a massive scale: for the Kurds in the first place, for the Shiites and for other Iraqis as well.
The dispatching of U.S. forces to shield encampments in Iraq for the displaced Kurds is a right step, but it is difficult to understand how U.S. forces can vacate the occupied parts of southern Iraq without first obtaining a firm commitment from Baghdad to alter the political status of the Iraqi Kurds very significantly.
Beyond this immediate -- partly moral and partly political -- imperative, it behooves the U.S. to pursue actively three broad goals: a regional security arrangement, a process for the redistribution of regional wealth and for enhanced economic cooperation among all the region's states (including Israel) and a serious movement toward Arab-Israeli peace.
Fortunately, there are signs the U.S. is moving in that direction. But to succeed it will have to pursue all three goals together. There can be no regional security, including arms control and other arrangements to minimize a repetition of the Iraqi aggression, without some progress on the other two central issues. And there can be no movement on Israeli-Arab peace, including eventually some form of statehood for the Palestinians, without a wider accommodation that tackles the region's strategic and social vulnerability.
President Truman recognized the challenge of relief, reconstruction and reconciliation. America rose to the challenge. That is why Europe is safe and healthy today. For geopolitical and moral reasons, America should undertake no less in the Middle East.
