HEADLINE: Boom in Manufactured Exports Provides Hope for U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In a quiet revolution, the United States, long derided as an industrial has-been, has become one of the world's low-cost manufacturers -- lower in many industries than Canada, Europe and Japan.
American factories now ship steel to Seoul, transistors to Tokyo, cars to Cologne and bicycle pants to Bologna. Exports ranging from beer and boards to carpets and computer chips have surged by 76 percent since 1986. At home, domestically made machine tools, electronics gear and cars -- some turned out in factories with foreign owners -- are muscling aside imports. 
 As a result, foreign trade is likely to power the economy for years to come. "Export-led growth may be the only feasible strategy for the United States," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. Indeed, the shrinking trade deficit, now at a seven-year low, is offsetting some of spending lost in the recession.
 
Growth May Continue
 Though exports have lately leveled off as growth overseas has slowed, forecasters at DRI/McGraw-Hill expect exports to grow 50 percent faster than imports during the rest of the 1990's.
What is behind the resurgence of American cost-competitiveness? Partly, of course, it is the dollar, high-flying in the mid-80's, returned to earth. Despite the dollar's recent bounce, its value is still a third below its 1985 level.
More enduring are the sweeping and painful changes undertaken by American managers and workers, which have revived flagging factory productivity. These changes have ended some of the worst excesses of the 70's, including pay increases that helped to price many United States products out of overseas markets while encouraging lower-priced imports.
For decades, American companies acted as though higher costs could always be passed on. The new attitude is captured by companies like the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a maker of machine tools based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which intends to cut the cost of its products by 5 percent a year.
How durable are the American gains? Certainly, an unexpected return to an overvalued dollar would wipe them out. So would slipping back into the sloppy habits of the past.
And low costs by themselves cannot guarantee global competitiveness in a world of increasingly well-heeled, choosy customers who, more often than not, care as much about quality, style, service and technical razzle-dazzle as they do about price. Buyers -- domestic and foreign -- are not likely to abandon superbly engineered German machine tools or reliable Japanese cars for cheaper but shoddier alternatives.
 
Beyond Burgers and Junk Bonds
 Those who still think of the United States as a good place to make burgers, "junk bonds" and Boeing aircraft, and little else, ignore a vast terrain friendly to the manufacture of old-fashioned goods like nails and light bulbs.
Illinois Tool Works Inc., based in Glenview, Ill., recently scrapped its plans to build another nail factory in Germany. And Osram Inc., a subsidiary of Siemens A.G., the German electronics giant, recently poured $3 million into a plant in Maybrook, N.Y., that produces light bulbs and auto headlamps.
These decisions partly reflect the favorable American manufacturing climate. In Illinois Tool's case, it costs the company about 20 percent more to make a nail in Germany than in the United States and twice as much to add capacity in Germany. Not only are bricks and mortar more expensive there, but companies are required to take on more commitments, in benefits and job guarantees, for their workers.
"We can produce nails here with less overhead and fewer social costs," said W. James Farrell, an executive vice president of Illinois Tool.
In Osram's case, most customers are in the United States, but the company expects to ship about a fifth of its products to European and Asian auto makers. "From an efficiency standpoint, we stack up very well to our German counterparts, sometimes to their surprise," said Paul Caramagna, Osrams' vice president.
 
Costs Lower in U.S.
 Though none should be taken literally, broad statistical yardsticks tell the same story. Estimates by Peter Hooper and Karen Larin, economists at the Federal Reserve in Washington, suggest that unit costs in the United States are 60 percent of those in Germany and 80 percent of those in Japan. DRI/McGraw-Hill, using different data and methods, estimates that American factory costs are about 10 percent below those of Europe and Japan.
And the United States is almost certainly among the lowest-cost producers of basic commodities. Take the raw material for those ubiquitous plastic detergent bottles with hourglass shapes. It costs 25 percent less to produce high-density polyethylene pellets in the United States than in Europe, and 15 percent less than in Japan, according to Chem Systems, a consulting firm in Tarrytown, N.Y. Back in 1985, when the dollar peaked, costs in the United States were no lower than in Europe and Japan.
The United States can make steel more cheaply than Germany or Japan, although Britain can make it more cheaply yet. Indeed, USS-Posco Industries now makes money shipping 5 percent to 10 percent of the cold-rolled steel from its plant in Pittsburg, Calif., to the Pacific Rim. The average cost of producing a ton of steel in the United States is now about $535, as against $542 in Germany and $614 in Japan, according to the WEFA Group, an economics consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
 
Paneling Tailored to Japanese
 Another successful export to the Pacific -- specifically to Japan -- is boards, by the boatload. The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, based in Portland, Ore., exports so much wood to Japan these days that it is making, in addition to its standard 4-by-8-foot paneling, a 3-by-6-foot version that the Japanese prefer. "Our costs are very competitive with Canada and Scandinavia," said Barry Lacter, the company's vice president for public relations.
The United States also seems to have regained ground in industries that many people had written off. American textile mills, it turns out, are very competitive in products for industry and the home. Judging by exports last year, Greeks like to sleep between American designer sheets and Saudis prefer to walk on American wall-to-wall shag carpets in their homes.
The new cost competitiveness varies from product to product, but what is striking is the huge across-the-board swing since the mid-80's. Indeed, the United States is even more competitive in manufacturing costs than it was in the late 70's, when its trade in factory goods was balanced and exports were booming.
 
Low Dollar Worked Wonders
 Consider how the dollar helped to create the shift. The dollar's value against other currencies is back where it was in the late 70's and early 80's. Even after a recent surge against the German mark and the Japanese yen, the dollar is worth about what it was last spring and about 30 percent less than in February 1985.
The lower dollar has done wonders for American industry, particularly machine tools. Exports last year jumped 23 percent while imports sank 5 percent. "The primary reason for that significant swing is manufacturing costs," said Norman J. Ryker, chief executive of Cross & Trecker. The company has recently expanded its sales force in Germany and Japan to sell its top export, the Sheffield machine, which is used to measure machined parts precisely.
At the same time, Cross & Trecker, which used to import some smaller tools from Japan, has not done so in six months. "It costs too much," Mr. Ryker said.
American factory productivity -- which has remained the highest in the world -- has been jack-rabbiting along in the 80's. Rising at an average rate of 3.6 percent a year, output per hour in American factories has been advancing faster than in the 60's and nearly three times as fast as in the 70's.
Efficiency gains in the American auto industry rose about 4 percent a year in the 1980's, thanks partly to the Japanese companies that build cars in United States plants known as transplants. "The transplants are close in efficiency to the best plants in Japan, and many Ford plants are as efficient as the transplants," said James P. Womack, an automotive expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. These days, Detroit is sending American-made models around the world.
Not all of the productivity gains resulted from shutting inefficient plants or slashing payrolls. Some reflect efforts to do things right the first time, an effort that almost by definition bolsters output per worker.
Take Motorola Inc., the nation's largest maker of computer chips, which has raised its productivity in part by reducing costly defects. After an intense five-year campaign, Motorola now measures defects in its popular microcontrollers -- chips that show up in everything from cameras to cars -- not in percentage points, but in parts per million.
"Our goal for mistakes is 3.4 parts per million -- not just in the products themselves, but in sales and service," said Kenneth C. Phillips, a company spokesman.
More than half of Motorola's sales in 1990 were overseas. That is one reason, no doubt, that the United States recorded a trade surplus in semiconductors last year, after years of deficits.
Finally, United States manufacturing workers are no longer the world's fat cats in terms of pay and benefits. At current exchange rates, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Americans earn $14.31 an hour in pay and benefits. German workers, in comparison, earn $17.58. In Japan, where pay has more than doubled in dollar terms since 1979, workers now earn the equivalent of $12.63 an hour.
Thus, part of the price of greater American competitiveness has been paid by American factory workers. Their purchasing power has been squeezed as blue-collar pay rose at a slower pace in the United States than almost anywhere else.

HEADLINE: Future in Mind, Choctaws Reject Plan for Landfill

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Miss., April 20

 BODY:
Invoking a sense of mystery about the land that has been their home for generations and expressing concern for future generations, the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has rejected a proposal to develop a hazardous-waste landfill near its reservation.
"We are close to the land and if you hurt the land it will come back to haunt you," said Carmen Denson, a member of the tribal council. Mr. Denson was among the opponents of the plan, which had sharply divided the 5,000-member tribe. 
 On Friday by a vote of 786 to 525, the Choctaws rejected the proposal to allow disposal of manufacturing waste products, including oils, cleaning solvents and other chemicals, on land nearby to be developed as a landfill. The developer said the plan could have meant as much as $30 million a year in payments to the tribe.
 
Some Are Troubled
 The proposal was the latest development in what many see as a troubling trend in the last two years of waste companies approaching Indian groups with proposals to use their lands to dump or incinerate waste.
Because of tribal sovereignty, Indian land is subject only to Federal regulation and is immune from the generally stricter state and local regulations, including taxation.
There is a growing environmental movement among Indians who see the proposals coming before tribal councils as attempts by waste companies to use sovereignty to evade stricter regulation.
George Farris, director of the environmental services division of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, said that there were no waste sites on Indian land yet, but that there were five proposals from among the 300 tribal councils nationally. Those included the proposal just rejected by the Choctaws, a plan that had advanced to the point of becoming a formal application and contract requiring the bureau's approval. Mr. Farris said the number of such proposals under discussion was decreasing.
For Odie Jim, 63 years old, the concern was not the national trend but what could happen to the land that his ancestors had doggedly held on to while most Choctaws were being driven to reservations in Oklahoma in the last century. Mr. Jim credited the tribe's ability to hold on to its language and much of its culture through the years to the members' succeeding in maintaining their connection to the land.
 
'Young Ones Will Have Nothing'
 "What if something happens to the landfill, like a leak and damage, and the tribe is sued and we lose the land," he said. "We, the old ones and the elderlies have to do the right thing for the young ones. If they sue us and we have no money, they will take the whole reservation and the young ones will have nothing."
Such views proved pivotal in the tribal referendum on the plan to go into business with a Jackson, Miss., company, National Disposal Services Inc.
But perhaps the most important message emerging from the voting on the 23,000-acre reservation near here, said Linda Farve, a leading opponent of the plan, is that people "will see that we are not easy prey for the waste companies and that we will speak out."
Lance Hughes, a Cherokee and executive director of Native Americans for a Clean Environment, said tribes around the country had felt pressure from proposals like the one here.
"We already have tremendous environmental problems on the reservations with deforestation, energy exploitation and other things," Mr. Hughes said, "and now they are trying to bring the waste products of all these processes back to us with the promise that we will make some money."
From the Dakotas to the Rio Grande, from Southern California to eastern Mississippi, there have been 36 proposals in the last two years to develop landfills or incinerators on Indian lands, Mr. Hughes said, citing surveys by his organization. Most such plans have been rejected by the tribes, while others are still under discussion.
 
Race-Related Concerns
 Mr. Hughes and other opponents of such plans see them as part of the phenomenon they call "toxic racism," for the tendency they see of environmentally hazardous dumps or landfills being located in communities that are poor, politically powerless and that frequently have large minority communities.
Concerns in the matter are being voiced, as well, by some industry groups.
Richard Fortuna, executive director of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, which is based in Washington, said that, for the most part, experienced and reputable companies had sought out Indian tribes and that their motivation was to avoid the political uncertainty of the process of getting approval from state, county or municipal officials. He said the purpose was not to avoid stricter state and local regulations.
The developments have also attracted attention in Congress, including that of Senator Thomas Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota. A spokesman for Mr. Daschle, a member of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, said the Senator had asked environmental committees currently considering reauthorization of major environmental legislation to consider regulating such sites on Indian land. The issue is scheduled to be taken up in hearings in the next few months.
The proposal here called for the waste company to operate the landfill for the tribe. The agreement called for an initial payment of nearly $500,000 to the tribe, a 10 percent share of the landfill's annual revenue and creation of more than 200 jobs. Estimates of potential earnings for the tribe ranged from $10 million to $30 million a year.
 The outcome of the referendum was a rare defeat for the Mississippi Choctaws' longtime chief, Phillip Martin, who has supported aggressive economic development efforts over the years. Mr. Martin oversees Indian manufacturing enterprises that employ 1,200 people and bring in an estimated $60 million in annual sales. He had pushed the landfill proposal through the tribal council last July, but last month, amid growing opposition, agreed to the referendum.
 
Questions About Conflicts
 The proposed venture with National Disposals Systems, a new company, had raised several serious questions.
Wilson Carroll, the assistant State Attorney General in charge of environmental issues, noted that the venture involved a proposal that the tribe buy 466 acres owned by the company in Noxubee County, near the reservation. Once the tribe acquired the land and placed it in trust, giving it immunity from local regulation, the land would be leased back to National Disposal Systems for development of the landfill. Mr. Carroll said that, among other things, the state was disturbed at the possibility of the Choctaws regulating the landfill while also benefiting from it.
Noxubee County is one of several eastern Mississippi and western Alabama areas considered particularly well-suited geologically for landfills. They stand on a thick layer of nearly impervious Selma clay, which is thought to be one of the best insulators for such developments.
The area is home to the nation's largest hazardous waste dump, at Emelle, Ala., just across the state line from Noxubee County. Two other companies have proposed hazardous waste dumps in the county, Mr. Carroll said.

HEADLINE: Florio and a Klan Leader Trade Accusations

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 19

 BODY:
In the wake of recruiting efforts by the Ku Klux Klan this month, Gov. Jim Florio has attacked the organization, not only for its white supremacist doctrines but also for its attempt to use the state's economic problems and his tax and gun control policies to win converts.
"We're in a national recession and when economic times are hard, we always see an upswing in bigotry and intolerance," Mr. Florio told a gathering of local religious and civil rights leaders and residents at the Temple Beth Ohr in Old Bridge on Wednesday.
 
 "Some people need to find someone to blame, it seems," he said. The Governor called the Klan members "apostles of hate" and said they were not welcome in New Jersey.
 Richard Fogel, the leader of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan for Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, said in a telephone interview that he was stung by the Governor's remarks, calling them "derogatory and antidemocratic.
"The Constitution guarantees our freedom of association and the right to say what we think," he said. Mr. Fogel called Mr. Florio's passage of a $2.8 billion tax program "almost dictatorial" and said his support of legislation banning assault rifles had "raised the ire" of gun enthusiasts.
"He is forgetting the real people, the dispossessed majority and listening to the special interests and organized minorities," Mr. Fogel said. Robed and hooded Klansmen carried that message when they handed out leaflets and Klan newspapers containing racial slurs in Gloucester City earlier this month. In addition, other followers of Mr. Fogel placed Klan business cards in mailboxes or taped them to store windows in Old Bridge.
Mr. Florio, who has embarked on a busy public schedule highlighting the benefits of his economic program to counter a lingering public antipathy to his programs before November's legislative elections, found a warm reception for his attack on the Klan and for his appeal for racial harmony at the temple on Wednesday.
Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's communications director, said some people think it would have been better to ignore the recruiting attempts. "They say these are small incidents, why give them publicity, but we think the publicity hurts them rather than helps them," he said. "If we don't speak up, then this type of activity has the darkness it needs to flourish."
According to a recent report by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, the Klan has about 50 members in New Jersey. Pennsylvania has the largest and most active Klan membership of any Northeast state, with 250 and 300 members, the report said.
Mr. Florio last year signed legislation that made racial and ethnic intimidation crimes a felony. In 1990 there were 824 complaints of crimes related to race, religion and ethnic origin, an increase of 36 percent from 1989.
In December the state police and office of Middlesex County Prosecutor Alan A. Rockoff arrested five people, identified as skinhead-Klansmen in Middlesex and Somerset Counties, on charges of illegal purchase and possession of semiautomatic weapons and handguns.
In the same month, the state police arrested three people including Joseph Doak of Clayton, the Grand Dragon of the state's chapter of the Invisible Empire, on charges of conspiring to inflict serious bodily harm on rivals in the group.
Among the businesses on whose windows the Klan members taped business cards was East Coast Custom, a silk-screening and printing shop run by Daisy Pendleton and two of her sons, Pat and Ben. The Pendletons, who are black, said the cards reminded them of 1974 when a cross was burned on the lawn of their home in Spotswood.
The Pendletons, who were among the first black families in their neighborhood, still live in the same house. They said they were saddened and angered but not intimidated by the Klan business cards. Ben Pendleton designed a T-shirt depicting a hooded Klansman inside an international stop sign and the words "Klan Buster."
"It'll never change," Mrs. Pendleton said. "It's not fair. We're just people trying to make a living."

HEADLINE: After 40 Years, Racially Split Schools Are a Legacy of One Southern Town

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUMMERTON, S.C.

 BODY:
The old whites-only high school is now an abandoned red brick hulk, but its ghosts still whisper and breathe, part of the indelible sense of race and turf that pervades this town where one of the most critical legal challenges to segregation began more than 40 years ago.
"I remember my husband standing out by the steps there and telling Thurgood Marshall, 'You'll never get us to integrate,' " said Marjorie Davis, a white woman whose children were in school during the challenge to segregation. "He said, 'We'll just abandon the schools.' And we did. The whites left and they never came back." 
 A recent television miniseries, "Separate but Equal," focused on Summerton's past as the site of one of five lawsuits that resulted in the Brown v. Board of Education ruling by the Supreme Court, outlawing segregation.
Four decades later, the invisible lines that divide the races still suffuse almost every aspect of life. The public schools that blacks sought to desegregate are now virtually all black. Economic and political power remains firmly in the hands of white residents, although they are overwhelmingly outnumbered by blacks.
In some ways, Summerton, with a population now below 1,000, is a special case, where the town's role in the racial history of the South has created a sort of stalemate that drags down both whites and blacks.
 
Reminder of Unchanged Times
 But in its daily life in churches and schools, in the decision of whites to eat at the Summerton Diner or blacks at the Sunshine Restaurant, in the artful social choreography that went into the staging of a town variety show not long ago, it is something far more universal. It is a reminder of how much remains utterly unchanged, not just here but in thousands of small towns throughout the South since the Brown decision on May 17, 1954.
"Like one of the Supreme Court Justices said, 'Some things you're not going to change,' " said June Ross, who owns a small bakery and delicatessen on Summerton's Main Street. "We've made a lot of progress, but there's a strain of Southern gentility that will never change."
Summerton's foray into history began in 1947, when black citizens organized by a preacher, J. A. Delaine, asked the all-white school board for help in operating a bus, so blacks, like whites, could ride in buses to their segregated schools.
When they were turned down, they went to court. In their lawsuit, named for Harry Briggs, a black mechanic who was one of the plaintiffs, and Roderick W. Elliott, the board president, the blacks asked not just for bus service but also for school buildings, services and education equal to those of whites. Argued by Thurgood Marshall, now a Supreme Court Justice, Briggs v. Elliott became one of five suits that were combined in the Brown decision.
 
An Easy Surface Sociability
 Since then, some things have changed here. Whites and blacks coexist with an easy surface sociability that is far more amicable than can be found in many Northern cities. But to many people, what has not changed is at least as significant as what has.
"The Supreme Court ruling had no effect on Summerton, then or now," said James Washington, president of the Clarendon County chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "When the decision came down, black people were jubilant. Pretty soon though, we realized that nothing had changed."
Summerton's schools reflect the slow, halting progression of desegregation in many Southern towns. In the early 1950's, the district built new schools, to provide what were said to be equal accommodations for blacks and whites. Despite the 1954 ruling, blacks and whites maintained those separate schools for more than a decade, until 1965. Then the district adopted a plan that allowed whites and blacks to choose which school they would attend. Four blacks attended white schools in 1965.
 
Neighboring Town Integrates
 Many whites deserted the district right away, setting up Clarendon Hall, a whites-only private school that still educates most whites in town. The rest left soon after. In 1969, there were 281 white students in the district. A year later, when desegregation began in earnest, there were 16. Before long, there were none. Of the 1,274 students in Summerton's public schools this year, 23 are white.
Summerton's problems seem particularly acute in contrast to schools in the county seat, Manning, 10 miles away, where the schools have successfully integrated and white enrollment has increased in recent years. Indeed, some whites there are from the Summerton district, taking advantage of various loopholes to cross district lines. But Manning has a stronger economic base and a less antagonistic racial history.
As whites left the three schools in the Summerton district, the town's commitment to the schools dwindled. The high school, Scotts Branch High, has some modern equipment like a small robotics laboratory and some dedicated teachers like Ophelia Darby. Using an $800 annual budget and old instruments that barely function, she has built a band that was invited to play at an African-American festival in Philadelphia this spring. But the physical plant is dilapidated and hopelessly out of date.
 
Belief in a Legacy
 "The building needs to be replaced," said B. J. Caldwell, a black woman who is the high school principal, "but there's no tax base here. And the attitude in general seems to be that the building is good enough for them."
Many blacks believe that the town's stagnation is partly a perverse legacy of the school lawsuit.
"I don't think the people who have power care if it gets any better here," said Mr. Washington of the N.A.A.C.P. "It's like they feel, 'You pulled this on us 20 years ago, and so we're going to keep you down as much as we can.' "
Most people in town realize that Summerton may never prosper unless its schools do. The schools are not producing the educated work force needed to attract employers, but without an added economic base, it will be difficult to improve the schools.
The superintendent, Milton Marley, who is white, said many younger whites would like to improve the schools. "There's a cadre of younger people in the community who are trying to get involved in redevelopment," he said, "but it's a long process."
The young whites find themselves facing the same choice their parents did 35 years ago: Do they want their children to be a small minority in an overwhelmingly black district, and one that is clearly substandard? Most make the same decision their parents did and send their children elsewhere.
 
Brief Feeling of Good Cheer
 For two nights recently, Summerton did come back to life. In a event awash in nostalgia and good cheer, the gymnasium of the shuttered white high school was reopened for the Stars of Summerton, a variety show to raise money for downtown revitalization.
Fox Tindal did his animal imitations; some of the leading men in town donned pink tights and tutus for a ballet skit, and others performed acts, some serious, on an old-timey stage set adorned with the slogan, "Here's to Good Old Summerton."
Blacks as well as whites performed, but the high school entertainment came from the Manning High School Choir, not from the Scotts Branch High band. And despite the hopes of some organizers that it would be otherwise, the audience was virtually all white.
Just as the abandoned school is still viewed as the territory of whites, the fact that whites planned the event and staged it at the old white school defined it for blacks.
"There is no trust between the races," said Ms. Caldwell, the high school principal. "There's automatic suspicion when whites are in charge of anything. It's sad, but it's true."

HEADLINE: Studying Bush Plan, 2 Schools Back It for Different Reasons

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Public School 51 and the Holy Cross School are just four blocks apart on the dreary fringes of Times Square. Many of their students are impoverished, and they speak a babel of foreign languages.
When President Bush proposed on Thursday that parents be allowed to send their children to schools of their choice and that Federal funds for remedial programs should follow them, some observers noted that the flow of students and money will most likely be in one direction -- from public schools like P.S. 51 to parochial ones like Holy Cross. That may be true. Nonetheless, the leaders of both schools welcome the chance to compete.
 
Concern Over Funds
 "It is our job," said the principal of P.S. 51, John Economides, "to make our school so attractive that parents will not be going to private or parochial schools." 
 Mr. Economides runs the kind of school that would buttress President Bush's argument for parental choice.
In the 10 years he has been at the school, he has insisted that homework be assigned daily and that students treat teachers and one another with courtesy and respect. Discipline at his school, Mr. Economides says, is as firm as that for which Roman Catholic schools are noted.
Since Mr. Economides arrived at P.S. 51, the school's ranking on the citywide reading test has improved dramatically -- from 619th out of 633 schools to 137th. Today, 64.7 percent of the students read above grade level, compared with 18 percent in 1980.
Still, Mr. Economides is concerned about what might happen should the school lose the Federal funds for remedial programs, which he said amount to almost $100,000 annually.
It could mean the loss of Susan Schauer, the remedial reading teacher, and Milagros Cuevas, the English-as-a-second-language teacher, both of whose salaries are paid out of the funds. It could also mean the loss of two paraprofessionals who work with children who lag behind their classmates. And it could mean more crowded classes for all of the school's 284 students.
Mr. Bush's proposal would apply only to states that allow their own educational aid to follow students from neighborhood public schools to other public schools of their choice, as eight states now do. New York is not among those states, but President Bush is hoping to spur a nationwide movement toward parental choice.
And it is not clear whether Congressional approval of Mr. Bush's choice plan would violate United States Supreme Court rulings affirming the principle of separation of church and state.
Along with most other Catholic schools across the country, Holy Cross, on 43d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, has long fought for increased use of tax dollars to help its students.
 
Crossing the Street
 To receive remedial instruction from teachers financed by the Federal funds, students must leave the red-brick building, cross the street and enter two trailers fitted with classrooms. Such Rube Goldberg-like conditions result from a 1985 Supreme Court decision barring teachers paid through public funds from teaching at church-supported schools.
"If this proposal enables more children to attend our school, we will be delighted," said the Holy Cross principal, Sister Mary Theresa Dixon.
She said that contrary to the myth that only wealthy children can afford private schools, half of her 225 students live at or below the poverty level.
Sister Mary Theresa said her school needed extra Federal money for remedial programs because students come from homes where 18 languages are spoken, including Vietnamese, Hungarian and two dialects of Chinese.
"That raises particular problems for us, problems like English as a second language that are exactly the ones" the Federal funds are supposed to address, she said.
The problems faced by P.S. 51 are not very different from those at Holy Cross.
 
'Inside Here It's an Oasis'
 The public school, at 520 West 45th Street, is a turn-of-the-century, five-story building that dominates a desolate block of automobile repair shops, theatrical supply houses and railroad tracks.
"Outside here, we have prostitutes and drug dealers," Mr. Economides says. "Inside here it's an oasis."
Three-quarters of the students are from Spanish-speaking countries or Puerto Rico, and most of the rest are black or Middle Eastern or Asian immigrants. All but 11 students qualify for a free lunch, and the school easily meets the city's cutoff for eligibility for the Federal funds, which requires 54.1 percent of a schools' students body to receive some form of public assistance or free lunches.
Once a school is eligible, the amount of money is determined not by the numbers of poor children, but by the numbers of those who read and calculate below their grade level. The idea is to concentrate money on helping children with learning deficiencies. In the city as a whole 367,000 of the 956,000 students receive the remedial services.
Mr. Economides has chosen to use much of his money from the Federal program to set up a full-time remedial class for third and fourth graders who read two years or more below their grade or who are recent immigrants. Ms. Schauer, who teaches the class, emphasizes get to reading even when she is teaching mathematics and scienc.
There are 20 students in Ms. Schauer's class, which allows the other third- and fourth-grade classes to have 25 students instead of 30.
On Friday, Ms. Schauer was preparing children to take the citywide reading test that will be given on May 7. She hadthem complete sentences from lists of appropriate words. One reading passage was about cats, and Ms. Schauer asked if anyone had a pet. Daisy Bentley said she had a cat named Calico.
"He's crazy," she said.
 
Impact of Change
 The thought of losing Ms. Schauer upsets Mr. Economides, who came to New York from Greece when he was 11 and was educated in the city's public schools and at private colleges. Not only the neediest students would suffer, he says.
"I only have 13 classes and 17 teachers," he said. "If you take away one teacher and one para, you're making a substantial difference. It would mean classes in the third and fourth grade would have more students. The school as a whole would hurt."
Still, if children from surrounding public schools were to choose Mr. Economides's school, as some now do, and brought Federal money with them, the school might be able to offset its losses.
"I could even get more money," he mused. "There are negative and positive aspects to everything."
A spokesman for the city's Board of Education, said the board did not approve of any plan that could reduce the district's funds from the Federal program.
One student who has chosen P.S. 51 is Shana Nixon, a sixth grader who began attending the school when she lived in the transient Holland Hotel nearby. Now she travels 45 minutes from Brooklyn each day to continue at P.S. 51 rather than attend the school in her neighborhood.
Sister Mary Theresa thinks the increased competition that Mr. Bush hopes to foster will ultimately improveneighboring public schools, which she contends spend far more money for an inferior education. Tuition at her school is between $1,700 and $2,000, which covers much of the school's expenses, while the Board of Education spends an average of $6,000 a year for an elementary school pupil.
"I think we are doing a superior job for a lot less money," the parochial school principal said. "Shifting some money will not only take onerous pressures off us but also put a little more pressure on the public schools to get their act together."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Bush's Plans for Kurds Stir Fears of Indefinite Military Role in Iraq

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's intervention in Iraq's refugee crisis has raised concerns that it will lead to an indefinite American military presence in a breakaway Kurdish enclave, or a nascent Kurdish state.
A number of Middle East specialists say they believe that President Bush, while taking a substantial risk by sending United States military forces into northern Iraq to establish and protect refugee camps, is addressing a humanitarian imperative to rescue the majority of Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds, who are engaged in a life-threatening exodus the scale of which is unparalleled in their history. 
 Some of those specialists are relatively confident that Mr. Bush will be able to extricate American forces after United Nations and other international relief forces are able to assume the task of feeding and caring for hundreds of thousands of Kurds.
But as the first large-scale campsites were being selected this weekend, the uncertainty coursing through the Bush Administration was apparent.
A number of Government and outside experts say they fear that Iraq's opposition will drag the United States into long-term intervention to protect "enclaves" and "zones" where refugees will refuse to leave as long as Saddam Hussein is in power.
 
Acting as 'Eyes and Ears'
 "The best outcome would be to provide massive humanitarian aid with large numbers of international personnel to supervise it," said Phoebe Marr, an Iraq scholar at the National Defense University. "They could also act as the eyes and the ears of the international community to prevent retribution by the Iraqi Government, and as soon as possible the Kurds could be integrated back into Iraq under some protection from the central Government."
"Now my fear is that the enclaves may become more permanent than we would like," Ms. Marr continued, "and the international involvement may be longer than we like and the Kurds would not be integrated under reasonable terms into their own country."
"Under understandable international pressure we are getting into something, but we cannot yet see a clear way out," she said.
Mr. Bush's refugee relocation plan, shaped in consultation with Britain, France and Turkey, is based not only on providing immediate humanitarian aid. Of greater political importance, it also seeks to prevent a Kurdish migration across Iraq's northern border into Turkey and reverse the tide of Kurds that has already washed into Iran.
By keeping the Kurds in Iraq, the United States and its allies have set the stage to try to force a political solution between the Kurds and the Baghdad Government while also protecting Turkey, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Syria and Iran from instability and greater economic burden. The open question remains whether the Kurds will move.
 
Getting Control of Refugees
 The consequences of a sudden migration of more than two million Kurds out of Iraq would only sow the seeds of future rebellions for all three nations, which are home to a total of 20 million Kurds, some experts said. It could also set off an extended guerrilla war in which Iraq's displaced Kurds might seek to harass the Baghdad Government in perpetuity and inflame border tensions in the region.
William Colby, former Director of Central Intelligence, said: "It seems to me that we are back to basic policy that we don't want to dismember Iraq. That means the Kurds will be consigned to living under Iraqi rule, and the test will be if they can get enough guarantees to assure the decency of their treatment for a solution."
An Iraq scholar, Christine Moss Helms, said: "Everything these Governments are doing is to make sure this population of Kurds will be a controlled population. At a minimum they are giving humanitarian aid, but in fact what you are doing is getting them under control while the Turks are doing everything they can to make sure these Kurds don't go further into Turkey."
That strategy also assumes that the United States and its allies will be able to extricate themselves from Kurdish areas after they get their emergency program of refugee centers up and running. United Nations officials thus far have indicated that a great deal of negotiation will have to take place before United Nations forces could step in and assume the task now being performed by thousands of United States Marines and Army personnel backed by more than 100 combat and transport aircraft and dozens of heavy lift helicopters.
 
Short-Term Reconciliation
 In addition, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, told reporters in Geneva Friday that she did not see how the allies would be able to coax hundreds of thousands of Kurds out of the mountains while Mr. Hussein -- the reason for their flight -- remains in Baghdad.
The critical political dimension of Mr. Bush's task in stepping into Iraq's internal affairs is that of building that confidence among the Kurds, who so far have shown no inclination to return to the homes they fled after their failed uprising and the repression that followed it.
 
Baghdad's Control of Cities
 Like it or not, Mr. Bush might be forced to cooperate with Mr. Hussein in fostering a new internal security climate in Iraq. That will also make it easier for Mr. Hussein to protect the integrity of his country as he struggles to rebuild, sell oil and hold on to power.
Kurdish leaders, still disappointed at what they see as Mr. Bush's decision to abandon their insurrection almost as soon as he had encouraged it, do not appear to be opposed to a short-term reconciliation with Baghdad if it means an end to the refugee crisis.
"If that cooperation is for the security and well-being of the refugees, plus a guarantee for their safety, then, yes, it is a good thing," said Latif Rashid, a senior official in the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan. "We consider the refugee problem only temporary, but our goal is to get rid of Saddam Hussein, and we will go on to achieve our national rights in a democratic Iraq."
As the American and allied relief effort moves forward, Mr. Hussein has actively sought to protect Iraq's sovereignty from any intervention that might turn into a permanent occupation or fragmentation of Iraq.
Mr. Hussein has challenged the legality of the military intervention while seeking to displace it with a separate refugee assistance agreement signed in Baghdad between Iraqi officials and a United Nations envoy, Sadruddin Aga Khan.
With 30,000 Iraqi Army troops estimated to be in the northern part of the country, the Baghdad Government is most likely to maintain its control over the major northern cities of Mosul, Zakho, Dohuk, and Erbil even as American soldiers labor on the outskirts putting up tens of thousands of tents, kitchens and portable hospitals to prepare for a carefully staged reverse exodus.
 
Risks of Another Vietnam
 Mr. Colby, who witnessed as a senior C.I.A. official the incremental escalation of the American intervention in Vietnam, said he did not believe the refugee effort begun by Mr. Bush posed the same risks.
Still the operation runs strongly against the grain of United States military officers who live by the post-Vietnam catechism that every military operation must have a clear objective, achievable military goals in support of tangible political objectives.
While the military has responded rapidly to Mr. Bush's directive to enter Iraq's internal turmoil on a humanitarian mission, strong misgivings about the Kurdish intervention are likely to persist, according to Pentagon officials.
"I can tell you the military wants to get out," said an Administration official.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. MARINES LAND IN NORTHERN IRAQ TO SET UP CAMPS

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, April 20

 BODY:
A battalion of American marines landed in northern Iraq today to start building the first refugee camp in what is to be an allied-protected zone for Kurds inside Iraq.
The nearly 500 marines, in full combat gear, flew by helicopter to Zakho, an Iraqi border city about 10 miles from the bustling new American military camp at Silopi, Turkey. They were to be joined, military officials said, by hundreds of British Royal Marine commandos now at the Turkish military airfield here in Diyarbakir and by French paratroopers. 
 An American officer said the allied ground troops, all from elite units, would set up a forward line along the main highway running southeast from Zakho.
 
No Iraqis in Sight
 The goal of the allied operation is to convince more than half a million Kurdish refugees huddling in squalid camps atop remote Turkish mountains that they will be safe from the revenge of Saddam Hussein. The refugees began their mass exodus after a Kurdish uprising after the Persian Gulf war was crushed by the Iraqi Army.
The marines landed in Iraq about 1:30 P.M. local time and soon took control of Zakho, said Lieut. Col. Bob Flocke, a military spokesman who made the trip and then returned here.
"We're there, and they're not," he said, describing the town as almost deserted, with no Iraqi troops.
Thousands of the Kurdish refugees fled Zakho for the mountains more than two weeks ago when the Iraqi Army retook the town, one of the last to fall, from Kurdish rebels. Many of Zakho's inhabitants are now living miserably on a mountainside high above the Turkish village of Isikveren.
 
'To Bring Refugees Back'
 Dayton Maxwell, an official of the United States Agency for International Development, said, "The idea is to bring the residents of Zakho back," adding that the new camp would also be used temporarily to shelter refugees whose homes are deeper inside Iraq.
"Obviously if security is there and the residents of Zakho want to come back, that is the first big step," Mr. Maxwell said.
Colonel Flocke said the camps would be organized and settled according to clan groups.
"They will not be intermixed," he said. "They have to come from groups who know each other, who respect each other, so the organizational structure doesn't have to be built from scratch."
Over 500,000 Kurds, Turkomans, Syrian Christians, Shiite Muslims and deserters from the Iraqi Army fled to the mountains along the Turkish-Iraqi border after President Hussein's forces put down the Kurdish insurgency in northern Iraq as well as a Shiite Muslim revolt in the southeast.
The Marine landing came less than 24 hours after Lieut. Gen. John Shalikasvili of the U.S. Army met with two Iraqi generals and reportedly told them to keep their soldiers at least 19 miles away from Zakho.
The first construction trucks are to roll across the battered bridge over the Hezel River at the Habur border crossing on Sunday morning, said Col. Don Kinghoffer, the Army spokesman at the Incirlik Air Base, command center for the military relief effort.
The construction is being rushed in the hope of bringing the refugees down from the mountains before disease and hunger, which have taken a toll that relief officials fear may be in the thousands, cause more deaths.
"The driving criteria are the terrible conditions in the mountains." said Lieut. Col. Mike Boyce, a Marine attache at the American Embassy who is working with the task force. "We can't leave them in the mountains. We don't have enough time. We don't have any choice. It's too hard, too difficult to feed them."
 
Facing Potential Problems
 The new American-led plan has been pulled together so hastily that vital details are still in flux, say officers working on the operation. The effort faces a number of problems, including the widely voiced reluctance of Kurds in the camps to return to Iraq for fear of retribution from the Iraqi authorities.
The allied deployment is intended to give reassurances. Western diplomats said the Iraqis had been told to withdraw to a line 19 miles south of Zakho so that the Americans can set up what they hope will be transitional camps on the flat plain between the river and the next jagged mountain range in Iraq.
"These guys are like the Berlin Brigade," the Western diplomat said, referring to the troops' function as a tripwire to bring retaliation should the Iraqis attack. "They are there to make the refugees feel safe."
Referring to the Iraqi military, Colonel Boyce said: "If they want to fight, they will be making the second biggest mistake in the last year. These Iraqis are going to have to leave."
But the plan for the safe havens is seen as potentially flawed by many international relief workers and experts in the region's long tribal and ethnic conflicts, including the struggle of the Kurds, a mountain people living in areas near the borders of Iraq, Iran, Turkey and Syria and the Soviet Union, to form their own nation.
In addition to the appalling conditions that the refugees are living in and the political effect that television pictures of their misery have had in the West, the plan to move them back to Iraq is also fueled by the reluctance of the President Turgut Ozal of Turkey to have them here in his poor country's southeastern and largely Kurdish region.
"The Turks see the whole thing as a security problem, rather than a refugee problem," an international aid worker said.
"What we're doing is creating the worst of the West Bank and Gaza Strip and Beirut," said another aid official, whose agency has long experience in those parts of the Middle East. He warned of internal struggles, including the possibility that not only Iraqi Government forces might attack the refugees but also the Marxist Kurdish Workers Party, which might deem them traitors for fleeing in the first place.
"Why should the Kurds believe the Americans?" the official said. "They believed them before, and look what happened." He referred to what were widely taken as American encouragements to the Kurds and other opposition groups to rise up against Mr. Hussein during the war, and a subsequent lack of military backing by Washington.
 
Marines Pour Into Silopi
 The marines who went into Iraq today, from the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, based on ships of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, have for the last few days been pouring into the new base at Silopi, from which military helicopters are flying food, water and medicine to the refugees in Iraq.
On Monday, sheep were grazing in the area. Special Air Force construction crews began putting up tents, and service teams set up kitchens and laundries. By the weekend, the base at Silopi was a humming tent city of some 2,000 troops serving as an American military logistics base. Supplies arrived overland from ports on the Mediterranean, and the base became a camp for the soldiers in Iraq, marines trained in special operations like night attacks and commando raids.
The marines carried night-vision goggles as part of their equipment today as they paused for a moment in prayer before boarding the helicopters to drop into Iraq.
"We do not expect an encounter with the Iraqis, but we are prepared for any contigency," Maj. Ron Gahagan of the Army, the Silopi base spokesman, told reporters.
 
Tents First, Then Buildings
 Silopi was originally intended as an emergency logistics base, officers there said, and now appears to be the logical forward operating point for the move to set up the camps in Iraq.
The current plans, Colonel Boyce said, were to put up tents in the refugee camps in Iraq as a first stage and then to build some kind of wooden buildings. It is hoped, he said, that Kurds who lived inside the protected zone before their exodus would return to their former homes and that others would move into the camps in hopes of going home someday.
The refugees, he said, would probably be brought down from the mountains in trucks, although he cautioned that some of the mountain encampments were so remote they could only be reached by helicopter. The American military is trying to work through traditional clan leaders to persuade the Kurds to go into the bases.
"They have to believe first they are going to be secure, and second that what they're going to have is better than what they have now," he said. "The first is going to be difficult, but if you have seen the camps they are in now, the second is not hard."

Kurd-Iraq Talks Reported
 IN NORTHERN IRAQ, April 20 (AP) -- Leaders of four Kurdish groups are in Baghdad trying to negotiate a settlement to the rebellion against President Saddam Hussein, rebels said today.
The talks started on Friday after Mr. Hussein expressed a readiness "to discuss everything with the Kurdish side except secession," said a rebel close to the Kurdish leadership.
The Kurds had been reluctant to negotiate, fearing that Mr. Hussein would renege on any agreement once his Government recovered from its shattering defeat in Kuwait.
They said they changed their minds in the face of the refugee crisis.
With the talks reportedly under way, Iraq today repeated an amnesty offer for the Kurds, saying they could return within 15 days without fear of retribution. Many Kurds do not believe the offer.

HEADLINE: The World;
Feeding on 19th Century Conditions, Cholera Spreads in Latin America

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
WITH the specter of cholera hanging over the Dickensian slums of Latin America, a news magazine here recently reproduced a 19th-century engraving of the Thames alongside a modern-day photo of Lima's sewage-choked River Rimac. The resemblance was striking.
As in 19th-century London, residents of Lima take 70 percent of their piped drinking water from their river, a waterway that also flushes much of their untreated wastes into the sea. 
Now cholera is making its first major visit to the Western Hemisphere in the 20th century. Its explosive spread -- 158,000 cases in Peru in three months -- has focused attention on how millions of Latin America's city dwellers make do with sewage and drinking water facilities reminiscent of 19th-century Europe.
"In Europe, cholera served to awaken people to the need to invest in sanitation," said Uriel Garcia, a doctor and former Peruvian Health Minister. "Today, cholera may awaken governments here and abroad to provide clean drinking water and sewage in Latin America."
Protected by clean water supplies, American epidemiologists today show little concern over the news that three visitors to cholera-plagued areas in the Andes were recently hospitalized in the United States with cholera symptoms. Cholera, spread by bacteria associated with human feces, can kill in less than a day with dehydration from severe diarrhea, nausea and high fever. In societies with good medical care, cholera is preventable and can be treated with antibiotics and intravenous rehydration. The last major American epidemic was in 1866. A minor outbreak along the Louisiana-Texas shoreline in the 1970's and early 1980's sickened 40 people, but none died.
"We have flush toilets, running water, hygienic practices," Myron M. Levine, an epidemiologist with the University of Maryland, said during a visit here last week. "Cholera is not traditionally an upper-class phenomemon. Typically, it's a disease associated with lower socioeconomic groups."
But for Latin America's slum dwellers, for whom clean water is a luxury, cholera could become a major and recurring health threat in the 1990's.
In Peru, 1,140 people have already died. Cholera has spread to Ecuador, Colombia, Chile, and a corner of Brazil's Amazon. Using Peru's experience as a yardstick, health authorities calculate that the disease could sicken 3 million Brazilians this year. Brazil was the site of the Western Hemisphere's last major cholera epidemic, in 1895.
Setting the stage for an explosion of the disease are a parade of statistics: 40 percent of Lima's 7 million residents do not have access to potable, piped water; 40 percent of Brazil's 150 million people do not have access to sewers. Washing hands and boiling drinking water are two vital measures with which even the poor can prevent the spread of cholera in normal times, but Peru's economic crisis has now set off sharp drops in the sales of both hand soap and kerosene.
"When you have to buy water to drink, it is very difficult to think of using water to wash your hands," said Edgard Necochea, a health program director here for the Agency for International Development.
In the mid-19th century, fear that cholera epidemics would recur prompted city authorities to create health boards in London and in New York, according to William H. McNeill's book "Plagues and Peoples." Overruling protests by taxpayers and property owners, these boards expanded underground pipe networks in those cities to provide universal access to clean water and to hygienic sewage disposal.
"The alarm cholera created in American and European cities provided the essential leverage for those reformers who sought to improve urban sanitation, housing, health services and water supply," Mr. McNeill wrote. "Cholera has, in fact, never returned to European cities since, thanks to systematic purification of urban water supplies from bacteriological contamination."
But many officials say there is a major barrier to resolving the problem that way in South America today -- a lack of money.
The Pan American Health Organization calculates that providing adequate water and sewage to Peru's 22 million inhabitants would require an investment by the Government of $320 million a year over the next 10 years. But in recent years, Peru has invested less than one-tenth that amount -- an average of $31 million annually -- and Peru's economy is in the middle of a wholesale collapse; the gross national product has dropped 30 percent in the last three years.
"Peru is 40 years behind in basic sanitation investments," said Eduardo Salazar Lindo, president of Peru's new Cholera Commission. As he spoke in his fourth-floor office at the Health Ministry, chants and police sirens could be heard on the street below. Striking nurses were marching, demanding a raise from their current pay level of $37 a month. Because of the strike, Peru's state-run hospitals confronted the cholera epidemic this month without staff nurses.
Preying on wounded societies, cholera is expected to further weaken Latin America's battered economies. Last February, a wave of barriers flew up around the world to block Peru's food exports. Most of the barriers receded, but at the same time tourism arrivals dropped by 70 percent.
Health experts say that to fight cholera, governments will have to execute long-range campaigns to permanently change the hygiene habits of Latin America's poor through sanitation education and through the universal construction of low-cost latrines, water purification units and rooftop water tanks for schools and for hospitals. For funding, the Pan American Health Organization plans to ask the United States, Europe and Japan to contribute to a $12 billion Latin American emergency health fund.
"Our hope is that cholera will suddenly disappear from Lima and Guayaquil, the way it disappeared from London and Paris," said Dr. Garcia. "Our fear is that it will become endemic, like in parts of Asia and Africa."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Residents of a shantytown near Chimbote, Peru, collecting drinking water from an open well. Contaminated water is largely responsible for the cholera epidemic. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The World;
A Reward, Not a Cure, for South Africa

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
IN the nearly 15 months since he set about to end apartheid, President F. W. de Klerk has tried to convince the world that the political changes he set in motion were irreversible. Last week, the European Community took him at his word, lifting a trading ban, imposed in 1986, on iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa. The community's move, which followed by four months its lifting of a ban on new investments, was welcomed here as presaging the end of an international framework of sanctions enacted in protest against the racist ideology that Mr. de Klerk is dismantling.
"The psychological effect of the decision is important," Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said at a news briefing. "It should now make it clear to South Africans that the way the State President has chosen is the way that Europe will support." 
 President de Klerk left Friday on a trip to Britain, Denmark and Ireland, amid euphoric domestic expectations that the European Community's decision could lead to other dividends, including an end to the international sports boycott that would put South African athletes back into the Olympics by 1992.
Yet South Africa, burdened by a predicted zero growth rate this year, 14 percent inflation and a scarcity of foreign capital, will find it hard to take advantage of the windfall without addressing the poverty, joblessness and attendant violence afflicting the nation's black majority.
"What we cannot do is attract new investments in an atmosphere of violence," Finance Minister Barend du Plessis warned recently. Without new markets, he said, South Africa would not be able to grow. And without growth, he said, the economy could spiral downward into chaos.
In 1986, South Africa was selling 400,000 to 500,000 tons of steel a year to European countries, according to Leslie Boyd, the chairman of the Highveld Steel and Vanadium Corporation. With the embargo, the industry had to turn to less profitable overseas markets. Now, Mr. Boyd said, "the only significant steel market still closed to South Africa is the United States."
But South Africa needs new investment to offset a capital outflow of 30 billion rand, currently about $11 billion, between 1985 and 1990. The fear is that the political violence, which killed more than 3,000 blacks last year and has killed close to 600 so far this year, could scare away potential investors, who might feel safer putting their money in Eastern Europe. "As we all know, investors do not easily invest in a situation where people are killing each other on such a scale in this bloodthirsty manner," Mr. Botha said.
His concern was echoed in the white business community. "Unless there are greater efforts towards unity and peace in our country, we will scuttle whatever benefits may accrue," said Deryk Spence, the chief executive of Castrol, the petroleum company.
 
A Question of Timing
 In lifting the sanctions, the European Community disregarded a plea from the African National Congress to let it decide when sanctions should go. The congress, which is maneuvering for advantaqge in future talks with the Government, has accused it of failing to stem the township violence. The congress warned that lifting sanctions would make Pretoria more intransigent. As sanctions evaporate, the congress may fall back on its strategy of "mass action" -- strikes, boycotts and other protests -- that could add to instability.
 Those reconsidering the efficacy of sanctions include a longtime proponent, the Anglican Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu. But the congress has not given up on sanctions. "Where we have failed at a multilateral level, we will take it up with individuals," Saki Macozoma, a congress spokesman, said after the community's decision. Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress's deputy president, was likely to argue for keeping sanctions on a visit to Japan, but the prime target was bound to be the United States Congress, which imposed the most stringent sanctions in 1986. Once Mr. de Klerk has freed political prisoners and repealed all apartheid laws, as he has promised, he will have met, in theory, all terms for lifting sanctions.
Sanctions have hit blacks hard, eliminating old jobs and failing to create new ones. Over a third of the country's potential labor force of 12 million now lacks formal employment and only 12 in every 100 newcomers can find work. Despair and deprivation engendered by the lack of opportunity have contributed to rising crime and instability.
Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, whose differences with the African National Congress have fueled factional fighting between their respective supporters, said sanctions should never have been applied because apartheid's victims suffer first. The congress says the jobless are casualties in a just war against apartheid. In fact, joblessness is also related to other factors like the declining price of gold, which produced an announcement last week that another 12,500 mine workers, most of them black, would be laid off.
The gloomiest prognosis has come from the Government itself, which says it does not have the resources to eliminate gross disparities between blacks and whites.
Chris Stals, the Governor of the South African Reserve Bank, told an economic conference in Italy earlier this month that South Africa could become ungovernable by 1995 unless its economy improves. Mr. Stals suggested that the mysterious "third force" that Mr. Mandela and others have blamed for abetting township unrest might be the economy itself. "We must not overlook the influence of the low growth rate on the prevailing violence," he said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Old Habits Ensnare the Middle East Again

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
APPEARANCES in the Middle East are almost always deceiving. The Persian Gulf war was initially and widely acclaimed as a decisive victory for the United States-led coalition. So it was, militarily. But it seemed decidedly less glorious last week as 10,000 American soldiers scoured the harsh Iraqi landscape seeking suitable terrain for vast refugee camps to save hundreds of thousands of desperate Kurds, the unanticipated human debris of the conflict.
And any expectations that the victory of arms would reverse historical trends, shatter traditional alliances, and bring gains for peace and stability in the region seemed last week to have been very premature. They seemed to have been overpowered both by patterns and rhythms long entrenched in Middle Eastern politics and by the consequences of an event much more far-reaching even than the war -- the disappearance of the Soviet Union as a player in that part of the world. 
 "What initially looked like a watershed in the Mideast may turn out to be one very long, loud hiccup," said a veteran diplomat in Tunisia, which opposed the presence of American forces in the region. "It was the collapse of the Soviet Union that made the gulf war possible."
From Morocco to Oman, in lands that backed the coalition and in those that did not, anxiety about the region's future is growing once more.
Before the war, optimistic analysts in Arab capitals and in Washington predicted that a decisive, quick military victory for the American-led coalition would address several major causes of instability. First, the argument went, the victory would make apparent the bankruptcy of Saddam Hussein's dictatorial form of government and thus reinforce democratic trends. Second, it would bolster prospects for economic development and dramatize the need to close the enormous gap between rich and poor Arab countries. And it would shift traditional, but outmoded, Arab political alignments; this, in turn, would enhance prospects for peace between Israel and the Arabs.
Even before the war was fought, analysts were hailing the emergence of the anti-Iraq coalition, which aligned wealthy Saudi Arabia with populous Egypt and militarily powerful Syria. In contrast to the Arab League, which had been rendered impotent by ideological, economic and geographic divisions, it was said that this new alliance would be more stable and would operate on pragmatic, realistic calculations. The Arabs' more extreme fringes would be neutralized and their self-deluding mythologies and oratory about political unity would be dropped.
But some analysts now fear that the new axis may itself be unstable. "Saudi Arabia and Egypt have long been suspicious of each other, for history, envy, and other good reasons," a senior Egyptian diplomat said. And many analysts say Syria's recent pragmatism predates the war; it is, they argue, much more a consequence of the decline of Damascus's traditional patron, the Soviet Union. By the time the gulf crisis began last summer, Damascus had few options but to seek economic and military support from the United States and the countries that rapidly became its new coalition partners.
At the same time, the outcome of the war does not seem to have led very many Arabs to abandon their dreams of pan-Arab or Islamic unity. And despite reports anticipating its demise, the Arab League clings to life.
Prospects for economic development or for closing the gaps between rich and poor nations have also not been enhanced by the war. The chances for sustained growth in Egypt are not good despite Cairo's efforts to restructure its economy. Saudi aid -- more than $2 billion in loans and debt forgiveness -- offers "a window of opportunity to resolve our economic problems," said Boutros Ghali, Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, "if we choose to use it." But there is also strong temptation to use the aid to continue deferring the painful economic restructuring that most Western economists say is essential to attracting investment.
No assistance from the gulf countries, moreover, can be expected for the Sudan, an economic basket case, or for Jordan and other poor countries that opposed the coalition. Even a proposal by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to establish a bank for reconstruction and development was quickly rejected by the White House. The Administration, instead, has sought reparations for Kuwait from devastated Iraq.
Prospects for Arab-Israeli peace have been improved only a little. While Saudis and Israelis shared the terror of being targeted by Iraqi Scud missiles during the war, Riyadh and other coalition members today are resisting the confidence-building measures being promoted by Mr. Baker on his tours of the Middle East. And the Government of Yitzhak Shamir, though ready to endorse some aspects of Mr. Baker's approach to setting up talks, is still resisting the fundamental principle that underlies key United Nations resolutions -- trading occupied territory for peace.
Perhaps most bitter of all to many Arab democrats is what they see as the Bush Administration's endorsement of brutal dictatorship, even if it is still that of Saddam Hussein, as the preferred form of government for Iraq. One uncomfortable fact that the Administration had to contend with during the war was that with the exception of Egypt, the Arab countries with the most active movements seeking democratization -- Jordan, Yemen and Algeria -- opposed the use of American forces to do battle with Iraq. Edward Mortimer, a British analyst of Arab affairs, commented in the latest issue of The New York Review of Books that the Administration's standard seemed to be that "while dictatorship is regarded as abnormal and in the last resort unacceptable if applied to Europeans, it is assumed to be, for Arab and Muslim peoples, the only workable alternative to traditional monarchy or to direct colonial rule by external powers."
Competing impulses weighed heavily on the Bush Administration last week as American troops sought once more to keep the peace. Its repeated statements that the Kurdish refugee rescue project would neither delay the homecoming of American forces nor draw the United States even deeper into Iraq's tortured politics reflected the enduring legacy of Vietnam -- a lingering fear of entangling involvements in unwinnable or unpopular conflicts far from home.
In the end, that fear was overcome by worry that the victory in Iraq was being sullied by seeming indifference to the plight of the Kurds, who had taken their cue from American pleas for Iraqis to rise up against their despotic ruler and whose straits now simply horrified many Americans. Mindful that the victorious American forces had stood by while Saddam Hussein crushed the Kurds' rebellion, Americans wanted President Bush to do something. So he did. But still American officials made it clear that they would ultimately prefer for Iraq a predictable, if nasty, dictator over an unpredictable effort to form a coalition or democratic government that could yield to the "Lebanonization," or bloody breakup, of Iraq.
This way of thinking, too, is nothing new. Through its support for the Shah in Iran, its tilt toward Saddam Hussein during the Iran-Iraq war, or the new reasons it has now found to work with the shrewd, patient and sometimes ruthless President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, the United States has often shown that it fears the consequences of encouraging democracy in the Arab Middle East.
