HEADLINE: The Region;
Albany's Budget-Balancing 'One-Shots' Will Reverberate for Years to Come

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
UNLIKE the Federal Government, New York State, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo likes to point out, does not have the capacity to print money when it needs it. But it does have something almost as good -- and almost as troubling. It has one-shots.
One-shots, simply put, are revenues from sources like reserve funds or proceeds from the sale of public property that the state can use -- one time, that is -- to balance its budget when tax collections fall short. Yet they are rarely simple. Often the state indulges in complex refinancing schemes and asset transfers that provide easy money up front, but in the long run cost taxpayers millions of dollars. 
 In recent years, as New York has sunk deeper into the red, the state has become increasingly inventive in coming up with one-shots; just recently, for example, it managed to sell its Attica prison, site of the bloody uprising in 1971, to one of its own authorities, the Urban Development Corporation, for a cool $200 million.
But as New York's use of one-shots has grown, so too has the criticism of the practice. Many analysts say the arrangements are emblematic of the buy-now-pay-later approach to budgeting that put New York into the fiscal mess it is in now. And as the state grapples with a budget gap of $6 billion -- a spending plan for the current fiscal year, due three weeks ago, is still nowhere near completion -- the issue of how much the state should rely on these special deals to balance its books is once again being grimly debated.
"Of all the proposals that have come forward, one-shots are the least courageous," said Raymond Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by business. "They simply postpone the day of reckoning; they don't prevent the day of reckoning."
The problem, fiscal experts say, is that one-shots by definition work only once, while the expenses they are financing are recurring. If the state uses a nonrecurring revenue to pay for an ongoing expense, then the next year it is likely to be faced with the same shortfall all over again.
"It's not the best financial management," said Charles Stein, past president of the New York State Government Finance Officers Association. "Because what do you do the next year, when you run out of one-shots?"
Last year, New York's reliance on such measures reached what many experts believe to be a record high; the budget was precariously balanced with almost $2 billion in nonrecurring revenues. This was one of several reasons why the state's credit rating was dropped two notches, to the third lowest in the country.
While New York had routinely raided its reserve funds for extra cash in the past, 1990 was the year when the art of the one-shot deal reached new extremes.
Take, for instance, the recently completed sale of Attica. The state paid for the prison once when it was built in 1931. Now it has sold the prison to the Urban Development Corporation in return for $200 million in cash. Over the next 30 years the state will buy the prison back, essentially paying for it twice. The irony of the sale was not lost on its many critics, who noted that the Urban Development Corporation's original mandate when it was set up in 1968 was to "facilitate the development of affordable housing for low-income persons."
This is how the deal works: In order to come up with cash for the state, the corporation had to issue bonds. These bonds are to be retired using payments the state will make to lease Attica for its prisoners. Once the bonds are paid off, three decades from now, the state will once again own Attica. But in the process of buying back the prison, the state will not only have to repay the $200 million purchase price, but will also have to pay, according to estimates by the State Comptroller's office, some $290 million in interest costs.
Many officials argue that such deals are justified by New York's fiscal straits. "We did not want to raise another $200 million in taxes, and we did not want to make another $200 million in cuts when the economic forecast was that this was a temporary downturn," said Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget director. "This was in essence taking out a second mortgage."
But others say that the one-shot strategems are simply exacerbating, rather than solving, the state's problems. Mr. Stein contends that New York City's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's was brought, at least in part, by the extensive reliance on one-shot deals to meet budget needs.
Still smarting from criticism about last year's fiscal legerdemain, Governor Cuomo proposed a much more modest menu of one-shots this year, totaling by his estimates roughly $600 million -- and by the State Comptroller's office roughly $1 billion. These proposals include the sale of Aqueduct race track to the Port Authority and the sale of route I-84 to the Thruway Authority.
In recent weeks, however, there has been growing pressure from the Republican-controlled State Senate to increase the use of one-shots. When the Senate proposed its alternative to the Governor's budget earlier this month, it offered a menu of some $1.3 billion worth of possible new one-shots, including calling in some $500 million of long-standing debts that are owed to the state from various authorities.
The plan prompted State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, also a Republican, to warn that "recent budget proposals and pronouncements raise the specter that the proliferation of one-shots may increase." And Mr. Cuomo warned that "any attempt to close a substantial part of the gap through one-shots would be unacceptable."
But as they like to say in Albany, where major decisions are invariably made at the last moment, "It ain't over till it's over." When the only other choice is a new tax, one-shots can start to look pretty irresistible.
 
FULLY SECURED
As one source of revenue to close Albany's continual budget gap, the state has sold Attica Correctional Facility to the Urban Development Corporation. The money paid by the U.D.C. went into the general state budget, and Albany will lease the facility back, paying the U.D.C. enough each year to repay the original purchase price, plus 30 years of interest.
 
U.D.C. purchase price for Attica prison -- $200 million
Interest (8% for 30 years) -- $290 million
In effect, the state borrows $200 million for immediate use, paying $290 million over 30 years for doing so. (Sources: Division of the Budget; State Comptroller's Office)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
For Some Two-Paycheck Families, The Economics Don't Add Up

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
SHE wakes when the baby cries, gets the baby dressed and fed, then puts on her own blouse and suit ($340, plus $11 for dry-cleaning), snags her pantyhose ($2), waits for the baby sitter ($60 a day), crams into the subway ($1.15), picks up coffee and a bagel ($1), goes to the office, meets a friend for lunch ($7), goes back to work, then home on the subway ($1.15), picking up dinner at the gourmet deli ($12) because she won't have time to cook.
And every payday, she asks herself the prime postfeminist question: should women with young children work? 
 Financially, the answer may be no -- at least for professional women, and at least in the short run.
For while more than half of all women with preschool children now hold paid jobs, many discover with dismay that their earnings are barely enough to pay for child care, taxes and the other expenses of working.
Soul-searching about whether the second income really makes the family any better off has become a staple of playground talk. Women's magazines have picked up the issue, too, as in Redbook's April article, "I Couldn't Afford My Job," a first-person account of a woman who quit upon finding that two-thirds of her take-home pay went straight to the baby sitter and the remaining third was too small to pay for office clothes, time-saving foods, transportation and the new higher tax bracket.
The personal math differs from family to family, and it rarely comes down to a simple accountant's tally. For many new mothers, decisions about whether, when and how much to work are complicated with a heavy overlay of feelings about family life, commitment to career, financial independence, personal identity and motherhood.
And having a chance to choose between going back to work and staying home with the baby is a luxury that millions of single mothers and less affluent women cannot afford. For women who are the primary support of their families, and those whose husbands earn $30,000 or less, paid work is usually a necessity: however low the wife's net pay, it is crucial to the family's finances.
It is impossible to generalize about how much a second job will yield because family spending patterns vary so widely, depending on such variables as commuting distance, child care and clothing needs. But because poorer families spend less on everything from day care to meals out, substantially more of their second income remains to be spent on other things.
For example, a suburban Minneapolis couple in which the husband earns $25,000 and the wife earns $16,000 would be likely to spend about $60 a week to keep the baby in family day care at a neighbor's house. Assuming that the wife spent $20 a week for coffee and lunches, and $15 a week for work clothes, the family would still come out more than $6,000 ahead if she keeps her job. And for that family, $6,000 represents about a 30 percent increase over the disposable income they would have if only the husband worked.
A Difference of $6,000
But in higher-income families, there is often a real question about whether the family reaps any significant financial benefit from the wife's work. A New York City family in which the husband earns $70,000 and the wife $50,000, might well pay $300 a week for a baby sitter to come to their home -- but as the adjacent chart shows, with other expenses that family's income would increase by less than $6,000 as a result of the wife's work, a difference that may not mean much improvement in the standard of living.
But most economists, feminists and social policy experts argue that even for women whose take-home pay covers nothing more than child care costs and commuting, staying in the work force is a rational economic decision over the long term.
"It's true that in the short run, for a few years, you might not keep much of your earnings," said Sheila Kamerman, a social policy professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work. "But continuing to work is an investment in your future earnings, and there does come a time when the child-care costs diminish, the wife's salary will probably go up, and there is a clear financial benefit. Meanwhile, women who take a long time out of the workforce are likely to find that they cannot command the same kind of salary when they are ready to go back in."
Experts also note that it is risky to depend on the father as sole wage-earner, given the harsh realities of layoffs, divorce and widowhood. And many cavil at the whole analysis, considering it wrong-headed to view child care costs as an expense to be charged against the mother's income.
"It's completely sexist to say that child care comes out of the mother's salary," argued Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington, "Child care is a family expense, like the mortgage or the heat."
In theory, maybe. But as a practical matter, child-care costs are different from other family budget items, since they can be avoided by one parent's staying home.
Many feminists use such budget analyses to argue for a national family policy that would improve the quality and affordability of child care and help mothers who work outside the home.
Men and women alike may question why it should be the mother who considers leaving her job -- but as a practical matter, working women earn 68 cents for every dollar men earn, and are therefore the obvious candidates for child care, another poorly paid job.
Sexism and policy issues aside, there is at least one economic analysis suggesting that mothers who do stay home don't save all that much. According to a 1989 study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, two-earner families spend only 18 percent more for child care than families in which the wife doesn't work -- and less than 5 percent more for women's apparel and food away from home.
"There are differences, but statistically, across all income groups, they just aren't that big," said Eva Jacobs, an author of the study. "It's not every working woman that wears office clothes and has lunch in a restaurant -- and the women who stay home have to have clothes and lunch, too."
Susan Swain, who left her job in community relations at a Connecticut utilities company in 1986, remembers her decision to quit her three-day-a-week job and stay home with her children. Although Ms. Swain works part time, her example echoes many of the problems faced by professional women with young children.
"My husband and I sat down and figured out that my salary, which was in the $35-$40,000 range, was just bumping him into a higher tax bracket," she said. "We were paying $250 a week for three days of child care for the two kids, and then I still neededbaby sitters to do the shopping and things on the days I was home. I was a professional, so I needed nice clothes, and my driving around meant a lot of wear and tear on the car. My husband is an accountant, and he said we were not making a lot of money on this. And I really wanted to be around more for my children."
It did not relieve the family of all costs, though: Ms. Swain ended up with a live-in nanny for two years after she left her job. With her youngest now in kindergarten, she has started a part-time job close to home.
"If I had wanted to get back in where I left, I might have had to step back in salary a year or two," she said. "I'm lucky to have been able to afford to do it this way, and I'm happy with the choices I've made. But if there's one thing I've learned, it's that there is no right answer. Everybody has to do what works best for them."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Mission Possible

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Nothing is impossible when it comes to Iraq. Everything is impossible when it comes to America. That is the misguided message emanating from much of Washington and the think-tank world.
 American leaders, at their most farsighted, hesitated only momentarily to sacrifice lives and fortune to drive Iraq from Kuwait. But when it comes to fixing up a disintegrating America, the task is beyond the skills and scope of government, they say. 
 Legions of pundits and experts demand that we now make a major effort to bring democracy to Iraq. But when it comes to doing something about America's deteriorating public schools -- the foundation of our democracy -- only very modest steps can be taken, they say.
The best minds and most powerful Americans, crying with wonderful outrage and passion, have mobilized to save the Kurds. But few have dollars and tears left for the crack babies, the homeless, the squalor and hopelessness of our poor -- the "Kurds of America."
 Don't tell me there is no money. Don't say these problems here at home are too vast and complicated to be addressed by government.
 We have heard enough of this fashionable intellectual defeatism from neo-conservatives, neo-liberals and now even from confused and self-doubting liberals, most of whom argue we can achieve anything in Iraq.
 The magnitude of the task and the money did not stop us in the Persian Gulf. The challenge of repairing America's roadways, railways, airports and public education system is no greater nor more complicated than that of transforming Iraq into a democracy. The passion and commitment to save the Iraqi Kurds also belong to America's Kurds.
 Rescuing America is no less a national emergency than restoring Kuwaiti sovereignty and helping a persecuted people in a distant land. It is more of an emergency -- for the world and for ourselves.
The Kurds can seek their freedom because there is a strong America willing to protect them. Our democracy and our free-enterprise economy were the lights that freedom fighters followed in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
 Our political and economic systems have been the models for the world. How ironic that just when nations finally reject Communism, our political and economic systems show terminal signs of stalemate and structural rot.
 Hysterical nonsense, the neos and cluck-cluckers say as the stock market surges over 3,000 and as they drive out to their country homes and send their children to private schools.
 Drive into New York City from La Guardia Airport and gaze on the filth people have learned to live with. Turn off the highway and motor through Harlem, more bombed out than Baghdad, and look at the dozens of black men on the corner of 112th Street and Lexington Avenue. Drugs everywhere. Go to this city's schools where young kids pass through metal detectors to catch the guns and knives they bring to menace others and defend themselves.
 Young people from other industrialized countries have long since surpassed ours in math and science skills. Germany and Japan have long since built better cars.
 Turn on your television and listen to younger Americans of all races talk. Few can communicate simple ideas in anything resembling English. Many of the Kurds being interviewed on Turkish mountaintops speak better English than our own people.
 Bend the ears of Bush Administration officials, legislators and experts, and you will hear these answers: Well, the American people just don't see the situation as a national crisis. Well, it takes Presidential leadership. Well, President Bush isn't interested in domestic affairs. Well, we have a Congress controlled by Democrats and a Republican President. Well, George Bush is moving now with educational reform. Well, you just can't throw money at these problems.
 Well, they are all right -- and dead wrong. If the United States, if these very same people, had bowed to such "realities" in the Persian Gulf, we never would have lifted a finger there. What gave us strength in the gulf was our national resolve and passion, the very ingredients needed now to find the money and the ideas to save ourselves.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Public Servants: Public Spirited?

 BODY:
Where is labor?
As New York City rides deeper into fiscal stringency, its municipal union leaders continue to respond mainly to their narrow constituencies. That is lamentable; historically, labor leaders have often been social statesmen, as in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. And it is counterproductive even in narrow terms. As New York City goes, so go its employees. If the city is to bounce back, it needs conscientious help from all sides, including -- indeed, especially from -- labor. 
 The city's immediate problem is a $465 million budget deficit in the 10 weeks remaining in this fiscal year. Closing it in so short a period is no easy task. The temptation will be to patch and paste in ways that will increase the deficit next year. That can be avoided with another approach, the most sensible one available: for labor to go along with the Dinkins administration proposal to furlough city workers, on a rotating basis, for at least three days.
Furloughing non-essential, non-emergency employees -- about two-thirds of the city's work force -- would save about $30 million a day. Furloughs are a last resort and an unpleasant one. They deny employees income and deny taxpayers services. But with the economy so weak and the city's problems so large, furloughs provide the cleanest, most direct way to save money fast. To ask public servants to contribute in this way to the city's salvation is only to ask for reasonable sacrifice.
So far, the fiscal crisis has meant little to the municipal unions. While Gov. Mario Cuomo is imposing a wage freeze on state employees, several city unions have already won raises, and the teachers' union agreed to a wage deferral only in exchange for sweeteners that will benefit the union in the future at a cost to the city.
Labor leaders now denounce the idea of furloughs in the same spirit, positioning themselves to extract concessions in return for cooperating. That is their standard role, getting the most they can for their members. But in this gathering crisis, there is another role for them: to step up to labor's tradition of social responsibility.
What's more, agreeing to a furlough would be in labor's own interest. If the city is forced to push 1991 costs into 1992, the likelihood of layoffs will increase. The anticipated deficit starting July 1 is already $3 billion -- and counting. Small wage losses now can help avoid lost jobs later. That in itself represents quite an incentive for the unions -- substantial enough for Mr. Dinkins to win their support without making any concessions.
New York City would not have emerged whole from the fiscal crisis of the 70's without help, indeed without leadership, from its labor unions. They can be a large part of the solution again, if their leaders now bring public spirit to the way they represent public servants.

HEADLINE: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded;
Meaningless Details

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am outraged by your April 17 article about the woman in the Florida rape inquiry, who you say "moved sharply up the economic scale 10 years ago." The only jump up the economic ladder you discuss is that the alleged victim's divorced mother married a man supposedly more financially secure than her first husband. Hardly relevant to the victim's character or the case. 
 Moreover, questions of naming the victim of a rape aside, you go much further in giving negative, meaningless details of the alleged victim's life in a blatant attempt to cast doubt on her character. What could information about how many parking tickets she has received, how fast she was going at the time, her high school academic record or that, like hundreds of thousands of women across the country, she is an unmarried mother possibly have to do with whether or not she was the victim of a rape in the morning of March 31?
You are playing the old game of discrediting the victim of a rape, which serves a twofold purpose: it often gets the attacker off the hook, and it makes hundreds of innocent victims afraid to come forward. A woman does not deserve to be raped whether or not she, like many other women and many men, patronizes bars, receives traffic tickets or lives in Palm Beach.
If you consider this type of personal information about the alleged victim necessary to serious reporting, then why didn't you give equal space to intimate details about the alleged rapist?
 
ANN K. HIRSCHMAN
Chevy Chase, Md., April 18, 1991

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The 168th Street IRT Station;
Vaulted Grandeur Deep Underground

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE IRT No. 1 line's elegant, barrel-vaulted 168th Street station received a $2.5 million rehabilitation last year that not only cleaned up some of the rougher spots, but also highlighted the clash of architectural esthetics and bureaucratic reality.
 New York's first subway opened in 1904 but reached only to 137th Street and Broadway. Two years later the vast stations at 168th and 181st and Broadway were opened. At these points the line is about 100 feet below surface, too deep for cut and cover construction. So the contractors blasted through rock for the tunnel and enlarged it to about 50 by 300 feet for the stations. 
Joseph Cunningham, a transportation writer, said the stations were designed, like the earlier stations, by Heins & Lafarge. They used the same elements as in earlier stations -- rich orange, iron-spot brick, soft mosaic patterns, deeply veined marble trim and Jacobean-style iron guard rails. But the long open station area is the astounding thing in a system usually marked by low ceilings and screens of columns.
 At the southern end of the vault the double portal over the tracks lends a railroad grandeur to what in other areas is just a utilitarian hole. Along the center line of the ceiling run a series of terra cotta medallions (for long-lost light fixtures), multicolored explosions of geometric meanders and lengthy floral work. Across the tracks runs the original elevated pedestrian crossing to the original elevator shaft on the east side.
 Although these spaces are among the most spectacular subterranean vistas in New York, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has designated only the earlier, 1904 stations of the IRT line. But the Transit Authority has made an attempt to recognize the 168th Street station's historic character. Strip fluorescent lighting has been replaced by reproduction torcheres on the side walls and fluted, park-type lamp standards on the overpasses.
 The lower walls have been given new tile and the careless runs of conduit, piping and other baggage have been removed or minimized. Some missing decorative tiles have been patched. The great tan brick vault has been swept of loose dirt, but not properly cleaned, and is still spotty and discolored. It is a small advance.
 TO analyze the methodology of station design and repair is to see how good intentions fight a host of obstacles. The lighting is one example.
 Robert Lombardi, the director of architecture, says the alternative to fluorescents, a mercury sodium mixture, produces the same number of foot candles. But the new mercury-sodium lights in old-style (but not original) fixtures have a smoky, orange glow. The station seems dark and riders complain, regardless of the meter reading.
 Mr. Lombardi also wanted to clean the vault, which would have helped brighten the station. But the Transit Authority requires chemicals much milder than those most building contractors use, and test patches gave spotty results. Also, the scaffolding for a full-scale cleaning would have been an enormous project with safety hazards for commuters.
 The new tile is the typical modern variety, with a deckled finish that does not remotely approach the deep, dreamy translucence of the original glass tile. But Mr. Lombardi says that only one company -- in Czechoslovakia -- stocks the old-style tile and that a trial order inexplicably cracked.
 Workmanship on tile and marblework, particularly the delicate border of a giant groin vault leading to the original elevator shaft, is wretched, with large smears of grout and poor installation and fitting.
 Some of the problems are in deciding what is original in the station. There is a collection of 50,000 historic subway photographs at the New-York Historical Society, but the society has no index to the material. The New York Transit Museum Archives has index books to the collection, but Richard Hellinger, the archivist, says they are too fragile even for use by authority employees. Some Transit Authority people have gone through most of the collections for specific projects, but no one has bothered to make even a rough list of the stations pictured in the collection for future reference.
 One problem is Transit Authority policy. It calls for three kinds of station improvements, none of which involves restoration. Such decisions are ad hoc, and economies of scale for a preservation-related approach -- from tile replacement to historic photographs -- do not exist. Station changes are considered individually even though the stations are a giant coherent act of architectural patronage.
 Such an environment makes the little advances at 168th Street seem like giant strides. And that, in itself, is the pity of it.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 12, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A Streetscapes column on April 21 about vaulted subway stations misidentified the location of the IRT station at 181st Street. It is at St. Nicholas Avenue, not Broadway.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
High-Seas Reprieve of Atlantic Salmon

 BODY:
Champions of the Atlantic salmon are delighted with the news that high-seas harvesting of the species by boats from the Faeroe Islands has been halted. The Faeroes are a group of Danish islands in the North Atlantic between Iceland and the Shetland Islands.
 The longline fishery, which began in the last decade, had been intercepting salmon bound for their home rivers in Norway, the United Kingdom, Ireland and Iceland. 
Wilfred Carter, president emeritus of the Canadian-American Atlantic Salmon Federation, said that the owners of the 26 Faeroese vessels authorized to fish for salmon had agreed to leave the fish alone for the rest of this season and during 1992 and 1993 as well.
 The fishermen will be compensated for this, says Carter: $582,000 in 1991 and 1992 and $688,000 in 1993. The first partial payment is scheduled for July.
 The unusual pact was agreed to April 15 by the fishermen. Orri Vigfusson, an Icelandic businessman, is the one most responsible for achieving the agreement, said David R. Clark, president of the federation, who added that it is a historic event in Atlantic salmon conservation.
 Vigfusson, whose company produces a vodka known by the brand name Icy, is a passionate Atlantic salmon angler. He said the settlement was reached after 18 months of negotiations and adds that Halldor Asgrimsson, Iceland's Minister of Fisheries, had given great assistance to the effort.
 Vigfusson also says that the Faeroese government has informed him that it supports the agreement. Looking ahead, Vigfusson sees a time when those in a Greenland high-seas salmon fishery may be similarly wooed.
 The Atlantic salmon's oceanic wanderings make proper management of the fish a matter of international concern. Spawned in clear, cold streams, young salmon descend to the sea to attain growth and maturity, then return in one, two or three years to repeat the cycle.
 Nearly all the salmon that survive their oceanic odyssey return unerringly to the streams in which their lives began. Unlike the various Pacific salmon, all of which die after the act of procreation, many Atlantic salmon are multiple spawners.
 When at sea, Atlantic salmon from many countries mingle together on their feeding grounds. Because of this, it is possible that salmon stocks from a single river could be devastated by a high-seas fishery.
 In the early 1960's, native Greenlanders launched a drift-net fishery for salmon in the Davis Strait. The salmon in that location were from rivers in Canada, the United States, Europe and the United Kingdom. That fishery now operates under a quota established by the North Atlantic Salmon Conservation Organization, whose members are salmon-producing nations.
 The North Atlantic organization's most recent quotas for the Greenland and Faeroese fisheries were 840 and 550 metric tons, respectively. In recent years, the fishermen in both endeavors were able to harvest only about half of their quotas. Salmon were in short supply.
 Ideally, salmon should not be harvested until they reach their home rivers. Were that the case, those responsible for each river's salmon production could make sure that enough fish got past the nets and past the anglers to achieve optimum production.
 Even when salmon do reach their home continent, they are sometimes intercepted by nets long before they reach their home streams. A fixed-net fishery off Newfoundland captures many salmon bound for other provinces in Canada and the United States, and an unlicensed drift-net fishery off Ireland is similarly indiscriminate.
 Although Atlantic salmon farming, which was pioneered by Norway, now accounts for most of the salmon that go to market (in 1990, 225,000 of the 235,000 metric tons harvested were from salmon farms) commercial pressure on wild salmon remains intense.
 Those who would greatly curtail or even ban commercial fishing for salmon point out that a salmon taken by a sport fisherman is worth many times more to the general economy than one caught by a commercial fisherman. In Canada, the average guided angler spends about $350 to catch a single salmon; that same fish, assuming an average weight of 10 pounds, is worth about $35 to the netter.
 Canada has banned commercial netting for salmon in New Brunswick. At the start of the ban, netters were compensated annually for not fishing. The Government then instituted a voluntary program in which the netters were paid a single lump sum to relinquish their licenses for all time.
 All save 100 or so netters took advantage of this. Carter believes that salmon netting will never resume in the province and that the government will soon make another license-buying offer.
 Canada has also purchased netting licenses in Newfoundland. A private organization, the Atlantic Salmon Conservation Trust of Scotland, has been buying up netting rights on some of that country's rivers.
 The Faeroese agreement differs from these arrangements in that compensation is continuing and the right to fish is not permanently relinquished. All the funds are not yet in hand.
 Under the pact's terms, Norway would pay 55 percent, Iceland 6 percent, the United Kingdom 22 percent and Ireland 17 per ent. This formula is based on the ratio of tagged fish from those countries captured in the Faeroese fishery.
 Salmon anglers and conservationists the world over, including the Canadian-American salmon federation's members, will also be asked to contribute to the Faeroese fund.
 Norway has already set aside $700,000 for the Faeroese, and, to help pay for this, will increase the license fees paid by its sport and commercial salmon anglers.
 Although the accord is a masterly achievement given the social and political complexities of the salmon conservation movement, some doubts about it exist. At a meeting of the North Atlantic organization this January, both Finland and Canada objected to the principle of paying compensation annually.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Building for the Performing Arts in Smaller Cities

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
For decades, the nation's larger cities have been building performing arts centers as focuses for their cultural activities.
Now this city of 60,000 in northwestern South Carolina has become the latest in a lengthening string of smaller cities across the country -- including Homer, Alaska (pop. 3,000) -- to discover the advantages of building a performing arts center, for the economic and social as well as the cultural benefits they bring. 
 The $42 million Peace Center opened here last November on a five-acre downtown tract whose redevelopment had long been a puzzle to community leaders. The center includes a 2,100-seat concert hall, a 400-seat theater, a cabaret theater and an amphitheater beside the Reedy River.
Community leaders say they are already seeing results: Downtown restaurants, hotels, florists and other businesses have experienced a marked increase in business.
"There is an excitement that I've never really seen before," said Betty Peace Stall, a Greenville native and chairwoman of the Peace Center Foundation, which runs the complex.
Greenville is part of a metropolitan area that includes three counties -- Greenville, Spartanburg and Pickens -- with a population of 640,000.
Architects say the trend has been developing for a decade. Among the cities that have built or renovated such centers, or are doing so, to meet cultural pursuits, revitalize downtowns, attract new business and stimulate the local economy are the following:
* Boise, Idaho (pop. 116,100), together with Boise State University, built a 2,000-seat theater, a small experimental theater and a school of music on the university campus for $16 million in 1982.
* Helena, Ark. (pop. 20,000), bordering Mississippi, built a 1,200-seat theater.
* San Luis Obispo, Calif. (pop. 40,900), needing a place for its Mozart festival, will begin construction within a year on a 1,500-seat, $15 million facility on the campus of California State Polytechnic University. The private, nonprofit Foundation for the Performing Arts Center has joined the city and school as a partner.
* Chattanooga, Tenn. (pop 165,200), spent $6.5 million to renovate the 70-year-old Tivoli Theater for a 1,800-seat concert hall two years ago.
* Memphis (pop. 666,900) renovated a similar 2,500-seat downtown theater in 1984 for $5 million.
"There is a significant trend for planning and building performing arts centers," said Ron Jerit, an architect with Jerit/Boys, theater consultants in Oak Park, Ill., which worked on the Greenville complex. "But everything about this tends to be low profile. The movement is masked because you have to look in unlikely places to find it."
No one agency has kept track of the number of performing arts centers built in the last decade, but architects who specialize in this type of work say there have been hundreds. About a dozen architectural firms specialize in theater design, including S. Leonard Auerbach & Associates in San Francisco, Artec in New York City, George Thomas Howard in Hollywood and Knudson/Benson in Seattle.
Performing arts centers range from a civic center built at the high school in Homer, Alaska (population 3,000) to the arts complex built here. Typically, a performing arts center will include a concert hall that can be adapted for a variety of performers, from touring companies to guest artists, and a smaller theater for local talent. Many have space for displaying artwork as well.
Mr. Auerbach said that many performing arts centers are "town and gown" projects, sponsored by a city and a local college or university. An example is the $22 million center recently opened at Johnson County Community College in Overland Park, Kan. (pop. 104,400). The continuing education complex features a 1,400-seat multi-use theater for touring productions and the local symphony, a 400-seat dramatic arts center, a 150-seat studio and a 100-seat recital hall.
"In the past, we've found that institutions were isolated, without much outreach to the community," Mr. Auerbach said. Joint ownership allows both the city and the schools to work together to their mutual benefit and meet the needs of the community.
Some state capitals, like Nashville, Tenn. (pop. 486,900), and Columbus, Ohio (pop. 581,500), have benefited from state-run complexes. In Columbus, a four-theater complex was built across the street from the capitol. It is included in a 38-story state government office building that was planned as part of a much-needed downtown revitalization project, Mr. Auerbach said.
Here in Greenville, the massive brick complex designed by Craig, Gaulden and Davis, a local architectural firm, came to be after nearly a decade of planning and fund-raising. Mrs. Stall's family, the Peaces, who owned two local newspapers, Greenville Piedmont andThe Greenville News, and still hold a minority interest in the Multimedia Corporation -- which now owns the newspapers -- gave an initial gift of $14 million.
The hope for spinoff benefits for downtown redevelopment and economic development were as much a factor for the project as improving the cultural scene. The property on which the center was built is across the street from the newspaper building and "was a slum," Mrs. Stall said. Several buildings on the site -- a textile mill, a mayonnaise factory and a coach factory -- had long been abandoned. For several years, community leaders had envisioned using them as a museum devoted to textiles, a primary industry here.
The Peace Center architects used several of the buildings in their design. Two serve as backstage space for the largest theaters. Another was gutted for an open-air pavilion for arts displays or picnics. Yet another will be renovated for 25,000 square feet of office space to be rented out.
This week, a reception hall, the cabaret theater and a cafe will open in the former coach factory. All, it is hoped, will make profits to help offset the losses the larger halls are expected to sustain.
All performing arts centers run deficits, Mrs. Stall said. While many receive financial assistance from their cities, she said, the Peace Center will operate on its own revenues and an $8 million endowment that has been pledged but not yet been collected.
The City of Greenville, Mrs. Stall said, assembled and improved the land for the center, at a cost of $4.75 million, with the expectation that the project would stimulate interest in redeveloping the southern end of Main Street.
A half-dozen or so multistory office buildings have been built in the last five years on the northern end of downtown, and many more buildings have been renovated.
Now though, a limited partnership has bought the property across the river from the Peace Center and may build housing, stores and office space, said Ron Geyer, a principal architect with Craig, Gaulden & Davis.
Mr. Geyer also said the center will help attract businesses -- a prime concern of local leaders since the decline of the textile industry. At the turn of the century, textile mills were by far the largest employers; as recently as 1974 they accounted for 52 percent of manufacturing jobs. But since then 8,000 mill jobs have been lost and as of 1989 -- the last year for which figures are available -- there were 18,700 textile workers out of a total of 52,300 manufacturing jobs.
"If you want to go out and get a more sophisticated investor, you have to get more sophisticated amenities," said Mr. Geyer. "Infrastructure used to be a big highway and lots of water and sewer. That's O.K. for smokestack recruitment, but what folks want now is headquarters."

HEADLINE: Focus: Performing-Arts Centers;
Energizing Downtowns in Smaller Cities

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
FOR decades, the nation's larger cities have been building performing arts centers as focuses for their cultural activities.
Now this city of 60,000 in northwestern South Carolina has become the latest in a lengthening string of smaller cities across the country -- including Homer, Alaska (pop. 3,000) -- to discover the advantages of building a performing arts center, for the economic and social as well as the cultural benefits they bring. 
 The $42 million Peace Center opened here last November on a five-acre downtown tract whose redevelopment had long been a puzzle to community leaders. The center includes a 2,100-seat concert hall, a 400-seat theater, a cabaret theater and an amphitheater beside the Reedy River.
Community leaders say they are already seeing results: Downtown restaurants, hotels, florists and other businesses have experienced a marked increase in business.
"There is an excitement that I've never really seen before," said Betty Peace Stall, a Greenville native and chairwoman of the Peace Center Foundation, which runs the complex.
Greenville is part of a metropolitan area that includes three counties -- Greenville, Spartanburg and Pickens -- with a population of 640,000.
Architects say the trend has been developing for a decade. Among the cities that have built or renovated such centers, or are doing so, to meet cultural pursuits, revitalize downtowns, attract new business and stimulate the local economy are the following:
* Boise, Idaho (pop. 116,100), together with Boise State University, built a 2,000-seat theater, a small experimental theater and a school of music on the university campus for $16 million in 1982.
* Helena, Ark. (pop. 20,000), bordering Mississippi, built a 1,200-seat theater.
* San Luis Obispo, Calif. (pop. 40,900), needing a place for its Mozart festival, will begin construction within a year on a 1,500-seat, $15 million facility on the campus of California State Polytechnic University. The private, nonprofit Foundation for the Performing Arts Center has joined the city and school as a partner.
* Chattanooga, Tenn. (pop 165,200), spent $6.5 million to renovate the 70-year-old Tivoli Theater for a 1,800-seat concert hall two years ago.
* Memphis (pop. 666,900) renovated a similar 2,500-seat downtown theater in 1984 for $5 million.
"There is a significant trend for planning and building performing arts centers," said Ron Jerit, an architect with Jerit/Boys, theater consultants in Oak Park, Ill., which worked on the Greenville complex. "But everything about this tends to be low profile. The movement is masked because you have to look in unlikely places to find it."
No one agency has kept track of the number of performing arts centers built in the last decade, but architects who specialize in this type of work say there have been hundreds. About a dozen architectural firms specialize in theater design, including S. Leonard Auerbach & Associates in San Francisco, Artec in New York City, George Thomas Howard in Hollywood and Knudson/Benson in Seattle.
Performing arts centers range from a civic center built at the high school in Homer, Alaska (population 3,000) to the arts complex built here. Typically, a performing arts center will include a concert hall that can be adapted for a variety of performers, from touring companies to guest artists, and a smaller theater for local talent. Many have space for displaying artwork as well.
Mr. Auerbach said that many performing arts centers are what he calls "town and gown" projects, sponsored by a city and a local college or university. An example is the $22 million center recently opened at Johnson County Community College in Overland Park, Kan. (pop. 104,400). The continuing education complex features a 1,400-seat multi-use theater for touring productions and the local symphony, a 400-seat dramatic arts center, a 150-seat studio and a 100-seat recital hall.
"IN the past, we've found that institutions were isolated, without much outreach to the community," Mr. Auerbach said. Joint ownership allows both the city and the schools to work together to their mutual benefit and meet the needs of the community.
Some state capitals, like Nashville, Tenn. (pop. 486,900), and Columbus, Ohio (pop. 581,500), have benefited from state-run complexes. In Columbus, a four-theater complex was built across the street from the capitol. It is included in a 38-story state government office building that was planned as part of a much-needed downtown revitalization project, Mr. Auerbach said.
Here in Greenville, the massive brick complex designed by Craig, Gaulden and Davis, a local architectural firm, came to be after nearly a decade of planning and fund-raising. Mrs. Stall's family, the Peaces, who owned two local newspapers, Greenville Piedmont andThe Greenville News, and still hold a minority interest in the Multimedia Corporation -- which now owns the newspapers -- gave an initial gift of $14 million.
"We were looking for something to do for Greenville," Mrs. Stall said.
The hope for spinoff benefits for downtown redevelopment and economic development were as much a factor for the project as improving the cultural scene. The property on which the center was built is across the street from the newspaper building and "was a slum," Mrs. Stall said. Several buildings on the site -- a textile mill, a mayonnaise factory and a coach factory -- had long been abandoned. For several years, community leaders had envisioned using them as a museum devoted to textiles, a primary industry here.
The Peace Center architects used several of the buildings in their design. Two serve as backstage space for the largest theaters. Another was gutted for an open-air pavilion for arts displays or picnics. Yet another will be renovated for 25,000 square feet of office space to be rented out.
This week, a reception hall, the cabaret theater and a cafe will open in the former coach factory. All, it is hoped, will make profits to help offset the losses the larger halls are expected to sustain.
All performing arts centers run deficits, Mrs. Stall said. While many receive financial assistance from their cities, she said, the Peace Center will operate on its own revenues and an $8 million endowment that has been pledged but not yet been collected.
The City of Greenville, Mrs. Stall said, assembled and improved the land for the center, at a cost of $4.75 million, with the expectation that the project would stimulate interest in redeveloping the southern end of Main Street.
A HALF-DOZEN or so multistory office buildings have been built in the last five years on the northern end of downtown, and many more buildings have been renovated.
Now though, a limited partnership has bought the property across the river from the Peace Center and may build housing, stores and office space, said Ron Geyer, a principal architect with Craig, Gaulden & Davis.
Mr. Geyer also said the center will help attract businesses -- a prime concern of local leaders since the decline of the textile industry. At the turn of the century, textile mills were by far the largest employers; as recently as 1974 they accounted for 52 percent of manufacturing jobs. But since then 8,000 mill jobs have been lost and as of 1989 -- the last year for which figures are available -- there were 18,700 textile workers out of a total of 52,300 manufacturing jobs.
"If you want to go out and get a more sophisticated investor, you have to get more sophisticated amenities," said Mr. Geyer. "Infrastructure used to be a big highway and lots of water and sewer. That's O.K. for smokestack recruitment, but what folks want now is headquarters."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The $42 million Peace Center, a performing arts complex, opened in November in Greenville, S.C. (Lynn Riddle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: SANDY BERGIN;
Housing Markets Evade Human Needs

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
THE housing market in Connecticut will be dominated by major shifts of population in the next 20 years that may reduce the number of first-time home buyers and make it difficult for those who now own homes to move up or out, says a new study by the State Housing Department.
By 2000, residents 25 to 34 years old, the traditional span for first-time home buyers, will decline by a quarter, the report said. During the same period, the number of people aged 35 to 44, those considered most likely to trade up to a more expensive home, is expected to grow by 22 percent. Consequently, the competition for available buyers will increase, which could cause the numbers of homes sold, along with home prices, to decline. 
 But one of the most disturbing aspects of the state's changing demographics is the growing population of residents in Connecticut's urban centers who are young, poor and struggling to find housing and jobs, said the department's director of research, Sandy Bergin, who edited the study. If this trend is ignored, she said, it could seriously alter the state's economic viability.
In an interview in her office in Hartford, Ms. Bergin discussed the details of the study and its impact on the housing market. Here are some excerpts from that conversation:
Q. How did demographics affect the 1980's housing boom?
A. During the 1980's, the housing demand was spurred by the generation of baby boomers aged 25 to 44 who were moving into the market all at the same time. Just as baby boomers displaced every other institution they came in contact with, from education to the labor force, so too did they have a tremendous impact on housing demands, especially the demand for new rental units and first-time entry-level housing. Subsequently, this caused supply to lag behind demand. As a result, housing prices escalated.
Q. How will this affect the trade-up market in the 1990's?
A. The boomers who got into the home purchase market in the late 1970's and early 80's are now considered to be in their peak earning years and ready to buy larger or more expensive homes. The problem is it's very difficult to sell the entry-level homes that they now live in. One reason for this is the fact that the number of 24- to 34-year-olds is expected to drop by 24 percent, and they are traditionally the first-home buying group. Because there are simply fewer of them, that may cause a decrease in demand for existing housing.
Q. Are there any factors that could change that?
A. It could be offset, because housing ownership rates in this age group have been lower during the 1980's, due to the very high prices of homes in Connecticut. If prices fall as a result of less demand, this will benefit younger boomers and other purchasers who have been shut out of the home purchase market.
Q. According to the study, the number of residents 85 and older will increase nearly 30 percent in the next 20 years. How will this impact housing trends?
A. This age group has a very high income ownership rate. Many of these people, though, need some assistance in daily living and may wish to move out of their homes into nursing homes or congregate facilities, which offer medical services on site. State and housing industries should certainly become concerned about building more housing for this age group, which will become larger and larger as time goes by.
Q. During the 1980's how did income levels shift?
A. Those in the lowest 20 percent of incomes got poorer, and those in the upper 20 percent very much got wealthier. The gap between the wealthy and poor in Connecticut is probably greater than it is in any other state. We have the highest per capita income in the nation, and our cities are among the most distressed in the nation. This disparity between these two Connecticuts is very disturbing.
Q. How has the demographic makeup of the state's cities and suburban areas changed?
A. We found that the suburban communities are growing much older than the urban centers, simply because the suburbs are made up of predominantly white non-Hispanic residents who are not having children at the same rate as Hispanic and black residents. In addition, the minority populations are growing younger and poorer and are remaining in the cities.
We try to make it clear that there is not an absolute identity between groups and poverty in racial and ethnic groups. But it's important to recognize that minorities in Connecticut are very much overrepresented among the very poor and among people who need assistance.
Q. Which households are most adversely affected by the changing demographics?
A. Because of the divorce rate and other factors, there has been a sharp rise in the number of single-parent female-headed families. They are disproportionately found among the groups in poverty in Connecticut. We found that 26 percent of all female-headed households headed by women aged 18 to 64 were living below the poverty line. And 40 percent of black and Hispanic female-headed households in this age group were living below the poverty line. As a consequence, there are a sizable number of families that cannot afford home ownership and probably won't be able to.
Because they are poor, they are renters of subsidized housing when they can find it. When they cannot, they pay an extraordinary amount of their income for shelter costs. Many of these families are on Aid to Families With Dependent Children and those payments may in no way keep up with the rise in rents.
For example, if families in poverty were renting a two-bedroom apartment at 30 percent of their grant, it would take a grant that was 205 percent higher in order to afford that rent.
Q. How big a role will the Federal Government play in the area of housing during the 1990's?
A. Certainly during the 1980's, when the Federal Government was almost totally removed from any activity in the housing field, states and localities had to pick up the tab, and there is no way they could completely do that.
The Feds are now getting back into the housing arena with the National Affordable Housing Act. And even though that won't provide a tremendous amount of additional dollars, it is certainly welcome by states with deficits like Connecticut.
Q. What's been the response from suburban communities toward affordable housing?
A. It varies from community to community. Some are open to affordable housing, not only as a way for their own children to stay in the area but also because they realize that to make a real community you need people of all income backgrounds and racial and ethnic backgrounds. That awareness, however, is not all-pervasive.
There is a degree of this "not in my backyard" attitude that we hope will begin to erode. One of the difficulties we face is the fear some folks have that affordable housing means high-rises or bleak public housing occupied by extremely poverty-stricken people who have all kinds of problems and are prey to criminals and drug-pushing. However, we don't build like that anymore. We understand that to crowd very poor people into one complex is a terrible thing.
Affordable housing in the 1990's will be for people with mixed incomes, middle class, poor, white and black people, families and nonfamilies. We're not talking about big projects. We're talking about a duplex here, a fourplex there, scattered sites that have attractive houses on them.
Q. How will a limited amount of affordable housing impact Connecticut residents?
A. If the patterns we have seen in Connecticut continue unabated, we will see even greater segregation by income and by race and by class. This will not be good for people who live in the central cities nor for people in the suburbs.
If the suburbs do not allow affordable housing to be built there, young people will leave, because they simply cannot afford to live there. Residents won't be able to maintain a labor force that will allow them the quality of life that they presumably are trying to protect by trying to keep certain kinds of people out.
Q. Though there are no statewide figures on the high school dropout rate, your study reported that the attrition rate among black students was 38 percent and among Hispanic students was 50 percent.
A. Yes, and that's a great concern to the business community. One of the reasons why the attrition rate is so high among Hispanics is probably because there is a lot of moving back and forth between the mainland and Puerto Rico. It could be that they finish high school there. However, these rates are still alarming, and the impact on Connecticut will be tremendous if large numbers of new workers that we need to sustain our industries do not have a high school education.
Q. The study was based primarily on the 1980 Census figures and available updated data. Why didn't you wait until the 1990 Census figures came in to do this report?
A. We decided that we couldn't wait until all the census information came out, which won't be until 1993. We needed to alert the housing industry to the political issues that we think are implicit in this report.
We wanted to alert people to the fact that these are the trends, and if they are left alone without being recognized, they could have a real negative impact on the quality of life in Connecticut. We're hoping that actions can be taken now to modify the negative trends and accentuate the positive.
Q. Now that some of the 1990 Census figures are beginning to trickle in, are they verifying projections made in the study?
A. One of the things we've seen from the 1990 figures is that Hartford is now the first city in Connecticut in which white non-Hispanic residents do not make up the majority population. So indeed, that coincides with the trend that we saw when we did the study that the cities are growing increasingly with residents from other racial and ethnic minority populations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sandy Bergin, director of research for the State Housing Department, was the editor of a study that found a growing proportion of Connecticut's urban residents were poor, young and struggling to find housing and jobs. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pattern of Change in Eastern Towns Shows How Highways Lead to Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
MAPPING eastern Connecticut by population shows three clear clusters of major growth during the 1980's, all suburban or rural towns along major highways, according to data from the 1990 Census.
"That's almost the classic example of how population trends are linked to the existence or improvement of transportation networks," said James G. Palma Jr., a planning supervisor with the Connecticut Census Data Center. 
 "Traffic planners always debate which came first, the highway or the need for the highway?" Mr. Palma said. "And the answer is, it's cyclical. Population movements tend to create demand for the highway. Then when the highway is built, it creates an even greater population movement."
One of the clusters of growth -- including Salem and Colchester, the towns that grew fastest in the state -- was along the corrdidor of Routes 2 and 11, extending southeast from Hartford and taking in East Haddam, Hebron, Columbia, Marlborough and Lebanon.
 
Towns Remain Rural
 Another growth cluster was along Interstate 84, extending northeast from Hartford through Bolton, Andover, Manchester, Vernon, South Windsor, Stafford, Willington, Woodstock and Eastford.
A third, smaller cluster -- Plainfield, Sterling, Canterbury, Brooklyn and Voluntown -- is along Interstate 395, a north-south route from the coast to the Massachusetts border.
Despite the growth, most of the towns remain rural, like Sterling, where town officials note that there are still no traffic lights or McDonald's restaurants.
In Sterling, which ended the decade with a population of 2,357, up 32 percent, the economic development coordinator, Trenton E. Wright, said a lot of people who work at Electric Boat in Groton or in towns over the Massachusetts border find the area near Interstate 395 attractive.
"You can come out here and get four acres and a three-bedroom house for $125,000," Mr. Wright said. "There's not a lot of places left in Connecticut where you can say that."
 
Decline in Cities
 But the explosive growth has meant some problems, including crowded schools and roads.
"You never recover enough taxes on a home to pay for the cost of education," Mr. Wright said. "If it continues like this, it's going to be a tremendous burden on the town, providing services."
Of 58 towns in the state east of the Connecticut River, 35 grew at a pace more than double the state's 5.8 percent population growth in the 1980's, and 11 grew at more than five times the average, the Census found.
But all the growth was in rural and suburban towns. The area's cities, New London and Norwich, continued a 30-year decline in population and now rank behind well-developed suburbs like Groton and Enfield. Elsewhere in the state, four of the five major cities showed population increases during the decade.
Salem and Colchester, two towns in the Routes 2 and 11 corridor that were largely farming communities even 10 years ago, saw the state's most explosive growth in the 1980's, 41.8 and 41.5 percent, respectively.
Debbie Delaney, owner of Mind Your Business, a bookkeeping company in Salem, moved to the town six years ago from Trumbull. The price and availability of land has made the town so attractive, she said.
"You can get a house with five acres of land here, or a 50-by 100-foot lot in Trumbull," Ms. Delaney said. "Then, when you start with a population of only 2,100, there's no place but up. The growth is inevitable."
Despite the growth, Salem, which still had only 3,310 people at the time of the Census last year, has retained its small-town charm, she said.
"Quaint doesn't really describe this town," Ms. Delaney said. "Unknown is probably a better term. People ask, 'Salem, Conn.?' A lot of our mail ends up in Massachusetts."
Salem's First Selectman, Hugh C. Teel, said, "We've become a community of dual-professional families, where one works in Hartford and the other works in New London, and it's an easy commute for both of them from here."
But the growth has caused some problems, Mr. Teel said. The town is engaged in a battle over whether to spend $5.25 million to expand its school, something that will add about $50 to the average homeowner's tax bill. The town landfill, which officials had expected to last for many years, will now hold out perhaps six or eight years, with proper management.
Mr. Teel predicted even greater growth for the town when Route 11 is completed. The limited-access highway now connects Route 2 to two local highways, Routes 82 and 85, in Salem, creating a bottleneck. Eventually Route 11 will be built south to Interstate 95, with exits in Salem.
"The traffic going southbound, particularly in the summer, is just phenomenal," Mr. Teel said. "There are a lot of businesses that would like to be on Route 85 but won't locate there right now, because the road is so congested."
 
600 New Condominium Units
 Colchester, which ended the decade with a population of 10,980, probably would have grown even faster than its increase of nearly 42 percent except for a moratorium on water hookups in its two-square-mile town center, said N. Reed Gustafson, the town's zoning agent, sanitarian, fire marshal and civil preparedness director.
The moratorium was put in place because of contamination in one of the town wells, he said, but equipment to clean up the water is expected to be in place by this summer.
"As soon as that moratorium is lifted, there's about 600 condominium units that are going to be built, or so I am told," Mr. Gustafson said. "I think you'd have to be crazy to build a condominium in this market. But we're still getting three or four applications a week for new construction, which makes us the busiest town in New London County."
Nine of the 11 towns covered by the Windham Regional Planning Agency saw above-average growth in the 1980's, said the agency's executive director, Margaret P. Reich. The trend toward the suburbs was not surprising, she said, because dozens of large farms went out of business and were subdivided for housing during the 1980's.
But the numbers have to be considered carefully, Ms. Reich said. "When you're only starting with a population of 1,700 people or so, if you add only 20 people that's more than a 1 percent growth," she said.
Mansfield seemed to grow only 2.3 percent during the 1980's, to 21,103 people, but that included the loss of almost 700 retarded people who had been residents of the Mansfield Training School until the state embarked on a program of moving people out of institutions, Ms. Reich said.
 
Transitional Places to Live
 The Census found that New London's population dropped 1 percent in the 1980's, to 28,540, and Norwich's dropped 1.8 percent, to 37,391. East Hartford, which is east of the river but usually considered part of central Connecticut, also showed a drop, of 4 percent, to 50,542.
Mr. Palma noted that the cities would have had to spend huge amounts of money on sewers, roads and other infrastructure to accommodate even a small percentage of growth.
In addition, he said, cities tend to be transitional places to live. East Hartford, Norwich, New London and other cities, have large amounts of rental housing, and until 1980, a lot of their units were occupied by baby boomers who were starting families.
"During the decade, the wage earners in a lot of those families got promotions," Mr. Palma said, "and they wanted to buy their own house. Some of them might have moved to their own house in East Hartford, but more of them probably looked down Route 2 to Hebron and Colchester, where the land is more available and affordable."
As the families moved out of the rental units, Mr. Palma said, many were occupied by single people, or one-parent families, so the population decreased even as the number of housing units increased.
"Why any town grows, or doesn't grow, is usually due to about 10 different reasons," Mr. Palma said. "But most frequently, it's a matter of where people want to live. And what these numbers say is people in eastern Connecticut in the 1980's wanted to live in the suburbs."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 23; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 608 words

HEADLINE: Life in the 20's

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Gleick; Elizabeth Gleick is a senior editor of the magazine New York Woman.

 BODY:

THE ART OF CARTOGRAPHY
By J. S. Marcus.
129 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $18. 
 Imagine a fortune-cookie writer with a highly developed sense of irony, a need to get some ideas across and a modicum of experience in the worlds of film, fashion and graduate school. You'd get someone a lot like J. S. Marcus, at least what you can see of him in "The Art of Cartography," his first collection of short stories. Like cookie fortunes, Mr. Marcus's stories are not necessarily untrue. Sometimes they're even apt. They're just not as deep as this clearly talented writer could make them.
Here are some of the fortunes in his cookies: "There is a difference between the presence of pleasure and the absence of pain; between flourishing and surviving; between there and then, and here and now." Or: "Physically, economically, politically, nobody wants to be in the middle, and everybody wants to be on the edge." Or: "In a way, nothing turns out to be what you think it is."
Aphorisms like these, and the tendency to substitute clever observation for thoughtful writing, make "The Art of Cartography" seem insufficient. ("Francine lives in a house across the street from Kew Gardens, and the man living above her breeds guinea pigs. She is working on a screenplay about a writer from Pennsylvania who comes to London and lives on top of a couple who breed guinea pigs.") This is not to say that there isn't some good writing here, because there is, along with some real intelligence. Just not enough.
Mr. Marcus holds up the life of people in their 20's (a startlingly unsettling time for many, as it happens) and examines it from several angles; he finds struggle, aimlessness, detachment, loneliness. But no single character stands out: whether it's a young woman who drops out of law school and follows an ex-boyfriend to Los Angeles, a young man who travels around the world as a film production assistant or a young American in a bank-training program in London, there's a sameness to these people. They could all be friends, certainly, or at least all have friends in common. Better yet, they could all be characters in a novel together.
And I'd look forward to a novel by Mr. Marcus; for one thing, there'd be a chance for his work to show some real development and continuity. For another, maybe he'd come closer to answering some of the important questions -- about place and belonging and movement -- that echo throughout this book of stories with names like "Home," "Leaving," "Everywhere," "Apart." After all, as he himself writes in the title story, "The old answers and the old questions are best, but people still want the most for their money."
Even broaching the questions is a good thing, though. For Mr. Marcus does know something about the life of a certain kind of person in his or her 20's, about how that period shifts from being a time of alienation to a time of freedom and back in just moments: "In the lives of those people," thinks one character of herself and her friends, "there are sudden and overwhelming desires to slow down -- to stop, if necessary -- before everything changes into something else, something different, unrecognizable, and lost."
But this same woman acknowledges in a later story, after she's left law school and returned to her old boyfriend, "How heavy we seemed, Everett and I, back where we began, but not exactly, as if all we could do in our lives was shift weight. We began to talk about Los Angeles and laugh. . . . There was a sudden lightness, a grace, in our joking, in our rhetoric."
J. S. Marcus gets all sorts of things right. If only he weren't quite so glib.
