HEADLINE: A Man of Unspeakable Thoughts

BYLINE: By Jonathan D. Spence; Jonathan D. Spence teaches modern Chinese history at Yale University. His most recent books are "The Question of Hu" and "The Search for Modern China."

 BODY:

BRINGING DOWN THE GREAT WALL
Writings on Science, Culture, and Democracy in China.
By Fang Lizhi.
Edited by James H. Williams.
Translated by James H. Williams and others.
Introduction by Orville Schell.
336 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.  
 Fang Lizhi, the Chinese dissident, likes sometimes to present himself as the very model of the absent-minded intellectual, a man so wrapped up in his own thoughts that he has little consciousness of the world around him. In middle school, he tells us in "Bringing Down the Great Wall," a moving collection of his essays, interviews and speeches, "I was so absorbed with the daydreams that my teachers aroused in me there that at times I would walk right into utility poles on the side of the road." But he at once adds a gloss to this fairly conventional metaphor, one that shows the mischievous and pragmatic side of his character: "So hard did I bump into them, in fact, that I can still remember the numbers that were written on those poles." It is not the pain he wants us to know he remembers, but the numbers.
As one of China's leading scientists, first in astrophysics and later in cosmology, Mr. Fang is very good indeed both at dreaming and at remembering the numbers. But as an incorrigible freethinker, who has seen with mounting anguish the hopeless state into which Chinese society is drifting, Mr. Fang also has become an accomplished expert at deliberately walking into immovable objects -- in this case, the hard-liners in the upper echelons of the Communist Party's political and educational bureaucracies.
Fang Lizhi is now one of China's best-known dissidents. He was accused by the Chinese Government of being one of the ringleaders of the huge spring 1989 demonstrations in Tiananmen Square; and, after the mass slaughter of civilians in Beijing on June 4 by the People's Liberation Army, he and his wife sought shelter in the United States Embassy. Allowed to leave the country in the summer of 1990, he has since received academic sanctuary in Cambridge University and in Princeton.
Mr. Fang's popularity and notoriety have been due in part to his visibility: as an internationally prominent scientist and the vice president of the important University of Science and Technology at Hefei in Anhui Province, he was at the forefront of those trying to train China's youth to participate successfully in the front ranks of the international scientific community. Mr. Fang has also got attention because he has been through a lot: he was purged and deprived of his Communist Party membership in the antirightist campaign of 1957 for his outspoken critique of the sterility of Communist party discussions; he was rehabilitated in 1978, after the Cultural Revolution; he was deprived once more of his party membership in early 1987, as the hard-liners struck back against the late 1986 student demonstrations; and he brought the Government's anger down on himself again in January 1989 when he appealed to the Party to release Wei Jingsheng, the foremost protester of China's long-crushed democracy movement of 1978, who had by then spent 10 years in jail. But, above all, Fang Lizhi has been listened to because he is witty, passionate, tenacious and articulate. Students have loved his speeches; whether he had prepared carefully or spoke off the cuff, he could hold an audience in the palm of his hand.
The rhythms of Mr. Fang's life as a highly visible protester against his Government's stupidity, greed and cruelty have inevitably led to his being compared to Andrei Sakharov in the Soviet Union and to Vaclav Havel in Czechoslovakia. But in various interviews Mr. Fang has always dodged all parallels with Sakharov, and has explicitly rejected those to Mr. Havel. He emphatically denies that he is a political leader and insists that he does not want to be one. It is one of the weaknesses of China, he explains, that the Chinese reject one leader only to submit themselves to another. It would be far better, he says, for the Chinese "to learn that democracy requires a confrontation of ideas and not a leader who says one thing and everybody follows. . . . If the Chinese people are expecting the appearance of a hero, it had better not be me. This expectation in itself is very unhealthy."
In "Bringing Down the Great Wall," James H. Williams, a scholar on science and technology in China, and a few of his colleagues have translated and compiled an admirably comprehensive selection of Fang Lizhi's written and spoken words,focusing on his works since 1979 and ending with some of the pieces he wrote after being allowed to leave China in 1990. Mr. Fang's writings are divided into sections corresponding to what they see as four sides of his nature: the cosmologist, the cosmopolitan, the democrat and the dissident. The translations are fluent, and the introductions to each section, along with Orville Schell's long introduction to the book as a whole, are intelligent and pertinent. The Fang Lizhi who is thus introduced to us is humane in an immediately accessible way: decent, courageous, sometimes evasive, sometimes sarcastic, urbane yet emotional, a socialist and an elitist, opinionated and impatient of official cant.
Readers today are likely to have trouble remembering just how "unsayable" so many of Fang Lizhi's thoughts were in the contexts in which he uttered them. His courage is thus not obvious to an outsider. The fervor of the students' responses came from the fact that they had never heard such words before, certainly not from a senior figure in the establishment. As Mr. Fang says in a beautiful essay, "The End of Forgetting History," this does not mean such things had not ever been said in China -- they had been said spiritedly in 1957 and in 1978 -- but the Chinese state had erased them from the record, replacing the vanished voices with a void that could be filled only with whispers.
In the mid-1980's, as Mr. Fang hit his stride as a social critic, a host of other Chinese were also trying to give their own versions of truth, not just in essays and speeches but also in films and paintings, novels and poems. But whereas most of them chose to be indirect to some extent, there was little that was indirect about Mr. Fang. He suggested to his audiences that the best global parallels for China were to be found in the zealotry of Iran, the economic stagnation of Poland and the terrible poverty of Chad; he told them "Marxism has become ossified," that the Government's habit of continually shifting its policies was "an infantile way of running an economy," and that the philosophical pronouncements from the Office of National Dialectics in the Chinese Academy of Social Science merely perpetuated "the image of a Chinaman with a long pigtail, clad in a Western suit."
During the 1980's, Deng Xiaoping and the Chinese Communist Party were trying to make people subscribe to the "Four Upholds," : the Socialist road, the dictatorship of the proletariat, Communist Party leadership and the leading role of "Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought." Mr. Fang countered these by saying that he believed a university should have its own four upholds: "a spirit of science, democracy, creativity, and independence." Told by a reporter that his four upholds" might be seen as "a little dangerous," Mr. Fang replied that perhaps he could clarify things by relating his four upholds to what the Government's four really referred to -- namely, superstition, dictatorship, conservatism and dependency. To give some idea of Mr. Fang's bravado, this particular speech was delivered to about 3,000 students and faculty at Tongzhi University in Shanghai in November 1986.
Commentators on China's various democracy movements, those of 1978, 1986 or 1989, have stated that there never seems to be any content to Chinese discussions of democracy, and that this makes the whole movement seem elusive. Mr. Fang, however, has offered frequent, crisp and intelligent analyses of what he means by democracy -- definitions that even those comfortably raised within such democracies might find hard to improve upon. Democracy, Mr. Fang told his Chinese audiences, means genuine pluralism rather than personalized attacks on the opposition; it means controlling corruption through public scrutiny and accountability; it means upholding the right to complain about injustice of all kinds; it means supporting the fundamental idea of shared human rights; it means governmental responsibility to its citizens; it means not relying on informers and not taking punitive action on the basis of casual suspicions; and it means refusing to quote as wisdom the observations of political leaders who know nothing.
Chinese and foreign journalists and Mr. Fang's student audiences have often asked how such values might be introduced into China. Mr. Fang has no easy answers. Perhaps change could come from within even if the external structures of government remain the same, he suggests, illustrating his point by using the words of a homely traditional Chinese metaphor: "In front of the shop the sheep's head keeps dangling, but inside the shop one sells dog meat." But, he says, before that happens the people must make it clear to the party that they want change. And that will not be easy, since the Chinese, unsure about what to do, are "like a swarm of headless flies, buzzing around in every direction."
But Mr. Fang suggests two ways out of this box. First, it is possible that the Government, faced with the strength and determination of the democracy movement in China and abroad, might be forced to change constructively, "just as a bandit gives in when he meets a stronger force." Secondly, it is possible that current global changes themselves might force the issue: "The greenhouse effect, the population explosion, are issues that cannot be solved without a global solution. If China cannot catch up with the rest of the world, the world will make China catch up with it."
Fang Lizhi may reject comparisons between himself and Andrei Sakharov or Vaclav Havel, but others will continue to make those comparisons for him. As Mr. Williams succinctly puts it in his introduction to one of the sections of this moving and intelligently orchestrated collection, Mr. Fang's great skill is that, "like Sakharov in the Soviet Union, he used the prestige of science to ferry ideas from beyond the margins of political permissibility into the general discourse on reform." We might supplement that comment with an idea that Mr. Havel expressed in his books "Disturbing the Peace" and "Letters to Olga": in the grim world of Communist dictatorship, where optimism seems too facile an idea, there is always a deeper force, something we can term "hope." Hope to Mr. Havel is the power that enables us to keep alive the belief that one day things will again make sense. This making sense of experience is one of the things that gives us courage as we pursue what Mr. Havel calls our "entirely obscure task" on this planet. Mr. Fang, this book shows, has the mental strength to keep that hope alive and to maintain the faith that one day all that he, his contemporaries and his country have gone through during the last half-century will somehow make sense. On the day that happens, the Great Wall will truly come down.
 
 
 
INTELLECTUALS UP FRONT

"For the democracy movement, of course, China needs leaders," said Fang Lizhi, the Chinese astrophysicist and dissident, during a telephone interview from the University of Louisville, in Kentucky, where he was visiting. Yet Mr. Fang refuses to be considered one of those leaders. "I do not like that job," he replied rather wearily. "I like teaching and telling people things. I'm a sparrow leader."
What Mr. Fang calls a sparrow, Americans call a gadfly. Indeed, it was Mr. Fang's outspokenness that forced him to seek refuge in the United States Embassy in Beijing before going into exile. He is now working on the topology of the universe at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.
Mr. Fang may not hope to govern, but he does believe intellectuals belong at the forefront of any functioning democracy -- quite the opposite of the situation in China. There, he said, "the party's first, the intellectuals last."
Mr. Fang assembled his speeches, letters and essays in "Bringing Down the Great Wall" so they would be on hand for debate. The first step toward reform, he said, is freedom of speech and freedom of the press. But how, aside from the book, does he hope to contribute to the conversation about China while living in New Jersey? "It's difficult," he said. "I am quite far from China. I have joined the Chinese students, I have joined some international organizations for human rights. I can still do something, but it is limited, obviously, to the issue of human rights." -- JUDITH SHULEVITZ

HEADLINE: Treasury Plan Takes Chains Off Banks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leonard Silk's April 5 Economic Scene column, "Giving the Banks Greater Powers," addresses critical reforms to the nation's financial services industry, but is misleading on the adequacy of the Administration's proposals.
Restoring safety to our banking system requires tough new rules governing capital adequacy and deposit insurance premiums, as well as improved accounting rules, earlier problem resolution and more frequent inspections by regulators. The column implies these are not covered by the Administration's bill. On the contrary, the Treasury plan includes strong provisions closely mirroring each of the General Accounting Office recommendations mentioned in the column. 
 A stronger banking system also requires capital from new sources. One aim of Treasury's proposal is to attract well-capitalized competitors, who have been prevented from competing with banks.
For decades, well-capitalized companies have been barred from affiliating with banks. This hurts consumers, taxpayers and the banking system itself. The Treasury proposal is designed to eliminate these outdated and costly restrictions on affiliations -- not to expand bank powers.
The column implies that the plan might permit banks with weak capital positions to enter new businesses and -- worse still -- that there would be no firewalls to insulate insured deposits (that is, taxpayers) from risky activities. The Treasury plan explicitly excludes all but the best-capitalized banks from new financial activities.
For too long Congress has debated limited reforms aimed at symptoms, instead of in-depth solutions to the underlying problems in our banking system. The erosion of efficiency, customer service and profitability are the result. This is a disservice to households and businesses, exposes taxpayers to needless risk and yields glaring competitive inequities.
Congress needs to act now to modernize laws governing our financial services industry both to reflect market changes and to restore safety and soundness to America's banking system.
 
SAM BAPTISTA
President, Financial Services Council
Washington, April 11, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;
For Some, Best Prose Is in Blurbs

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
SIMON & SCHUSTER is apparently still deciding whether to publish "Just Killing Time," a novel by Derek V. Goodwin that was submitted with phony endorsements, or blurbs, from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh. Whatever is decided, one thing is sure: The "blurb industry," as some publishing executives call it, is recession-proof and is here to stay.
Few books appear without at least one testimonial to their value or to the skill of their authors. No matter that many blurbs on book jackets and in advertisements amount to literary backscratching, in that they are written by friends of the author, the agent or the editor. They serve their purpose if they call attention to a particular book in a very crowded field. 
 "When 55,000 books are published each year, you are desperate for ways to distinguish your books from everybody else's," said Paul Gottlieb, president of Harry N. Abrams Inc. "The right person writing a blurb for the right audience can sometimes make a tremendous difference in sales."
The conventional, though unproved, wisdom is that blurbs can turn undecided readers into buyers. "But there's a presumption among the marketing people that they're especially important for the sales reps and booksellers," said Donald I. Fine, the president of Donald I. Fine Inc.
When he was head of Arbor House a few years ago, Mr. Fine published in hardcover "The City Primeval" by Elmore Leonard, then a relatively unknown author of paperbacks. He sent galleys to John D. MacDonald, soliciting a blurb. Mr. Fine recalled, "MacDonald called me and asked, 'Who is that guy? He's teriffic,' and we used that line in our advertising."
Novelists are said to be more generous about giving blurbs than are writers of nonfiction, many of whom are specialists and some of whom are careful not to bolster the reputation of real or imagined rivals. "Fiction writers who have struggled, and writers of such genres as mysteries and science fiction, tend to enjoy helping other writers," said Kent Carroll, publisher of Carroll & Graf Publishers Inc.
Even well-established literary writers are often willing to provide a helping hand. William Least Heat-Moon attributes much of the success of his 1983 best seller, "Blue Highways," to Robert Penn Warren, who called it "a masterpiece." That blurb, by the winner of Pulitzer Prizes for both fiction and poetry, adorned the book's jacket.
And the reputation in the United States of the Italian writer and chemist Primo Levi owes much to Saul Bellow, whose memorable blurb -- "This is the book it is necessary to read next" -- adorned the jacket of "The Periodic Table" by Mr. Levi, published by Schocken Books in 1984.
But blurbs can backfire. "Hyperbolic blurbs on a book that doesn't measure up create as much skepticism as giving four stars to a mediocre restaurant," said Fred W. Hills, a senior editor of Simon & Schuster.
One book reviewer, who insisted that he not be identified, said he saw blurbs in a negative light. "The enthusiasm in most blurbs," he said, "is probably a gauge of the blurb writer's relief that the book he's endorsing is inferior to anything he can write."
Still, certain blurbs are likely to make even reviewers take notice. "I try to get blurbs from people who don't usually blurb," said Ann Godoff, the editor in chief of the Atlantic Monthly Press. She did just that when she elicited a blurb from Graham Greene for "The Hidden War" by Artyom Borovik, a Russian journalist. Printed on the jacket, the quote declares: "I've read no other account of the war in Afghanistan equal to this . . . This is literature, not journalism."
Publishers usually cast as wide a net as possible for blurbs. Thus, the back jacket of "The Prize" by Daniel Yergen consists entirely of blurbs from such authors, scholars and media personalities as John Chancellor, Simon Schama, James Schlesinger, Doris Kearns Goodwin, Theodore Levitt and Paul A. Samuelson.
Even blurbs by relative unknowns can help in certain situations. "If it's the right quote," said Alan D. Williams, the publisher of Grove Weidenfeld, "it can make you feel guilty for not knowing who it is."
Blurbs by literary writers are likely to be of little help in promoting romance novels or self-help and diet books. When William Morrow & Company published "Swim With the Sharks" by Harvey Mackay a few years ago, a book about motivation and negotiating, it ran an ad with blurbs from Ted Koppel, Walter F. Mondale, Gloria Steinem, Fran Tarkington, Gerald R. Ford, Robert Redford, Billy Graham, Gov. Mario Cuomo, Norman Vincent Peale and 18 others.
Of course, whoever chose the spurious blurbs by Mr. le Carre and Mr. Wambaugh for "Just Killing Time" knew enough about publishing and book buying to know that the imprimatur of both men, who give blurbs infrequently, would greatly enhance the book's value by appealing to the audiences of both authors.
Some publishers have even demanded that authors deliver blurbs from established writers, in return for advertising the book. But almost no one is more cynical about blurbs than publishing people themselves.
"If you're trying to sell paperback reprint rights to one of your books," Mr. Carroll said, "and you have teriffic reviews from The New York Times, The New Yorker or The New York Review of Books, reprinters are interested. But if I sent a sheet of blurbs from six important writers, they'd come back and say why did you send me this?"

HEADLINE: First Fall in Net At 3M Since '85

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 21

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the Scotch tape and abrasives maker known as 3M, has reported its first drop in quarterly profits since 1985. It attributed the decline to the sluggish world economy.
The company said its first- quarter net income fell 11 percent, to $300 million, compared with $335 million in last year's first quarter. The earnings were equal to $1.37 a share, down from $1.51 a year earlier. Sales rose to $3.39 billion from $3.16 billion. 
 "A decline in U.S. economic activity and slower growth abroad held back demand in many 3M product lines," Allen Jacobson, the company's chairman, said on Friday. The company added that its earnings outlook for the rest of the year was uncertain.
The company said a sharp downturn in its Brazilian business hurt earnings in the quarter, while United States sales rose about 2 percent from the 1990 period. Overseas, sales rose a modest 5 percent, ending a string of 12 consecutive quarters of double-digit gains.

HEADLINE: Gloomy Season on Farms as Dip in Profits Is Seen

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 21

 BODY:
A new mood has settled over the nation's farming regions: a sense of concern at predictions by agricultural economists of a drop in farm profits.
It is a sharp contrast to the outlook of just a year ago. Then, farmers were preparing to plant their first crops of the 1990's with an exuberance born of three years of recovery, and last season did not disappoint them. Harvests were good, livestock profits thrived and the farmers enjoyed yet another year of record income, the third in the last four. 
 But as 1990 ended, a cloud was already looming on the horizon. Grain prices were falling and Congress was preparing to cut farm subsidies.
Now it is planting time again, and while no one is expecting a replay of the farm crisis of the mid-1980's, most experts are predicting a drop of 5 to 10 percent in agricultural profits. That would mean the difference between money taken in by farmers and the expenses they paid out, their net cash income, was about $55 billion. Such a performance would still be substantially above the $36.6 billion farmers made in 1984 in the depth of the farm recession, but a noticeable drop from last year's $58 billion.
 
Split Farm Personality
 This year, as often happens, American agriculture is showing a split personality. Bearing the brunt of the downturn are grain farmers like Darwin McCall, who grows wheat near Salina, Kan. More fortunate are diversified producers like E. W. Dixon, who raises hogs anf grows the corn to feed them on his farm near Turney, Mo., about 40 miles north of Kansas City, and Lawrence Gladbach of Mendon, Mo., who raises cattle and hogs and grows grain.
Grain prices are down, with wheat expected to average about $1 a bushel less than last year's prices, which averaged $3.72 a bushel. Government subsidies will make up part of that loss, but those have now been cut. The prices that producers receive for livestock have been good for several years, and any decline is considered likely to be small.
"It looks like we'll get a decent crop," Mr. McCall said. "That's the good part. But prices, that's the bad part. It doesn't look like we'll get much for it."
Mr. Gladbach said: "Thank God for the cattle and hogs. If we had to depend on wheat and corn this year we'd be out of luck."
Unlike the recession of the mid-1980's, there is little about this year's downward drift in their fortune's that is of the farmers' own making. The farm recession was largely the aftermath of excesses in farmers' borrowing and spending, often to buy more land and equipment, stimulated by a decade of expanding exports and growing income. When foreign demand slipped and a downturn came, many of those farmers found themselves loaded with debts and trying to make a living on land bought at impractically high prices.
Since then, farmers who survived have pursued austere borrowing and spending practices. They have steadily reduced their debts so that, as Mark Drabenstott, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, noted the other day, they are now better able to weather a setback than they have been in many years.
"With a conservatism born of the farm crisis, farmers have kept their debts well in hand," Mr. Drabenstott said. "Agriculture has put its financial house in order. Now if the farm bankers have a problem it is finding more borrowers, not in collecting on their loans."
The expected downturn, Mr. Drabenstott and others said, is most likely to be largely a result of world developments and Government actions. With 1985 legislation, the Government spent its way out of the farm recession, raising farm income with big Federal payments and promoting exports with subsidies.
 
8% Cut Seen in U.S. Payments
 But wheat crops elsewhere in the world were so good last year that they have dashed prospects for exports. Many farmers are now using surplus wheat, normally a food for people, to feed their livestock. This practice has dampened demand and prices for corn and other feed grains for livestock.
Another big blow to many farmers is a result of the Federal budget deficit. Their Federal subsidies have been cut by 1990 farm legislation and by the deficit-cutting budget measure.
Direct Government payments to producers of major crops like grains and cotton, which often account for most of a farm's profits, are expected to drop about 8 percent, says Gregory Gajewski, economics editor of the Agriculture Department's magazine, Agricultural Outlook.
The livestock side of the farm economy, on the other hand, is healthier. Mr. Gladbach, for instance, sold cattle the other day for more than $80 per hundred pounds, a level he could only dream about a few years ago when the same animals would have brought a little more than $50 a hundredweight.
Those prices, as well as the record prices consumers have been paying for beef, have largely been a result of restraint by farmers, who cut the size of the national herd for years and now have only gradually begun to expand.
Hog growers have also kept their production in check and their prices higher. The increases in red-meat prices have, in turn, stimulated demand for broiler chickens, so that increased consumption has helped offset the price-dampening effects of expanded poultry production.
The livestock picture is further enhanced by the reduced cost of the grains needed to feed the animals.
Such contrasts extend beyond the Middle West and the grains and animals its farmers produce. While West Coast farmers, despite recent rains, are still feeling the effects of a long drought, many farmers in the Southeast have been hard hit by flooding.
And while dry weather has blighted fields of winter wheat in northern Texas, northwest Oklahoma, western Kansas and parts of Nebraska, there are farmers like Mr. Dixon and Mr. Gladbach in the Corn Belt who are waiting for waterlogged fields to dry before they can plant.
While grain producers complain about sinking prices, cotton growers in the South are planting with renewed hope, expecting higher prices as a result of strong demand overseas and tight foreign supplies. And as producers of meat animals enjoy high prices, dairy farmers are complaining. After the price of milk they sold to processors climbed 12 percent last year amid fears of scarcity, they have now seen the price plummet 24 percent. Retail prices have slowly followed.
The sum of all these differences, said Mr. Drabenstott of the Federal Reserve Bank, is this: "We're going to see a slowdown in the farm recovery. And though livestock will help bolster many farmers' income, you can expect a 5 to 10 percent drop over all in farm profits."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Optimistic Analysts See Further Drops in Rates

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Although the recent decline in long-term interest rates came to a sudden halt on Friday, optimistic money-market analysts insist that the pause is only temporary, resulting mostly from technical factors. High among the factors they cite is the large volume of Treasury borrowings scheduled for the next three weeks.
Moreover, the optimists say rates could resume their decline after the Federal Reserve's policy makers meet on May 14. 
 But those who hold that the decline has ended say a combination of an economic revival and more borrowing by Federal, state and municipal governments will force interest rates higher.
 
Long Bond Yielding 8.24%
 Interest rates, as measured by the yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bonds, climbed last week. Late Friday, the price of the Treasury's long bonds had dropped enough to raise the yield to 8.24 percent, from 8.17 percent the day before and 8.14 percent a week earlier.
"While the credit markets have taken a bearish view, as reflected by the rise in yields, bond prices will resume their advance in a matter of weeks," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at DKB Securities Inc., the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo.
Mr. Braverman, who has maintained for many months that the trend in interest rates is downward, said Friday that there were several reasons why the decline in long-term rates had suddenly halted.
"For one," he said, "a relatively large supply of Treasury paper is coming to market in a relatively brief period, and at a time when yields on such debt has declined substantially in recent weeks."
 
$21 Billion Auction
 This week the Treasury will auction $21 billion of two- and five-year notes. Many Government securities dealers who bid at the April 10 auction of $8.5 billion of seven-year notes were unable to distribute the issue to retail customers without incurring losses.
On May 7 to 9, the Treasury will hold its quarterly refunding auctions. Some $35 billion of notes and bonds are expected to be offered. The terms of the refunding are to be announced on May 1.
Along with the temporary surge in the supply of Treasury securities, Mr. Braverman cited the usual short-selling by dealers, speculators and others who plan to bid for this week's offerings.
On Friday, dealers atributed part of the price decline in Treasury debt issues to short-selling. The short-selling is expected to increase as the refunding nears.
By selling short in the Treasury market, or selling borrowed debt issues similar to those they plan to bid for, the dealers in Treasury debt and others hope to hedge against a decline in the price of their newly acquired issues.
 
Offsetting Potential Losses
 If prices do fall after an auction, the loss may be largely offset by the profit made by buying back, at a lower price, the securities previously sold short. Conversely, if prices rise after the auction, the increased value of the newly acquired inventory should largely offset the loss on the securities sold short. Moreover, when the short-sellers close out their positions, the resulting buying tends to push prices higher.
But earlier in the week, when the Dow Jones industrial average finally broke through the 3,000 barrier, some dealers feared that managers of pension and mutual funds and other institutions would shift more of their holdings out of Treasury issues and other fixed-income securities and into stocks.
These fears are expected to be factored into the bidding at the auctions, despite the retreat of stock and bond prices late last week.
 
'A Decline of This Magnitude'
 Mr. Braverman of DKB Securities said another reason that bond prices should resume their climb could become clear on Friday, when the Government releases its report on the gross national product in the first quarter. He expects the data will show a decline of 3.5 percent, compared with the 1.6 percent decline reported for the last quarter of 1990.
 Had it not been for a surge in exports late in 1990, fourth-quarter G.N.P. would have been down 5.1 percent, he pointed out.
"A decline of this magnitude ought to be enough to finally galvanize any but this Federal Reserve Board into more responsible easing of credit," he said. "In fairness, however, the last meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee did reveal unusually sharp divisions over whether or not to ease interest rates. We believe the May 14 meeting could well lead to a resumption of a series of small steps to ease credit through the rest of the year."

HEADLINE: J. C. Penney's Woes Tied to Lack of Identity

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The J. C. Penney Company had high hopes that by now it would be enjoying the fruits of its 1987 transformation from a full-line department store to primarily a clothing store.
Instead, it has run into a buzzsaw of problems that are cutting heavily into sales and earnings. 
 The company has just reported a 6.6 percent decline in its March sales compared with a year ago, and sales at stores open at least a year were down 8 percent. While Sears, Roebuck & Company said Thursday that its profit had soared 91 percent in the first quarter, analysts say they expect a 50 percent drop in earnings when Penney issues its first-quarter report on May 14. Those declines follow a dismal 1990, in which Penney's earnings fell 26.1 percent.
Robert Gill, vice chairman of Penney, which is based near Dallas, said the company expected to report a "substantially down quarter" in its next earnings report.
Many retailing analysts and consultants say Penney's troubles stem partly from stiff price-cutting by competitors and partly from the chain's failure to attract fashion-minded women looking for exciting styles and well-known brand names.
Even so, these experts have mixed feelings about Penney's continuing experiment to sharpen its 1,800 stores with the right mix of national clothing brands and glitzier decor and merchandise. While these changes may eventually pay off, analysts say, Penney seems to have no distinct merchandising or pricing identity.
"Penney is perhaps the single retailer most vulnerable to broad economic trends," said Andrew D. Regan, an analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York, "given its position as a mid-priced store in a merchandising transition, seeking to convince shoppers to experiment with the new Penney approach of more upscale products. Such experimentation is more difficult to encourage when the consumer is cautious."
Penney's prices are generally moderate, but its stores do not carry the wide variety of discounted merchandise that Wal-Mart stores do. And, while Penney's clothing is generally of high quality, it has yet to catch up to a Macy or Nordstrom in designer-level fashions. Penney is "known more for its pricing than for its women's wear brands," says Daniel D. Barry, a retail analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York.
 
Trying to Step Up Efforts
 Company executives acknowledge that they have not moved quickly enough to add more familiar labels and say they are trying to step up those efforts.
"We've made some progress," said Mr. Gill. "In women's furnishings, we have added Warner and Bally, but we do need more brands in women's sportswear. We would like to get the Liz Claiborne line, which is the major sportswear line in department stores. But we remain hopeful that the company will ship to us and not just the traditional department stores in our markets.
"Our sales will be flat for same stores, partly because our catalogue sales have contributed to that. Since Desert Storm, the number of catalogue phone calls has dropped 18 to 20 percent since last year, to recent days when they were down just 4 percent. So a lot of consumers just aren't buying. But our most recent books, for the spring-summer period, are doing better."
Some analysts say that while Penney, like many other stores, has been hurt by consumer caution, it could do better if it moved faster to place national brands in its stores, especially in the crucial women's clothing departments.
Those analysts noted how Penney's sales and earnings soared in the first two years after it dropped major appliances, toys, sporting goods, big electronic products and automotive accessories, and they cite the success since then of its children's and men's clothing.
Many of Penney's root problems are similar to those of some other large chains, notably Sears. Penney is having trouble switching from store brands to national brands and like Sears, its huge catalogue business, representing about 18 percent of total volume, is not performing well.
While Sears's latest results indicate that it is getting control of its internal operating costs, Penney's operating expenses appear to be rising.
 
A String of Problems
 Mr. Regan of Donaldson, Lufkin sees a string of problems. "More important than the actual results," he said, "were the unfavorable trends driving them: consistent, top-line weakness; declining, but still high, gross margins and poor expense control. Poor sales momentum, weakening margins and rising expenses going into 1991 reinforce our projection of modest earnings growth in the year ahead and into 1992."
Mr. Gill denied that Penney had failed to keep operating costs low. "While our sales have been lackluster," he said, "we are one of the better performers in keeping costs low. This year, we are operating at the same expense levels of 1990."
Penney's stock closed Friday at $52, up 25 cents, continuing a recent trend in the low- and mid-$50's. That is about the midpoint of the year's range of $70.125 and $37.375.
 
Goods Not Profitable Enough
 Penney executives say they made the change away from big-ticket department store items because those goods were not profitable enough. And they add that research showed customers looking for that merchandise preferred to shop at specialty stores, not the malls where Penney stores are largely situated.
Penney's changes, like Montgomery Ward's action the same year to drop its century-old catalogue, the oldest in retailing, were viewed as significant and risky moves.
For two and a half years, it appeared that Penney's move to give up about $1.5 billion in volume, an amount equal to its operating income of that year, was a risk that was paying off. Net income rose to $807 million in 1988, from $608 million in 1987 and just $478 million in 1986.
But, in 1990, Penney's much-watched effort started to falter, and family apparel was particularly hard hit.
A recent visit to the Penney store at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City, L.I., gave some indication of what the chain may be up against. Roosevelt Field is the largest mall on Long Island, and Penney and Macy's are both anchor stores there.
"I like Macy's because it has nice clothes and there's no pressure," said one shopper, Harriet Feldheim, of Oceanside, L.I. "I like brand names, and I never go to Penney."
Another shopper, Suad Raby, of Great Neck, L.I., said: "Brand names aren't important. Macy's has higher-quality merchandise than Penney, and their prices are higher but not unreasonably. I'm going to shop more at Penney because of their low prices."
Brand names do not mean much, said Mary Ellen Korshek of Garden City South, L.I. "Personally, I think Penney's quality is just as good as Macy's, and their prices are lower, so that's where I go."
 
$16.4 Billion in Sales
 Still, Penney's huge size -- the 1,800 stores and 2,000 catalogue sales offices, all accounting last year for $16.4 billion in sales -- is not lost on the experts. The company also has the most extensive telecommunications and information systems in the industry and a reputation for specifications for private brands that are among the most stringent.
Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore, has lowered his estimate of Penney's first-quarter earnings to 69 cents a share from his previous estimate of 88 cents, against the previous year's $1.21 a share. But Mr. Buchanan says he is still optimistic long term on Penney. "Looking ahead, we expect quarterly year-over-year earnings comparisons to improve gradually as the year progresses," he said.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Paper Defies the Ad Slump

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
As New York City's three big tabloids march off to something resembling newspaper Armageddon, their spoils are looking rather paltry. Advertisers are watching their budgets, readership is on the wane, and profits bear only a ghostly resemblance to their former selves.
Meanwhile, the publishers of a smaller tabloid are looking at a future in which their competition may be thinning and their circulation growing. 
 The difference is one of language. Despite the odds against any newspaper dodging the impact of a faltering retail economy, the men who run El Diario-La Prensa, New York City's largest Spanish-language paper, believe it is a life-saving distinction.
"All advertising-sensitive media have been getting hammered over the last year or two," said Peter W. Davidson, El Diario's president. "There's still a huge potential in serving the Spanish-language market."
So far, the paper is reaping the benefits of that potential. In the six months ended Sept. 30, the most recent period in which Audit Bureau of Circulations figures are available, El Diario's weekday circulation grew 8 percent, to an average of 57,099. The gains came despite a 10-cent price increase, to 45 cents a copy.
And El Diario's advertising revenues rose 19.7 percent in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, with total revenues rising about 10 percent, executives of the privately owned paper said. They declined to give specific revenue or profit figures.
The fuel of El Diario's growth is a furious expansion of the Spanish-speaking market. In New York City alone, the 1990 census found the number of people identifying themselves as Hispanic rose 18.8 percent over the 1980's, to 1.7 million.
Across New York State, the Hispanic population rose 33.4 percent, to 2.2 million. Connecticut's Hispanic population grew by 71.2 percent and New Jersey's by 66.4 percent.
 
Big Expansion Effort
 But El Diario has not limited its sights on New York and its surroundings. In recent months, the paper's delivery trucks have ranged as far south as Washington and as far north as Montreal, finding little competition in between.
To the west, the paper has been sifting for new ventures among the Spanish-language weeklies in such cities as Chicago and Dallas.
On May 1, El Diario will embark on its first such effort, taking over production of a San Francisco weekly, El Mensajero. By teaming its production plant in New York with local distributors and reporters in other cities, El Diario's publishers hope to develop a network of local dailies or possibly a national publication.
How far they are able to reach, however, may also depend on how they fare at home.
So far, while its executives say the paper has turned a steady profit since 1986, it has fallen short of the high hopes that Mr. Davidson voiced when he and a group of investors bought the paper 20 months ago for about $20 million from the Gannett Company. But that has not dimmed confidence.
"The market is just out there waiting," said El Diario's publisher, Carlos Ramirez.
As newspaper territory, much of Spanish-speaking New York remains unconquered. For a paper that not so long ago thought of its constituency in clear-cut terms -- "Spanish" New York was a Puerto Rican city, and El Diario was foremost a Puerto Rican paper -- the last two decades have brought striking changes.
Puerto Ricans now make up barely half of New York City's legal Hispanic residents and perhaps only a third of all Hispanic residents in the metropolitan area, demographers for the city Planning Department say.
 
The Other Two-Thirds
 El Diario's editors believe that Dominicans and Ecuadoreans, newer immigrants with different concerns, comprise nearly another third of the area's Hispanic residents.
The last third is more complicated still: Spanish executives and former Mexican farm laborers, political refugees from Central America and professionals from South America.
"Two years ago, you could still say that the most important group were the Puerto Ricans," said the paper's editor, Fernando Moreno. "Now you can't say that anymore. The community has grown much more cosmopolitan at all levels -- intellectual, social, economic."
In recent months, El Diario has been changing quickly, too. It has redesigned and shifted its focus. Like the country's Spanish-language television news programs and the two larger Spanish-language dailies, La Opinion of Los Angeles and El Nuevo Herald of Miami, El Diario has been working hard to become more cosmopolitan. News from Latin America is being covered more extensively.
Mr. Moreno said El Diario would not neglect local news of Hispanic interest, but would try to balance it against the importance of other news.
"Our people have the same needs as everyone else," he said.
"If there's a war in the Persian Gulf, I'm not going to put on the front page that Congressman Serrano had a car accident," he said, referring to Jose Serrano, a Bronx Democrat.
Predictably, the reorientation has prompted some suggestions among the paper's competitors that El Diario may lose readers in trying to become too much for too many.
In Queens, especially, a handful of tiny weeklies oriented to different Latin nationalities have sprouted. El Especial, a weekly in Union City, N.J., has risen to what its publishers claim is a circulation of 60,000 after only five years. El Vocero, Puerto Rico's largest paper, has a steady readership of about 30,000 around New York. Only Noticias del Mundo, which is sponsored by a branch of the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, has seemed to falter.
 
Broadcasting Outlets
The area's two New Jersey-based Spanish-language television stations and its principal Spanish-language radio station have grown as well. But Mr. Davidson and some of his competitors said El Diario's biggest challenge was coming from the economy.
"I think they have good times ahead if they can hold on and stay in business," said Mara M. Rankin, the general manager of WXTV-Channel 41, the leading Spanish-language station. "But it may be a long wait."
 Directing the paper's growth is an unlikely troika: Mr. Moreno, a writer of fiction who was raised in Tangiers and educated in Spain; Mr. Ramirez, a man of Puerto Rican ancestry, born in Queens and trained as an accountant, and Mr. Davidson, an "Anglo" banker who arrived as general partner of El Diario Associates by way of Stanford, Harvard and Morgan Stanley & Company.
 Initially, Mr. Davidson and Mr. Ramirez expressed hopes of 20 to 50 percent annual growth in advertising revenues. But both of them see promise in the 19.7 percent growth last year, although much of it came from a big increase in ad rates.
 "We still have a lot to do," Mr. Ramirez said. "I see this big advertising pie and I don't think all of the Spanish vehicles - television, radio, newspapers - have half of it. Bloomingdale's does not realize that our readers shop there. All of our readers are not waiters and doormen."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Municipal Bonds And Extra Yields

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
BORROWING short and lending long can be a sure road to wealth -- unless short-term rates rise too far.
That method of enhancing yield has helped to produce a hot product in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Effectively, it allows buyers of long-term municipal bonds, which pay interest around 7 percent, to borrow some of the purchase money at short-term municipal bond rates, which tend to be around 4 percent. The extra yield goes into the pockets of the long-term buyers. 
 The product is a closed-end municipal bond fund, with both common and preferred stock. It is the preferred stock that gives it the borrowing characteristic, and that enables the holders of the common stock to garner the extra yield.
A closed-end fund is similar to an open-end mutual fund. The main difference is that shares in the fund trade on exchanges, or over the counter, rather than being sold and redeemed by the fund itself. As a result, the shares can sell for more, or less, than the underlying value of the securities in the portfolios.
For a fund manager, a big advantage of running a closed-end fund, compared with an open-end one, is that less cash needs to be kept on hand because there is no threat that investors will redeem shares. Thus more of the money can be put to work.
Although closed-end stock funds have been around for decades, they did not make their debut in the municipal bond market until 1986, during a boom in the issuance of closed-end stock funds. The boom in such stock funds has ended, but closed-end municipal funds continue to sell well.
The adding of preferred shares to closed-end municipal funds did not start until 1988, when $614 million in such shares were sold. That figure grew to $1.2 billion the following year and to $1.5 billion last year. In the first quarter of this year, $461 million of preferred shares were sold, according to John Nuveen & Company, which pioneered the use of preferred shares and still issues more than all its competitors combined.
There are now closed-end funds that specialize in bonds of certain states, including New York, Pennsylvania, California and Florida, as well as funds that buy municipal bonds from throughout the country.
The preferred shares are similar to auction-rate preferred stocks issued by many companies, in that they promise the investor in the preferred a way to get out after a very brief interval, in this case seven days. The preferred shares are issued in $50,000 denominations, with the interest rate set every week.
Effectively, the preferred shares are a super-safe way for an investor to park money for tax-free income with no concern over loss of principal. The mechanism by which the rate is set is supposed to assure any investors who want out at the end of the week that they will be able to get out.
Timothy R. Schwertfeger, an executive vice president at Nuveen, said one advantage for the funds was that the municipal market had a relative shortage of short-term borrowers. Generally, those are cities and states that borrow money pending the receipt of taxes. Because the preferred shares are only one-third of a fund's total capitalization, there is virtually no chance of a default from them, so demand for the paper is high.
For the common holders, the benefit while short-term rates are low is that they get some of the yield from bonds that were bought with the short-term investors' money. Moreover, if interest rates fall, as they have recently, the net asset value of the common shares will rise even more rapidly than the value of the underlying bonds.
That enthusiasm has led to buyers of the closed-end funds being willing to pay more than net asset values for the shares, with an average premium of around 5 percent. Mr. Schwertfeger said in an interview that he believed that premium reflected a market feeling that interest rates would continue to decline, thus driving net asset values up further.
But the flip side of the advantage will occur if rates begin to rise. As short-term rates rise, the amount of yield left over for the common holders will decline. If long-term rates also rise, the value of the bonds the funds hold will fall, and the net asset value of the common shares will decline more rapidly than the value of the bonds.
The market consensus, for what it's worth, is that there is little danger of a sharp rise in interest rates in the near future. But owners of closed-end municipal bond funds should remember that such an event is possible, and that the extra yield they are now receiving was available in part because they were willing to take on that added risk.

HEADLINE: Europe Stumbles in Computers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 20

 BODY:
Europe's computer makers, outmuscled by their American and Japanese competitors, are desperately fighting for survival. They are laying off thousands as they struggle to slash their losses, but some analysts say most of them will either collapse or sell out to competitors overseas.
"The game is pretty much lost," said Dorian Foyil, who follows European computer companies for UBS Phillips & Drew in London. "It's just a matter of time before they disappear." 
 Many European officials say they cannot let the continent that gave the world Aristotle and Galileo be vanquished in such a crucial industry. They fear that the disappearance of Europe's computer makers would weaken other industries, including automobiles, aerospace and consumer electronics.
 
Shocked by Japanese Incursion
 Many Europeans were appalled in July when the Fujitsu group of Japan bought 80 percent of Britain's leading computer maker, International Computers Ltd.
"We want to keep the European industry European," said Filippo Maria Pandolfi, technology commissioner of the European Community.
Demonstrating how far governments are willing to go, France recently pledged more than $1 billion to shore up the capital of Compagnie des Machines Bull and help pay for its research. Bull, France's largest computer manufacturer, lost $1.2 billion in 1990.
Across the Rhine, Nixdorf Computer A.G. lost $600 million in 1989 before agreeing to be acquired by Siemens A.G. as an alternative to bankruptcy.
Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, has laid off a third of the workers in its money-losing computer division as part of a companywide revamping that led to a $2.25 billion loss last year. Olivetti S.p.A., Italy's flagship computer company, has reacted to declining profits by laying off 7,000 workers.
Europe's manufacturers are besieged by American competitors, who draw encouragement from computer prices often 50 percent higher than in the United States and who have benefited from the dollar's weakness in 1989-90. And Europe's $45 billion computer market is expected to grow faster than the more mature American market. The Compaq Computer Corporation, based in Houston, boasts that its sales in Europe soared 50 percent last year.
"The profits are there to be had," said Mr. Foyil, the analyst. "If the Europeans can't make money in their own backyard, they're not going to make money in the future."
Some analysts say Europe's computer manufacturers will remain far behind the Americans and Japanese in efficiency and innovation. Since Europe's manufacturers are far smaller, they have far less money for research and development. The combined computer sales of Europe's four leading computer companies are just one-third of I.B.M.'s. Siemens-Nixdorf, Europe's largest computer maker, ranks just fifth in worldwide computer sales.
 
U.S. Advantage in PC's
 The growing market for personal computers is enhancing the American advantage. Led by I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., the five largest sellers of personal computers in Europe in 1990 were all American.
While the Continent's top computer makers are sustaining heavy losses, the International Business Machines Corporation, with 12 factories in Europe, had European earnings of $2.98 billion last year, almost half of the company's total profits.
But with European economies slowing, I.B.M. said the Continent had contributed to its dismal first-quarter results. And the company is trimming its European staff.
Still, many American companies are having greater success abroad than at home. "If you want to know where the major U.S. personal computer firms are making money these days, it's not in the U.S.," John Sculley, the chairman of Apple Computer Inc., based in Cupertino, Calif., said recently. "There really is no European computer industry. So we are doing well there."
 
Slow to Innovate
 The Europeans have been handicapped by a late start. Key inventions that originated in the United States took years to cross the Atlantic.
The European manufacturers developed in small domestic markets that gave them few economies of scale. As the companies fell further behind I.B.M., several nations merged their small computer makers into single national champions, which the governments lavished with orders.
Nurtured by their governments, the European companies felt little need to keep up with advances developed in the highly competitive American market. "I am profoundly convinced that the origin of the weakness of European industry is fragmented markets and short-sighted protectionist policies." Carlo de Benedetti, the chairman of Olivetti, told a group of reporters recently.
Fragmented markets mean large bureaucracies for small domestic bases, marketing staffs for each European country, and extra work adapting computers for Spanish or Italian companies. The Europeans have suffered more than I.B.M. in Europe because I.B.M. can spread its costs over a huge domestic market.
Europe's fragmentation has inflated staffs so much that Bull's computer sales per employee were $120,000 last year and Siemens's $145,000, while Apple had sales of $420,000 per employee.
 
Alliances May Be Necessary
 Many industry experts say European companies must work more closely together or even merge. "If the Europeans don't want to disappear, they have to form alliances among themselves," said Francis Lorentz, the chairman of Bull.
Twenty years ago, European governments pushed Bull, Siemens, International Computers and Olivetti to form one giant company, but these producers failed to agree on who would run it.
Now, every European computer maker seems to think the others are too ill to be partners. Olivetti's talks with International Computers and Philips have collapsed.
Still, there are some small joint ventures, like an agreement between Bull and Olivetti to make automated teller machines for banks. Under agreements with non-European producers, NEC Corporation of Japan is helping to produce Bull's largest mainframe and Hitachi Ltd. is making some of Olivetti's most powerful machines.
 
Strategies for Survival
 Each company is charting a survival strategy. Bull is taking a $600 million charge to lay off 20 percent of its workers and close 7 of its 13 factories. The company has sought to reach global scale by acquiring the computer businesses of Honeywell Inc. and Zenith Electronics. Bull has joined the manufacturers who back open systems, which allow one computer maker's hardware to be linked to another's.
"They have a sustainable long-term strategy on paper," said Jonathan Portch, an analyst with the International Data Corporation in London. But that strategy may face some problems.
Open systems mean lower profit margins than proprietary systems. And some customers may still consider Bull too small to serve their needs. "The big spenders on the big mainframes are usually multinationals," said John Newman, a consultant with BIS Strategic Decisions, a computer consulting firm. "They're looking not for national suppliers, but global suppliers. Historically, the European computer manufacturers are not seen that way."
Olivetti, Europe's leading producer of personal computers, is straining to keep up with American and Japanese manufacturers. But it remains strong in selling computers to banks. Alluding to the government subsidies that many other European computer makers receive, Mr. de Benedetti said, "The only information-technology company in Europe that has no Godfather and is not losing money is Olivetti."
Siemens's computer division has suffered losses since it acquired Nixdorf in January 1990, but it hopes to be profitable by late 1992. Thanks to Siemens's huge hoard of cash and stronger demand from a reunited Germany, many analysts say Siemens is the healthiest of Europe's computer makers.
 
European Commission's Plan
 Philips officials vow to remain in the business, but many analysts question the company's commitment because they see Philips relying on Asian suppliers for many personal computers. "Philips will get out of the computer business," Mr. de Benedetti predicted. "In other countries there will be a process of selection and consolidation."
The European Commission, the European Community's executive branch, wants to help the Continent's computer makers survive without lavishing huge subsidies on the industry. The commission plans to aid the companies by establishing a "European nervous system" that would enable Italy's tax authorities to transfer data to Britain's, for instance, and let shoppers use their bank cards in teller machines from Malaga to Munich. The commission is also helping to finance Joint Silicon Structures, a multibillion-dollar consortium to develop advanced semiconductors.
Several computer executives said that even with a $5 billion budget, the commission's efforts were too modest, considering the American advantage of a huge domestic market and Japan's success in keeping much of its domestic market closed to foreign competition.
Some commission officials say France's aid to Bull gives the computer maker an unfair advantage and violates the commission's rules limiting subsidies. But French officials argue that the rules on subsidies may have to be loosened to keep Europe's computer industry alive.
"The industry does not grow spontaneously like a mushroom in autumn," said Roger Fauroux, France's Minister of Industry. In his view, it needs "a favorable environment and intelligent help from the state."

HEADLINE: CROTONA JOURNAL;
Bronx Man Is Smitten By the Bug

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
If Sotero Calo had his way, the streets of the Bronx would be crawling with bugs.
Mexican beetles. 
 Mr. Calo is not an eccentric entomologist but a mechanic with a mission -- to keep his beloved Volkswagen Beetles scooting about the streets of the South Bronx. As president of the Puerto Rico Volky Club, he wistfully notes that his ovoid object of desire is now built only in Mexico.
"The demand there is so great, they can't make enough," he said. "I hope that car returns to New York."
But emissions and safety standards make it nearly impossible to market that car north of the border, so Mr. Calo satisfies his Beetlemania by tinkering with the hardy remnants of the five million Volkswagens sold in the United States between 1949 and 1979. With a surgeon's skill and a craftsman's soul, he and the club's nine other members chop, paint and otherwise transform the lowly Beetles into revved-up roadsters that escort politicians and prom queens at special events.
Children rush to the curb and excitedly jump up and down, pointing out their favorites whenever the club's caravan rumbles down the street with a white convertible Beetle in the lead. Rolling behind are Beetles with fat black tires, Beetles with fluorescent pink hubcaps and Beetles with booming speakers ringed by lights that pulsate to the beat of salsa music.
Invariably, the loudest cheers are for Mr. Calo's "Volky pickup," a bright yellow 1971 Beetle whose rear was lopped off and replaced with a jacked-up wood-paneled flatbed that sits atop flaring exhaust pipes.
"The Volky is the only car for me," said Mr. Calo, a rumpled, portly man who also makes his living fixing cars. "It's a unique car, but they're all the same. Anything you put on it will make it stand out."
In the same way, Mr. Calo's efforts stand out in his part of Crotona, a weary dust-blown patch of the Bronx surrounded by gaping lots and street-corner drug dealers. The wooden house on Mohegan Avenue where he lives with his family and the adjoining garage and garden is an automotive oasis cluttered with fenders, tires, transmissions and the ever-present Volkies in various stages of repair.
Mr. Calo, 47 years old, started the club in 1982, soon after buying his first Volkswagen in fulfillment of a dream he had as a child in Puerto Rico. While tooling around the Bronx one afternoon, he was approached by Israel Baez, another Volkswagen owner who wanted to start a custom car club like the ones popular in Puerto Rico.
Over the years, members have joined the club in much the same serendipitous manner, encountering the caravan on the street and falling in behind. New members do not have to have pristine Beetles to join, but they have to promise to fix them up soon after.
They gather each week at the "Volky Garden," a community garden that abuts Mr. Calo's house, and help each other with repairs and improvements on cars dating back as far as 1953, whose engines are cleaned more often than some people brush their teeth.
Like true believers, they still lament the passing of the Beetle. "It was an economical car and Americans don't like economy," Mr. Calo theorized. "They want something that breaks down fast so they can sell it fast."
He and his club have an eye for true luxury, especially with the green convertible whose spotless white interior is accented by a Rolls-Royce-style hood and mahogany running boards. "Everywhere we go, we put a Volky next to a Mercedes or a Cadillac and everyone looks at the Volky," he said. "We've proved it."
Those high-priced land yachts will get a run for their money when the club combines two Beetles to build a four-door limousine complete with a bar, televison and stereo. "That is my dream," Mr. Calo intoned. "I hope to do it before dying."
Mr. Calo knows value -- both in cars and people. Apart from serving as escorts at weddings and "Sweet 16" parties, he and fellow club members are familiar volunteers at parades and youth festivals, giving free rides -- and a strong anti-drug message -- to youngsters. On Halloween they convert their clubhouse into a haunted house and on Mother's Day they whip up a small feast for the neighborhood.
Recently, envisioning a broad auto-lovers' confederation devoted not just to cars but to promoting Hispanic culture and civic pride, Mr. Calo convened a meeting of six other auto clubs from as far away as Hartford -- greeting arriving visitors with Beetle reception committees lurking on the off-ramps of the Cross Bronx Expressway.
In communities once so blighted they were compared to post-war Berlin, a group of men devoted to salvaging German cars are trying to revive the neighborhoods. Their spirit is summed up by one word they have emblazoned on their club's jackets: "conquistando," conquering.
"Since 1982, we've been conquering the streets, and we haven't fallen," said Mr. Calo. "We want to overcome."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Ghost of '75 Dogs A Wary Dinkins In Fiscal Struggle

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
John E. Zuccotti vividly recalls telephoning the White House on the night of Oct. 16, 1975. The incoming First Deputy Mayor was calling to inform President Gerald R. Ford that New York City would run out of money in the morning. Mr. Zuccotti was told that the President was already asleep.
But at Gracie Mansion that night, city officials and their financial advisers were rudely, if belatedly, roused into grappling with the apparent denouement of a lingering crisis. While they scraped together enough cash to avert an immediate default, a contingency committee convened to ponder a fundamental question: Whom should the city pay first if it runs short of money? 
 The surprising consensus: water-supply workers and bridge tenders (since Federal law required that drawbridges be left raised if they are unattended). Also, police, fire and sanitation employees and hospital workers and suppliers. Teachers were a low priority, since classes would probably be suspended.
A last-minute investment of teachers' union pension funds made the doomsday planning moot. But it marked a defining moment. It prompted the city to review its priorities and, at least hypothetically, to acknowledge its limits and adjust its agenda.
Today New York City and State face a combined deficit of about $10 billion through July 1992. But City Hall, as in early 1975, has again been diverted by inconsistency and chronic drift, by finger-pointing and by suspicions about the motives of a Governor unable to balance his own budget and further frustrated with a Mayor whose administration seemed at times to have made matters worse.
 There is little sense of crisis. There is less consensus about solutions.
 In contrast with 1975, the credit markets haven't closed to the city, although Mayor David N. Dinkins would rather avoid unnecessary borrowing because the city is being charged junk bond rates (and rising rates could portend worse market jitters).
The current fiscal year's deficit, if it doesn't grow, is generally regarded as manageable with a cohesive program to slash purchases, tap reserves, speed payments due from Albany, engage in gimmickry that fiscal monitors agree to wink at, cajole the City Comptroller into cooperating and coax municipal unions into making modest concessions.
"You'd have to take the scenario pretty far down the road to get to where we were then," says Ira M. Millstein, a lawyer who was advising Mayor Abraham D. Beame in 1975. "That was a crisis. This is just a mess."
But how will officials come to grips with projected deficits in the state's fiscal year, which began three weeks ago, and in the fiscal year the city starts 10 weeks from today? The city's budget gap has been made worse by Albany's; both are driven by the recession. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been further hobbled by his reluctance to be perceived as usurping the authority of the city's first black Mayor.
Would Mr. Cuomo even want to? No, because he has enough trouble with the state's finances without being held directly responsible for the city's. Yes, because the resurgence of the Financial Control Board, over which he presides and on which the Mayor sits, might buy fiscal flexibility and a reprieve for the Governor, for Mr. Dinkins and for many of his constituents, who might otherwise lose their city jobs, be deprived of city services and be taxed heavier. Hence ambivalence, although the Governor would rather be perceived as a victim of circumstance than a co-conspirator.
"Politically," says Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, "no governor is eager to intrude on the city unless he has absolutely no choice or is absolutely certain of success. Neither condition prevails at this point."
Meanwhile a window of opportunity is slipping shut. Mr. Zuccotti, now a real-estate development executive, says the Mayor "quite frankly could do more."
"There's no question that the criticism about leadership is valid," he says. "I'm not saying what he had to do is easy. But it's a plus in the sense that if he does step up to the plate, he could do a lot."
Mr. Rohatyn says he doesn't regret having voting for Mr. Dinkins. But he says that what he terms the city administration's "policy schizophrenia" and "inept" labor negotiations -- compounded by the state's deficit -- have contributed to "creeping paralysis" rather than to boldness. "Political leaders need a clear, simple crisis symbol," he said, adding that, unlike 1975, "they do not have it today."
They may, if the financial mess is allowed to fester. Then the debate may shift to whether some temporary return of the control board would confer a strategic opportunity, an excuse to avoid tough choices or a stigma to be avoided at all cost.
