HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Cuomo Sends Dinkins Smoky Fiscal Signal

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 21

 BODY:
New York City officials readily concede that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo plays politics at a level far above theirs, a level that one aide to Mayor David N. Dinkins likened to three-dimensional chess.
In rosier times, there might have been an esthetic appreciation of the Governor's mastery. But amid this year's frenzy of fiscal distress, there is a growing frustration -- and confusion -- among city officials about moves that Mr. Cuomo has made in recent weeks. 
 Many members of the Dinkins administration view Albany as a place through the looking glass, where what is said is not always what is meant. With New York City slipping closer to crisis every day, city officials say the Governor has been sending fuzzy and sometimes contradictory signals about his positions on the city's labor negotiations and whether he really opposes a takeover of the city's finances by the state's Financial Control Board.
City officials can only speculate about the Governor's real agenda, and Mr. Cuomo's aides suggest that any perception of brinksmanship is the paranoid invention of the Mayor's staff. But in politics, perception is often reality, and the timing could prove perilous, given the high stakes for both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins.
Many political analysts warn that Mr. Dinkins will be a one-term mayor if he does not quickly disprove the critics who say he is not up to the task of managing the country's largest city. Mr. Cuomo, meanwhile, seems eager to use his austere state budget proposal to demonstrate -- certainly to disgruntled voters in New York and perhaps to a national electorate -- that the caricature of him as a tax-and-spend liberal is unfounded.
But at a time when the political destinies of the Mayor and the Governor are so tightly interwoven, the uncertain relationship between the Capitol and City Hall has made it harder to break the impasse over the state budget and protect the city from receivership.
On Friday, for instance, Mr. Cuomo made it clear that he still felt that the state could not offer financial help to the city until Mr. Dinkins extracted concessions from municipal labor unions. That obliterated the impression that Dinkins aides said they got from a meeting with Mr. Cuomo on Thursday.
Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo emerged from that meeting to declare confidently that the city could and would avert a takeover by the Financial Control Board. The Mayor said at a news conference that state help no longer depended on union concessions. The Governor, standing at his side, did not protest.
Because the public feud between Mr. Cuomo and the municipal unions had created a logjam in negotiations between the city and its workers, city officials welcomed Mr. Cuomo's silence.
But Mr. Cuomo said in an interview on Friday that his position had not changed. He said he could not justify offering state aid to the city when his own budget called for layoffs and a wage freeze for state workers while Mr. Dinkins recently gave wage increases to municipal unions.
"How do I explain to this state and its workers that instead of taking wealth and finding a way to share it with them, I in effect shared it with a city that used wealth it didn't have -- otherwise they wouldn't be asking you for money -- to give to its employees?" Mr. Cuomo asked.
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, one of the most influential municipal unions, said his mood had swung from delight to depression in one day. "I am now very disappointed," he said on Friday night. "It just distresses me."
 
Cuomo's Sincerity Questioned
 Perhaps the most telling evidence that the Dinkins administration regards Mr. Cuomo with suspicion is that city officials question whether the Governor is sincere when he says he does not want the Financial Control Board to take over the city's finances.
 
'Nobody Could Figure It Out'
 "There were doubts," said one top Dinkins aide, whose views were echoed by a second. "Nobody could figure it out."
Mr. Cuomo has said repeatedly said that such a takeover should be avoided at all costs, and his aides have painted the prospect as an enormous liability for him. The control board, which was created as a result of the 1975 fiscal crisis and is led by Mr. Cuomo, would regulate the city's finances if the city has a deficit of $100 million or more at the end of its fiscal year on June 30.
Some city officials say that by talking so much about a takeover, Mr. Cuomo has undermined confidence in the Mayor and contributed to what may become a self-fulfilling prophecy. They speculate that the Governor is trying to divert attention from the state's own big significant fiscal problems.
"One theory," said one Dinkins aide, "was that he was going to be blamed for New York City's problems in any event. And if he was going to need some power to deal with these issues, the control board would give him an institutional mechanism to deal with them.
"The other theory was that if he was going to pursue other aspirations, the control board mechanisms are so strong that there has to be a solution. And so that would seem like a fiscal success story compared to whatever impression is left about the state's problems."
The head-scratching became vigorous on Tuesday, when the Governor said he was exploring whether it would be possible to raise the $100 million deficit limit to help avoid a takeover.
By implication, Mr. Cuomo seemed to suggest that he did not believe Mr. Dinkins could bring the city's budget gap, currently estimated at about $300 million, to under $100 million in less than three months.
A day later, the Governor said his lawyers had concluded that such a move would not be legal. But in the interim, yields on city bonds rose slightly, and some because of uncertainty that some bond traders attributed it to uncertainty caused by Mr. Cuomo's comments. If the yields, or interest rates the city must pay, remain high, the cost of the bonds increases for the city.
"He put something out, he knew it was wrong, and he affected the city bond market, just to keep the pot stirred up on the control board," said a top Dinkins aide. "Why? Maybe to distract attention from what is going on in the state."
Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo are longtime friends and political allies who supported each other in early campaigns. By all accounts, Mr. Cuomo relates more easily to the dignified Mr. Dinkins than he did to former Mayor Edward I. Koch, whose trips to Albany were often marked by combative demands for state aid.
 
Relationship Naturally Hostile
 "Koch is feisty and fighting and taking shots and calling you names all of the time," Mr. Cuomo said on Friday. "David is not like that."
But because the state essentially acts as the city's financier, the relationship between Mayor and Governor is naturally a hostile one. And with the recession drying up both fiscal and political capital, there may not be enough money in New York to insure success for both men.
"When you're dealing in a zero-sum game, which is what we're doing, it's extraordinarily difficult to allocate resources and to allocate sacrifice without injuring somebody," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and an adviser to both men. "And that's the exercise they're involved in."
Throughout the budget negotiations, Mr. Cuomo has not hesitated to use the city's financial problems to pressure the Legislature to approve his plan. which is now three weeks overdue. Legislative aides continued to discuss the budget this weekend.
Last week, Mr. Cuomo shot down a proposal backed by both houses of the Legislature that would give the city Board of Education and other school districts an infusion of school aid during the budget impasse. The bill might help the city avoid borrowing, but it might also relieve the pressure on the Legislature to pass a new budget.
In a series of news conferences last week, Mr. Cuomo said that the state budget delay was harming the city. "It is, as a matter of fact, dangerous, we hope not destructive," Mr. Cuomo said.
Because the state cannot forward school-aid payments or revenue-sharing grants to the city without a budget, the delay will probably force the city to borrow $1 billion later this month, costing about $20 million in interest. That would contribute to a $300 million gap in the city's current budget and a $3 billion gap next year.
 
Comments Aimed at Assembly
 The Governor's comments were aimed at the Assembly, which is controlled by Democrats based in New York City. Led by Speaker Mel Miller of Brooklyn, they have opposed Mr. Cuomo's plan to fill a budget gap of more than $6 billion through $4.5 billion in spending cuts and $1.5 billion in new taxes and other revenue measures.
Early last week, Mr. Miller suggested that the city would gladly pay the cost of borrowing money if further delay would ultimately result in a more generous state budget.
The comment outraged Mr. Cuomo, and his staff encouraged Mr. Dinkins to issue a statement, along with City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, urging the Legislature to act quickly. When the statement was released last Tuesday, the Governor argued at a press conference that it undermined Mr. Miller's position.
Mr. Miller suggested that City Hall was being manipulated. "They're between the devil and the deep blue sea and I don't think we should make them the pawn," he said.

HEADLINE: American Express's Hard Times

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The American Express Company, long a dominant force in the financial services industry, faces a series of difficult challenges as new competition and more bad debts land on its corporate doorstep each day.
The problems are multifaceted, from increasing numbers of customers who fail to pay their charge-card balances, to protests by restaurateurs against the commissions they must pay on sales charged on American Express cards. 
 The company also sees a possible need to strengthen the capital base of its brokerage subsidiary, Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., which received hundreds of millions of dollars in capital infusions just last year. In a conference call with industry analysts, the company said it was considering several ways to increase Shearson's net worth, including the issuance of common stock, some of the analysts said.
 
The Biggest Challenges
 But the biggest challenges for American Express appear to be in its bread-and-butter charge-card business, which is suffering amid increased competition from cards issued by banks and other companies, including A.T.& T. and Sears, Roebuck. In addition, there are signs that many American Express cardholders reflect a broader trend among consumers toward saving more money and spending less.
American Express's troubles were harshly evident last week, when the company said it was adding $50 million to its reserves to cover loan losses. An increasing number of customers are failing to pay off the loans they have received in conjunction with the company's charge cards.
While company executives said that the problems in the first quarter resulted from unusual circumstances, including the Persian Gulf war and the recession, the stock market reacted quickly to news of the increase in loss reserves. American Express shares tumbled $1.25 on Friday, to $28, in active trading.
Company executives said that the recent results, while disappointing, did not affect the overall health of the company. They added that they planned to make aggressive investments in the company and in new initiatives. "There is nothing that has changed in our franchise," said G. Richard Thoman, chairman and co-chief executive of the Travel Related Services division. "Now is the time to go on the offensive."
Customers' deteriorating credit, which affects virtually every type of charge card offered by the company, strikes at the heart of American Express: Travel Related Services, or T.R.S. as the division is known, has been the engine behind American Express's growth. Last week, the company reported a 25 percent decline in the division's earnings, in what analysts said was the unit's first earnings drop in 25 years.
 
'Magical Growth Enterprise'
 "For many years, T.R.S. was a magical growth enterprise," said John Keefe, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. "But they are reaching another stage. The market has changed. Competition is no longer based on prestige or image -- the competition is based on cost."
Analysts and company executives said that the bad debts piling up in the travel division stemmed largely from credit lines extended to owners of the company's Gold Card and Platinum Card, which are given to the company's wealthiest clients.
 
Recession Hurting the Affluent
 According to an analysis issued on Friday by Paine Webber Inc., loss rates from the lines of credit of the company's cards now exceed 7 percent of receivables, or nearly twice the loss rate of the portfolios of bank credit cards, primary competitors of the American Express cards.
For the first time, the company's claim to having a wealthier clientele than issuers of bank cards is proving to be a problem, as the recession produces more and more layoffs among well-paid white-collar workers.
"The recession is really affecting the affluent sector of the marketplace," said Ed Cooperman, also chairman and co-chief executive of the travel services division. "When our people have been picking up their phones at card-member centers, we have been hearing more than ever before, 'I just lost my job.' "
Mr. Cooperman said in an interview that he believed many of the problems were a "short-term phenomenon" stemming from the war and the recession. But some analysts said last week's announcement clearly signaled a fundamental change in the business of American Express.
The company has begun to undertake a number of intiatives in hopes of strengthening its position. Under one plan, which American Express executives said had been in the works for months, fees would be cut to merchants who agree to use a new technology, which would electronically transmit information about a charge sale to the company, eliminating the need for the paper slips that are currently sent to the company by merchants.
 
Protests Against Fees
 The plan comes as a number of restaurateurs around the country have been loudly protesting the fees they must pay to accept the American Express card. The Nilson Report, a Los Angeles credit-card newsletter, said the commission on American Express charges, also known as the discount rate, ranges from 2.5 percent to 5 percent of the amount charged, compared with 1.25 percent to 3.5 percent charged by bank cards.
At the same time, executives say they are exploring a number of joint business operations and other efforts to help expand their charge-card business. "It wouldn't surprise us to see more strategic alliances, more advertising programs and more visible investment into technology in the marketplace" during the second quarter, Mr. Thoman said.
But the tide of consumer defaults, a difficult element for the company to control, leaves analysts concerned about the future.
"If we were to see a similar credit provision taken in the second quarter," said Mr. Keefe of Lipper, "I would be very concerned not only for American Express, but for the economy in general."

HEADLINE: U.S. Giving Certain Boat Owners Exclusive Rights to Fish Off Coast

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Without fanfare, Washington has begun to turn over to private interests the exclusive rights to the multibillion-dollar harvest of fish off the United States coast.
Since 1976 the Federal Government has controlled the right to fish up to 200 miles off the coast, and in most cases it has allowed any American with a boat to do so. Washington is now allowing eight regional councils dominated by local fishing interests to hand out exclusive rights to the catch, transferrable rights that could be worth tens of billions of dollars. 
 Many scientists, economists and industry leaders stoutly defend the change from collective ownership of fishing rights to private. The current policy, they say, has led to too many boats chasing too few fish, undermining efforts to preserve fisheries for future generations and helping transform once-plentiful seafood into a luxury.
But for all the enthusiasm over doing away with open access, there is deep division over who should financially benefit from the distribution of the rights.
While the regional councils seem determined to bestow this windfall on owners of fishing boats, other analysts say the fishing rights should be auctioned, with the proceeds going to the United States Treasury, much as Federal mineral rights are sold to the highest bidder.
"Any allocation other than to the nation would be an injustice," said Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard University.
And crewmen of fishing boats wonder what the process holds for them. "If it is necessary to privatize the fishery in order to save it," said Peter Soileau, a boat captain in Seattle, "each licensed participant should get a share."
The policy of privatization began last year, when the Mid-Atlantic Fisheries Management Council awarded boat owners the rights to harvest two species of clams in the region's coastal waters. A far bigger test will come in the North Pacific, where plans to hand out rights to the valuable halibut and sable fish catches are likely to be approved by the North Pacific Fisheries Management Council this summer.
 
Invasion by Foreigners
 Current United States fishing policy is largely a response to catastrophic overfishing by foreigners in the 1960's, said Peter Fricke, an analyst for the National Marine Fisheries Service, a Commerce Department agency that oversees the harvest in Federal waters.
Annual catches of haddock off New England, which had long been sustained at about 50,000 tons, shot up to 150,000 tons with the arrival of the Soviet trawling fleet in the early 60's. But the glory days were over in a twinkling. By the early 1970's the fish population had plummeted and the haddock catch had fallen to 35,000 tons.
In response, Congress passed the Magnuson Fisheries Conservation and Management Act in 1976, extending an "exclusive economic zone" from the traditional three-mile coastal limit to 200 miles and creating eight regional councils to end the anarchy. Members of the councils were nominated by state governors and appointed by the Secretary of Commerce.
As intended, the act has served the interests of the American fishing industry at the expense of foreigners. But the councils have not come to grips with the problem of overfishing by Americans.
Many species in the once-rich New England fishery have never been allowed to recover from the foreign invasion. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, a watchdog group, estimates the shortfall at 137 million pounds of fish a year, worth $350 million. Ports like New Bedford, Mass., that service the boats and process the region's catch remain deeply depressed.
Production in other coastal regions is generally stable or rising. But as ever greater numbers of American boats have been drawn into Federal waters in response to the rising demand for fish, the pressure to allow catches beyond biologically sustainable limits has increased. According to the fish and wildlife foundation, one-third of all commercial species -- among them, swordfish, Atlantic salmon and California halibut -- are in decline. If the decline continues, already-high prices for fish will soar.
A related problem, said S. Fred Singer, an environmental scientist at the University of Virginia, is the potent incentive to overinvest in an industry that permits access to all comers. In most fisheries, a small number of boats could catch the maximum sustainable yield at a cost that represents a tiny fraction of the value of the harvest. Nonetheless, it remains profitable for new boats to enter the business, even when they are permitted to work only very short seasons.
Lee Anderson, an economist at the University of Delaware and a member of the mid-Atlantic council, noted that 140 boats participated in the harvest of the Atlantic surf clam last year. Yet to maintain the clam beds without locking out any boats or restricting any participant's catch, the council was forced to limit clamming to 144 hours a year.
Off Alaska, the halibut season usually consists of two or three frenzied, and frequently dangerous, 24-hour periods. With so brief a season, fresh halibut is rarely available.
Another consequence of limiting the catch without limiting access, said Clem Tillion, an adviser to Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska, is that when forbidden fish are accidentally caught they are thrown back to a certain death. The loss in Alaskan waters is roughly one-tenth of the catch, he estimated.
 
Action by the States
 State commissions still control fishing within three miles of shore, and some have tried to close entry to new boats. But in every case, the action has come when there were already too many boats. Another tactic is to limit technology. In the Chesapeake Bay waters controlled by Maryland, for example, oyster boats must be sail-powered and the gathering must be by hand.
But Mr. Singer has argued that a far more effective way both to prevent waste and curb overfishing is to create private harvesting rights that can be sold to those who can fish most cheaply, a thesis now being tested.
The mid-Atlantic council has divided rights to the catch of surf clams and ocean quahog clams among boat owners according to past catches. Most of the clam boats will now probably be retired, with their quotas sold to the handful of boats sufficient to harvest the catch. Boat owners remaining in business will have strong incentives to prevent overfishing or polluting because damage will be reflected in the market value of their clamming rights.
Much of the fight over transferable rights is about who will get what. Mr. Soileau, the Seattle-based captain, said crew members deserved a stake. Under the current system they can expect to buy their own boats after years of savings. But once individual rights are created, they will have to buy those as well.
 
A Hurdle for Rights
 Buying rights could be a formidable hurdle, and Canada, which is two years into its own experiment with transferrable fishing quotas, offers clues to how expensive they could become.
Bruce Turris, an economist with the Canadian Department of Fisheries, said that halibut quotas were selling for three times the value of a year's catch and that they would trade for much more if it was legal to accumulate enough of them to keep individual boats operating at full capacity. If such "stacking" of quotas was permitted, he said, it would be possible to retire as many as three out of four halibut boats.
Steven Edwards and Steven Murawski, at the New England Fisheries Center in Woods Hole, Mass., said a privatized system that allowed the Georges Bank harvest to return to its maximum potential and to cut costs of fishing in half would generate $120 million in annual savings.
Mr. Edwards estimated that one-fifth of the savings would go to consumers, as the price of fish fell, and that the rest would go to owners of the fishing rights, which would be worth roughly $1 billion.
Mr. Tillion estimated that the savings from privatization of the much larger Alaskan fisheries would be $1 billion a year. If he is correct, the market value of these rights would be at least $10 billion, Mr. Cooper of Harvard said.
 
Why Not the Treasury?
 Why, Mr. Singer asked, should the benefits not go back to the Federal Treasury?
One reason is that the Magnuson Act apparently bars the Government from charging for rights that are now given away, though Congress could amend the law.
Another reason, Mr. Edwards said, is that "fishermen have been given the impression they own the resource." And boat owners have great influence over the regional councils, particularly in regions like the North Pacific where sport fishing is not a serious factor.
In any change making the fish harvest more efficient, the biggest losers would be the owners of boats no longer needed for the harvest, Mr. Tillion said.
But "the public could afford a buyout" of those owners, Mr. Edwards said, because the efficiency generated through privatization would presumably exceed the losses to those who had been fishing inefficiently.
A buyout, like an auction of rights, would require Washington to take an aggressive role, and few of the analysts found that probable.
Fisheries policy is not a pressing issue in Congress and is little understood by lawmakers. The fisheries service, which oversees the regional councils, has been stretched thin by budget cuts and has little incentive to extend its reach beyond its traditional turf.
Economists at the White House and the Office of Management and Budget understand the consequences of privatization. But they have their eyes glued on the efficiency goal, and are apparently not prepared to slow the march toward privatization in order to redirect the savings to the Treasury.

HEADLINE: SCRAMBLE FOR JOBS: GRADUATING INTO A RECESSION - A SPECIAL REPORT.;
Degrees and Stacks of Resumes Yield Few Jobs for Class of '91

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
America's spring crop of college graduates -- a million young people who matriculated in the booming 1980's with rosy visions of abundant and lucrative career choices -- face the bleakest job market in a decade or more, especially in the New York region and the rest of the Northeast.
Caught in a recession that has stripped the nation's economy of 1.5 million jobs since last summer, the class of '91 has found far fewer corporate recruiters on campus and fierce competition for a pool of entry-level jobs that some experts say has shrunk 30 percent from last year. 
 Interviews with scores of seniors and placement counselors at 25 colleges and universities across the nation, and with government officials, corporate personnel directors and other job-market experts, show that the recession, which has generated widespread layoffs and long unemployment lines, has also eroded the market value of higher education.
"For many graduating seniors, the door to the employment office has been slammed shut -- and bolted," said Victor R. Lindquist, director of placement at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., and author of Lindquist-Endicott Reports, an annual study of employment trends for college graduates.
 
Lowering Expectations
 Only weeks before commencement, many traumatized seniors have been forced to abandon or postpone dreams of Fortune 500 careers and other mirages born four years ago when they were freshmen in the heyday of junk bonds and horizons as unlimited as corporate profits.
Instead, the seniors have had to scramble for interviews, widen their job searches, lower their expectations and -- if lucky -- settle for lesser jobs with smaller companies in more obscure locales. Some, finding a silver lining in hard times, are considering public service, the Peace Corps, teaching or other more accessible alternatives that are personally gratifying.
But for many, the job hunt has become a disheartening struggle of resumes, rejection and uncertainty. Some say graduate school may offer a refuge from the day of reckoning; but others, frightened into paralysis, have decided to take "interim" jobs as clerks or waiters -- or just go home and ride out the recession.
"It feels as if we're stepping off the precipice," said Andrew Abrams of Manhattan, a senior at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. "A few years ago, people were talking about how much money they would make. Now we are just looking to be employed."
How bad is it? "The job market is so bad I've been unable to find a suitable job in North America," said Glen Lockwood, a history major at Princeton, who said that despite his fluency in French, Spanish and Indonesian Malay and his nearly perfect grades, he had received not one job offer from 42 international corporations.
H. Edward Babbush, placement director at California State University at Long Beach, said he had never seen an economic downturn with a more severe impact on graduates' job prospects.
"We've been through up-and-down cycles before, but this is the worst I've seen in 30 years," Mr. Babbush said. "Firms that were trying to hire 2,000 new employees last year may only be hiring 200."
Gale Varma, a manager of college recruiting for American Telephone and Telegraph, said the company recruits at 169 colleges and receives 100,000 letters a year from seniors seeking jobs. But this year the number of new people hired will be cut drastically.
"We are probably down 40 percent in hiring," Ms. Varma said. "Our first commitment is to existing employees."
Du Pont, the diversified chemical manufacturer, has cut its campus recruiting visits from 40 to 10, said Richard Koffenberger, the company's senior college relations supervisor.
 
A $100,000 Degree: Where's the Payoff?
 Stuart Himmelfarb, the head of Roper CollegeTrack, a market-research company in New York that focuses on college students, said a survey last October, even before the dimensions of the current recession were evident, showed that 60 percent of this year's seniors were worried about finding a job in their chosen fields.
Jennifer M. Farrell, a 22-year-old political science and history major at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., who wants a job with a government agency or large organization in Washington, said employers were telling her frankly that they were not even looking at her resume. "I just can't find anything out there," she said.
Abdul Chohan, a 20-year-old Pakistani majoring in chemical engineering at the University of Rochester, is among the few who do not anticipate trouble. "There are more job choices for chemical engineers," he said.
In the long run, no one doubts that those who have invested four years of hard study and up to $100,000 for a college degree will get good jobs eventually -- perhaps later this year if the recession eases -- and that they will be spared the grinding unemployment and poverty that often faces those with limited or no higher education.
"I'm not very worried about this crop of graduates," said Dr. Sue Berryman, director of the Institute on Education and the Economy at Columbia University's Teachers College. "I'm not trying to say there won't be angst and frustrations for them. But the economy favors this group of individuals over the long haul."
The prospect of ultimate success, however, has not eased the pain of students who have toiled for good grades, worked outside jobs and sacrificed for what now seems a chimera -- people like 22-year-old Sharon Gurfield, a journalism major at Rutgers.
"I expect to be living at home for another year at least," said Ms. Gurfield, who has an A-minus average and helped pay her tuition with freelance writing and work as a substitute teacher and public relations aide. "I expect to be poor for quite a while because nobody is hiring. I have a stack of rejection letters to match the stack of resumes."
At Queens College in New York, Jane Velez, a 23-year-old English major, has been looking for a job in writing or publishing since last September.
"I've been looking at the classifieds every day, sent out close to 100 resumes, gone to job fairs and have been on so many interviews," she said. "Do you know what I've been reduced to? Either a job in some little retail shop for six bucks an hour, or a clerk working in the Social Security office."
 
Flexibility May Be The Key to Success
 Andrea Nelson, a University of Texas senior, said her job search had left her with no pretensions or illusions. "My goal?" she said. "Anything! I will go anywhere and take anything."
That kind of flexibility in a changing job market may be an important attribute of successful young people in the next decade, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Middle Atlantic regional commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"Many of the graduating seniors face disappointment and a need for readjusting their sights," he said. "The realities of the job market are changing much faster than ever before, and reacting to the new realities is going to be a prime skill for making it in the new economic environment of the 90's.
"The traditional career -- going into a field and staying with an employer -- is the wave of the past. Now the wave is going to be developing not one but several disciplines, and adapting to the new currents as the tides change -- and the tides these days are swift and changing rapidly."
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the current recession had hit harder in the New York region and the Northeast than in much of the rest of the country. But he said that despite severe job losses and layoffs, its effects were not as harsh as those in the recession of 1981-82.
But other experts, including Mr. Lindquist at Northwestern, said the impact on the job market for graduates seems greater than a decade ago. "My feelings are that this year is probably a bit tougher," he said.
Mr. Lindquist said jobs were sharply limited in virtually all large corporations, and especially in financial services, defense industries and heavy manufacturing. But he said there were still many openings in some fields, including chemical engineering, information systems, computers, health care, accountancy and teaching.
And, he said, there were hidden job opportunities in many smaller and mid-sized companies. "It's a little pocket of prosperity, where business is growing, steady and profitable," Mr. Lindquist said.
But he added: "These organizations, unlike the larger firms, do not usually recruit on campus. The students have to go out and find them."
 
No Decline Is Seen In Starting Salaries
 While jobs are hard to find, starting salaries have apparently not declined, and have even inched up somewhat. Mr. Lindquist, citing an average increase of about 4 percent, said most salaries for first jobs in nontechnical fields for liberal arts or business graduates have ranged from $12,000 to $33,000 this year, while those with specialized skills have drawn starting salaries in the $28,000 to $38,000 range.
As corporate recruiters have cut back campus visits and reduced hiring, some colleges are offering workshops and other aid to students in the hunt for jobs that experts say are out there but hidden, or at least never advertised.
Personal contacts through alumni, professional organizations and other networks are crucial in finding such jobs, placement directors say, but even lists of companies in a field are helpful as a starting point.
At some colleges, career fairs are growing -- Rutgers has 10 a year -- and computer databanks are providing likely employee-employer matchups.
"The fast-trackers will get good jobs, but the majority of students are going to have to work harder and longer to find a company that is expanding," Mr. Lindquist said. "It's not going to be with Fortune 500, but most likely with the second- or third-tier of organizations."
Ann Robertson, director of career services at Adelphi University on Long Island, said a willingness to move out of one's region was vital. "Be willing to travel and you'll have a better chance," she said.
 
Seeking Alternatives In the Public Sector
 One option in the dismal job market, many students and job counselors say, is work in the public-interest sector. More students than ever are asking about jobs in the Peace Corps and Teach for America, a program to supply teachers for schools in disadvantaged areas of the country.
"There has been a reaction to the hedonistic life style of the 80's reflected in the rise of interest in the public sector," said William H. Corwin, associate director of Princeton's Career Placement Office.
"I'm interested in having a career that has the potential for allowing me to affect social change," said Ingrid Eagly, a senior at Princeton, who plans to attend law school. "Something in the public sector will allow me to do that."
While a large segment of every senior class applies to graduate or professional schools -- 24 percent of last year's seniors did so, the United States Department of Education says -- even more applications are expected this year as seniors put off job searches.
"One reaction has been a retreat into professional education," said Acy L. Jackson, the director of career planning and dean of students at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y. "There has been a definite increase in the number of people here applying to graduate school, including a 30 percent rise in law school applications."
But graduate and professional school fees are high, and many students who have borrowed from the Government, banks and relatives to pay for four years of college are already too indebted to think of postgraduate studies. For them, a job is not just a luxury.
 
Alarming Thought: Repaying the Loans
 Christine Hudson, a 21-year-old senior at Southampton College of Long Island University who wants a career in journalism or communications, has worked as a secretary and lived with her parents in Wading River, L.I., through college. She owes almost $20,000 in student loans.
"In six months, the loans have to start being repaid," she said. "That's a frightening thought." So she will continue to live at home while she hunts for a job to cover the loans, her car payments and her expenses. "I will just do everything I can so I am not slapping hamburgers on Long Island," she said. "I don't want that to happen."
The prospects have disheartened some. Russell Kane, a political science major on the dean's list at Columbia, has had only one offer -- a paralegal job -- from 15 applications to banks, law firms and Federal agencies. "I've learned to live with rejection," he said.
Kenneth Friedman, with no job, doubts that the $100,000 his parents paid for his five years at the University of Rochester was worth it. "In retrospect," he said, "if you choose a good state school you can get a good education for signficantly less money."
But Denis DePierro, an English major at the State University at Buffalo who has had nothing but bad news from 220 job applications, has no doubts. "Of course it was worth it," he said of college. "You have to keep plugging away. What else can you do?"
Mr. Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics agrees. "Education is still the key," he said. "For those who have gone through college, the future is still one of promise in the long run."

HEADLINE: Budget Director's Mixed Outlook

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
A big turnaround in the United States economy could come by May or June, the Bush Administration's budget director, Richard G. Darman, said today.
But he said chances for a full recovery were clouded by the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and by banks' lending policies. 
 "We're in the process of turning," Mr. Darman said on "Newsmaker Sunday," a Cable News Network program. "I think that there's about a 70 percent chance, I would say, that people will look back at May or June and say, in one of those two months, we turned."But Mr. Darman expressed limited confidence in the Fed and said a tight monetary policy and the lack of credit could derail the recovery.
"I think the real growth potential of the economy is higher than the Fed does," he said, "and I think that if the Fed continues to believe it's as low as it is, it's self-fulfilling."
Mr. Darman said the Persian Gulf war helped to stimulate the economy by restoring consumer confidence, making the cost of the war fairly insignificant. He said the war's costs to the United States should not exceed the projected $15 billion.

Anhouse of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony.

Her mother, Helaine Joyce Knickerbocker, is a lawyer and a member of the legal staff at the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York. 
 The bridegroom, 35, is the president of Automated Panaproducts, an office equipment company in New York. He graduated from Great Neck South High School and attended Hofstra University. His mother, Marcelyn Anhouse, is the director of urban renewal and housing review at the New York City Department of City Planning. His father is a senior inspector for the City Taxi and Limousine Commission.

HEADLINE: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick;
Paying More for Less

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have practiced medicine in New York State for 40 years, the last 20 in a rural, economically depressed area. According to "Low Medicaid Fees Seen as Depriving the Poor of Care" (front page, April 2), New York ranks lowest of the 50 states in the ratio of Medicaid to Medicare fees to physicians, and most poor people use hospital emergency rooms for their care.
New York State policy encourages this misuse of emergency rooms. If a patient with, for example, an acute eye problem, goes to the hospital emergency room for care by someone who is not a specialist in ophthalmology, it costs Medicaid $72 in my area and as much as $110 in other parts of the state. If the patient comes to me for care, I am paid $16, up from $9 only a short while ago. 
 This thinking by the medical bureaucracy in Albany results in relatively poor care at a higher taxpayer cost.
 
JERRY H. JACOBSON, M.D.
Ogdensburg, N.Y., April 3, 1991

HEADLINE: Braking the Soviet Slide

 BODY:
As the Soviet economy spirals downward and new political fissures erupt everywhere, it's easy to write off the Soviet Union and its bickering leaders as has-beens. But remarkably, allies of both Mikhail Gorbachev and his archrival, Boris Yeltsin, are trying to put together a reform coalition that offers new hope for Soviet politics and policy.
Indeed, the coalition may represent a last-ditch opportunity to reverse the Soviet slide toward disintegration and counter the threat of hard-line dictatorship. President Bush would be wise to support this hopeful development. 
 Some hard-line U.S. officials are flirting with more drastic alternatives. They want to withdraw backing from Moscow and support the rebellious republics. They keep pushing for maximum Soviet concessions in arms talks, a position that has the perverse effect of strengthening Soviet opponents of deals with the West.
American hard-liners share the apocalyptic assumptions of some radicals in Moscow and the republics that the the center cannot hold, that today's turmoil in the Soviet Union is merely a prelude to an inevitable and cataclysmic revolution. Events could prove them correct. But experienced politicians in Moscow reject that assessment. They are trying to pull reformers together and provide a viable alternative to the center-right coalition now in charge in the Kremlin.
Two struggles are being waged today in the Soviet Union. One struggle is for the soul of the country; it pits those who are prepared to take to the streets to bring about change against those who fear chaos and favor a strong leader. A less visible struggle is raging within the Communist Party over power and policy, dividing top officials in all institutions, even in the military and the K.G.B.
The center-right coalition that Mr. Gorbachev has embraced now plays on popular fears of chaos. It insists on imposing union on fractious republics and seeks to smother spontaneous efforts to establish markets. It also wants to suppress independent voices in the mass media.
As a result, many citizens who fondly remember the early, heady days of Mr. Gorbachev's glasnost find themselves in a state of despair; some believe that only by taking to the streets can they revive the old momentum for change.
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin clearly need each other -- to withstand the forces of reaction within the party, the military, the K.G.B. and the military-industrial complex and, more broadly, to find a middle ground between the equally undesirable choices of revolt and repression.
There are small but significant shards of evidence that the two rivals are beginning to understand their mutual need and are heeding the wise counsel of former Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. "True democrats," says Mr. Shevardnadze, "will cooperate with normal conservatives if they are united by a common goal -- saving the country."
Reform groups have begun roundtable discussions to form a center-left coalition. They have Mr. Yeltsin's blessing. And they include representatives of the republics, the party and other political movements, even striking miners.
Together, they could provide the intellectual and political power to move the Soviet Union beyond perestroika to functioning markets. Together, they could allow a new Soviet commonwealth to be freely formed from the bottom up instead of imposing union from the top down. Together, they could reopen glasnost and provide outlets for voicing grievances besides taking to the streets or going on strike.
Soviet reformers are well aware of the price of failure. "Nobody has the power to isolate us except ourselves," says Mr. Shevardnadze. "Self-isolation -- that is the main danger." America's interest lies in having the reform coalition gel. Mr. Bush could deliver that message -- in person, in Moscow, soon.

HEADLINE: Net Falls 79% at Champion

 BODY:
The Champion International Corporation, the large paper and wood products company, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 79 percent, principally as a result of lower prices for pulp and falling demand for lumber and plywood.
The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said its earnings dropped to $15 million, or 8 cents a share, from $70 million, or 67 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales for the quarter were down 9.4 percent, to $1.16 billion, from $1.28 billion in the quarter a year earlier. 
 The market for wood products has been particularly sluggish in recent months, primarily because of the impact of the nation's recession on construction of new housing. Wood products accounted for 22 percent of Champion International's sales last year, and paper products accounted for 78 percent of sales.
Several analysts said the results were higher than they had anticipated. They cited the company's announcement in February that it expected earnings to be roughly at a break-even level for the first quarter. At that time, Champion International said that price cutting had been unrelenting in certain grades of paper and that its wood products business was operating at a loss. Also, Champion International announced in February that it was cutting its quarterly dividend by 81 percent, to 5 cents from 27 cents.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Champion International's shares were down 62.5 cents, closing at $26.375.
Andrew C. Sigler, Champion Internation's chairman and chief executive, said that weak paper pricing had dealt a blow to the company's increased production. "Coming as it did on top of dismal conditions in the wood side of the business, this slide on the paper side puts our results just above the break-even level," Mr. Sigler said. "The second quarter looks tough. And beyond that, it's too soon to tell."
The company said the increases in production were the result of major improvement projects and increased productivity of its work force.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SCENE;
Why Older Men Keep on Working

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
MEN in their late 50's and early 60's occupy a difficult position in the American labor market. Generous company pension plans have encouraged some to retire, while layoffs and staff cutbacks have pushed out others. For years, these inducements and pressures shrank the number of older men in the labor force, but that is no longer happening.
The change is evident in Labor Department data. Right after World War II, 90 percent of all American men between 55 and 64 years of age either held jobs or were actively job-hunting. Early retirement was shunned. But circumstances changed, and over the next four decades, the percentage of this age group in the labor force fell steadily, to just under 68 percent in 1985. And there the decline stopped. 
 "It is fairly impressive that older men are holding their own, even in this recession," said Philip Rones, an economist at the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics who studies this age group. "A year or two ago, I wasn't very sure the exodus had ended. But now I am."
Economists and executives offer a variety of explanations for the change. One is that the labor force bulged with the entry of women and the baby- boom generation, and these new workers competed with older men. They were also the targets of layoffs. Seniority made them the highest paid -- and therefore the most costly to corporations seeking to become more competitive. And they had pensions to fall back on if they were laid off.
"The least brutal way to shrink staff was to offer early-retirement incentives to people approaching retirement anyway," said Walter Maher, a Chrysler Corporation executive. But above all, older men seemed inclined to drop out. The advent of generous company pension plans, starting in the 1950's, to supplement Social Security, made leisure attainable, not only for white-collar managers but also for factory floor hands covered by plans negotiated by their unions.
"In 1950, if you were 60 years old and you were laid off, you tried just as hard to find a job as a 40-year-old," said Gary Burtless, a Brookings Institution senior fellow. "The reason was that there were not a lot of pension plans, and early retirement, largely for this reason, was socially unacceptable. Now there is no stigma to being a 55-year-old healthy man, retired and living in Tempe, Ariz."
Fifty percent of American workers today are covered by company pension plans. Studies by Mr. Burtless and others show that the maximum benefits available under these plans often begin when workers are in their late 50's. Most such workers are men. They greatly outnumber older women in the work force, and women have generally not worked enough years to be eligible for generous pensions.
Inducements for older male workers to leave are still present. Chrysler, for example, will sweeten the pension of any white-collar worker who is at least 53 years old and has 10 years of service. In figuring the pension for these early retirees, the company will add three years to that person's age and three years to his time on the job. Both steps increase monthly pensions.
Given such incentives, why should older men be more resistant to leaving the labor force than before? Two pressures to get out have disappeared: Women are no longer seeking work in such growing numbers, and the new generation entering the labor force is much smaller than the baby-boom group. In addition, the inducement to leave is fading a bit: Many company pensions are not as rich as they were a decade ago.
Prospective early retirees may also be losing confidence that even generous pension checks will be enough to pay their bills. Rising health-care costs and concerns that overall inflation will reignite make them increasingly nervous, experts say. Many retirees, in fact, work part time to help make ends meet, surveys show.
The new resistance to early retirement raises once again the question of whether older workers, men or women, are seen by corporations as being more costly than younger workers for the amount of work they do. A generation ago, few doubted their value. Now there is concern that seniority drives up an older worker's wages to the point that a younger person, earning half the salary, might be almost as productive. Japanese companies, in fact, deal with this issue by reducing the wages of most people over 55.
A more popular view among labor economists is that early retirements deprive the nation of skilled workers needed for robust economic growth. It also deprives the Government of revenue from income and payroll taxes, notes David Wise, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "We are wasting a lot of people," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. Adds 11 Models To Minicomputer Line

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. "refreshed" its three-year-old midrange computer line yesterday, introducing 11 new models that perform up to 60 percent faster and cost 10 to 40 percent less than the minicomputers they replace. But at the same time, the company acknowledged that sales of its minicomputers lagged behind the rest of its hardware products in the United States in the first quarter of 1991.
The midrange line, called AS/400, was introduced in 1988 to merge I.B.M.'s System/36 and System/38 minicomputers, used by small businesses and the departments of large corporations. The International Business Machines Corporation has sold more than 100,000 of them, mostly outside the United States, the company said. 
 Yesterday, I.B.M.'s top marketing executive in the United States said the first quarter had been a "financial disaster" for the company. But he emphasized that he had not changed his expectations that the company's midrange computers would meet their double-digit growth goals for this year.
 
'We Have Our Fingers Crossed'
 "We have our fingers crossed for the rest of the year," said the executive, William O. Grabe, vice president and general manager for marketing and services for the United States. "I think we can still make up the ground we've lost before the end of the year."
He acknowledged that his job had been made more difficult because it was impossible to predict the direction of the economy in a recession and after "a war that started and ended in a single month." The main factor affecting I.B.M.'s financial health this year has been the company's delay in introducing the fastest of the new System/390 mainframe computers. These machines are not scheduled to be shipped until the second half of the year, and any delay could prove devastating, analysts have said.
The machines introduced yesterday significantly extend the reach of the company's AS/400 line on both ends. A new high-end machine, the D80, may be priced as high as $1.5 million, and a new entry-level minicomputer, the D04, will start at $15,000.
"It looks like they've met the competition," said Myron Kerstetter, a computer industry analyst at the Gartner Group, a Stamford, Conn., market research firm. "I was surprised by the aggressive pricing. The AS/400 is growing market share, particularly against Digital's VAX's."
 
Advances of New Machines
 I.B.M. executives said the computers consisted of 75 percent new hardware technology and had the second version of the company's OS/400 operating and control system, which is designed to improve connections both with other I.B.M. products and with those made by competitors.
Mr. Grabe said yesterday in an interview that the company believed that it had about 20 percent of the worldwide market for midrange computers, about the same market share held by the nation's second-largest computer maker, the Digital Equipment Corporation.
But Mr. Grabe said that I.B.M.'s double-digit growth in yearly sales of the AS/400 had not principally come at Digital's expense.
"It's not Digital who has lost," he said. "There are a lot of weak players in the industry."
Among other companies that make competing computers are Prime Computer, Data General and Unisys.
 
Variety of New Technologies
 In its product announcement yesterday, I.B.M. offered a variety of new technologies designed to keep the AS/400 competitive with the new client-server method of computing that is becoming increasingly popular in businesses. In client-server computing, much of the computer brainwork is done at desktop personal computers that send information to be stored to the larger minicomputers.
To enhance such systems, I.B.M. said it was adding fiber-optic lines to permit high-speed connections and was also offering an optical disk system capable of storing the equivalent of up to 300,000 pages, enough to stuff a two-drawer file cabinet.
Many industry analysts have speculated that the growth of the AS/ 400 product line would be limited by I.B.M.'s new RS/6000 computer work station line, introduced last April. Mr. Grabe said that the AS/400 was on a comparable technology track with the RS/6000.

HEADLINE: American Express-Japan Bank Talks

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The American Express Company is in negotiations with Sumitomo Bank Ltd. to establish a joint company that would issue charge cards in Japan, people who have been briefed on the talks said yesterday.
In the plan under discussion, the jointly run company would issue only the American Express gold card, with Sumitomo acting as the underwriter for credit lines that can be attached to the charge card. 
 An American Express spokeswoman in Japan confirmed that the two companies were in negotiations, but declined to provide details. Officials at Sumitomo's offices in Tokyo could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Some people who have been briefed on the talks cautioned that the deal was not final. "This is by no means signed, sealed and delivered," one executive said.
If an agreement is reached, the deal would be the second joint-venture agreement this month that the American Express Company has developed with a foreign bank. Earlier, it agreed with Lloyds Bank of Britain to issue a jointly sponsored corporate gold card.
But unlike the agreement with Lloyds, a deal with Sumitomo would not focus on the corporate market. Rather, people who have been briefed on the plan said, the joint venture under discussion would issue gold cards for the general consumer market, instead of the corporate market.
 
Access to Japanese Market
 People who have been briefed on the talks with Sumitomo said that American Express was looking to the large Japanese bank to provide both credit quality and greater access to the elusive Japanese market. The company currently issues charge cards in Japan, but a deal with Sumitomo is considered as a move that would greatly expand American Express's influence in the market.
"Clearly, the intent is that you want to have a strong partner," one person who has been briefed on the talks said. "It is a new segment of the market for American Express. And Sumitomo brings a lot to the table in terms of their existing customer base and their credit quality."
Under the terms of the deal being discussed, Sumitomo would assume a role in Japan similar to that of Centurion Bank, which underwrites credit lines of domestic gold cards. Sumitomo would provide the lending power necessary to establish credit lines that could be attached to the gold cards.
American Express is turning to joint ventures with foreign banks at a time when the quality of the credit lines attached to some of its premier cards has been rapidly deteriorating. The deterioration of those credit lines resulted last week in American Express adding $50 million to its reserves to protect against bad loans.
American Express executives have said that the problems at the company stem largely from the recession and the Persian Gulf war, which resulted in a cutback in consumer spending. Also, the recession is causing a cutback in the white-collar work force, meaning that many carriers of the company's gold and platinum charge cards can no longer pay their bills.
The result of the current tumult is that American Express's Travel Related Services division, which oversees the card and has been the engine of the company's financial growth, experienced its first earnings loss in 25 years in the quarter just ended.
By getting into joint ventures, American Express will be able to expand its market at the same time it limits the potential exposure from such growth. In other words, if there are credit problems that develop in other markets, the problems will be shared with the partners.
But officials of the company expect that the rest of the year will be difficult for American Express, partly because of the cost of entering such joint ventures.
In statements yesterday at the company's annual meeting, James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of American Express, said that the company expected to see slower profit growth throughout the rest of the year, in part because of expenditures the company planned to make in new corporate strategies.

HEADLINE: Saudi Group Now Owns Over 5% of Chase Stock

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
A Saudi Arabian investment group holds just over 5 percent of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, according to a filing made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The $159 million stake is the second large Saudi investment in a leading United States bank in recent months.
In February, a member of the Saudi royal family, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, invested $590 million in a new issue of convertible preferred stock that if converted will equal about 10 percent of Citicorp's common stock. At the time of the purchase, Prince Waleed already owned 4.9 percent of the banking company's common stock. 
 The two investments differ in that Citicorp was actively seeking additional capital and offered its new equity issue on highly favorable terms. By contrast, the group investing in Chase, led by Suliman S. Olayan, acquired 6.7 million Chase shares on the open market, so the investment does not result in an infusion of new capital. The shares were bought through a subsidiary of the Olayan Group called Crescent Diversified Ltd.
 Chase's stock price fell yesterday, as did many other bank stocks, and closed down 50 cents, at $18.875.
Robert Marsh, a spokesman for the Olayan Group, said the subsidiary had owned slightly less than 5 percent of Chase for almost a year. According to the S.E.C. filing, Crescent purchased 1.2 million shares between March 1 and April 15 at prices ranging from $14.37 to $20. It was this latter, additional investment that pushed the stake to 5.023 percent, just over the 5 percent level that requires public disclosure.
Depending on the Saudi group's continuing evaluation of the banking industry, the economy and Chase's management, "it may increase or decrease its investment," said Mr. Marsh, who stressed that the Olayan Group always had a reputation for being a friendly, long-term investor.
A spokesman for Chase Manhattan, Fraser Seitel, said that Crescent, which is registered in the British Virgin Islands, had been a shareholder for many years. "They are familiar to us, friendly to us," Mr. Seitel said. "Chase is grateful they've expressed long-term interest in the bank."
Despite the size of Crescent's investment, it is not the largest holder of Chase stock. According to the bank's latest proxy statement, the Wall Street investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Company holds 8.4 percent of the banking company, with voting power over about half of that amount.
The Olayan Group has long shown an interest in the financial industry. Among the companies in which it owns stakes are CS First Boston, Transamerica, First Chicago and J.P. Morgan, Mr. Marsh said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Further Gains While Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose further against major foreign currencies yesterday as traders expected stable United States interest rates and continued economic weakness in Europe.
Traders said the dollar dipped briefly in afternoon trading on a rumor that President Bush had a heart attack. The White House denied the report. 
 Gold prices rose, partly on news of a strike by Soviet gold miners in sympathy with Soviet coal miners. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $357.90 a troy ounce, up $1.20 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained 70 cents an ounce to close at $357.20.
Jesse Torres, a currency trader with the First Boston Corporation, said European economies were suffering from the same problems that depressed the United States economy in late 1990 and early 1991.
Traders generally believe most of the bad news concerning the United States economy is over, and the economy has stabilized. Several other traders said the dollar had rallied on perceptions that the United States recession had bottomed out, which means interest rates are not likely to be lowered further. Higher interest rates tend to strengthen the dollar.
Also helping the dollar is the belief that central banks overseas are not intervening in a coordinated fashion to slow the dollar's rise, traders said.
The dollar also gained against the German mark throughout the day after reports that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany lost a key election in his native state of Rhineland. That, coupled with rising problems faced by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, strengthened the dollar, said Curtis Perkins, a currency trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group.
The dollar has traditionally been used as a safe investment in times of turmoil.
Against the German currency, the dollar jumped in New York to 1.7645 German marks, up from 1.7360.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar settled in New York at 139.49 yen, up from 138.35 yen on Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.80 yen, to a closing 138.70 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 139.35 yen.
In London, the British pound sank to $1.6925, from $1.7204 late Friday. In New York, it cost $1.6955 to buy one pound, compared with $1.7205 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4700 Swiss francs, up from 1.46785; 5.9455 French francs, up from 5.8575; 1,301.25 Italian lire, up from 1,282.00, and 1.15875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15495 late Friday.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
The Iraqis, Living Primitively, Blame U.S. for Their Torment

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 22

 BODY:
Amid the cacophonous hammering of the coppersmiths in Baghdad's busy souk today, a man in a black turban named Ali was busily chopping up plump fish with an ancient hatchet.
"Only five dinars each," he sang out. "Same price as before the war."
By the standards of postwar Iraq, Ali's plump fish were a bargain. 
 The United Nations trade embargo, the allied bombing raids and an overvalued currency have combined to send prices soaring and transform the reasonably comfortable lives most Iraqis lived before the Persian Gulf crisis into lives of deprivation, struggle and fear.
The result is a widespread bitterness toward the United States and its allies for what Iraqis see as an attempt to reverse their country's material progress, with Government officials among those complaining that the people are being punished for events they had no say in.
 
A Step Back in Time
 "It's an irony that President Bush is always saying he has no quarrel with the Iraqi people, only with Saddam Hussein," said Iraq's Secretary of State for Information, Naji al-Hadithi. "It's an irony, too, that the civilized world is seeking to extinguish civilization in the developing region."
Manal al-Alusy, the head of the Iraqi Women's Federation, said: "We have no gas or electricity for cooking, so I go out into the garden and gather wood. I've returned to the way my grandmother lived."
This year, she said, food shortages meant that she sometimes took up to eight hours to prepare the family's evening meal during Ramadan, the Muslim month of prayer and daytime fasting.
What particularly angers many Iraqis, in addition to the trade embargo, is the allies' decision to bomb the country's electric generating stations and destroy its telephone system.
They argue that this campaign was intended to demoralize the population and undercut the Government, not to serve any military purpose.
 
Hospitals Are Hurt, Too
 "We saw planes coming back three and four times to wipe out country telephone exchanges that only served local needs," Mr. Hadithi said. His ministry now has just one working telephone line for local calls.
As a result, the hardships caused by the shortages of food and other items resulting from the trade embargo are being supplemented by a near total absence of communications within the country. Meanwhile, the serious lack of electricity means not only houses without lights, but also paralyzed medical equipment in hospitals and laboratories, as well as paralyzed water treatment plants and sewage stations.
Before the gulf war, Iraq imported nearly 70 percent of its food needs. Since the imposition of trade sanctions last August, Iraq has been given permission several times to make small food imports as stocks declined. And earlier this month the Security Council ended all restrictions on buying food. But the Council still has not allowed Iraq to start selling oil on the world market again to pay for the food imports it desperately needs.
As a result, the price of many necessities has shot up, sometimes by 1,000 percent or more. A kilo of flour, which used to cost 70 fils, or hundredth parts of a dinar, rose to over 7 dinars, but has now slipped back to around 4 dinars after the Government brought in a consignment. Meat that was 2 to 3 dinars before the war is now 14 dinars or more.
Similarly, sharp increases have occurred in the price of many other food items and manufactured products like light bulbs, razor blades and batteries as supplies dry up. Price increases on this scale are clearly painful in a country where the average monthly wage is only some 55 dinars and a secretary in Baghdad might take home about 110 dinars a month.
 
Wage Increases Rejected
 The Government has introduced a rationing system under which all families get part of their basic needs at the prices that prevailed before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But a recent report by the World Health Organization said this allowance gave no more than the bare minimum of calories needed for survival, and Iraqis said all families were forced to supplement their rations by purchases of high-priced free-market food.
Rising prices have predictably brought pressure for higher salaries. But while the Government has granted pay raises to the military, it is holding the line against a general wage increase. On Sunday, Parliament met in closed session to discuss the country's economic problems. Afterward, its Speaker, Saadi Mehdi Saleh, warned that higher salaries would only fuel inflation.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Kuwait Prevents an Opposition Protest

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, April 22

 BODY:
On the day Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited here to evaluate Kuwait's progress toward democracy and rebuilding the country, the Government moved forcefully to halt an attempt by opposition groups to denounce the country's new Cabinet.
The groups intended to meet with foreign journalists today to declare that the Cabinet appointed on Saturday was simply a shuffling of ministers, almost all of them members of the ruling Sabah family, whom the opposition blames for the crisis leading up to he Iraqi invasion of Aug. 2. 
 This morning, about two dozen opposition figures gathered in the Goverment-owned Kuwait International Hotel to speak at a scheduled news conference. Some time during the night, however, someone had gone through the hotel, the center for most of the international press corps, removing printed announcements of the briefing, which had been posted throughout the building.
 
No Approval Granted
 As Government critics milled about, passing out copies of their statement on the new Cabinet, a hotel manager hustled into the ballroom to declare that the meeting could not be held because it had not been approved by the Information Ministry. An armed Government security guard in camouflage fatigues switched off the lights, forcing everyone into the hallways.
In the Information Ministry's office in the hotel, the daughter of Kuwait's Crown Prince, Jamail al-Sabah, was hurriedly giving directions to ministry staffers. Although she holds no formal position, her place in the royal family accords her unchallenged authority within the Government. In some cases, it has been she alone who has approved credentials for foreign journalists.
A flustered ministry official, Hissa al-Shaheen, said that her office had ordered that the opposition news conference be halted.
"Yes," she said, "the ministry has to approve it. You can't just hold a conference. If they want a specific arrangement, they have to send a letter and we then approve it."
 
Baker Sees the Emir
 The opposition news session was thwarted as Mr. Baker paid a brief visit and told the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, that Washington's willingness to continue to support Kuwait militarily and politically would be influenced by its commitment to human rights and democratization. Mr. Baker said afterward that he had received assurances from the Emir that the Government was working to uphold democratic principles.
Mr. Baker interrupted his Mideast peace mission to meet with the Kuwaiti leadership at the behest of President Bush. The visit was apparently prompted by mounting concern in the Administration that the flagging pace of reconstruction in Kuwait, and recent allegations of human rights abuses there, were raising politically explosive questions about just what sort of government the United States had fought to restore.
Speaking to reporters after his hourlong meeting with the Emir and the Prime Minister, Crown Prince Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, Mr. Baker said he told the Kuwaiti leaders that "the ability of the United States to continue to support Kuwait politically and from a security standpoint, in a manner in which we supported them against the brutal aggression of Saddam Hussein, would be enhanced if they evidenced full respect and commitment to the preservation of human rights."
Asked whether he had received any assurance from the Emir and the Crown Prince on human rights and the expansion of democracy in Kuwait, Mr. Baker replied:
"Yes, I did. The Emir and the Crown Prince and their colleagues were very forthcoming on both of those issues." He cited the Emir's recent pledge to hold elections next year and to consider voting rights for women.
 
Opposition Gathers Momentum
 Since the new Cabinet was announced Saturday, opposition groups have been meeting throughout Kuwait City to draft the statement made public today denouncing the Government and its policies. Critics say the Cabinet does not represent the Kuwaiti people, especially those who remained during the seven-month Iraqi occupation.
The Emir, who suspended an elected National Assembly in 1986, has promised elections for sometime next year, but has refused to specify when the vote will be held or who will be permitted to cast ballots. Many opposition figures, some of whom were jailed by both the Kuwaiti Government before Aug. 2, and by the Iraqis during the occupation, are incensed at what they say is an effort to preserve the prewar government structure.
"We have no democracy in Kuwait," said an angry Mohammed al-Khadiri, a leader of the Democratic Forum, a secular, liberal opposition group. "It's very clear. We are asking for democracy, the implementation of the suspended Constitution, forming a real democratic government and to have human rights -- individual rights to speak, to read, to write, to have a small conference, which is forbidden."
Mr. Khadiri, who spent a week in jail in July for human rights activities and then two weeks in Iraqi prisons in February, said the failure of the Government to permit opposition groups to speak out was an ominous sign.
 
Unrepresentative Government
 "We have the same problem as before," he said. "All we are asking for is a government that represents all political parties and respects the program of the people. This Government does not represent the program of the people."
Standing in the dimly lit hotel ballroom amid a confusion of voices after the news conference was thwarted, Sami al-Katrash, a professor of economics at Kuwait University and a member of the Islamic Constitutional Movement, held an impromptu news conference of his own to read from the oppposition statement.
The opposition, he said, demands a return to the nation's Constitution of 1962, which guarantees a free press and free elections. In addition, he said, a specific date for the election must be set and a Cabinet chosen not in the councils of the Sabah family, but as a product of representative government.
And last, Mr. Katrash said alluding to the Iraqi invasion and occupation, the opposition insists on "holding to account all officials responsible for the catastrophe and not excusing their responsibility for what happened before and during the ordeal."
 
Resentment of Those Who Left
 Among perhaps 150,000 Kuwaitis who remained here during the occupation, there is growing resentment against those who fled into exile, including the royal family and the Government.
Although it is difficult to assess the exact degree to which existing opposition groups represent popular opinion, it appears from many conversations that together they broadly express the dissatisfaction of Kuwaitis now in the country. Altogether, seven groups signed the opposition statement, ranging from fundamentalist Muslim to vaguely socialist.
Today's action by the Government was an unusually visible clampdown on its critics, given the recent weeks of relative freedom.
As the new Cabinet comes under heavy criticism, Kuwaitis and experts on the region also say its makeup may reflect another chapter in a lively feud between two branches of the ruling family -- the Jabers, to which the Emir belongs, and the Salems, to which Crown Prince Saad belongs.
 
The Salems Now Dominate
 "This family fight has resolved itself for now with the crushing victory of the Salems," Jean Gueyras, the Mideast expert of the French daily Le Monde said in a commentary today, noting that four of the five ministries allotted to members of the ruling family went to relatives of the Crown Prince.
This is a reversal of fortune. In the past, relatives of the Emir tended to dominate major portfolios.
Mr. Gueyras said in his analysis that regardless of the feuding among the Sabahs, the family continues to keep control of major decision-making, denying any real participation by members of the democracy movement.
