HEADLINE: High Court Clears Way for Indian Casino

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn., April 22

 BODY:
The United States Supreme Court today, in a victory for the sovereignty of Indian tribes, cleared the way for the Mashantucket Pequot to open a gambling casino in this rural town near the Rhode Island border.
The Court, without comment, refused to hear a last appeal by state officials trying to block the casino. The 200-member tribe had contended that Connecticut was required to negotiate with it over gambling, under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, because state gaming laws allow casino gambling in "Las Vegas nights" for charitable purposes. 
 The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act gives federally recognized tribes the right to negotiate the operation of games of chance if that form of gambling is already permitted in the state.
Federal District Judge Peter Dorsey in Hartford and the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the Pequot contention. The tribe has been operating a high-stakes bingo hall since 1986.
 
'A Tremendous Victory'
 "This is a tremendous victory for Indian tribes throughout the United States," the Pequot tribal chairman, Richard (Skip) Hayward, said at a news conference here this afternoon. "It means that state governments must deal with us on equal terms as sovereign governments."
Mr. Hayward added, "This decision will allow us to become self-sufficient and self-determining."
The tribe's lawyer, Barry A. Margolin of Portland, Me., said the Supreme Court's refusal to hear the state's arguments was a "landmark decision."
"Congress required the states to sit down at a negotiating table with tribal governments as equal sovereigns," he said. "This case tells the states that they will lose if they try to evade that obligation."
Last winter, at the request of the Pequot, a Federal mediator approved a plan for a casino that would allow most traditional casino games, with the exception of slot machines, which are not allowed under state law.
The building, which is scheduled to open in the fall, is expected to be about half the size of the smallest casino in Atlantic City, with a capacity of about 1,000 customers.
"You won't see a lot of glitz and glitter," said Alfred J. Luciani, a lawyer and former casino executive in Atlantic City and Las Vegas who will become the chief executive officer of the casino. "This will be one with nature, a lot of New England architecture."
Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said the state would cooperate in its role as the casino's chief regulator. "We are entering a new chapter of cooperation between the state and the tribe," he said.
He also said he was pleased that an Indian tribe, a publicly owned, non profit entity, was operating the casino rather than a private enterprise. "It is crucial that it is an Indian tribe involved," he said.
He added, though, that he remained adamantly opposed to the expansion of casino gambling in Connecticut because of the potential for the proliferation of organized crime.
Numerous state legislators have argued that the Pequot should not have a monopoly on the revenue raised from the games, particularly when the state is so fiscally strapped. Connecticut also operates or allows lottery games, jai alai, dog racing and off-track betting.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has also stated his opposition to using the proceeds from casino gambling to help fill a $2.6 billion budget shortfall over the next 15 months.
 
$80 Million in Revenue
 Mr. Hayward estimated that the Pequot casino would garner $80 million in revenue and yield $10 million in annual profit, most of which would be used to a build a Pequot museum, a research center and additional housing for tribe members on the 1,700-acre reservation.
Mr. Luciani added that the casino would employ 1,500 to 1,900 people and would greatly enhance the economy in Ledyard, a town of about 15,000 residents, and throughout New London County, which has been hit hard by job losses at several defense-related companies.
The Pequot, in March 1989, were the first Indian tribe east of the Mississippi to secure a gambling compact with a state under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.

HEADLINE: Honeymoon Sours for Haiti President

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 18

 BODY:
When the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was elected President by an overwhelming margin in December, crowds of jubilant Haitians filled the air with cries proclaiming their country's rebirth.
But a couple of months into Father Aristide's presidency, the optimism has begun to give way to a realization that Haiti's road to economic and political revival is thickly strewn with obstacles, and many wonder whether the new Government has the ability to surmount them. 
 The President's critics generally give the politically inexperienced priest high marks for having tamed a power-hungry army and for ending a long series of street robberies.
But even many ofhis allies complain that the new Government, which has few experienced high-level officials, has shown little grasp of economic issues or matters of governing.
Proclaiming control over inflation as a top priority, the Government last month froze prices for some basic goods. When this failed to stop prices from rising, or goods from disappearing from the shelves, the official press cast blame on "the invisible hand of a few foreign powers." chants.
While the Government gropes for economic answers, popular frustration has been rising. On April 15, one person was killed and several hurt in a northern city, Cap-Haitien, in a demonstration against rising prices.
The next night, after a suspicious fire that destroyed the Marche Hyppolite, a 19th-century market that was a major commercial center here, crowds of angry Haitians coursed through the streets of Port-au-Prince.
Prime Minister Rene Preval, a former baker, called in a broadcast for calm and said "this Government will serve for five years, not one day more or one day less."
Jean-Robert Martinez, a Senator from the National Front for Democratic Change, which sponsored Father Aristide's candidacy, echoed criticism by other legislators. "Right now," he said, "we are falling into a cascade of incidents, a certain anarchy, with no sense of direction."
 
Settling Old Scores
 Friends and critics of the Government have said that instead of capitalizing on its enormous post-inauguration popular support to push through new programs, it has squandered good will by pursuing perceived demons from governments past.
In the most hotly discussed incident, the Government arrested and briefly jailed former President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot in connection with a failed coup attempt by rightists in January. The move drew chilly reactions from the United States and other donor countries whose financial help the Government actively seeks.
Many Haitians were dismayed by what they saw as a gratuitous slap at Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot.
"This country needs tourists and investors," said a dismayed human rights campaigner who has supported the Government. "Even if you have something serious against Madame Trouillot, it can wait six months. What they did was send out the exact opposite of the kind of signal the country needs to be transmitting to the world right now."
The new Government's ties with the Haitian legislature, after a brief honeymoon in which Father Aristide was granted special powers to speed through administrative changes, have also grown troubled. Senators, including several from the party that sponsored his candidacy, have complained that the Government has ignored the Senate's consultative role in important appointments.
Recently, the Government asked private business to lend it "thousands and millions of dollars," within the space of four days, in order to "create jobs and fight inflation."
When journalists asked whether businesses would not feel coerced, Commerce Minister Smarck Michel said, "This is not an ultimatum." When the deadline passed, the Government announced it had collected $5.3 million, mostly from state-controlled corporations. Many business owners grumbled privately that despite the Commerce Minister's disclaimer, they found the approach intimidating.
"Nobody is crazy enough not to give," said a merchant, who despite his resentment lent $2,000. "In Haiti it doesn't matter what the Government says. If your name is not on the list, you won't feel completely safe."
